PUB-DATE: August 25, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 2868 words

HEADLINE: A Welcome for Immigrants Turns to Resentment

SERIES: Reinventing California -- Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Rich and poor, legally or not, they came to Southern California by the millions over the last decade, foreigners in search of a better life or political refuge. The immigrants were mostly welcome at first, filling unwanted jobs in a robust economy, opening businesses and sweetening the good life in sunny California by working cheaply as maids, gardeners and dishwashers.
But today the welcome has worn out. 
 Immigrants are now widely perceived as an economic drag on taxpayers, sucking up health, school, police and other services while spreading crime, dirt and disease. With its economy struggling through the worst slump since the Great Depression, its cities battered, its government services breaking down, California, and particularly Southern California, has begun to say "no" to more immigrants.
"Illegal immigration is the hottest issue in the state," said Assemblyman Bill Morrow, who represents an affluent district stretching through Orange and San Diego Counties. "We've got to say to the Federal Government, 'If you don't close the border, we will.' "
Politicians ranging from conservative Republicans like Mr. Morrow to Democrats like California's two Senators, Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein, have been tripping over each other to offer new ideas for controlling immigration. On Aug. 17, the two Senators toured the border near San Diego with Attorney General Janet Reno and saw the capture of would-be illegal immigrants. "We've got to close our borders," said Ms. Boxer in a recent interview.
Some days earlier, Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican facing a tough battle for re-election next year, made a three-day tour of Southern California, demanding that Washington reverse what he called "the rewards" for illegal immigrants by ending their medical and education benefits and calling for a constitutional amendment to deny citizenship to their American-born children. Because immigration is a Federal responsibility, Governor Wilson says there is little the state can do to stem the tide.
The complaints are based mostly on the assumption that immigrants are lured here by generous public services. In fact, immigration experts and the immigrants themselves say, the main reason they come is that they need jobs and Americans are willing to hire them. And few of the remedies offered so far propose to intensify penalties on Americans who employ illegal aliens.
 
Land of Immigrants
 Nowhere are the complaints more pointed than here in California, which absorbed more than a third of the country's legal immigrants over the last decade, more than half of the refugees, and now has half of the estimated 1.3 million illegal immigrants, mostly in Los Angeles, Orange and San Diego counties.
How Southern California absorbs this wave of immigrants, mostly brown or yellow-skinned, and whether the huge flow prompts the kind of anti-immigrant violence seen recently in Germany, France and Japan, are crucial questions. The answers could presage the experience elsewhere as the United States becomes a land of ethnic diversity.
But for now, the argument by many experts that illegal immigrants do work Americans are unwilling to do, contribute more than they receive, and add to the cultural mosaic is heard less frequently as the economy here continues its slump.
Anti-immigrant fever has also taken root in the state legislature. Twenty-one bills aimed at immigrants, some patently unconstitutional, were introduced this year, mostly by conservatives who once favored immigration as good for the economy and a deterrent to unionized labor.
Many of the bills were meant to deny public housing, health care, welfare, education and drivers licenses to illegal aliens, and most either failed or have stalled for now. Hispanic lawmakers and other opponents of such legislation say that while immigrants do use health and welfare services, they come to California for one reason only: jobs. To deny them services, they argue, could cause public health problems that would lead to even greater public expense.
Some of the debate has been tinged with racism. In May, Assemblyman William J. Knight, a Republican from Palmdale, a Los Angeles suburb, caused an uproar in the legislature by circulating a piece of doggerel from a constituent mocking Hispanic immigrants. It read, in part:
Everything is mucho good.
Soon we own the neighborhood.
We have a hobby -- it's called breeding.
Welfare pay for baby feeding.
 
The Economy
A Smaller Part Of a Smaller Pie

As recently as 1985, an Urban Institute study concluded that Mexican immigration was a great boon to the California economy, meaning lower prices for goods and services, low inflation and low unemployment. But today, fewer and fewer Californians agree with that assessment.
"The economy has created the reality and perception of a zero-sum game in which citizens see themselves as pitted against immigrants," said Wayne A. Cornelius, director of the Center for U.S.-Mexican Studies at the University of California at San Diego. "They see the quality of life declining, the state government going bankrupt. They assume it is because too many people are flooding into the state."
The pressures and stress are no less pointed for the immigrants themselves, who find themselves caught between an increasingly hostile host country and a cruel economy in their homelands.
On a recent morning in Santa Ana, the seat of Orange County, immigrants gathered on the corners and the littered parking lotsalong Euclid Avenue, waiting for work, any work -- painting houses, clearing brush, carrying lumber.
"The government is closing around," said one 29-year-old man, who would give only his first name, Francisco. He added that it had become more difficult to obtain real or counterfeit drivers licenses and Social Security cards needed to get work and state medical coverage for his wife and three children.
Still, he said, life is better for him here than it was three years ago when he gave up selling T-shirts to tourists in Acapulco at $7 a day to compete for casual jobs paying $5 an hour in Santa Ana. "There are no jobs in Mexico," he said. "I need a job for living."
Another man, like others along the street, said that there was so little work now that he had been forced to send his wife and children back home to Mexico.
 
A Shift in Thinking
 The huge flow of low-skilled immigrants into a depressed economy has begun to change the thinking among some economists. Among those who has changed his mind is George J. Borjas of the University of California, San Diego. His 1990 book, "Friends or Strangers: The Impact of Immigrants on the U.S. Economy" (Basic Books), concluded that immigrants had not undermined Americans' income or job opportunities. Now, he says there is indeed an effect.
"If we have a huge influx of unskilled immigrants, it's almost unavoidable that the unskilled labor market will be affected," he said in a recent interview.
Even as illegal immigrants are reviled, Southern Californians hire them by the thousands to mow lawns, trim trees and clean and paint their homes, as well as wash dishes and dice vegetables in restaurants. Employers often prefer them to Americans because they work hard and seldom complain.
Indeed, immigrant advocates contend that they are both exploited and blamed. "Immigrants take jobs Americans don't want," said John Palacio of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund office in Santa Ana. "They are not only blamed for economic ills, but exploited for cheap labor. But they contribute much more than they receive."
 
The Numbers
Immigrant Influx Alters a Region
 Over the last dozen years, Southern California has been swept by immigration of a magnitude not seen since New York at the turn of the century. Much of it was legal, a result of the Immigration Control and Reform Act of 1986, which conferred amnesty on illegal immigrants resident here since before 1982.
The act also imposed penalties on employers who hire illegal immigrants with the expectation that this would limit job opportunities and eventually slow the flow over the border. But lax enforcement and easily obtained false documents have defeated this barrier.
The immigrants have transformed the region: Russians moved to Hollywood, wealthy Iranians to the West Side of Los Angeles, Armenians to Glendale. There were also Israelis, Ethiopians, Iraqis, Egyptians, Lebanese, Ukrainians, Palestinians.
But mostly the immigrants have been Mexicans and Central Americans, and in smaller numbers, Asians -- Koreans, Chinese, Vietnamese, Thais, Filipinos, Cambodians, Laotians, Hmong. And so a Little Phnom Penh sprung up in Long Beach, a Little Saigon in Westminster and an affluent, suburban Chinatown in Monterey Park. Two-thirds of the Salvadorans and Guatemalans in the United States are in California, mostly Southern California.
 
Fewer Natives
 In all, the population of California grew by a staggering 6.1 million during the 1980's, and census experts attributed 37 percent of the growth to foreign immigration. Though the state's growth has slowed since the 1990 Census, immigration has not; in 1991-92, the state gained an estimated 303,000 immigrants from other countries even as it experienced a net loss of 41,000 Americans to other states.
Of the 8.9 million legal immigrants admitted to the United States since 1989, 3.2 million -- or more than a third -- came to California. That was more than to New York, Texas, Florida and Illinois combined. More than half the 3 million illegal aliens who claimed the amnesty offered in the 1986 act settled here in California; three quarters were Mexican. And there are about 655,000 political refugees, many from Southeast Asia, nearly half those who have come to the United States since 1986.
And there are the illegal aliens, an estimated 200,000 in San Diego County alone, 9 percent of the population. The Hispanic population of Orange County has doubled in a decade, to nearly 600,000, a quarter of the population. Two-thirds are not citizens, perhaps half of them here illegally.
The foreign-born account for one of every three residents of the Los Angeles-Long Beach metropolitan area and one in five in the Anaheim-Santa Ana area in Orange County. Only the Miami area, with 45 percent, has a higher proportion of foreign-born residents; New York's population is 27 percent foreign born.
The influx is unlikely to abate soon. Without tougher controls, an additional 10 million immigrants can be expected to come to the United States during this decade, said George Vernez, an immigration analyst at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica.
 
The Backlash
'They Are Taking Jobs Away'
 Probably nowhere has the backlash against immigrants been sharper than in Orange County, where they are widely seen as having corroded a once-pleasant middle-class way of life. There have been bitter disputes over street vendors, overcrowded apartments and bilingual teaching in the public schools. Santa Ana is more than two-thirds Hispanic.
On a recent afternoon, several members of an anti-immigration group, Citizens for Action Now, gathered in Barbara A. Coe's dining room in Huntington Beach. The group claims 412 members and is one of 15 groups in the California Coalition for Immigration Reform.
"They violate our laws and demand we feed them, clothe them and educate them in their own language," Ms. Coe said. "They are taking jobs away from American citizens." She recalled telephoning seven landscapers for gardening work; most hung up, she said, when she demanded that no illegal immigrants work on her property.
An Anaheim resident named John Cosak, an inspector at a military plant, recalled a recent Sunday visit to downtown Los Angeles. "It was another country," he said. "Hispanic immigrants were having a paseo, walking on the sidewalk, eyeing each other, playing loud music. I felt displaced and alienated. They are on the attack."
To this group, the immigrants are here not just to make a living but to "reconquer" Southern California for Mexico. "The recent migrants are not immigrants," said Richard Alard, an engineer from Fountain Valley. "They are Mexicans living in America."
Hispanic advocates see racist and elitist overtones to all this. "When they say immigrants, they mean Latinos," said Harry P. Pachon, executive director of the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials.
"They are not talking about middle-class Asian engineers, but day laborers and gardeners who make life easier for Southern Californians. They are not competing for aerospace jobs. When Hughes and Lockheed move away, those were not undocumented workers. We are looking for scapegoats."
 
The Costs
Seeing a Strain On Services
 As long as California's economy was booming and tax revenues kept pace, little public attention focused on the fiscal burden of immigration. Indeed, his Democratic detractors note that Governor Wilson, as a Senator, sponsored a amendment to the 1986 immigration act that gave permanent residency to nearly a million Mexican farm workers.
Now Mr. Wilson is asking the Federal Government for $1.4 billion that he says is owed to the state for services to refugees and immigrants demanded by Federal immigration laws and policies.
The fastest growing state expense for Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main welfare program, is for the American-born children of illegal aliens, and spending for them has nearly quintupled over the last five years. "This is a major demographic problem California has to face at some point," said Professor Borjas of San Diego.
During the 1992-1993 fiscal year, refugees, amnesty applicants, and their citizen children and children of illegal immigrants ate up 18 percent of California's welfare budget, up from 10 percent in 1987-1988. The cost was $1 billion, nearly triple five years earlier.
Under law, illegal immigrants are generally ineligible for public services, but there are many exceptions. They are entitled to "restricted benefits" under Medi-Cal, the state health program for the indigent, for emergencies and pregnancy-related problems. And a 1982 ruling by the United States Supreme Court requires local schools to educate all children, regardless of legal status. A long-standing complaint of local governments is that what taxes illegal immigrants do pay mostly go to the Federal government, leaving local agencies to carry the burden of providing services.
In a study conducted last year, the Auditor General of California put the net annual burden to the state and local governments for the 200,000 illegal aliens in San Diego County at $145.9 million. A similar study by Los Angeles County, where recent legal and illegal immigrants and their children make up a quarter of the population, put it at $947 million a year, or 31 percent of total county expenditures. Immigrants were also found to count for 23 percent of spending by school districts in the county.
Both studies failed to account for the contributions the immigrants make to the larger local economies, and a more recent and more cautious study by the Orange County Administrative Office concluded that it impossible to calculate the costs to the county but called on the Federal government to correct "the fiscal imbalance" immigrants caused.
Many of Orange County's top elected leaders see advantages to the influx of immigrants. "They still contribute as much as they are alleged to take," said Harriett Wieder, a Republican who is chairwoman of the county Board of Supervisors. But she added, "The Federal Government should be assuming more responsibility, because lax immigration enforcement has resulted in an inundation of the undocumented."
And many business people find the immigrants good customers. "They deal in cash and I don't have to worry about checks bouncing," said Chuck Linnert, owner of Linnert Roofing in the city of Orange. Still, Mr. Linnert, who says he uses only legal residents on his crews, says he often loses jobs to competitors using cheaper illegal labor.
That raises the difficult question of whether immigrants are seriously damaging the economic prospects for unskilled and semi-skilled Americans in a depressed economy, particularly for young blacks. Until now, economists have generally agreed, immigrants performed the jobs unwanted by citizens, like dishwashing, but Mr. Linnert's experience is evidence that illegal workers may be in direct competition with Americans.
Unless the United States adopts draconian border controls, there is little to suggest much will soon change. Given the differences in wages between the United States and Mexico, migration will continue for at least a decade even if the North American Free Trade Agreement, or Nafta, meant to improve economic conditions in Mexico, is ultimately approved, according to Philip Martin, an economist at the University of California at Davis.
"Regardless of Nafta," he says, "you are looking at a larger number of people coming across the borders as opposed to fewer."

 California accepted more documented immigrants than any other state for the 1983-1992 fiscal years. Estimates of the number of illegal immigrants vary widely, but some indicate that one million illegal immigrants entered the country in 1992. California was the final destination for 75 percent of all illegal immigrants in 1992. Graph tracks documented numbers of all immigrants to the U.S. and those to California, annually, since 1983. (Source: Immigration and Naturalization Services) (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: U.S. Determines China Violated Pact on Missiles

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has determined that China has violated an international arms control agreement by shipping sensitive missile technology to Pakistan and therefore must be subjected to United States economic sanctions, officials said today.
Officials said that the Administration has yet to decide on the nature of the sanctions that will be imposed on China as a result of the violation of the agreement, the Missile Technology Control Regime. 
 Under American law, the Administration is required to impose varying degrees of economic sanctions depending on the seriousness of the violation. The law also gives the Administration the authority to impose sanctions and then waive them if that is deemed to be in the national interest.
 
Strictest Penalty Not Imposed
 State Department officials met today and decided not to impose the strictest measure of economic sanctions since the intelligence agencies determined that the Chinese had not shipped actual missiles, but rather technology that would allow Pakistan to build M-11 missiles, officials said.
But even if a trade embargo is limited to electronic equipment, space systems or other technology, this could affect a multibillion-dollar market.
The State Department officials would not provide any details on sanctions since China has not been officially notified of the determination. But this evening, they began telling members of Congress of the decision to impose the measures.
And several officials confirmed that a determination had been reached that China's actions were a violation of the arms control treaty. Officials said an announcement of sanctions could come as early as Wednesday.
"I don't have any specific time when a decision concerning sanctions might be made, but I should point out that U.S. law requires us to move expeditiously," said Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman.
Although Beijing did not sign the missile control treaty, it promised last year to abide by its provisions in order to avoid trade sanctions that were about to be imposed by the Bush Administration.
After an extended internal debate over China's record on human rights and arms sales, the Clinton Administration this spring decided to grant China most-favored-nation trade status. But Mr. Clinton outlined a series of concerns, including the missile technology sales, on which he said China would be judged in future consideration of its trade status.
Though reports about the sale of the missile technology have persisted for several months, American intelligence agencies were split over whether evidence indicated a violation by China and Pakistan of the control regime.
The issue was raised by Secretary of State Warren Christopher during a meeting last month in Singapore with the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen. It was also discussed by Lynn E. Davis, Assistant Secretary of State for International Security Affairs, during a trip to Beijing in July.
In addition, State Department officials have recently met with representatives of Pakistan to see if they could shed light on the transfers of missile technology.
Chinese officials have consistently denied violating the arms control agreement. Last month Mr. Qian said that evidence of the transfer of M-11 technology was a fabrication. The technology in question would allow Pakistan to build the M-11 missile, which is capable of delivering an 1,100-pound nuclear warhead a maximum distance of 186 miles.
The dispute with China is similar to a recent controversy with Russia over the sale of rocket engines and technology to India. Last month, Moscow agreed not to proceed with an agreed-upon sale of rocket motors and technology, which the Indian Government said it wanted for its space program.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 588 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
A Federal court overturned a law barring telephone companies from providing television programming over their networks. The ruling, which is certain to be appealed, could clear the way for an all-out race between telephone and cable television companies to provide hundreds of channels of television and two-way communications services over fiber optic networks. [Page A1.]
The regional Bell telephone companies are split on how to respond to A.T.& T.'s planned acquisition of the nation's biggest cellular carrier. They also disagree on technical issues, which could make it hard to match A.T.& T. in advanced new services. [D1.] 
 Bell Atlantic is trying to assemble a consortium that could rival A.T.& T. by bidding on radio licenses for a coming generation of wireless personal communications services. [D5.]
Digital computer technology will be used to preserve 55 million feet of Movietone newsreel film shown from 1919 to 1963. [D5.]
 
Markets
Stocks resumed their record-setting pace, spurred by lower interest rates and prospects for higher corporate earnings. The Dow industrials surged 32.98 points, to a new high of 3,638.96. [D1.]
Strong demand at the Treasury's two-year note auction helped prices gain in the credit markets. The 30-year Treasury bond's yield fell to 6.19 percent, a new 16-year low. [D14.]
The dollar gained against the yen after Bank of Japan intervention. Gold prices fell. [D16.] Oil prices retreated. [D16.]
Uncovered short positions in Nasdaq stocks rose to another record high, as more traders bet prices would fall. [D17.]
 
Companies
Mazda dismissed its top American executive and said it would reduce its U.S. headquarters staff about 35 percent. The moves reflect depressed sales made worse by the yen's steep rise. [D1.]
Sales of cars and light trucks built in North America rose 5.2 percent in mid-August after a slow start to the month, suggesting that the recovery by domestic auto makers remains on track. [D3.]
Toys "R" Us is planning to open Books "R" Us departments in about 170 of its stores by October after successfully testing the concept in about 30 stores for almost two years. [D1.]
Dell Publishing will reopen Dial Press, an imprint closed in 1985. Susan Kamil, most recently an editor at Random House's defunct Turtle Bay imprint, will be editorial director. [D2.]
Texas Instruments anticipates work-force reductions in its military unit because of cuts in Pentagon spending. [D3.]
Deere surprised Wall Street by far exceeding third-quarter sales forecasts and reporting a tenfold increase in earnings. [D3.]
A former Warner Brothers executive, John Calley, has been named president of a revived United Artists Pictures. [D3.]
 
International
The Clinton Administration asked an appeals court to overturn a ruling requiring an environmental-impact statement for the North American Free Trade Agreement. The statement could seriously delay Congressional approval of the pact. [D1.]

Three of the closest aides to Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen -- his chief of staff, his press spokesman and his personal secretary -- are leaving the Treasury Department, fueling speculation that Mr. Bentsen may step down. [A10.]

HEADLINE: Dow Hits New High At 3,638.96

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks resumed their record-setting pace yesterday, encouraged by lower interest rates and prospects for higher corporate earnings.
The Dow Jones industrial average surged 32.98 points, to a new high of 3,638.96, surpassing the level of 3,615.48 set on Friday. The Dow set record highs in the last four trading days last week but paused on Monday to consolidate. 
 Yesterday's impetus included higher bond prices, which pushed interest rates down. [Page D14.] Also helping stocks were Deere & Company's report of a surge in third-quarter profits and improved sales figures for the nation's auto makers.
 
Wide-Ranging Advance
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 270.7 million shares, up from 212.5 million on Monday. The number of advancing issues totaled 1,301, while 698 declined.
Traders said the advance was across the full breadth of the market, with investors taking particular interest in consumer stocks and high-technology issues. Also setting highs yesterday were the Big Board composite index, up 2.24 points, to 255.15; the Standard & Poor's 500 index, up 4.54, to 459.77; the American Stock Exchange composite, up 4.69, to 453.20, and the Nasdaq composite, up 4.28, to 735.14.
Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief investment strategist for Gruntal & Company, said "the glue that is holding this market together" is low interest rates and "the fact that Congress and the President are on vacation, so they can't possibly do any damage until after Labor Day."
 
Computer Industry Meeting
 He also noted that investor demand for high-tech stocks could have been spurred by a conference of computer networking software and hardware companies in California.
The annual meeting usually generates interest among portfolio managers, Mr. Battipaglia said, which may have been reflected in active trading yesterday in stocks listed on Nasdaq, which has a heavy number of technology issues.
"It's hard to ignore companies that have shown growth rates of 50 to 75 percent annually," Mr. Battipaglia said.
Newbridge Networking, for instance closed up 2 3/8, to 71 5/8, after hitting a 52-week high of 72 1/8. Scientific-Atlanta was up 1 3/8, to 33 1/4.
A big gain in Caterpillar, one of the 30 stocks in the Dow industrial average, provided some of the early leadership.
Caterpillar, which closed up 1 3/4, to 82 3/8, and hit a new 52-week high of 83, accounted for much of the Dow's early advance. The company said it had begun shipping 295 tractors, parts and tools worth nearly $100 million to Russia. It was Caterpillar's largest sale to Russia since 1983, when the United States lifted its embargo of oil- and gas-related products to the former Soviet Union.
Buying in Caterpillar was also spurred by a big rise in Deere, which closed up 5 1/4, to 74, setting a new 52-week high. The farm-machine maker reported strong third-quarter earnings and announced expectations of higher production worldwide.
Deere's earnings surged to $100.1 million, or $1.31 a share, from $9.1 million, or 12 cents a share. Analysts had expected per-share earnings of 80 cents to $1. Many revised their earnings forecasts after the announcement.
General Motors, gained 1 5/8, to 46 3/4; Chrysler 7/8, to 42 1/4, and Ford, 1 5/8, to 51 3/4. The nation's auto makers reported that sales of cars and light trucks built in North America rose 5.2 percent in mid-August, recovering from weakness early in the month and resuming the moderate recovery of July.
Shares of Caldor rose to as high as 28 5/8 but closed unchanged at 28. Thomas Filandro, an analyst at Gruntal, upgraded his rating to outperform select from outperform, according to a report from the brokerage firm.
Albertson'sfell 1/2, to 55 1/2, as Smith Barney Shearson downgraded it to neutral from outperform. On Monday, the supermarket and pharmacy chain posted second-quarter earnings of 60 cents a share compared with 50 cents a year earlier.
Sodak Gaming rose 3 1/4, to 28 1/4, on news that the company had signed an agreement to distribute Innovative Gaming's video blackjack and video craps gambling machines in the United States and Canada. Innovative Gaming rose 1 1/4, to 14.
Wheeling Pittsburgh rose 1 5/8, to 12. Merrill Lynch reiterated its near long-term buy rating.
Intel fell 3/4, to 63 1/2, on reports that I.B.M. was trying to develop clones of Intel's microprocessors. Some analysts said that could put competitive pressure on Intel, which dominates the chip market.
Scientific Games, which went public yesterday with an offering of 2.5 million shares at 14, closed at 18 1/4. The company recently won a contract to supply the New York State Lottery with about $7 million of automated prize validation equipment.

HEADLINE: Bosnian Croats Again Deny A Food Delivery to Muslims

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Bosnian Croat leaders refused again today to allow a United Nations convoy deliver food to an estimated 55,000 Muslims who are reported near starvation in the eastern half of the city of Mostar.
Just hours after giving permission for the 19-truck convoy to deliver some 200 tons of food and medicine to eastern Mostar, the Bosnian Croats reneged, demanding first the return of the bodies of Croatian militiamen killed in the fighting that has raged in the city since early May. 
 "There is a strong desire from the Croats to get the bodies of their troops," the chief political officer of the United Nations force, Cedric Thornberry, said in nearby Medjugorje, where negotiations with the Croatian leaders are being held at a military base. "We thought it was settled."
[The two sides agreed to an exchange of soldiers' bodies, clearing the way for the convoy to reach Mostar on Wednesday carrying aid to both the Muslim-controlled east side and the Croatian-held west side, Reuters reported.]
[In Berlin, United States military officials reported that Air Force planes made the first drop of food to Mostar early Wednesday, the Associated Press reported. Two C-130 transports dropped more than 13,400 military rations into the city that had become the "No. 1 priority" for the food packets in Bosnia, a United States military statement said.]
 
Aid Barred Since June
 The Bosnian Croats have not allowed the United Nations to deliver aid into eastern Mostar since June, except for a token amount of medicine taken in on Saturday by Mr. Thornberry.
"The Bosnian Croats are leading us a merry dance," said Lyndall Sachs, the spokeswoman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
Sarajevo radio reported this afternoon that heavy fighting erupted in Mostar at 5:45 A.M. local time with an artillery attack by Bosnian Croats that claimed the lives of five children and wounded 15 civilians.
Heavy clashes lasted until this afternoon, news reports from the city said.
Sarajevo radio also reported that the Croats shelled the nearby Muslim-controlled town of Jablanica and surrounding villages and that snipers attacked people attempting to flee Mostar over mountain tracks, killing a young girl.
 
Hospital Moves to Basement
 Shelling has reportedly rendered some 60 percent of eastern Mostar's buildings uninhabitable and the makeshift local hospital has moved all its patients to the basement.
Bosnia's Foreign Minister, Haris Silajdzic, said today that changes must be made to a United Nations peace proposal before the Muslim-led Bosnian Government will accept it. The plan divides Bosnia and Herzegovina into a Serbian, a Croatian and a land-locked, Muslim-dominated Bosnian republic.
"The future Bosnian republic, the central republic, is not in my view viable either economically or geographically," Mr. Silajdzic said at a news conference. He clearly indicated that the Bosnian Government would demand that the once predominantly Muslim towns of Bijeljina, Zvornik, Visegrad, Foca, Prijedor, Sanski Most and Kljuc be joined with the proposed Bosnian state, which comprises only about a third of Bosnia and Herzegovina's prewar land area.
The Bosnian Serbs drove out nearly all of the Muslims from these towns in their so-called "ethnic cleansing" campaign during the last year.
"The lines on the map are a victory for nationalism and aggression," Mr. Silajdzic said. "Genocide is rewarded."
If these areas are not returned to Bosnian Government control, he said, the thousands of survivors who fled the attacks "will never be able to return to their homes."
Mr. Silajdzic clearly indicated that the co-chairmen of the Bosnia peace talks -- Lord Owen of the European Community and Thorvald Stoltenberg of the United Nations -- pressured the Bosnian Government to accept the peace plan but denied that any linkage was made with future deliveries of aid or money for reconstruction.
"The co-chairmen are doing a not-so-clean job for the international community and it is in large part not their fault," he said. "These men are giving the green light for the continuation of the aggression if the Bosnian Government does not sign the agreement. This makes it obviously an ultimatum."
At a meeting of their self-declared parliament in May, the Bosnian Serbs rejected the original peace plan, and there is little likelihood that their forces will abandon the territories the Bosnian Government is demanding, referring to them time and again as "holy Serbian land."
 
Serbs Deliver Threat
 Radovan Karadzic, leader of the Bosnian Serbs, said today that his forces would have no choice but to continue the war if the Muslim-led Bosnian Parliament rejects the peace plan at a session scheduled to be held here on Friday.
"If the Muslims continue to fight for nothing," Mr. Karadzic said, "we will reconsider our offers and withdraw our concessions."
Mr. Karadzic said that his parliament will also meet on Friday to discuss the peace proposal and that he expected it to be approved.
Leaders of the Bosnian Croats have already indicated that they will back the plan.
In Sarajevo today, two people were killed and seven others were wounded when a shell landed on a crowded street in the historic old town, local hospital officials said. Sarajevo radio also reported today that Bosnian Serb forces were continuing an attack on the towns of Maglaj and Tesanj.

HEADLINE: Poor Peru Stands By as Its Rich Past Is Plundered

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOMAS DE LACHAY, Peru

 BODY:
Two hours north of Lima, a dirt road off the main highway runs into the desert, past a chicken farm and up to a series of rounded hills. At the base of the hills, in an area the size of a football field, the ground is pockmarked with holes, some 12 feet deep.
Strewn around are pieces of ancient pottery and fragments of human bones from the Chancay culture, which flourished between 700 and 1400 -- worthless items diggers left behind. In the holes are the remains of passages and burial chambers that have nearly been demolished. 
 Gone are any pieces that can be sold to tourists, antiquities dealers or collectors in Lima. Also gone is most of the archeological evidence that would help scientists better understand this complex civilization.
 
Ceramics Taken Away
 "They pulled some good pieces out of there just yesterday," said a passer-by who would not give his name. "They said they found some big ceramics."
Lomas de Lachay is one of thousands of places in Peru where looters are excavating ancient ruins, erasing archeological evidence, and then selling the country's cultural heritage at an alarming rate, faster perhaps than in any other country in Latin America.
To be sure, grave robbing is not new in Peru. In 1987 the opening by thieves of a spectacular tomb in the north touched off a looting frenzy around the country that archeologists say has increased with Peru's current troubled economic condition.
But new patterns have emerged among those seeking to uncover and sell antiquities. Poorly guarded museums have become a target for those seeking to sell antiquities to international collectors, and there has been a rash of museum burglaries, many involving the theft of priceless items.
And Peruvians can point to the developed countries, like the United States, Japan and those in Western Europe, where rich collectors have created a lucrative market for their antiquities that makes it almost impossible to stop peasants from plundering ancient sites.
Indeed, Government officials say looters working with rich collectors in Lima, who in turn work with international investors, have developed sophisticated trafficking networks for antiquities, illegally exporting an untold number out of the country.
 
No Money to Protect Sites
 Strapped for cash, the Government has abandoned the care of all but the most famous archeological sites and the most valuable antiquities. Officials recently announced that they were studying the possibility of selling the management of Peru's heritage to entrepreneurs.
For Peru, which along with Mexico has the richest archeological heritage in all of the Americas, the plundering of such treasures not only continues a historical pattern set 500 years ago by the Spanish, but is also the product of social and economic problems of the late 20th century.
Conquerors as well as survivors have sought to harvest the golden riches of societies like the Moche, which flourished in the northern coastal desert from about 250 B.C. to A.D. 400; the Nazca culture and its vast complex of mysterious lines etched in the southern Peruvian desert; the Tiahuanaco culture around Lake Titicaca, and the country's most dominating civilization, the Inca, whose empire in the 15th century stretched from Venezuela to Patagonia in Argentina.
After five years of deep recession, which has left 70 percent of Peruvians in poverty, the economy is showing only the first signs of recovery. The economic strain has led the Government and the public to choose development over cultural preservation.
"It's sad to say, but there is no money, and I doubt there will be any money in the future," Pedro Gjurinovic, director of the National Institute of Culture, said in an interview with El Comercio of Lima. "It is now clearly demonstrated that the state has turned its back on the preservation of our patrimony."
 
Incidents Reported Frequently
 News of the destruction of Peru's treasures appears frequently.
For example, in Cuzco, the heart of the Inca empire until the Spaniards came, thieves broke into the archeological museum of San Antonio Abad University in February and stole 58 gold and silver necklaces, pins, figures and other objects. The robbers were caught within 36 hours, but most of the treasures were lost forever. They were melted down for their silver and gold.
In June, residents of a shantytown on the outskirts of Lima, while digging a well, unearthed skeletons from the Ichma culture, 600 years old, destroying burial chambers and archeological information.
In July, officials discovered that the country's national Museum of Archeology, Anthropology and History was missing three ancient textiles of the Paracas culture and possibly several others, and that parts of the Nazca lines had been destroyed by a construction company, which deposited rubble at the site.
"We have seen a big increase in the looting of our cultural heritage in recent years, and a real indifference on the part of the public and the Government," said Elias Mujica, an archeologist and former head of the National Institute of Culture. "International capital consumes our cultural patrimony, and national agents facilitate it. It's almost as profitable as the cocaine trade, but without the risks. And Peruvians really don't care that we are losing it."
 
Bias Against Indian Origins
 The long-held bias of many Peruvians against their Andean origins creates a deep ambivalence toward the Indian cultures that flourished here.
Grave robbing really began during the Spanish conquest, when gold fever led to widespread looting of grave sites. But to the consternation of many of the Spanish, the Peruvian gold was not always what it seemed to be, as artisans often used alloys containing less than 50 percent gold and silver. Such was the case in the items stolen from the Cuzco museum.
Huaca, the Quechua word for burial site, has long been part of the daily argot. A huaco is an object taken from such a site, and huaquerismo is the practice of looting graves. The looters are known as huaqueros.
Huaquerismo became a national issue in 1987, when grave looters in the town of Sipan, 380 miles north of Lima, discovered the richest burial ground known in the Americas, containing the vaults of nobles and priests belonging to the Moche culture.
After a number of gold pieces were discovered, hundreds of villagers spent days digging and sifting the soil, looting almost 100 pieces, until the Government moved in with soldiers and policemen. Now, armed guards stands watch 24 hours a day at Sipan.
"We have problems from time to time, especially when people get wind that we have found some gold," said Walter Alva, chief archeologist in charge of the excavation, who carries a .38-caliber pistol.
 
Driven by International Market
 But in the same way that Peruvian peasants help satisfy the international demand for cocaine by raising coca, huaqueros dig graves because they know that a vibrant, though illegal, international market exists that assures them income.
The foreign demand, said Mr. Mujica, the archeologist, has been the reason for a recent spate of spectacular museum robberies. For example, in February 1992, a 2,000-year-old mantle from the Paracas culture was stolen from the Museum of Archeology, Anthropology and History in Lima. It was found two months later in the basement of Lima's international airport.
"All the robberies in the last three years have been requested from abroad," Mr. Mujica said. "If someone in Japan or Chicago wants a piece, they will ask someone here and the robbery is carried out."
There are big loopholes in Peruvian law on trading in antiquities. Anything in the ground -- oil, minerals or antiquities -- is the property of the state. But once taken from the ground, it ceases to belong to the state and can be passed into private hands.
Collectors admit to financing looters, letting them do the illegal part of extracting the pieces. Once the items are excavated, collectors say they can buy them, register them with the Government and in effect own them legally.
And they argue that private collectors take much better care of the antiquities than the Government does. They note, for example, that in Lima, the ceilings of museum storage rooms are collapsing on priceless ceramic pottery collections.
"If I buy antiquities from huaqueros, I am helping the poor peasants to survive and eat, and I am helping Peru protect its antiquities better than the Peruvian state can," said Enrico Poli, who has one of the finest collections of pre-Columbian and colonial art in the country and has been sued by the Government and jailed in the past for illegal trading in antiquities.
One solution for halting the continuous outflow of antiquities, most archeologists argue, is to teach Peruvians the value of their heritage. But modern Peru has a complex relationship with its history that is reflected in its attitude about treasures from the Incas, Moche and other old civilizations.
"There is a certain shame about our past," said Percy Ardiles, an anthropologist and the director of cultural activities in Cuzco. "We were conquered by the Spanish, dominated for 500 years, so how do you teach pride in our culture? We want to be white, and we are ashamed to remember that our ancestors were Indians. So how do you teach people to protect our Indian antiquities?"
 
Development Over Culture
 In the end, with Peru's economic needs and the demands of the military and Government workers seeming to overshadow the silent treasurers of its past, the Government has decided in favor of development over culture. Thus, there may be no alternative to handing over the management of monuments and antiquities to entrepreneurs.
In the ancient city of Chan Chan, the largest mud city in the world, covering 5.5 square miles near Trujillo, officially sanctioned excavation began in 1964. Because of a lack of resources, only a fraction of the remains have been excavated. Looters are constantly digging in areas of the city. Unique murals are decaying.
The financing from the Government is $5,000 a year, barely enough to pay the salaries of a few security guards.
Mr. Gjurinovic of the cultural institute says letting entrepreneurs charge tourists for visiting Chan Chan, plus organizing events like concerts and other cultural activities related to the ancient city, could bring in enough to prevent further decay and vandalism.
"I would think that many are going to disagree, because there are those who think the tourist is the great destroyer of our patrimony," he said in the newspaper interview. "But you have to realize that if they are coming to Peru, it is to visit our cultural patrimony. No one thinks of coming here to look at skyscrapers."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Yen, With Help of Bank of Japan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained ground against the Japanese yen yesterday after the Bank of Japan reportedly intervened to keep the dollar from falling back toward another postwar record low.
In New York, the dollar ended at 103.70 yen, up from 103.10 on Monday. The dollar was mixed against other currencies. 
 Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for October delivery, the most active near-term futures contract, closed at $373.10 an ounce, off 60 cents. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $371.50, down $1.
Angelo Evangelista, a vice president at Bank of Boston, estimated that the Japanese central bank bought almost $1 billion in dollars yesterday.
He said, however, that the market generally remained bullish on the Japanese currency because a Japanese Cabinet meeting last week on the rising yen "didn't come up with a darn specific item to reduce the trade surplus."
Japan's trade surplus increases the value of the yen, since importers in other countries who are buying Japanese goods must purchase more yen to pay for those goods.
The yen traded in a narrow range, however, as some investors feared the Federal Reserve might once again intervene to support the dollar, as it did last week, traders said.
The dollar also fell against the German mark, ending in New York at 1.6785 marks, compared with 1.6835 marks on Monday. Trading in the German currency was cautious as investors waited to see if the German central bank, the Bundesbank, cuts interest rates tomorrow.
"The market is awaiting the Bundesbank's meeting," said Dorit Ronnen, a foreign exchange trader at the Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York. Traders were mixed about the likelihood of a rate cut, which would likely cause the mark to lose some strength since mark-denominated investments would earn less.
The British pound slipped against the dollar, falling to $1.4985 in New York, from $1.5024 on Monday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Texas Instruments Sees Job Cuts

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Texas Instruments confirmed today that it anticipates work-force reductions in its defense and strategic electronics unit of 4,800 jobs by the end of 1997 because of cuts in military spending.
The unit, which accounts for 27 percent of the company's revenue, now employs 13,500 people, down from a high of 25,000 in 1988. 
 The projections, contained in a memo written by two employees and leaked to The Dallas Morning News, were made in response to a question at an informal session last week between management and employees, said Tony Geishauser, a Texas Instruments spokesman. The newspaper published the memo today.
Mr. Geishauser said that the figures were rough estimates and did not reflect firm plans to eliminate jobs. Should the company receive additional military contracts, he said, or succeed in converting more of its defense production to commercial work, the number of jobs at risk would be smaller.
 
Stock Price Declines
 Texas Instruments' shares fell $1.625 in New York Stock Exchange trading today to close at $82.625, after having steadily risen in recent months.
Company earnings have exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates in recent quarters, partly on the strength of strong demand for computer memory chips, and also from one-time licensing fees from companies using its technology. Analysts say most of the company's businesses are robust.
Mr. Geishauser also said that the military work-force reductions need not mean layoffs because other divisions of Texas Instruments were growing and many employees could be transferred. Other employees might be offered incentives to take early retirement and attrition would account for some further reductions, he said. He added that of 11,500 jobs eliminated since 1988, 26 percent were layoffs.
"That was during a down period, but now we're in a rise," the spokesman continued. "Everything is looking good for T.I., but as everyone knows, defense spending is going down."
 
'93 Orders Are Down
 At the end of the first quarter of 1993, Texas Instruments said, orders for defense electronics were 3 percent lower than in the comparable period of 1992. Second-quarter orders were also lower, down 28 percent. But orders were unusually high in 1992, because the Pentagon restocked missiles that had been used during the Persian Gulf war. These contained Texas Instruments chips.
Millard J. Phelps, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist, found the defense-unit job cuts logical. "It is understandable that they are going to do this," he said. "It is sort of like saying, 'Hey, Mr. Government, if you don't give us more work, we're going to cut more jobs.' They have a fix on what the size of the company needs to be to remain profitable."
While orders and revenue have declined for the $1.9 billion defense unit, it has been consistently profitable, Mr. Geishauser said. "We've always been a profit-making group for T.I. and we intend to continue to be."
The internal memo also said that the defense group was looking at another "voluntary termination retirement package" that "may not be as lucrative as the one offered in 1991."
In 1991, a buyout plan offered pension benefits as if the employees retiring were five years older and had been employed five years longer. Another severance package that year was offered to employees within five years of retirement.

HEADLINE: The Nicaraguan Tragicomedy

 BODY:
The sad recent history of Nicaragua has turned into a tragicomic opera in the past week. Leftover militants from each side of the civil war of the 80's have taken hostages, and dozens of people are still being detained by both groups.
It started last Thursday when Jose Angel Talavera, the leader of a "re-contra" group calling itself Northern Command 3-80, invited a delegation that included two Sandinista legislators to talk about reintegrating his disaffected followers into civilian life. It was a ruse. Mr. Talavera's group took at least 38 members of the delegation hostage, demanding that President Violeta Chamorro dismiss a prominent Sandinista, army chief Humberto Ortega, from her Government, along with Minister of the Presidency Antonio Lacayo. 
 In response, a group of Sandinista supporters stormed the National Opposition Union headquarters in Managua on Friday and took 34 hostages, including Vice President Virgilio Godoy. Since then, both Mr. Talavera's group and the Sandinista supporters in Managua have released some hostages. Political leaders on both sides have urged the groups to free the rest, and Nicaragua's Roman Catholic Primate, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, has tried to mediate.
What can American leaders do to ease this latest crisis? Not a lot. Policy makers and Congressional leaders might support Mr. Talavera's goal of removing Mr. Ortega from his position as army chief. Under his leadership the Nicaraguan military has allowed international terrorist groups to operate with impunity in Managua, and the army's role in last month's assault by former civil war partisans on the town of Esteli has been questioned. But if Mrs. Chamorro removes Mr. Ortega, she must not do so as a result of arm-twisting by the likes of Mr. Talavera.
U.S. diplomats have been pressuring Mrs. Chamorro to get rid of Mr. Ortega for a month now, and the Senate has voted to cut off U.S. aid until the military cleans up its act and answers some pressing questions about terrorist activity in Managua. But the U.S. could take two more steps that, while they might not loom large in the short term, could make some small progress toward healing the vast wounds wrought by Nicaragua's recent history.
First, President Clinton and his State Department could acknowledge that many of Nicaragua's problems stem from 12 years of disastrous Reagan-Bush policy in Central America. Treating Nicaragua's tensions as a cold war proxy battle and arming and training its contra rebels caused unnecessary suffering, crippled the country's economy and sharpened its social divisions. Those divisions are largely responsible for the current sorrows.
Neither Mr. Clinton nor his diplomatic appointees can reverse this unhappy history. But his Administration can, at the very least, enforce U.S. law.
Reputable news reports suggest Mr. Talavera is receiving both logistical and financial help from the Nicaraguan and Cuban exile communities in Miami. United States neutrality laws forbid its citizens to abet the overthrow of a government with which the country is at peace; these laws were consistently violated throughout the 80's. The Justice Department can investigate these allegations and prosecute anyone found to be helping the rebels in Nicaragua.
With these steps, Mr. Clinton can send a strong message that the days of tolerating this sort of meddling and adventurism are over.

HEADLINE: Saudis Without Dollars

 BODY:
Remember when economists stayed up nights worrying about how the world would ever be able to recycle Saudi Arabia's huge petrodollar surpluses? Today's worry in Washington, as Times reporters documented in a pair of articles this week, is about the dangers that flow from Saudi Arabia's equally huge deficits.
Financial reserves that less than a decade ago totaled $121 billion have melted away, spent on lavish social programs, eccentric development schemes, subsidies to domestic and foreign friends of the Saudi royal family -- and weapons. Since the Persian Gulf war, the largest share has been going to weapons, especially those bought from the United States. 
 In the short run, this recycling of American dollars spent on oil for U.S.-made weapons is good for the American economy. But in the longer term, it could bring trouble. The rough economic equilibrium that is achieved comes at considerable risk to Middle Eastern stability.
The sad history of America's relations with the Shah's Iran in the 1970's suggests how badly things can go wrong. Weapons can't guarantee domestic tranquillity, nor assure permanent friendship.
Saudi Arabia, a vast but thinly settled country, sits on top of the world's largest known reserves of oil. Even with today's relatively low petroleum prices, oil exports still earn Riyadh more than $40 billion a year.
But in every year since 1983, Saudi Arabia has run both a trade and a budget deficit. When calculated as a percentage of gross domestic product, Riyadh's $7.4 billion budget deficit last year was twice as large as Washington's. Since the Persian Gulf war, about $16 billion in annual Saudi spending has gone to defense.
More than $30 billion in Saudi arms purchases from the U.S. are currently pending, plus $6 billion more in civil aircraft. Last week President Clinton phoned King Fahd to lobby for U.S. aircraft companies as Saudia, the state airline, prepares to order a modernized fleet. The Export-Import Bank is prepared to grease the Saudia sale with more than $6 billion in American taxpayer-backed loan guarantees.
Though it is no longer flush, Saudi Arabia is scarcely bankrupt. There's still plenty of oil underground, and much wasteful spending could be cut. And, as Americans will be particularly infuriated to learn, Saudi citizens still pay virtually no taxes.
Tax-free benefits are doled out to keep Saudis reasonably content with an authoritarian system that offers limited rights and no meaningful opportunity for political participation. Some analysts worry that the kind of austerity policies that now seem to be called for could provoke social unrest.
As long as the U.S. maintains its present thirst for imported oil, it will keep pumping lots of dollars into the Middle East and keep looking for ways to cycle those dollars back into the U.S. economy. When oil dollars go to the lightly populated, autocratically ruled Arab monarchies of the gulf, America doesn't have much to sell them besides weapons.
That tends to lock both sides into an unhealthy, mutually addictive, arms-for-oil relationship. Unless, that is, Congress finally musters the intellectual grit to treat America's addiction by passing a balanced energy tax and endorsing a strategic conservation plan to go with it.

HEADLINE: Hunger On the Farm

BYLINE: By Ray Marshall; Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor under President Jimmy Carter, is professor of economics and public affairs at the University of Texas.

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Even at the height of the harvest season, around one-third of American farm workers are unable to find jobs. Although the Federal Commission on Agricultural Workers reported this spring that there were surpluses of farm workers all across the nation, the Labor Department continues to allow growers to employ about 19,000 temporary agricultural workers from Mexico and the Caribbean. These jobs can and should be filled by domestic workers.
The "H-2A" visa program, which is part of the immigration law, allows agricultural employers to temporarily hire resident foreign workers (although not illegal aliens) when they can't find American citizens for the job. The law also requires growers to offer the aliens wages and working conditions comparable to those available to domestic workers. 
 During the Reagan-Bush era, however, the Labor Department consistently refused to enforce these standards. Many growers began paying these workers substantially less than they do citizens. And in 1987, the Reagan Administration lowered the wages of aliens nationwide by about 20 percent. Farm wages dropped nationwide and thousands of citizens lost jobs.
The H-2A program exempts growers from Social Security or unemployment tax payments. It guarantees a strong, young work force that they can select without regard to anti-discrimination laws. And they can rely on immigration officials to deport workers who are fired for any reason.
Growers can also use any pretext to dismiss domestic farm workers who refuse to work under squalid conditions or who don't meet unreasonable production quotas.
To make matters worse, growers and their lawyers have developed legal tactics to evade the program's meager worker protections. In the East Coast apple areas, the Reagan Labor Department permitted growers to switch from a per-apple pay rate to an hourly wage in order to circumvent a Federal court order that required increases in the piece rate.
In Florida, sugar cane workers are commonly paid up to $40 one day for cutting eight tons of cane (a typical daily quota) and as little as $25 the next day for cutting the same amount. Workers are not told how their wages are calculated, and they have no way of knowing whether they are being cheated. The companies claim the rate system can't be explained in objective terms because the pay depends on conditions in the field that only a foreman can assess.
For the companies' purposes, however, the rate is remarkably predictable. Before the season begins, the companies budget a fixed wage amount per ton of cane cut and year after year they generally come within a few pennies of hitting their target. Still, the Labor Department under Ronald Reagan and George Bush accepted the companies' argument and refused to regulate payment at a per ton rate. The Clinton Labor Department may well take a different stand. It has agreed to decide whether this shell game comports with the law. If it decides against the sugar companies, they may owe their workers tens of millions of dollars in back pay.
The visa program is an object lesson in poor labor policy. As a captive work force, the alien workers can't bargain for decent wages or go to a different employer. To solve this, before resorting to foreign workers, employers should be forced to make good-faith efforts at recruiting American citizens, at decent wages and under civilized working conditions. Employers should not be allowed to establish unreasonable production requirements that can only be met by young foreign workers, who are forced to work scared and hard to avoid deportation.
It would be much better policy to have the Labor Department recruit U.S. citizens for available work. If the Government can locate enough U.S. workers for a given harvest, the grower should be prohibited from hiring aliens for the job.
Unless the Labor Department curbs these abuses, it will contribute to the poverty of thousands of American farm workers. And the problems will spread as employers in other industries learn that they too can hire temporary foreign workers at substandard wage rates.

HEADLINE: In America;
Youth and Optimism In the 90's

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
Each decade the memories become more vague, but with the release of new papers on the Kennedy assassination and this weekend's 30th anniversary observance of the March on Washington, 1963 is again in the news.
Roger Staubach, the Navy quarterback, was supposed to have been on the cover of Life magazine that last week in November, but his photo had to be pulled and replaced by a portrait of the slain President. 
 Daisy Bates, a civil rights leader from Little Rock, Ark., recalled in a recent magazine interview that she was the person scheduled to address the crowd at the Lincoln Memorial immediately after Dr. Martin Luther King's "I Have a Dream" speech.
"They were applauding so wildly," said Ms. Bates. "No one could hear me. No one was listening to me. . . . At the end of my two minutes, I realized that no one heard a word I said."
It was an extraordinary time. The transition from the 50's to the 60's was accelerating but was not yet complete. Miniskirts, flower children, the big Vietnam buildup, black power -- they were all still in the future. In 1963, the baby boomers were in the early stages of their extended adolescence. They would be heard from shortly.
The turmoil was already under way. The civil rights leader Medgar Evers was shot to death in Jackson, Miss. Four black girls -- three teen-agers and an 11-year-old -- were killed when the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala., was bombed. And Americans were astonished by photos of a Buddhist monk who had set himself aflame to protest the regime of Ngo Dinh Diem in Saigon.
Nevertheless, it was a great time to be young. More youngsters than ever were graduating from high school and going on to college. The economy was surging. Jobs were plentiful. Political leadership was young and exciting and pointing toward a glorious future. We were putting men into space and sending young people abroad in the Peace Corps. Optimism ruled.
Even the bloodshed of the civil rights movement was seen in a positive light. The victims were martyrs, the mourned but necessary casualties of the increasingly successful battle for justice and equality.
When protesters locked arms and sang "We Shall Overcome," there was never any doubt in their minds that they would. You had to be weird in those days to believe that progress was not a permanent state of affairs.
Thirty years later young people still manage to be optimistic, but it's harder now. In 1993, you can come out of college laden with degrees and still have to struggle to find work.
"I have to stay in school because there are no jobs available," says Jack Mortell, a senior at the University of Hartford who hopes to go on to law school.
Nevertheless, when asked if he is optimistic, he replies, "Yes, very."
Sean Downs, a senior at Baruch College in Manhattan, says: "I have it worse than my parents. They got married young, mom didn't work and they bought a house at the age of 25. I doubt I'll even buy a new car by then."
But is he optimistic?
Oh yes. "Because I won't stop until I get what I want."
Optimism may be more essential now than ever. In the inner cities, young people whose futures were supposed to have been assured by the successes of the civil rights movement are faced with the daily bloodshed of life in the neighborhood. As they dodge bullets, fend off drug dealers and attend the funerals of their peers, inner-city youngsters have to draw on exceptional reserves of optimism just to imagine making it into adulthood.
As for political leadership, young people seem profoundly unimpressed. A representative view was expressed by Joanne Dionisu, a 24-year-old financial analyst from Paramus, N.J.: "I feel our political leaders are not competent and that they are out to help themselves and their own careers, forgetting about the major issues facing the country."
Creative approaches to the enormous problems of the 1990's seem to be in short supply. But young people are weird; they don't need reasons to be optimistic.
In the 1960's, it was the young people -- fired by energy and enthusiasm and optimism -- who rose up and took the country in a new direction.
Perhaps it will be the same in the 90's.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Why the Marines Declared War on Marriage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As an experienced civilian counselor and advocate for enlisted members of the Armed Forces, I was surprised to see Gen. Carl E. Mundy, the Marine Commandant, put into writing the longstanding military policy of discouraging marriage or committed emotional relationships by enlisted people, especially males. 
 For women, the message is that pregnancy and children only get in the way of military service, and many branches counsel abortion, adoption or discharge. Recruiters regularly discourage mothers from joining and often require single parents to provide legal documents giving custody of children to others before they qualify to enlist. Once in, women face the dilemma of submitting to constant sexual advances or being baited and targeted as lesbians.
Perhaps Secretary of Defense Les Aspin refused to allow General Mundy to formalize the policy because of the apparent irony of blocking both active homosexuals and heterosexuals from enlisting. Despite the arguments made in favor of such a policy by Bernard E. Trainor (Op-Ed, Aug. 13), most of the difficulties married enlisted members face arise from the sexism, intolerance and unreasonable hostility of the commanders when personal hardships arise.
The comments of Mr. Trainor, a former Marine lieutenant general, fairly drip with these attitudes and condescensions. "Soldiering at the rifleman's level is a single man's game," he states, as if he hasn't heard a word of the debate about the expanding roles of women in combat.
I have seen marriages broken, and children harmed, too often at the caprice of indifferent officers. Meeting family needs or pleading hardship is seen as goldbricking. And woe to the women, enlisted or dependent, who have had to rely on military gynecological services, or whose pregnancies have inconvenienced the mission.
Our military is neither voluntary (drawing most enlistees in through deception, premature enlistment and economic impressment) nor democratic, as Mr. Trainor asserts and then bemoans. It is the last bastion of rigid, white, upper-class male supremacy and the most venal remaining institutional example of sexism, racism and privilege.
Today's young soldiers are trained and reinforced in sexist language and assumptions from basic training to officer school. The Tailhook scandal was not an isolated instance of harassment or rape, crimes that average at least three times reported civilian levels. Young women in the Philippines have brought suit against the United States military to pay for the care of children created in the strained subculture of prostitution that surrounded our bases there. This exploitation is commonly tolerated, even encouraged by military officers. As one ranking officer responded, "Some men drink, some men fight, some men rape -- it's all a release."
Clearly, the military wants to take young, single men and make efficient killers out of them. The complications that come with emotional attachment, human weakness and divided loyalty are too much for some military officers to bear.
Perhaps the real ban in the military is not on types of sexuality, but on human love.
 
JOHN JUDGE
Washington, Aug. 13, 1993

HEADLINE: In Sovereign Georgia, Crime, Civil War and Empty Coffers

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TBILISI, Georgia, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The sound of gunfire is so frequent in one Tbilisi neighborhood that its residents now call it Chicago. Mindful of an audience that long ago stopped going out after dark, the city's theaters and concert halls schedule performances only in the afternoon.
The Metekhi Palace, Georgia's sole luxury hotel, has a sign that politely asks guests to check their firearms before entering -- a request that did nothing to stop a recent visitor from firing off a few rounds as he tried to barge past armed security guards. 
 Even with the yearlong civil war in Abkhazia muffled by a cease-fire, violence continues to torment Georgia, a country of 5.5 million deep in the Caucasus. Two weeks ago, an American identified as a C.I.A. agent was shot and killed on an open highway in what local officials say was a random shooting.
Last week a German woman, a secretary at the German Embassy here, and a companion were stopped at gunpoint by masked men in western Georgia, robbed of their money, jewelry and car and left by the roadside.
Bandits have always been part of the lore of the Transcaucasus, a region described in Russian literature as steeped in both romance and cruelty. Its dramatic mountains and ravines are inhabited by dozens of tribes and clans who over the centuries have been subdued, sometimes only barely, by succeeding empires, the Persian, the Ottoman and the Russian.
"Read Tolstoy," a Westerner said. "It is all in there." Tolstoy served as a young officer in the Caucasus, and wrote about those times.
 
Playing the 'Great Game' Again
 In recent weeks, Tbilisi has been buzzing with talk about a new "Great Game" developing in the Caucasus, a replay of the old British-Russian rivalry that dominated Central Asia at the turn of the last century.
This time, the theory runs, the West, wary of Russian ambitions, has begun to strengthen its presence in this mysterious and volatile region with a mix of high-level diplomacy and old-fashioned espionage.
By focusing more attention on the new nations on Russia's periphery, some Western governments, particularly the United States and Germany, have been sending Moscow the message that it cannot treat the former Soviet republics as its own backyard.
President Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister whose personal relationships with Western leaders have helped bring badly needed aid to Georgia, said in an interview this month that the Clinton Administration had shown a new appreciation for the subtle relationships involved in the Caucasus.
"I think the new Administration has a more realistic picture, and sees the important role the Caucasus can play for peace in the world," he said. "They also realize that if the Caucasus is not peaceful, many countries might get involved, and a big fire could start here."
It is practically an article of faith in Georgian politics these days that Russia deliberately stirred up the separatists in Abkhazia, on the Black Sea, to keep Georgia weak and Russia's military presence strong. While hard evidence of such a conspiracy by Moscow is lacking, it seems clear that the Russian military, which has two battalions in Abkhazia, at least supported the Abkhazian side.
Mr. Shevardnadze credited President Clinton and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany with having personally relayed to President Boris N. Yeltsin their concerns about Russia's activities in Abkhazia. Since then Russia, Georgia and the separatist government in Abkhazia have agreed to a new cease-fire that for the first time includes a role for United Nations observers on the territory of the former Soviet Union.
The slaying on Aug. 8 of Fred Woodruff, the American envoy, in the back seat of a jeep driven by Col. Eldar Gogoladze, Mr. Shevardnadze's chief of security, has helped feed some of the more elaborate cloak-and-dagger theories about the United States role in the Caucasus. An investigation by the Georgian police, who are being helped by a small team from the F.B.I., has been pointing strongly in another direction: last Friday, the police announced that a 21-year-old soldier had confessed to shooting at the jeep after it had failed to stop when he tried to flag it down for a lift.
In an interview in Tbilisi, one of the two women who were in Mr. Gogoladze's Niva, a Soviet-made jeep, said she was certain that Mr. Woodruff's death was accidental. "It was an accident, I am 100 percent sure," said the woman, who asked not to be identified. "It was a blind bullet."
Still, Mr. Woodruff's presence in the region is a testament to Washington's deepening involvement. According to local sources, a team of Georgian security guards have already gone to the United States for training, while a more comprehensive assistance program for the police force here -- as well as in other former Soviet republics -- is in the works.
"A lot of things might be done for training, for military staff in particular," Mr. Shevardnadze said, speaking of American assistance. "This is a legitimate sphere for cooperation. It is absolutely acceptable."
Residents of Tbilisi have already detected some improvement in the local police force. "Now they have uniforms, and they have weapons," said one resident, noting that not long ago the police manning the roadblocks on the outskirts of the city were dressed in jeans and T-shirts, making them indistinguishable from the criminals.
 
Some Obstacles Cleared
 Lawlessness is just one of the problems that confront Mr. Shevardnadze. Another is trying to keep this fierce but fragile country together when its various regional and ethnic clans are in open defiance of central authority in Tbilisi.
"The only thing under Georgian control is really nothing," said a Western observer who, like many others in this capital, fear that without Mr. Shevardnadze, Georgia might fall apart.
In fact, Mr. Shevardnadze recently succeeded in clearing away some of the obstacles to Georgian unity. He managed to outmaneuver two powerful military commanders who had flagrantly challenged his authority ever since he returned from Moscow 16 months ago. He accepted a cease-fire over Abkhazia, which has proved to be more popular than his nationalist critics had expected. And last week he won the Parliament's approval of a new Prime Minister, Otar Patsatsia, whose most significant qualification is that he is from Mingralia, a rebellious region in western Georgia.
"At this stage, we have to think of how to survive, of reconciliation," said Thomas Gamkrelidze, chairman of the Parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee, who noted that if Parliament had had its wish, Mr. Shevardnadze would have taken on the post of Prime Minister himself. "Everybody, even the opposition, agrees that Shevardnadze cannot go," he said, "that that would mean chaos."
Some would argue that chaos is already at hand. Not only is crime up, but the justice system has collapsed, leaving people to settle their scores through old-fashioned vendettas. The Georgian economy is in ruins: the coupon issued last April on a par with the Russian ruble as a precursor to Georgia's new currency, the lari, is now worth one-sixth of a ruble or less. At this rate, the average salary is less than $3 a month, and as prices of everything from electricity to fruit rise sharply, people are panicking about how they will survive next winter.
 
Economic Reform Lags
 With the Government's attention on Abkhazia and its internal political skirmishes, economic reform has gone nowhere. Industry and most of agriculture -- including the legendary vineyards of eastern Georgia -- remain state-owned. There are still only a handful of private restaurants in Tbilisi, a paltry offering considering Georgia's reputation for good food and wine and exuberant hospitality.
Crime, too, has had a debilitating effect. Tbilisi, which in the Communist era was a haven for small-time traders skilled at dodging the official ban on private enterprise, has little of the kiosk and cafe culture that has so dominated Russia's post-Communist transformation.
"Opening a restaurant can be a dangerous business," a resident said. "Soldiers coming back from the front in Abkhazia come in, demand to be fed, then demand to be toasted by all the guests for their heroic deeds. And then just for good measure, they'll shoot up the place as they leave."

Desperate for Russian rubles, and maybe a chance to leave the country, some residents of Tbilisi gather in a park to sell their apartments and belongings. (Otto Pohl for The New York Times) (pg.
