HEADLINE: $1 BILLION IN SALES OF HIGH-TECH ITEMS TO CHINA BLOCKED

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The United States announced today that it would ban American exports of almost $1 billion in high-technology goods to China over the next two years to punish Beijing for selling sensitive missile technology to Pakistan in violation of international arms-control agreements.
An official said the trade restrictions could be greatly widened, to $3 billion to $4 billion worth of goods a year, if intelligence agencies concluded that China had sold Pakistan whole missiles, and not just missile components. 
 The Government said the ban announced today would not affect Chinese exports to the United States or China's preferred trading status, which President Clinton extended in May despite concerns about China's human rights violations.
 
Sanctions on Pakistan
 Michael McCurry, the State Department's spokesman, said the United States would also impose economic sanctions on Pakistan, although the amount of banned exports would be small.
Chinese officials have repeatedly denied that their country has violated the Missile Technology Control Regime, an agreement China has not signed but has agreed to abide by.
Mr. McCurry said the sanctions would prevent American companies from receiving export licenses to sell China advanced electronics equipment as well as technology for space systems and military aircraft. He said the United States now sells China between $400 million and $500 million of such technology each year.
 
A Cost for U.S. Companies
 "They will not be able to conduct that business," he said in a news briefing, referring to American companies. "That's a significant cost that we pay. But it, again, reflects the seriousness with which we look at the issue of proliferation, which we consider one of the, probably the most important, arms control issue in the 1990's."
According to the State Department, the area that will be hit hardest is space satellites, both satellite sales to China and the practice by which United States companies pay China to send their satellites into space. The United States had already barred sales of most military-related high technology items to China after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989.
On Tuesday, American officials disclosed that sanctions would be applied to China, but they did not describe them in detail. American export-control laws required the Government to impose the sanctions after it determined that China had shipped components that would help Pakistan build M-11 missiles, whose technology was developed in China and which have a range of 300 miles and can carry nuclear warheads.
One official said American intelligence agencies had concluded that China has sent missile parts to Pakistan, but he added that intelligence officials might yet find that China had shipped complete missiles. In that case, he said, the sanctions could be expanded to restrict Chinese exports to the United States.
The United States imposed the sanctions after China repeatedly rebuffed requests to answer questions about the shipments to Pakistan. In news briefings and interviews today, State Department officials seemed ambivalent about the sanctions, on the one hand saying they were angry about the shipments and China's refusal to own up to them, but on the other hand signaling that they had been pushed into the sanctions by highly specific laws.
State Department officials said President Clinton had reviewed the decision before it was announced.
"It's obviously a serious issue," said a senior Administration official, who insisted on anonymity. "We would not have taken this step if it weren't. We tried to clarify this issue with both China and Pakistan before moving. We reached a point where we didn't get the clarifications needed, and under the law we had no choice but to go ahead."
The official indicated that the United States hoped to move ahead with China on other issues, like human rights and trade.
Hughes Aircraft of Los Angeles is one of the companies that will be hit hardest. It has contracted to sell China one satellite and a ground station for $80 million and was negotiating to sell two other satellites. In addition, China has indicated that it might buy up to 10 satellites from Hughes by the end of the decade.
"Obviously we're concerned about the impact this will have on our business," said David Shea, a Hughes spokesman. He said his company was worried that European manufacturers like British Aerospace or Aerospatiale in France might seek to sell their satellites to China if Hughes cannot.
United States officials said they were concerned that the sanctions would hurt American companies, but Lynn E. Davis, Under Secretary of State for International Security Affairs, said, "When you make this determination, the law specifically states you can't take into account the effects of the sanctions."
She said the European countries, unlike the United States, do not have laws that impose trade sanctions when the non-proliferation agreements are violated. But she said that those nations "share our goals for non-proliferation of missiles," and that the United States planned to urge them not to let their companies take advantage of the American move.
Experts on China called the sanctions moderately tough, since the Administration could have announced sanctions and then waived them. State Department officials indicated that they were seeking a proportional response, in effect banning all exports to the two Chinese agencies responsible for the sale to Pakistan: the Defense Ministry and the Ministry for the Aerospace Industry.
In the Presidential election campaign last year, Mr. Clinton vowed to take a tough stance toward China over its human rights violations. Nonetheless, in May he announced a one-year extension of China's most-favored-nation trading status, with any further extension conditioned on China's improving its human-rights record.

HEADLINE: State Dept. Balkan Aides Explain Why They Quit

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
It was the kind of gut-wrenching cable that came across Jon Western's State Department desk every day for almost a year: a 9-year-old Muslim girl raped by Serbian fighters, then left in a pool of blood while her parents watched helplessly from behind a fence for two days before she died.
"This was pretty indicative of the type of things we were getting on a daily basis," Mr. Western said. 
 It was the kind of cable that led Mr. Western earlier this month to quit his job as an Eastern Europe analyst out of frustration with what he considered America's lack of resolve in solving the Bosnian crisis.
"The whole thing has been very demoralizing and very depressing," said Mr. Western, a soft-spoken man whose boyish features belie his age of 30. "I found myself walking home every night just angry and bitter. My wife could tell you of my large mood swings. You can't read through the accounts of atrocities on a daily basis, add them up and see what's happening and not be overwhelmed. It calls into question your morality."
Mr. Western is one of four mid-level staff members who have quit the State Department in the past year to protest United States policy toward the conflict in the former Yugoslavia, saying they could no longer countenance a policy they feel rewards Serbian aggression.
 
Malaise Over the Balkans
 The four said in interviews today that their actions were symbolic of a larger malaise within the State Department over America's policy on the Balkans.
"The dissent is not confined to the European bureau," said Mr. Western. "I've covered or been associated with the Yugoslav issue since the outbreak of hostilities. In my time, I have met one, possibly two people, in the department below the level of assistant secretary who believe in the policy."
Stephen Walker, the Croatian desk officer who resigned this week, also said that anger with the policy toward Bosnia runs deep. After word swept the building that he too was quitting, Mr. Walker said he was approached by numerous colleagues "who said they agreed with my frustrations with the policy."
Three of the dissidents -- Mr. Western, Mr. Walker, and George Kenney, who quit last year -- spoke in a joint interview today about their experiences at the State Department and about why they oppose current American policy towards Bosnia. A fourth, Marshall Harris, a one-time leader of the dissidents at the State Department, could not attend the group session, but was interviewed later by telephone.
 
'A Certain Luxury'
 The three who quit recently said they feel that others would resign if it were not for family responsibilities. "The four of us are young," said Mr. Western. "That affords a certain luxury of being able to make the jump. We don't have all the commitments and responsibilities to family. We're not 20 years into a career."
"We don't have kids going off to college," said Mr. Walker, 30.
State Department officials reacted testily when Mr. Harris quit, the first of the most recent spate of resignations. Some officials emphasized Mr. Harris's youth and low ranking in the department and suggested that he was quitting because he was not involved more in policy making. Such comments caused anger within the State Department and after the resignations of Mr. Western and Mr. Walker, State Department officials have gone out of their way to say that resignation is an honorable form of protest.
Dissent within the Government's foreign policy apparatus over high-profile and contentious issues is nothing new, and neither are such resignations. Cyrus R. Vance quit as Secretary of State in 1980 to show his disagreement over President Carter's decision to attempt to rescue American hostages in Iran. Anthony Lake, the present National Security Advisor, was one of 10 National Security Council staff members who resigned in 1969 and 1970 over the Vietnam War.
But, virtually everyone at the State Department agrees that there has not been such public protests by those given the task of carrying out a policy since the height of the Vietnam War.
 
Administration Criticized
 "This Administration has used and manipulated the media and public opinion on Bosnia," Mr. Harris said, "and so we should not hesitate to do protest so publicly and make our views heard."
Ironically, the resignations come at a time when even they admit that the State Department under Mr. Christopher has become more open in allowing staff members to express dissenting views than during the tenure of former Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who virtually cut out the Department's career professionals from policy making. But the three who just quit say that while they and others who agree with them can express dissatisfaction internally, there seems to be little change in the policy.
"My problems were not with the process, or the access," Mr. Walker said. "I felt that from my position I had sufficient opportunity to voice my opinions, my frustrations; that the Department has tried to give opportunities to the professionals to bring up other options. But despite these opportunities that people have had, it's had little or no affect on policy. And that, I think, has increased the level of frustration within the Department."
The dissidents cited a news conference given by Mr. Christopher on July 21 as the low point. While Serbian forces were intensifying their siege of Sarajevo, the Secretary of State told reporters that the United States was doing all that it could consistent with its national interest.
The next day, Mr. Walker said, Serbian forces lobbed more than 3,700 artillary shells into the capital city. "The signal sent to the Serbs was we're doing everything we can, go ahead, have a good time," Mr. Walker said.
 
A Specific Alternative
 Mr. Kenney was the only one to provide a specific alternative to current policy.
"We should have a clearly stated goal of getting rid of the Serbian government," he said. "Just putting an economic embargo and sanctions on them is not going to do enough. We ought to close our embassy in Belgrade. Cut diplomatic ties. Throw them definitely out of the U.N. Have Radio Free Europe broadcast into Serbia, telling the Serbian people, that, hey, you've got a lousy Government, and until you change it, you're going to suffer."
There were differences in what appeared to be important about American policy toward Bosnia. Mr. Walker spoke often in broad policy terms, saying the Administration's inaction would harm American credibility, undermine United Nations peacekeeping efforts, and lead to a peace settlement that would not hold. He said it would also set a dangerous precedent for the oppression of ethnic minorities elsewhere in the world.
"No matter how you look at it, the policy as it stands right now is wrong," he said. "That's why dissent and frustration is so widespread and consistent."

HEADLINE: With a Boom in the Desert Over, Transplants Are Feeling Stranded

SERIES: Reinventing California -- Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORENO VALLEY, Calif.

 BODY:
The desert that stretches east from Los Angeles shimmers with mirages: brand-new cities like this one that replicate the Southern California ideal, with miles of identical single-family homes, each with its small green lawn and two-car garage.
Just three or four years ago, riding the California boom, these homes were being built so fast that the newcomers sometimes had nowhere to shop. The area became known as the Inland Empire -- San Bernardino and Riverside Counties -- the most rapidly growing region in the United States. 
 But with the collapse of the California economy and the abrupt shrinking of the military and aerospace industries, the region's growth has come to a halt. And with the Pentagon continuing to close bases, the local economy will be squeezed for years.
 
Search for Housing
 Nearly one million people in search of affordable housing moved in during the 1980's, the forward edge of what seemed an endlessly expanding regional economy in a stifling and often smoggy area about the size of Oregon. Many were employed in the military and aerospace industries of neighboring Los Angeles and Orange Counties, industries that supported the Southern California economy for half a century.
The price they have paid is a bumper-to-bumper commute of as much as four hours round trip. About 300,000 commuters jam the Inland Empire's freeways every day, said John Husing, a private economist who specializes in the region.
Now, many of the settlers have lost their jobs and are stranded with their new homes in the middle of the desert, part of the fading mirage of ever-rising prosperity.
As they hose down their lawns in an endless battle against the desert sun, worrying aloud about the rising crime rate and falling real estate values, they call into question the ideals of continuous expansion and easy living that have fueled Southern California's growth for two generations.
In a dozen interviews at their homes along the quiet streets of Moreno Valley, where the trees are too young to offer much shade, many people said they were looking for a way to sell their new houses and move away. They give various reasons: they are tired of the long commute; they want to look for jobs out of state; it's the smog; it's the crime and the gangs that have followed the population into the desert.
"We're leaving as soon as we can," said Jennifer Wickman, a 23-year-old police officer, who said gang violence was growing in Moreno Valley. "But first we've got to get some equity in our house. We just bought it a year ago."
 
Ills of a Larger Arena
 The rapid growth and uncertain future of the Inland Empire mirror the heady and abruptly stalled growth of Southern California at large.
"It's a microcosm of the ills that are right now affecting the southern half of the state," said Jack Kyser, chief economist of the private Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County.
In addition to the military and aerospace industries, Southern California has been supported by national and international exports, which are also now slumping. At the same time, its population has swelled, attracting people from within the United States and from across its borders.
Like Southern California at large, the Inland Empire is counting on a growth of local manufacturing and other industries to revive its economy. But it, too, is burdened by state regulations like air quality standards and expensive social programs like workers compensation that were imposed when economic costs seemed to be no barrier.
 
Economic Pattern
 As the state's population continues to increase, officials of cities like Moreno Valley are counting on a pent-up demand for housing to help revive the region's growth once the economy begins to recover. And with increased population, they say, will come local industries that could eventually lessen its dependence on faraway commuter jobs.
City officials are hoping to repeat the traditional pattern of expansion in Southern California, in which population is followed by services and small retail outlets, then major stores, offices and manufacturing -- the pattern in Orange County and the San Fernando Valley.
Moreno Valley has been designated by the state as a recycling-market-development zone; once the economy revives, it is hoping to attract manufacturing industries that use recycled material.
For the time being, the city's unemployment rate hovers above 11 percent, compared with a statewide rate of 9.6 percent, said City Manager Norm King. And it could get worse.
Already reeling from the recession, the city will be further hurt by the scaling back of nearby March Air Force Base, with an estimated loss of 4,600 civilian jobs in the region. Both private and government groups are trying to decide how to use parts of the base; base conversion remains among the biggest question marks for a Southern California recovery.
And on June 30, developers abandoned a projected 3,000-acre business and residential center for Moreno Valley, in which they had invested years of planning. It was expected to bring in 21,000 permanent jobs and nearly 8,000 new homeowners.
The developers cited "the unprecedented deterioration and continued faltering of the Southern California development environment."
 
As Varied as It Is Vast
 The vast Inland Empire, stretching more than 200 miles from Los Angeles County to the state's eastern borders, has nearly doubled in population to about 2.9 million, from 1.6 million in 1980. If it were broken off as a separate state, it would rank 32d in personal income, just ahead of Arkansas.
Its character is as varied as its size suggests. The range becomes clear driving from the urban decay of the long-established city of Riverside to the relative success of Ontario, with its airport and warehouses; from the quiet college campuses of Claremont to the resorts of Palm Springs and Lake Arrowhead.
But it is the brand-new cities like Rancho Cucamonga, Moreno Valley and the even more distant Adelanto across the San Bernardino Mountains from here that demonstrate the hungry growth of the region.
A decade ago, the city of Moreno Valley did not exist. About 15,000 people lived in three small towns here, 70 miles from downtown Los Angeles, where farmers struggled to grow potatoes and alfalfa on the baking, scrub-covered land.
The new city was incorporated in 1985, and local residents like Curt Montgomery, a salesman, watched in amazement as the paved roads came in, then the stop signs, then the traffic lights, then the shopping center.
"It just went in instantly," he said. The city's population is now 135,000.
Marty Kunard, an early resident who works for a company that repairs CAT scanners, also looked on as the city expanded around him. "In the last two years the developers were just playing leapfrog with each other," he said. "You could watch them going up the sides of the mountain."
With three-bedroom, two-bathroom detached houses selling for as low as $100,000 -- among the lowest prices in the region -- people like Karen Henderson Kreiss, a music teacher, joined waiting lists and hoped to rediscover the relaxed and affordable way of life that she said characterized Orange County 20 years ago, before it was overtaken by congestion.
It was growth like this that put the Inland Empire in the lead for housing starts as recently as 1990, with 28,658 permits issued, according to U.S. Housing Markets, the research service of Lomas Mortgage USA.
But by the first quarter of this year, the two-county region had fallen to 19th among 53 housing markets around the nation, with just 2,775 permits issued, a 26 percent drop from the previous year.
At the same time, home foreclosures in the region rose more than two-thirds during the first five months of this year over the corresponding period last year, paralleling a similar rise throughout Southern California, according to TRW REDI Data, a Riverside-based market research company.
Not surprisingly in a region that had experienced rapid growth but with relatively few indigenous industries, it is the construction industry that was hardest hit by the slowdown, with a loss of 10,000 jobs in 1991 and 1992, according to a report by the Chapman University Center for Economic Research.
"Because of the geographical size of the area, you see pockets of economic growth versus some areas that are really taking it hard," said Esmael Adibi, the center's director. "You're going from a 9 or 10 percent growth rate to now flat or negative. That's a big variation."
 
Extraordinary Downturn
 What makes this economic downturn tougher for Southern California than any in the past, he noted, was that it is not simply cyclical. With steep and permanent cuts in military and aerospace jobs, the region is left groping for a new vehicle for recovery.
For a city built on the dream of an ideal way of life, Moreno Valley's perfect rows of red-roofed houses harbor considerable discontent, from the college student who complains that there is nothing to do to the man who has taken to praying in his car to keep himself from exploding in rage in the rush-hour traffic.
"It's affordable here; that's all it is, affordable," said Lorie Ringham, whose husband, Kenny, lost his $67,000-a-year job with McDonnell Douglas last year and now works as a security guard for $9 an hour.
Mr. Ringham said he had found a new job near Los Angeles but could not move until he sold their house. It was appraised two years ago at $140,000 and is now worth $110,000.
 
Rise in Social Status
 Bob Roma, a retired engineer who helped build Pershing 2 and Patriot missiles, and his wife Chris have lived the Southern California story.
Newlywed and living in New Jersey in 1951, they decided, "Let's go to California,"and moved to Los Angeles. Like so many newcomers at that time, Mr. Roma found a job right away in aerospace.
Rising into the middle class, they bought a home in the Los Angeles suburb of Gardena when the area was still largely agricultural. As the quality of life deteriorated, they looked elsewhere, and seven years ago they bought one of the first model homes here.
Mr. Roma, who is 65, suffered the two-hour commute until his recent retirement. His daily routine, as he described it, was not unusual. "I leave the house at about 4:45 in the morning, so I have to get up at 3:45," he said. "If I get home at about 7:30, she has the dinner ready. Read the paper. Go to bed at 8:30. Then up again in the morning and on the freeway."
Mr. Roma endured, though he thought of putting a pistol in his pickup truck as protection against angry fellow commuters. "In that bumper-to-bumper traffic every day, people really get irritated," he said.
Now, he said, the only problem is the thick smog. Mr. Roma has heart problems, and his doctor has advised him to move away. But with the continuing economic slump, he does not know when there will be buyers for his house.
"We're stuck here now," his wife said as they stood on their carefully tended lawn, their two-car garage open behind them. "We've been thinking of selling the house, but I'll probably be living in Moreno Valley all my life."

HEADLINE: Avoiding a Values Test, County Cuts All Art Funds

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARIETTA, Ga., Aug. 25

 BODY:
Facing a proposal to limit arts financing to groups that support "community, family-oriented values," the Cobb County Commision here has voted instead to cut off all money for the arts next year.
The vote on Tuesday, coming after the commission's condemnation of homosexuality two weeks earlier, has turned up the volume again on a dispute over homosexuality and community values that has deeply divided this suburban county of 450,000 people north and west of Atlanta. 
 The clear loser in this dispute is a group of shellshocked arts organizations, ranging from children's theaters to the local symphony, which find themselves suddenly scrambling to make up for the funds they had expected to receive from the county.
"I'm just perplexed by the whole thing," said Kirsten Oxlund, operations manager of the TellTale Theater, which performs plays at local schools on the themes of safety and avoidance of drugs. The company had received about $6,500 of its $100,000 budget from Cobb County. "This is a little company that's making a difference for a lot of kids, and it's hard to see why we're forced to suffer."
This year Cobb County will spend $123,000 of a $142 million budget on nine arts groups. Contributions range from $3,620 for a local children's theater to $40,959 for a critically praised Marietta theater group, the Theater in the Square, which inadvertently set the furor in motion because of a handful of complaints about one of its offerings. The county had planned to spend $110,000 next year.
 
Convention Boycott Urged
 At a news conference on the Marietta town square today, homosexual and citizens' groups critical of the actions called for a boycott of the county's new $43 million convention center, asking those would hold conventions there to take their business elsewhere.
But county commissioners predicted that the economic effect of such an effort would be negligible.
On Tuesday, the five-member board of commissioners sidestepped the most pressing issue -- what kind of art it could support -- by voting unanimously to eliminate all the money it spends on local arts groups. The money will go instead to law enforcement.
Gordon Wysong, the commissioner who has been the most vocal supporter of the measure, said the county had set an example for the nation.
"It was about redefining government's role," Mr. Wysong said. "Government on a local level was told by both sides, 'You can't make these kinds of decisions for the arts,' and we agreed. So we got out."
But angry critics said the move was simply an attempt to deflect moral issues while gutting support for any arts activities that could be even remotely controversial.
"Their vote last night to kill county support for the arts had nothing to do with taxes," said Jon Greaves, head of the Cobb Citizens Coalition, which opposed the anti-gay resolution and the proposal to limit financing of the arts. "It was an act of desperation by leaders who are unwilling to deal with the difficult issues of free speech and intolerance in this community."
Cobb County, which ranges from working-class bedroom communities to upper-income golf course developments, is a largely white, staunchly conservative suburb. Newt Gingrich, the combative House Republican whip, represents 70 percent of the county.
The current dispute had its roots in at least two issues. One was a decision by the City of Atlanta to grant domestic partnership status to the partners of city employees who are homosexuals. A second was a handful of complaints about the fare at the Theater in the Square. One production, "Lips Together, Teeth Apart," was criticized for its references to homosexuality.
Officials at the theater said they had already received an outpouring of support and hoped to make up the lost money through private contributions and memberships. Smaller groups were less confident. And virtually all of them were astonished that their mainstream fare had run into a buzzsaw.
"It's all very ironic," said Thomas S. Holman, executive director of the Marietta-Cobb Museum of Art, which gets $22,000 of its $240,000 budget from the county. "Someone said to me we couldn't be any more apple pie unless we handed out apple pie at the door."
 
'Intolerance of Diversity'
 At the news conference today critics of the resolution, including the Atlanta chapter of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, called for an economic campaign against Cobb County. The group advocated diverting convention business from the county and said businesses that are thinking about relocating in Cobb County need to understand they will be moving to "an area which has demonstrated an intolerance of diversity."
But Mr. Wysong said he thought the stand against homosexuality would be more likely to help the county's image than harm it. He said he was not worried by economic retaliation.
"The idea that some fly speck of an economic boycott is going to affect the county is ridiculous," he said. "It didn't work in Colorado and it won't work here."

"It was about redefining government's role," he said. (The Marietta Daily Journal)

HEADLINE: Shipping Company Assessed Largest Election Fine Ever

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25

 BODY:
State and local officials have levied an $895,000 fine against a foreign-owned shipping company that admitted funneling laundered money to dozens of politicians since 1989, including the gubernatorial campaigns of Gov. Pete Wilson and Dianne Feinstein.
Officials said the fine on Tuesday against the Evergreen America Corporation was the largest for a political ethics violation in the nation's history. The previous record, also in California, was $292,500 in 1988 against William Bryan, a Sacramento County Supervisor, for failure to disclose economic interests. 
 The fine against Evergreen America, the American agent for the Taiwan shipping company Evergreen Lines, one of the world's largest operators of container ships, is substantially greater than previous ones for campaign fraud, which have tended to be $100,000 to $200,000.
Most recently, the Federal Election Commission fined Senator Bob Dole more than $120,000 for election-law violations in his 1988 Presidential campaign; that is the largest fine for any Presidential campaign organization.
The Evergreen fine is seen as part of a crackdown on political corruption at a time of waning public confidence in the political process. Campaign reform became a issue in the 1992 Presidential campaign, in part because Ross Perot was able to tap into a rising tide of public frustration with the status quo.
 
'A Growing Sensitivity'
 "It's an important message that these kinds of violations are going to be treated seriously," said Fred Wert heimer, who heads Common Cause, a public affairs lobby. "I think it reflects a growing sensitivity that is starting to develop all across the country. The campaign finance problem is out of control. It's undermining public confidence, breeding cynicism, and it's demanding responses."
The fine was the result of a yearlong investigation of Evergreen America by the California Fair Political Practices Commission and the Los Angeles City Ethics Commission. Ben Davidian, chairman of the state agency, said the inquiry began when the city agency was reviewing campaign-contribution statements and noticed that many donations were coming from Evergreen employees.
Officials said the investigation uncovered a broad money-laundering scheme in which the company tried to skirt contribution limits and reporting requirements by having employees and their friends and relatives donate a total of $172,000 to state and local politicians. They said the employees were reimbursed by the company.
 
'Gave Money to Everybody'
 Investigators said there was no evidence that the politicians knew the money was coming from Evergreen America. But Mr. Davidian said he found it hard to believe that a company would go to such lengths to make donations and then not make its identity known.
"Evergreen gave money to Democrats, Republicans, and independents," Mr. Davidian said. "They gave money to everybody. They had to expect they were going to get something in return. How they would get something if they had hidden the source of the contributions, I don't know."
Among those receiving money were former Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, who got $10,000; several members of the Los Angeles City Council and Ms. Feinstein, a Democratic Senator from San Francisco who received $42,000 in her losing race for governor in 1990.
Mr. Wilson, a Republican from San Diego who defeated Ms. Feinstein, received $4,000, which he said today that he would return. Ms. Feinstein, whose donation was Evergreen's largest, was traveling today and could not be reached for comment.
 
Fine Is Split
 Under a Los Angeles ethics ordinance, money that went to Mr. Bradley and other city officials must be returned to the city, said Ben Bycel, executive officer of the Los Angeles City Ethics Commission. The city will also receive half the fine, with the other half going to the state because of the joint investigation.
Mark E. Beck, a lawyer for Evergreen America, said the company had paid the fine in full on Tuesday. "The company is acknowledging that its San Pedro office made a mistake based upon advice they had gotten that obviously was in mistake," he said. "The company is taking action to resolve it. As far as we're concerned, it's resolved. There are no other investigations going on."
A spokesman for the Federal Election Commission, Fred Eiland, said he could not confirm or deny that the agency had begun its own investigation of the company.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Intervention By Japanese Central Bank

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen and other currencies yesterday after the Bank of Japan intervened on its behalf, catching the market by surprise.
Also supporting the dollar was a report of mild German inflation, which increased the chances of Germany's central bank cutting interest rates today. 
 In New York, the dollar jumped to 105.05 yen, from 103.70 yen on Tuesday. The dollar also rose to 1.6850 German marks, from 1.6783 marks.
Gold prices increased slightly. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for October delivery, the active near-term contract, gained 60 cents, to $373.70 an ounce. The Republic National Bank quoted spot gold at $372.00 an ounce, up 50 cents.
The Bank of Japan bought large quantities of dollars in Tokyo at 104 yen when the market had not been expecting action until the dollar fell close to 103 yen. American fund managers and corporations jumped on the bandwagon, pushing the dollar above 105.20 in New York.
"Continued displays of determination by the Bank of Japan have lent significant support to the dollar," Keith Cheveralls, foreign-exchange manager at Nippon Credit Bank, said.
 
Waiting for Japan's Trade Plan
 Dealers estimate that Japan's central bank has spent $6 billion on intervention so far in August.
 But the dollar could falter, they said, if Japan does not soon announce a plan to deal with its weak economy and large trade surplus soon. Moreover, the Federal Reserve has not intervened since last Thursday, when its purchases pushed up the dollar nearly 5 percent in three hours.
"Mostly, it's the B.O.J. against the world," Richard Koss, managing director at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, said. "Is it willing to do that forever?"
The dollar rose against the mark as only modest inflation in several German states raised hopes for an interest-rate cut today.
"The market's factored in a 25 basis point discount-rate cut," Michael McKeever, a dealer at Fuji Bank, said. The mark also fell against several other European currencies.
Lower German interest rates would make securities denominated in marks less attractive to investors.
The British pound fell to $1.4820 in New York yesterday, from $1.4984 Tuesday. In London, it finished at $1.4820, down from $1.4960 Tuesday.

HEADLINE: House Republican Leaders Assert Health Plan Will Push Taxes Up

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
House Republican leaders today made a preemptive assault on President Clinton's health plan, asserting in a new report that the Clinton approach would lead to major new taxes, burdensome new government regulations and a huge loss of jobs among small businesses.
The document, released by the House Republican Conference, signaled the intensity of the coming struggle over revamping the health care system. Mr. Clinton is not scheduled to release his plan until late September, but the Administration has already begun to campaign for its basic principles with a series of speeches and briefing books. 
 The document, which was not voted on by House Republicans, was released in the name of the conference chairman, Dick Armey of Texas, the third-ranking Republican in the House. It represents one of the first major assaults on the Administration's proposals, and Mr. Armey asserted that it reflected "some basic concerns that most Republicans share."
Republicans in Congress are far from united on the health care issue, and some, particularly in the Senate, have sounded far more conciliatory toward the Administration in recent weeks.
 
'Massive New Taxes'
 But the report declares, "Indications are that the Clinton plan will destroy jobs, burden the economy with massive new taxes, lead to a form of health care rationing and put the best health care system in the world in serious jeopardy, all because the Clinton White House is approaching the health care problem as a monolithic one to be fixed in one fell swoop."
Kevin Anderson, a White House spokesman, responded tonight: "This is such transparent demagoguery that it is laughable. He is throwing every scare tactic in the book at a plan that hasn't even been announced, and not a single bit of it sticks in the face of the facts.
"The President's plan will achieve simplicity and improve quality, savings that will fuel job creation, and, most importantly, the security of health care that's always there, for every American, no matter what."
Like the briefing book the Administration issued to members of Congress a few weeks ago, the Republican report is first and foremost a political document. Titled "Worse Than the Disease? An Analysis of the Clinton Approach to Health Care," it asserts that requiring all employers to contribute to health insurance for their workers -- a requirement that is expected to be a main part of the Clinton plan -- is "a Dr. Kevorkian plan for jobs," a reference to the Michigan doctor who assists in suicides.
 
'Managed Coercion'
 The report continues: "It is an economic axiom that driving up the cost of labor reduces the number of job opportunities. Employers who are compelled to provide employees a certain benefit do not pay for the added cost, they shift it on to employees (by reducing other benefits or the number of employees) or on to consumers (by raising prices.) Either way, employees are harmed."
The document also gives a new name to the philosophy of health care restructuring that the Administration has embraced -- the mix of government regulation and market forces known as managed competition. "To distinguish the pure theory of managed competition from the highly bureaucratic version that is reportedly the heart of the Clinton plan, we will refer to the Clinton version as 'managed coercion,' " it declares.
The report asserts that the Clinton plan, which is expected to revolve around community insurance purchasing cooperatives for businesses and individuals, is ominously bureaucratic and a big step down the road toward a government-controlled system.

HEADLINE: Progreso Journal;
In a World of Plastics, Can Yucatan Find a Place?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROGRESO, Mexico

 BODY:
In the steamy villages along the northern tip of the Yucatan Peninsula, a few Maya Indians still grow the long-stalked hemp plants that for more than a century were used to make the twine and rope that once brought great wealth to this part of Mexico.
But the hemp that this area is known for -- it is not to be confused with cannabis, also known as hemp, which comes from a different plant -- has almost disappeared, driven out by the development of plastics and synthetic rope and cheaper production in Africa and South America. 
 Now work and the rhythm of life are very different for Mayans like Samuel Tun Cauich, 32, who earns the equivalent of about $5.65 a day gluing together hand-painted mirrors for shipment to the United States.
The company he works for, Capriccio, is one of several dozen that Yucatan State has helped bring here to fill the gaping hole left by the demise of the hemp industry. In the struggle to find a replacement, the state has worked harder than most others in Mexico to lure foreign businesses and develop local companies. The effort has concerned local critics who see ancient ways of life disappearing.
But many Yucatecans believe that even work in an overheated factory or a gloomy warehouse is better than just dreaming about the past.
 
A Century as King
 "After the hemp shut down the villages were split up and people went in every different direction because we had nothing to eat," Mr. Tun Cauich said. "Now I'm doing all right, I guess, and my father is all right, but we're not earning anything like we did before."
What happened to his family is fairly typical of how the collapse of the hemp industry strained the fabric of life in Yucatan. For more than a century hemp was king. Its spiked leaves were processed into a coarse thread that was shipped from this port city and the nearby port of Sisal all over the world.
In Merida, beautiful white and pink mansions reflect hemp's past glory, just as unrestored mildew-covered mansions nearby show how hard this area has fallen in 50 years.
Mr. Tun Cauich was born in Tahmek, a Maya village 26 miles southeast of Merida. His father grew the hemp plant, called henequen, and sold it first to private middlemen.
In 1964, the industry was nationalized. Mr. Tun Cauich's father sold his hemp to the Government company, Cordemex, at heavily subsidized prices. Mr. Tun Cauich's older brother Alfredo worked at a processing plant, and later at Cordemex.
But no amount of subsidy could keep Yucatan hemp competitive. In 1991 the national Government cut its losses and dissolved Cordemex.
Now most of the hemp fields are gone and many of the steel-sided buildings that housed Cordemex are empty. Mr. Tun Cauich said his father lives off his pension and what hemp he can sell to the local market, where there still is some demand. His brother Alfredo took his severance pay from Cordemex to open a small butcher shop, while Mr. Tun Cauich took a job in a Merida factory.
"It's better now, but there are many, many things that make life here very hard for us," he said.
Without hemp, the state of Yucatan needed to take the unusual step of starting a business development program, said David W. Goff, project director for the state Secretariat of Industrial and Commercial Development. So far it has attracted 29 small assembly plants, called maquiladoras, in which parts are brought from the United States, assembled here and shipped back to the United States. Such plants are numerous along the Rio Grande border but rare here.
The state of Yucatan now has business representatives in Chicago, Coral Gables and El Paso, and advertises its advantages heavily. One advertisement caused a stir this year because in it Yucatan offered American businesses labor costs below $1 an hour.
Critics of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which would lower most border tariffs among the United States, Mexico and Canada, complained that the advertisement showed how the difference in wages between the United States and Mexico would lead American businesses to flee south of the border. The advertisement was withdrawn.
A local official with the National Indigenous Institute, Christina Pech Cuc, has opposed the maquiladora program because she says it speeds up the migration of campesinos to the city, destroying what is left of traditional culture. But for at least one maquiladora worker, it is the heat, more than the low salary or the loss of tradition, that is hardest to accept.
Every morning the worker, Adam Flores, bicycles two and a half miles from the village of Dzitas to the San Angelo Sports Products Company plant in the Yucatan Industrial Park. His job is to stand between two large ovens operating at around 500 degrees Fahrenheit while pouring molten blue plastic into the mold of a longhorn steer head.
The heads are shipped to Texas, where aspiring cowboys use them to practice lasso roping. San Angelo is owned by a United States company and was relocated from Texas less than three years ago partly to take advantage of lower wages. After two years on the job, Mr. Flores, a 29-year-old father of three, earns the equivalent of about $14 a day.
"Compared to what someone would get in the United States that's very small," he said. "Here, it's O.K., but still, you're always lacking something."

GRAPHIC: Photo: For more than a century, the hemp industry was the fabric of economic life in Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. Then, plastics and synthetic rope swept away the region's traditions as well as its wealth. A Maya worker learns new skills painting designs in a state-supported industrial program. (Gerardo Magallon for The New York Times)
 
Map of Mexico City showing location of Progreso.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Trade Dispute With China Spurs Drop in Wheat Prices

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Wheat prices tumbled yesterday after the United States said it would suspend hundreds of millions of dollars in exports to China because of that nation's reported sale of sensitive missile technology to Pakistan, traders said.
The sanctions, mostly on high-technology equipment, prompted worries that China would retaliate by halting purchases of American grain. China is eligible to buy more than 5.5 million tons of American wheat under a subsidized export program. 
 On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat for September delivery fell 4 cents a bushel, to $3.05 1/4.
Traders said wheat futures also came under pressure after the Canadian Government estimated this year's wheat crop at 34.2 million tons, up about 2.2 million tons from the latest estimate by the United States Agriculture Department.
On other commodities markets, cotton prices shot higher as worries about crop damage from insects in the Mississippi fields caused heavy buying.
December cotton rose 1.63 cents a pound, to 58.17 cents, on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Crop experts said Mississippi would see its cotton crop reduced if farmers could not control a heavy infestation of beet army worms.
"This outbreak is the highest we have seen since 1988," said Bob Head, an entomologist and crop consultant.
 
Lower Energy Prices
Meanwhile, oil prices closed lower, despite continuing uncertainty about a possible strike in Nigeria, a big oil exporter to the United States, and a surprising drop of 4.7 million barrels in gasoline stocks in the latest week.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, October crude oil fell 3 cents, to $18.32 a barrel, and September unleaded gasoline lost 0.55 cent, to 53.25 cents a gallon.
Live hog and pork belly prices were higher on anticipation of an American purchase of pork to be donated to Russia.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, February pork bellies closed at 48.775 cents a pound, up 0.425 cent, while October live hogs rose 0.550 cent, to 45.975 cents a pound.
After the close of trading, the Agriculture Department said it would spend $19 million to buy pork carcasses for Russia.

HEADLINE: Nigeria Gas Price Rise Ignites Fury at Government

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 25

 BODY:
In an oil-producing country accustomed to having some of the world's cheapest fuel, the decision this week by the military authorities to raise gasoline prices ten-fold has set off anger, anxiety and panic buying.
The move to introduce a new higher-priced grade of gasoline and make fewer pumps selling lower-priced fuel was even seen as part of a diabolical scheme by the military ruler, General Ibrahim Babangida, to foment chaos as an excuse to retain power. 
 "I think some people want to set this country ablaze," said Morgan Anibo, acting general secretary of the Nigerian Labor Congress. "Those who introduced this should be regarded as enemies of the country, not patriots."
And as Mr. Anibo and other analysts pointed out, raising the price of gasoline from about 11 cents a gallon to nearly a dollar a gallon would almost surely ignite a firestorm of protests even in relatively wealthy economies of Western Europe and the United States. But the impact of higher prices is far worse here, where the average worker earns about $27 a month.
Indeed, the desperate search for pumps distributing lower-priced gasoline today tended to overshadow the start of a three-day campaign of civil disobedience called by human rights activists in an effort to press the military ruler to step down and make way for an elected government.
Senior Government officials announced on Sunday that General Babangida would resign Thursday, and hand over power to an appointed interim government. But organizers of the strike insist they will not be satisfied until the military hands over power to elected civilians.
Moshood Abiola, a wealthy publisher and industrialist who is widely believed to have won the annulled June 12 presidential elections, is reported to have gone to Great Britain. Associates say that Mr. Abiola received death threats here earlier this month and that they have warned him against a hasty return to Nigeria.
Here in Lagos, the biggest city in Africa's most populous country, millions of workers stayed home today, as virtually all banks, shops and Government offices were closed. Most public transportation was also shut down.
Unlike a similar protest earlier this month, which emptied the city's usually congested streets, traffic was lighter than normal, but still relatively brisk, partly because of motorists searching for stations still selling gasoline at low prices.
Moreover, the strike's impact seems to have been limited to Nigeria's southwest region, Mr. Abiola's political and ethnic base.
Reuters reported that conditions were normal in Abuja, Nigeria's new federal capital, where a military parade was scheduled to bid farewell to General Babangida on Thursday. The same was said of the northern and mostly Muslim cities of Kano and Sokoto, where people were said to be going about their business, apparently oblivious of the protest.
Nigeria has long been under pressure from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to raise its heavily subsidized fuel prices, but has refused to do so until now, local analysts and diplomats say, because of the civil unrest higher prices might cause. Modest price increases last year touched off some of the worst rioting here in recent memory.
The new two-tier pricing system was made effective at midnight last Monday. About 80 percent of Nigeria's foreign exchange earnings come from petroleum exports, most of it to the United States.
In announcing its decision, the state-owned Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation said gas stations could still sell the cheaper regular grade, now priced at about 3 cents a liter, or about 11 cents a gallon, but would have to reserve some of their pumps for the new Super Three Star gasoline, costing about 34 cents a liter, or $1.05 a gallon.
The Government added that 35 percent of gas stations would be required to sell both grades, while some would sell only Super Three Star, and the rest would sell the old grade. Many Nigerians believe, however, that the cheaper grade of gasoline will soon be phased out.

HEADLINE: U.N. Counts on U.S. Rangers to Find Warlord

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Aug. 25

 BODY:
After more than two months of guerrilla attacks against United Nations peacekeepers, their commanders say the arrival of 400 elite United States Army troops Thursday will not only help in the capture of a fugitive clan leader but will also be critical in regaining control of the streets of Mogadishu.
The deployment of the Rangers is part of a move by the United Nations to capture Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, who has stymied the United Nations mission here, officials say. 
 In an effort to neutralize General Aidid and begin a reconciliation with his backers, the United Nations has also stepped up talks with members of his clan. But General Aidid has repeatedly turned down the suggestion of quietly going into exile while the United Nations prepares his trial.
The arrival of the Rangers, who will be under United States command, underscores the United Nations' reliance on Washington. They will join more than 15,000 United Nations troops in Mogadishu, most of whom are pinned down in their compounds by several hundred Somali militia.
United Nations officials, who as recently as last month insisted the capture of General Aidid was an isolated operation that would not affect the stability in the rest of the country, now say he must be arrested as soon as possible if the relief mission in Somalia is to be successful.
General Aidid has been accused of masterminding an ambush on June 5 that killed 24 Pakistani peacekeepers. On June 12 the United Nations began bombings and raids aimed at destroying his power base and put up a $25,000 reward for his capture. But his militia has continued its guerrilla war against United Nations troops, with ambushes and daily mortar and rocket attacks on their compounds.
More than 30 peacekeepers have been killed and hundreds of Somali civilians have been killed and wounded, feeding the growing anti-United Nations feeling in this city. The troops have hunkered down.
In the latest phase, General Aidid's militia has focused on United States troops, killing four G.I.'s on Aug. 8 with a remote-controlled mine on a Mogadishu street. There have been three other similar explosions that wounded several other American soldiers.
United Nations officials say General Aidid now may have access to Soviet-made SA-7's, shoulder-held anti-aircraft missiles, and therefore the United Nations has closed the airport to commercial flights and has grounded its fleet of huge white Soviet helicopters that ferried its employees from their residences to headquarters.
"Aidid is holding back the economic rebirth and rehabilitation of this country," said Jonathan Howe, a retired United States Navy admiral who is the United Nations special envoy in Somalia. "We're dealing with a terrorist. The sooner he is out of circulation and in a legal process, the happier I'll be."
 
Officers Are Frustrated
 The hunt has begun to frustrate high-ranking military officials, who would have preferred to act in early June. But although the Rangers are trained in urban warfare, night raids and long-range reconnaissance patrols, their success is not certain and the United Nations still faces limited choices in capturing General Aidid. The Rangers will also patrol the city, officials said.
Initially the United Nations relied on military air strikes to destroy General Aidid's power base. These were discontinued when a vituperative international outcry followed a helicopter attack on July 12 that killed dozens of Somalis, and an angry crowd stoned four journalists to death.
United Nations officials say they are concerned about not creating an image abroad of peacekeeping troops turned vicious policemen, but the military has expressed frustration at the criticism.
With bitter sarcasm, the deputy United Nations commander in Somalia, Maj. Gen. Thomas M. Montgomery of the United States Army, said: "It is the unalienable right of the Somali militia to kill and maim United Nations soldiers. But it is treated as a human rights violation if there is any military response against those responsible."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Cable and Phone Companies: Foes or Allies?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The question of who will build and control the "information superhighway" to deliver interactive television, hundreds of channels and telephone service to the consumer's home in the future, has long been regarded as a pitched battle between the giant local telephone and cable television monopolies. But if a Federal court decision on Tuesday is upheld, it is likely to usher in an era of cooperation between the two industries that can be expected to vastly change telecommunications competition.
Such cooperation could accelerate the use of interactive television and other services. It might lower the fearsome price for replacing today's limited-capacity phone system with an advanced fiber-optic network, a price estimated at $275 billion -- more than $3,000 a household. 
 The new competitive lineup might also restrain the rise in cable television rates by giving cable companies new competition from phone companies. "The court ruling was terrific for cable TV consumers," said Kenneth G. McGee, vice president for the Gartner Group, a high-technology research firm in Stamford, Conn.
The decision by the United States District Court in Alexandria, Va., will almost certainly be appealed. If it is upheld by higher courts, it could be revised by new laws from Congress. But if allowed to stand, the decision would let telephone companies for the first time own and offer video services in their own territories.
The case for cooperation between the two giant industries is a strong one because they are complementary in many ways. Telephone networks are good at switching millions of phone calls in a flash, but their copper wires do not have enough capacity to carry an acceptable TV picture. Cable networks have high capacity, but are largely one-way transmissions and are not built for switching.
Phone-company billing systems are good at tracking billions of small transactions, something cable companies are not good at, and in which they must develop skill if they are to offer video-on-demand services.
Combining resources would be ease the burden in building new networks. The largest local phone companies, known as the Baby Bells, have annual revenue exceeding $95 billion. The cable industry's annual revenue exceeds $24 billion.
"Any way you look at it, cooperation makes a great deal of economic sense," said Wendell Bailey, vice president of science and technology for the National Cable Television Association. The resentment between the two industries would still have to be overcome. Almost in the same breath, Mr. Bailey added, "But if cooperation means the phone companies own the farm and we're just a field hand, then we don't want it."
Not everyone is sanguine about the possibility of cable and telephone alliances. "It would be the triumph of the monopolies," said W. John Aronson, consumer communications analyst for the Yankee Group, a market research firm. "The phone companies, which monopolize large areas, would cooperate with cable TV companies, which monopolize small areas."
Cable and phone companies are already cooperating in various ways. In February, Southwestern Bell, the local phone company in Texas and Southwestern states, agreed to buy two cable systems for $650 million, both outside the company's service area. In May, U S West agreed to invest $2.5 billion in a Time Warner venture as well as to develop advanced technology for consumer video services. And in Britain, American phone companies like Nynex and U S West are allowed to provide both cable television and telephone service.
Recent state and Federal regulatory and court rulings had given phone companies greater latitude outside their territories, but only to carry video programs -- not to own or make them -- within their areas.
Tuesday's ruling, in which the court said the companies could produce and own the programs, came in a case brought by Bell Atlantic, one of the Baby Bells. The company owns phone carriers from New Jersey through Virginia and is eager to build advanced fiber-optic networks nationwide. Though the ruling applies only to the Bell Atlantic case, it appears to be broadly applicable to any phone carrier, especially GTE and the six other regional Bells.
Nynex's experience in Britain might hint at the future in the United States. The Government there wanted to encourage rapid introduction of cable television services by letting experienced companies offer a variety of communications services. "We are the company that the Bell Atlantic ruling makes possible," said Eugene P. Connell, president of Nynex Cablecomms in England.
As American regulators require more competition in the regional Bells' markets, the Bells fear their efforts to provide universal service will be undermined. Businesses and long-distance companies like A.T.& T. have been charged high fees to use the regional Bells' networks, subsidizing service in rural areas. "Assuming the Bell Atlantic ruling is upheld, video could be an important source of revenue," said Robert C. Fuehr, a US West vice president.

HEADLINE: Strong Yen May Bring Operating Loss at Toyota

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation, the strongest of Japan's automobile companies, may suffer its first operating loss ever this year if the Japanese yen stays at its current high level, officials said today.
"That means we are faced with the most serious potential crisis in our company history," Ryuji Araki, the general manager of Toyota's financial division, told reporters. 
 The rise of the yen, which makes cars produced in Japan more expensive and therefore less competitive on world markets, is only the latest problem. The Japanese economy is in a stubborn slump, and the European Community's car market, where Japan's market share is restricted by a voluntary agreement, is rapidly contracting. In the United States, Japanese companies have lost market share in the last year because the yen's appreciation has forced them to raise prices and because the Big Three auto makers, which have improved the quality of their vehicles, have become more competitive.
 
 
Income Declines Again
 Toyota, which was founded in 1937, is Japan's No. 1 auto maker and is the world's third-largest, after the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.
The company's prognosis, a testament to the new troubles of Japan's once nearly invincible auto companies, was made as Toyota officials, including its president, Tatsuro Toyoda, announced financial results for the last fiscal year, which ended on June 30. Sales were flat while net income fell 25.8 percent, the third consecutive yearly decline.
The company made it clear that a fourth consecutive decline was on the way. While the company is forecasting a thin operating profit for the parent company for the year that began in July, the projection is based on an exchange rate of 110 yen to the dollar. If the yen stays closer to 100 to the dollar, officials said, the profit may disappear.
Analysts are not seriously worried about Toyota. The company has huge financial reserves that could tide it over a temporary loss, and it has what rivals consider the strongest balance sheet of any auto maker in the world. It is regarded as perhaps the most efficient, tenacious and resourceful of Japan's auto companies. Toyota also controls two-fifths of Japan's domestic passenger car market and is in a position to gain share from its Japanese rivals, particularly Nissan and Mazda, which are in much more serious straits.
But the travails of the company that created the "lean production" system that is widely emulated is a sign of the trouble spreading through Japan's auto industry.
"If things are this bad for Toyota, they must be much worse for the other companies," said Benjamin Moyer, an auto industry analyst for Merrill Lynch in Tokyo.
On a consolidated basis, meaning the results of its subsidiaries are included, Toyota reported net income of 176.5 billion yen, or $1.7 billion, based on the June 30 conversion rate of 107 yen to the dollar. That is down from 237.8 billion yen, or $1.9 billion, a year earlier.
Operating income fell 16.8 percent, to 181.9 billion yen, or $1.7 billion. Net sales rose five-tenths of a percent, to 10.21 trillion yen, or $95.4 billion, from 10.16 trillion yen.
 
 
Sales Plunge in Japan
 The company's worldwide sales of motor vehicles dropped 1 percent, to 4.46 million units. But in Japan, the company's biggest market, sales fell 7.4 percent, to 2.16 million units. The company's exports rose 1.6 percent, to 1.72 million units, with growing shipments to Southeast Asia and Latin America offsetting drops in exports to North America and Europe.
Toyota provided forecasts for the year that began in July for only its parent company. According to those projections, production of vehicles in Japan, net sales and net income are all expected to drop.
Each fall of 1 yen in the dollar's value costs Toyota about 10 billion yen, or about $100 million, in lost income annually. The company is projecting an operating profit of only 70 billion yen for the new fiscal year and only 10 billion yen for the first half. But that is at an exchange rate of 110 yen to the dollar. By those calculations, if the dollar is below 103 yen, the forecasted profits would be wiped out. Yesterday, the dollar rose in New York trading to close at 105.05 yen.
"We intend to pursue every opportunity in that regard to avoid a loss," Mr. Araki said.
 
 
Fewer Models
 Toyota is trying to cut costs by designing fewer and simpler cars. It is also trying to reduce its white-collar work force by 30 percent. To do so, it has taken 30 percent of white-collar workers off their normal jobs and assigned them to cost-cutting. Officials said there was fat to cut, because the company had become somewhat bloated during Japan's "bubble" boom in the late 1980's.
Asked if the company would resort to layoffs, breaking the tradition of lifetime employment, Mr. Araki said, "Unless we resort to price increases, it will be difficult to avoid that."
The company is expected, however, to resort to price increases. Reports here have said Toyota plans to raise prices about 5 percent, on average, on 1994-model cars to be sold in the United States. That might be followed by another increase later in the model year.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Is Endorsed by Speaker of City Council

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins, seeking to rebound from the unwelcome glare of his deposition on the Crown Heights violence, won the endorsement yesterday of the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, and announced the hiring of one of the Speaker's top aides for his campaign staff.
The announcement on the steps of City Hall was part of a broader strategy to reach out politically to the city's white middle-class neighborhoods -- a constituency that Mr. Vallone represents -- where support for Mr. Dinkins is weakest. 
 That the Democratic Speaker endorsed the Democratic Mayor was not surprising despite some ideological differences and frequent institutional frictions between Mr. Vallone and Mr. Dinkins.
 
Added Significance
 But the endorsement took on added significance with the announcement that Mr. Vallone had relinquished one of his chief aides, Kevin R. McCabe, to join the Dinkins campaign as its director of political operations.
Senior officials hope that Mr. McCabe can provide the Mayor's campaign with organizational skills and strong ties to predominantly white, politically moderate and conservative sections of the boroughs outside Manhattan, where enthusiasm for Mr. Dinkins appears to be lagging and where his Republican-Liberal opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, is considered strongest. In his campaign, Mr. Giuliani yesterday released his plan for improving the city's school system. [Page B3.]
Of Mr. McCabe's joining the Dinkins team, a campaign aide, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said: "This gives us a good balance. It shows we're a campaign for everyone." Mr. McCabe is likely to give the Mayor's campaign greater access to local political organizations in Council districts throughout the city.
Mr. McCabe's title on the City Council staff is director of the operations division, but he is also steeped in the complex politics of the Council's 51 districts.
Both Bill Lynch, the former deputy mayor who is the Mayor's campaign director, and Mr. McCabe said they had been talking for some time about his joining the campaign.
But the announcement yesterday came at an opportune time for Mr. Dinkins, who has been reeling for a week under the weight of a city investigative report that criticized how senior administration officials handled the awarding of a lucrative Parking Violations Bureau contract and the embarrassment of being questioned in a legal deposition on his handling of the 1991 Crown Heights disturbances.
The second all-day session of the deposition is scheduled for today at Gracie Mansion.
 
Liaison in Queens Talks
 Mr. McCabe, who lives in Forest Hills, played a major role last spring as the liaison in private talks between the Dinkins campaign and the Queens Democratic leader, Representative Thomas J. Manton.
Mr. Manton endorsed the Mayor, which was a major blow to the mayoral hopes of Andrew J. Stein, the Council President who was then planning to challenge Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic mayoral primary. Within a week of the endorsement by Mr. Manton, an old friend of Mr. Stein's, the Council President dropped out of the race.
Mr. Lynch said Mr. McCabe would have broad responsibilities in the Dinkins campaign, helping in everything from the media campaign to relations with local, state and national elected officials. His prime job will be to coordinate the Dinkins campaign's citywide political efforts with its more local concerns, Mr. Lynch said.
Mr. McCabe, who is a respected figure at City Hall as an all-purpose troubleshooter for Mr. Vallone, said he hoped to be helpful to the Mayor in areas of the city where Mr. Dinkins is perceived to be weak politically. While acknowledging implicitly that the Mayor was unlikely to actually outdraw Mr. Giuliani in votes in many predominantly white, conservative neighborhoods of the city, Mr. McCabe said he thought that there were ways to improve Mr. Dinkins's standing.
 
'A Step Back'
 He said he thought the campaign could persuade some skeptical voters "to take a step back and re-evaluate where they really are."
"I'm not talking about dramatic 20-point jumps in any places," Mr. McCabe said. "I'm talking about an aggregate, in which you pick up people who think and understand how difficult this city is to govern, how good the Mayor really has been on certain issues."
Mr. Vallone, in endorsing the Mayor, acknowledged that they have often disagreed on issues, but he said they had reached a consensus on most of the important matters, including the city budget and the expansion of the police force.
The Speaker compared the last four years, when the city was striving to withstand a deep recession, to a turbulent airline flight.
"I want an experienced pilot at the helm," Mr. Vallone said. "We have an experienced pilot at the helm now. We've been through a lot of rocky air together, and I think we'll have a much better future with David Dinkins."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Faulted on Education Plans

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Offering his vision of how to improve New York City schools, Rudolph W. Giuliani formally endorsed the breakup of the central Board of Education yesterday, but then came under attack for what one political opponent called a "180-degree flip-flop" on the issue.
His proposal appeared to be a reversal of his previous stance that breaking up the central board would only increase the bureaucracy. Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, a Democrat who has proposed a similar breakup of the board, accused the Republican-Liberal candidate of reversing views that he offered as recently as July. 
 Mr. Giuliani said in a more recent radio interview that he supported breaking up the Board by creating boards in each of the five boroughs; in yesterday's speech he again endorsed the idea during a broad address on educational issues.
Seeking to offer incentives to improve educational quality, he also urged raises for teachers and others who deal directly with students, but he did not say how he would pay for the increases. The Mayor has resisted raising teachers' salaries, and the teachers' union is currently working without a contract.
 
Interest Groups for Adults
 Mr. Giuliani's proposals, made during a speech at the Roosevelt Hotel, at 45th Street and Madison Avenue, formed the core of what he called a broad "agenda for reform." That agenda stressed increased policing in and around city schools coupled with a return to the basics in education and a move away from what his briefing paper typified as "the interest-group politics which engulf the central Board of Education," a focus his paper described as serving the interests of adults instead of students.
Taken together, his proposals both adopted some ideas already under consideration and at the same time drew the broad outlines of a school system in which discipline and performance are given priority over social concerns. Harking back to his vocabulary as a prosecutor, he said he wanted the police to "secure the perimeter" of city schools while giving principals more control over their students, teachers and custodians.
Yet both his speech and a 19-page briefing paper provided little detail of how the changes would be made. Though Mr. Giuliani decried everything from decrepit school buildings to out-of-date textbooks and said he would give teachers a salary increase "as an incentive to elevate the proficiency of teaching," he did not outline where the money for those improvements would come from.
Ms. Messinger's plan, devised with Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens, backs a decentralization of power and the transfer of decisions on such matters as policy, supplies and where to develop experimental schools to the district level.
 
Reversing Position
 In adopting parts of that plan, said Ms. Messinger, Mr. Giuliani reversed himself on comments made before the Education Priorities Panel on July 13. In that meeting, Mr. Giuliani said he was leery of creating borough boards because he feared that it would cause a proliferation of patronage and perhaps increase the city's bureaucracy. He repeated that concern yesterday but said he hoped to deal with it by requiring a cut in the overall level of bureaucracy.
More troubling to Ms. Messinger was Mr. Giuliani's statement that he would require at least half of all school board members to be parents of children in the school system, a requirement he could not meet himself, since his two children go to Catholic schools within the city.
Ms. Messinger said she backed that idea herself, but added that that in the course of researching her plan, she had discovered that such a requirement would be unconstitutional.
"If Giuliani knows that but went ahead and said it anyway," said Ms. Messinger, "then that is really pandering. You know, the guy is running for mayor and there aren't too many details and one of the few details he has won't work." Ms. Messinger is a longtime supporter of Mayor Dinkins.
 
'Fiasco,' Dinkins Staff Says
 Leah C. Johnson, Mayor Dinkins's campaign press secretary, responded to the speech yesterday with a statement that the Republican-Liberal candidate "goes 0 for 2 on so-called policy plans." Ms. Johnson said halving the Board of Education's bureaucracy would cut only 1.5 percent of the budget and would not save much.
"With this education fiasco," she said, "Rudolph Giuliani falls into the same trap he fell into with his economic plan: His numbers simply do not add up."
Among Mr. Giuliani's other proposals were these:
* A commitment to allow principals more control over staff hiring and firing decisions and the supervision of the work of custodians in a manner that would not conflict with overriding state and city laws.
* Creating a two-block crime- and drug-free zone around city schools, and giving police the responsibility of training school security guards and running background checks on those employees.
* A shift to grade promotions based on merit instead of "benevolent" promotions driven by social priorities.
* And a commitment to limit board terms to eight years and schedule school board elections at the same time as general elections.
 
Would Call on Specialists
 Mr. Giuliani spoke generally about the troublesome issues that dominated discussion in the school board last year. He did not define who would decide such difficult matters as condom distribution in the schools, AIDS education or sex education relating to homosexuality. And he did not mention the much-criticized "rainbow curriculum."
Instead, he offered to bring a wide array of specialists together.
"Once elected, Rudy Giuliani would immediately meet with the five Borough Presidents, educational specialists, key legislators, state education officials, union representatives and representatives of educational interest groups and develop a strategy for resolving unanswered questions," his briefing paper promised.
That group would have its work cut out. Tucked among the candidate's proposals were promises to create more innovative schools, increase cooperation between city schools and local colleges and universities, study the possibility of having local school boards take over the city's Head Start and day care system, expand evening, weekend and summer programs and "look to the use of schools as service centers for adult literacy and English courses; health and child care programs; and social events for students and parents."
Money for those improvements would presumably come from the state. Mr. Giuliani said he would fight for more money.
