HEADLINE: Operation Match: Donate Pint, Then A Meets O-Positive

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARAMUS, N.J., Aug. 23

 BODY:
"You look kind of familiar; you're sure we haven't met somewhere before?" Familiar words, but the scene is not a singles bar; it's the recovery room at the Bergen Community Regional Blood Center.
This is singles' donor night, and the cover charge is a pint of blood. Short, white-haired Frank has just sat down next to Amy, a petite woman who, like Frank, is wearing a tag identifying her by her first name. 
 After an animated few minutes during which Frank and Amy find that they have the same blood type, A-positive, the twosome, arms bandaged, leave to find sandwiches in the refreshment room and continue their discussion.
This is the eighth singles' blood-donor evening at the center since the promotion began in August 1989.
"We'd need four drives to get this many donations in one night," said Rita Polchin, director of donor recruitment for the center. She's busy this evening running around and making sure everyone mingles.
 
Each August and January
 Ms. Polchin explained that singles' blood drives are held each August and January, when blood supplies are low because people are on vacation and schools have shut down. Tonight was a godsend, she said; about 90 pints, or units of blood, were collected, which went a long way toward meeting a shortage of 300 units.
The center has been hard-hit by all the corporate layoffs, which have cut into bloodmobile collections at offices. "This economy has hurt us so badly, I can't tell you," Ms. Polchin said. The Regional Blood Center, which employs Ms. Polchin, is a private nonprofit organization supplying blood to hospitals in four counties; the blood donors are volunteers.
For weeks the center has been running ads in the singles' sections of newspapers saying, "Come meet your type" and, "Blood donors are the right type." Food, prizes and fun were promised. About 45 singles' groups sent fliers, and some of them, like Volunteer Ventures and Parents Without Partners, are on hand to help with registration and games.
Most of the participants have given blood before. Many affect an air of nonchalance; they just happened to walk in and were surprised to find a singles' event taking place. Nonetheless, they are game to play games and see what develops socially.
 
Jackpot for a While
 Paul Oliver, a blood donor, says he hit the jackpot last year: he won the door prize of a gift certificate to a local restaurant and he met a nurse that very evening to share his prize with. The couple has broken up.
About 15 percent of the 112 participants who have come tonight will find out that they can't give blood this evening, Ms. Polchin said. Low or high blood pressure, colds, allergies, even a recent visit to the dentist are the most common reasons they will be eliminated.
"Can you believe it; here I am a first-time donor and I've been turned down because of low blood pressure," a woman named Cindi tells Hank Horowitz, who is from Fair Lawn. He makes her a poodle out of a balloon to cheer her up. He works in the shipping department of a large company, but moonlights as a clown at birthday parties on the side, he explains.
"Don't worry about it, be like me: I'm here to party," Mr. Horowitz says, smiling.
Meanwhile, Allan Susen is feeling a little out of it. A banker from Haledon, he is giving blood in a corner of the donor room. "I'm married and I just came over to make a direct donation for my mother," Mr. Susen explained. "My wife is waiting for me out in the parking lot; that is, I hope she's waiting for me."
 
A Game of Pictionary
 A staff member walks over to Ms. Polchin to say that the parking lot is filling up and that traffic should be directed to the Grand Union lot. Ms. Polchin agrees.
Eventually, a game of Pictionary begins in the refreshment room.
"Hi, my name is Dennis; do you all know how to play this?" asks a volunteer, dividing the room into two teams and pulling tall, embarrassed Celeste to the front of the room and over to a blackboard, to draw a mug representing the word "brew" that her team will try to figure out. They guess ice cream soda and root beer, but can't get it. It doesn't matter, though; this game is an ice-breaker and it's accomplishing quite a lot.
Dave Rotondella, a ponytailed contractor from Cliffside Park who is wearing a pink baseball cap and two earrings, walks in and several women give him the eye.
"I donate four times a year and I just happened to come over tonight," Mr. Rotondella says as he reaches for a soda. "Lucky me; this is a definite bonus."

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 13.13 to Reach Another High

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks traversed record territory yesterday for the second consecutive day, fueled by gains in cyclical issues, which are among the first to benefit in an economic recovery, and lower interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 13.13 points, to 3,652.09. It was the sixth time in seven trading sessions that the Dow closed at a new high. 
 Most other stock indexes also closed at record highs yesterday, withstanding a bout of selling near the end of trading. Buying momentum from Tuesday, when the Dow gained 32.98 points, supported prices, analysts said, but some profit taking tempered the carry-over.
 
Nasdaq Index Off
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was strong, with 301.7 million shares traded, up from 270.7 million on Tuesday. The number of advancing issues led decliners by 1,108 to 865.
The Nasdaq composite, the only major index to decline, was off 1.48 points, to 733.66.
Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president and market analyst at Tucker Anthony Inc., sounded a cautionary note on the market advance.
"With industrials, utilities and bonds all at new highs, the market has gotten overbought and could pause to digest recent gains," he said.
He saw the high-technology sector as an example of overbuying, saying that while prices could still move higher, "time is running out on this cycle and investors are urged to move to seats near an exit."
"But if investors must buy," he said, "they might consider oil and telephones as a somewhat defensive position."
Bond prices were initially weakened by a report that sales of existing homes improved in July. But bonds rallied and interest rates fell after the July report on durable goods orders showed weakness in manufacturing. Low interest rates make the potential returns from stocks more appealing to investors.
"The bond market says the economy is dead and the stock market sees it recovering by buying cyclicals," David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, said. "It will be interesting to see how this all plays out."
 
Effects of Cable Ruling
 Airline and cable-television equipment stocks were among the bright spots yesterday.
Shares of cable-equipment makers surged amid expectations of ballooning sales to telephone companies, which were freed by a Federal court ruling on Tuesday to enter the cable television business.
Broadband Technologies was up 6, to 40 3/4. Scientific-Atlanta rose 3, to 36 1/4; DSC Communications was up 4 3/8, to 65 3/8, and General Instrument climbed 3 3/8, to 49 1/2.
Delta Air Lines gained 2 1/4, to 55 1/2, on an upgrading of its stock by Paul Karos, an analyst at First Boston, to buy from hold. AMR, parent of American Airlines, was up 1 3/4, to 67 5/8; UAL, parent of United Airlines, gained 2 3/4, to 149 1/8, and USAir rose 1/4, to 16.

HEADLINE: Luxury-Tax Refunds Start

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Internal Revenue Service is ready to begin refunding several million dollars to retailers who collected the now-repealed luxury tax on expensive yachts, jewels, furs and planes.
Most customers who paid the tax on those items since Jan. 1, 1993, should get in touch with the merchant for a refund, the I.R.S. said today. But a person who paid the tax directly to the I.R.S., as on a purchase from a merchant abroad, for example, would need to claim a refund from the I.R.S. by filing Form 843. 
 Though Congress repealed the tax on yachts, jewelry, planes and furs, it remains in effect on luxury cars. The $30,000 threshold above which the car tax applies, however, will be raised each year to account for inflation.
The repealed tax applied to jewelry and furs costing more than $10,000, yachts above $100,000 and planes over $250,000. The tax was imposed as part of a deficit-reduction plan enacted in 1990. It produced $305 million in Federal revenue during the 12 months ending last Sept. 30, the most recent period for which figures are available. About 90 percent of the money was paid on expensive cars.
In general, refund claims must be filed within three years after the due date of the original tax return, or two years after the tax is paid, whichever is later.

HEADLINE: American Vanguardists Find Audience in Europe

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VASSIVIERE EN LIMOUSIN, France

 BODY:
The 1960's and 70's were the golden age for American performers to find work in Europe. Conservative American arts institutions stifled the vanguardists, while the underdeveloped American regional opera scene forced singers abroad.
Now, even with the lingering recession at home, American singers can find work with American companies and the evolution of trendy performance spaces around the United States has created a network for contemporary musicians, theater directors, choreographers and performance artists.
At the same time, the recession in Europe, combined with the development of local talent and an increasingly nativist attitude, has curtailed job offers here for Americans. Yet Americans still do get overseas, and not just high-profile directors like Robert Wilson. Two interesting, veteran New York performance artists, Connie Beckley and Joan Jonas, appeared in France and Germany in June, while all season long Mr. Wilson has been busy with new European projects. 
 Ms. Beckley is also a composer and sculptor. She has long been active in New York, but never quite so prominent as Laurie Anderson, whom she in some respects resembles. Ms. Beckley's is a quieter, subtler, more introspective art than Ms. Anderson's. It doesn't seek a broad audience, nor has it attained one.
 
Alone but With Help
 Typically, she works alone, as Ms. Anderson did before she got record-company support and hired a backup band. In both cases, to be sure, "alone" means onstage alone; there are eager helpers for the sound and lights, so this remains a collaborative process.
Ms. Beckley's piece "Melody on a Curve" was presented in mid-June at one of the many vanguard performance spaces that now dot the European landscape, in this case, the Kunstlerhaus Mousonturm in Frankfurt as part of a series of New York-related performance events. If opportunities in Europe for American artists have declined, interest in American novelties remains strong. Ms. Beckley's performance was an offshoot of a two-month stint she spent at the University of Giessen near Frankfurt, teaching about vanguard theater.
Typically of Ms. Beckley, her piece had all the ingredients of an opera with none of the brash assertiveness that form implies. She laid out what might have seemed like a dogged series of tasks, then executed them in a way that evoked all manner of emotions, some more purely esthetic, others sweet or moving or troubling.
As one entered the room, one found a circle of black, helium-filled balloons huddling close to the floor. In the course of an hour, Ms. Beckley crawled around the circle, freeing each balloon to float upward to the length of its tether. Each tether was slightly higher than the last, making a gradually unfolding upward curve of balloons. (Ms. Beckley said afterward that it took four hours to tape the balloons in place for each performance.)
As she liberated the balloons, she sang songs or recited fragments of text or assumed poses. Some passages involved memory, real or imagined; all flowed together into an artwork that felt coherent even if one could never quite figure out how the coherence was achieved.
If Ms. Beckley represents New York Minimalist cool surviving through the hot 80's into the practical 90's, then the 1960's-flavored performance style of Joan Jonas has survived an even longer journey. In late June, as part of a tour that included indoor performances in Berlin, Ms. Jonas offered "Variations on a Scene," a piece seen in an earlier form at Wave Hill, overlooking the Hudson in Riverdale, the Bronx. It is hard to imagine it indoors, even with video evocations of its outdoor setting, since it so much relied on the charms of nature, and in particular the spectacular setting of the Arts Center on the Ile de Vassiviere here.
 
A Socialist Legacy
 The island sits in the middle of an artificial lake created to supply hydroelectric power to this central French region and now a popular vacation setting. On the island is a sculpture park with a striking post-modernist building, complete with a slim, conical tower, designed by Aldo Rossi, the Italian architect. This Arts Center houses a regular series of exhibitions and workshops, but is itself worthy of a pilgrimage, one of the finest legacies of Socialist arts construction in the Jack Lang era.
Ms. Jonas is an important figure in the history of New York performance art, one of the first to use video in live theatrical pieces. She has also long been concerned with women's issues in a way that has encouraged other female artists and arts writers to incorporate that agenda into their own work.
Unfortunately, this latest piece seemed more fragmentary and self-involved than communicative. It consisted of a sequence of scenes in different locations on the center's grounds, with the loyal audience traipsing along dutifully. Some of the scenes commanded one's attention: performers appearing over a low rise signaling and semaphoring mysteriously to one another, or a striking German performer, Geno Lechner, hurling herself brutally across the wide lawns. Alvin Curran's music, which blended with Ms. Jonas's own sound collages, was characteristically haunting. But the setting, both natural and architectural, outshone this particular performance decisively.
Mr. Wilson's work can be seen occasionally in his native United States, as can that of Ms. Beckley and Ms. Jonas. But unlike them, he gets by far the majority of his opportunities abroad.
 
Wilson's 'Alice' and 'Orlando'
 The two most notable Wilson events this season (this fall there will be Wilson stagings of Susan Sontag's play "Alice in Bed" at the Schaubuhne in Berlin and of Puccini's opera "Madama Butterfly" at the Bastille Opera in Paris) were "Alice" at the Thalia Theater in Hamburg and "Orlando" at the Theatre Vidy-Lausanne in Switzerland.
"Orlando" was Mr. Wilson's French-language restaging of a monologue, originally adapted by the director and Darryl Pinckney, the American writer, from Virginia Woolf's novel. First seen in 1989 in German with the remarkable Jutta Lampe of the Berlin Schaubuhne delivering the two-and-a-half-hour text, the Lausanne version was redone for Isabelle Huppert, the French stage and film actor.
Miss Huppert is eager to expand this "Orlando" into a feature film, shot on location. That would be a first for Mr. Wilson, and perhaps Miss Huppert would shine on screen, although one has to wonder how much money is available, in the wake of Sally Potter's "Orlando," for two artsy movies on the same theme; Mr. Wilson's office claims not to be concerned about that. On the stage, however, Miss Huppert was no match for Miss Lampe, lacking the German's range and technical command of this most demanding of theatrical showcases.
"Alice" is a sequel to "The Black Rider," which was also a product of the Thalia Theater and which at long last is set to reach the Brooklyn Academy of Music this fall. With alternately quirky and touching songs by Tom Waits, who was also Mr. Wilson's collaborator on "The Black Rider," "Alice" examines Charles Dodgson, who under the pen name Lewis Carroll wrote the beloved tales of Alice and her curious entourage of Wonderland creatures.
The text by Paul Schmidt, an American, sensitively explores Dodgson's curious relationship with young girls, and principally with Alice Liddell, the main model for the literary Alice. Mr. Schmidt, Mr. Waits and Mr. Wilson do not shy from the queasier implications of this obsession, which Dodgson expressed in photography as well as prose. But they also honor him and the art he produced. As acted and sung by the same fine ensemble that appears in "The Black Rider," in the same quaint and curious mixture of German and English, "Alice" is both entertaining (Mr. Wilson's evocation of the Wonderland phantasmagoria) and moving, with the Wonderland scenes used to evoke Dodgson's inner demons.
Perhaps it is more moving for English-speaking observers who grew up on the "Alice" books than for Germans; the German critics were cooler to "Alice" than they had been to the campier, funnier -- and more German -- "Black Rider." But the final scene of "Alice," with Annette Paulmann as Alice Liddell in extreme old age reminiscing fondly about her loving mentor, is the stuff of great art.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Three-Division Playoff Format Likely Next Year

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Negotiations between baseball owners and players for expanded playoffs and three-division play very likely will be brief and successful, given the public positions of the two sides, and the new format should be implemented for the 1994 season.
Boston's John Harrington, chairman of the owners' schedule format committee, said today that the owners are prepared to move quickly to realign the National and American Leagues from two divisions each to three divisions each. The Players Association has indicated it would approve an additional round in the pennant playoffs if the owners took that step. 
 "Absolutely, we're all for three divisions," Harrington said by telephone from Boston. "It's not an impossibility to do it for next season. One of the reasons we were proceeding slowly was to make sure we had given the Players Association adequate time to consider it. We didn't want to create the notion that we were trying to ram something through. We felt it was better to phase in these changes -- expanded playoffs one year, three divisions the next."
When the owners approved the additional round of playoffs for next season, they said they wouldn't consider going to three divisions before 1995. Then Monday, Donald Fehr, head of the Players Association, said that the players opposed expanded playoffs that would include two non-championship teams but that they would consider the new round if each league's playoff included three division champions and the second-place team with the best record.
"I was pleased to hear Don say that with certain conditions they would favor three divisions," Harrington said.
If any element could bog down the negotiations, it would be agreement on how the players would be paid for the post-season games.
"The difference between this year and years past is a new element -- the form the television package takes," Eugene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said, declining to discuss the subject further.
Harrington, Bill Giles of the Philadelphia Phillies and Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, will meet Thursday in New York with Orza and Lauren Rich, also a union lawyer, to begin negotiations on the changes. Fehr is on vacation.
"We'll show them why we want to do it, show them the fan survey showing why the fans want it," Harrington said. "We'll go over the economics, what it means for the game with more races. Then it's a matter where if everybody wants to do it, we'll have to get ownership to sign on when they meet in Boston next month. We'll make certain schedule adjustments and impleent it for 1994."
The owners will meet Sept. 8 and 9. If negotiators for the owners and players agree to the new format, some teams would have to be persuaded that the placement of their teams is important to the overall effort of making the leagues more attractive.
If any National League team is to change divisions, it must give its approval. The Atlanta Braves would prefer to be in the Eastern Division instead of the Central, but, Harrington said: "I think they've looked at it and can adapt. I don't think any National League team would raise their veto power if they're moved to a different division."
The American League has no veto provision. Approval of the change would require 10 votes from among the 14 clubs.
The Detroit Tigers appear to be the A.L. team that likes the three-division alignment the least because they are scheduled to be in the Central Division, separated from their old A.L. East rivals New York, Boston, Cleveland and Baltimore.
 
A Delicate Balance
 The Texas Rangers, Harrington said, don't want to be in the Western Division unless the teams play a balanced schedule under which teams would play the same number of games against each team regardless of which division they are in.
"We'll have to talk it out with those guys to be fair," Harrington said, "but I'm confident we can resolve it at the meeting next month."
Fehr, in a letter to Ravitch on Monday, said an unbalanced schedule "clearly deserves serious scrutiny," but if time made it impractical, "we would be willing to consider a three-division, balanced schedule for 1994."

HEADLINE: Film Festival '93: An Emphasis On the Epic, as Seen Personally

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
The New York Film Festival, now in its 31st year, will lead off on Oct. 1 with Robert Altman's "Short Cuts," a three-hour panorama of life in contemporary Los Angeles that is based on the short stories of Raymond Carver, and close two and a half weeks later with "The Piano," Jane Campion's bizarre love story set in 19th-century New Zealand. The Campion film, to be shown on Oct. 17, shared the Palme d'Or at the Cannes International Film Festival in May with Chen Kaige's "Farewell, My Concubine," which will also be shown here.
The festival comprises 32 films, which will be shown at Alice Tully Hall. About half the films are from the United States, France and Britain. In a departure from past festivals, Eastern Europe and Latin American film makers are barely present, their place usurped by film makers from China, Taiwan and Hong Kong. 
 The films range in length from Tim Burton's 11-minute animated film "Vincent," to Mr. Altman's 189-minute epic, which is just 9 minutes longer than Ray Miller's "The Wonderful, Horrible Life of Leni Riefenstahl," one of six documentaries in the festival. There are familiar names from past festivals, like Ken Loach, the Taviani brothers, Ms. Campion and Chantal Ackerman, and newcomers like Pierre Yameogo of Burkina Faso.
 
A Guitry Retrospective

 
 As in past years, the festival will present a retrospective program; this fall the subject will be the French director Sacha Guitry. Seven films by Guitry, who was an important influence on Orson Welles, Alain Resnais and Francois Truffaut, will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater from Oct. 1 through 7. Guitry's best-known film, "The Story of a Cheat," will be shown at Alice Tully Hall as part of the main festival program.
Richard Pena, the chairman of the festival's selection committee and the program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, said the festival did not organize its program around any particular theme. "It's a way of seeing world cinema that comes with a vision of where things are now and where they are going," he said.
Nevertheless, Mr. Pena did point to trends and currents that are reflected in the 1993 festival program. "You'll see several films that could be called, for lack of a better term, personal epics," he said. "These are film that take an ambitious look at a broad swath of history but filter it through one person's experience."
Examples include "Farewell, My Concubine," which covers the most recent half-century of Chinese history through the story of two men who meet as apprentices at the Peking Opera, and "The Puppetmaster," set in Taiwan under the Japanese occupation during World War II. "The Night," a Syrian film, looks at the struggle of Arabs in southern Syria to establish a sense of identity in the 1930's and 40's, when the country was under French rule.
Tran Anh Hang, a Vietnamese living in France, lovingly recreates the day-to-day life of a household in Saigon during the late 1950's and early 60's in "The Scent of the Green Papaya."
 
Trend Toward Emotion

 
 Mr. Pena also said that many of the films in this year's festival reflect a more emotive approach to film making than has been shown in past years. "A number of films really require the kind of personal involvement we tend to associate with the older, classic films, but without the romanticism and sentimentality," he said. " 'Shades of Doubt,' for example, deals with a case of incest and the emotional breakdown of an entire family." The film is the work of the French director Aline Issermann.
The festival will include four British films. Two are bleak portrayals of working-class life in contemporary Britain: Ken Loach's "Raining Stones," about an unemployed Manchester man who becomes involved with loan sharks, and Mike Leigh's "Naked," about the tenants of a London house. In "The Snapper," a comedy, Stephen Frears picks up the story of the same fictional lower-middle-class Dublin family that was portrayed in Alan Parker's "The Commitments." In "Blue," the director Derek Jarman, who has AIDS, bares his soul in a monologue while standing against a blue screen.
One of the more unusual films in the festival is "It's All True: Based on an Unfinished Film by Orson Welles." The documentary reconstructs a turning point in Welles's creative life, his ill-fated attempt to film a multi-part epic in Brazil in 1942.
At the center of the documentary is 50 minutes of film that scholars thought had been lost by RKO, the studio that sent Welles to Brazil and then pulled the plug on the project. The film that Welles sent back, all of it unedited rushes, was rediscovered in the mid-80's and edited by Richard Wilson, Welles's assistant in Brazil, relying on shooting scripts and other documents, as well as his own recollection of conversations with Welles.
The reconstructed episode from the uncompleted epic tells the story of fisherman from northwest Brazil who traveled by raft to Rio de Janeiro to present a list of grievances to the president. The incident was taken from the newspapers, and Welles used the actual fishermen as actors.
"In formal terms, the film looks very much like what the Italian neo realists would do about six years later," said Mr. Pena. "Here you have Welles, in one of his most fertile creative periods, right after 'The Magnificent Ambersons,' embarking in an entirely new direction."
 
A Return to Poland

 
 On rare occasions, unsolicited films make the final cut. This year, the festival's jury chose "Birthplace," a Polish documentary about a Polish-born American Jew who returns to his hometown to find out what became of the relatives he left behind when he fled the Nazis.
The oddball in this year's lineup is "Tim Burton's Nightmare Before Christmas," a stop-action animated film directed by Henry Selick and produced by Mr. Burton, the director of the Batman movies and "Edward Scissorhands."
The festival will also include "Ruby in Paradise," the first film by Victor Nunez since "A Flash of Green' in 1985, and "The War Room," a documentary by D. A. Pennebaker that follows the activity at Democratic campaign headquarters during last year's Presidential campaign.
In addition to Mr. Pena, the judges for this year's festival were Wendy Keys, the film society's executive producer for programming; David Ansen, the film critic for Newsweek; Stuart Klawans, the film critic for The Nation, and Joan Juliet Buck, the film critic for Vogue, who is a new member of the committee.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Seeing the Bright Side of Castro's Cuba

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
In the dear, dire days when there were two sides to the cold war, journalists of a certain bent ranged the world and brought back rhapsodies to countries like Stalin's Soviet Union, Mao's China and Sadinista Nicaragua. When one such People's Paradise fell into disfavor, there was always another to celebrate. Among the minor side effects of what tonight's offering in the "P.O.V." documentary series delicately calls "the collapse of the socialist camp" has been the drying up of that once rich vein of inspiration to television documentary producers. But take heart: Cuba remains.
"Miami; Havana" begins with snatches of interviews on attitudes of Cuban-Americans in Miami toward their motherland and of Cubans in Cuba toward the United States. Hard political lines and softer personal feelings are expressed on both sides. The program's point of view is represented by Wayne Smith, a former State Department official in Havana and a longtime critic of American policy. He wants an end to the economic embargo of Cuba and a resumption of normal relations. 
 But that issue, eminently worth discussing on television, is forgotten as the program, part of the "P.O.V." series, gives way to severe Castrophilia both in pictures and in words. The United States is blamed for Cuba's current economic difficulties, but the narrator reports in what used to be Tasstalk that "great efforts are being made in agriculture" and there are "great advances in science." She does not fail to mention the free health care and the free education; less attention is paid to free elections or a free press. If you think you have heard this sort of thing before, you have, about every people's democracy that ever existed.
There are a few muted criticisms of Havana, but the dominant theme is pounded in by young Cubans shown saying "Si!" to Fidel Castro; elderly Cubans shown dancing ("We're quite happy here"), and a man who declares that his return home after living miserably in the United States for a while made him feel like "the happiest man on earth." This repatriate is interviewed on a lovely beach ("The beach belongs to the people"), in the company of children enjoying ice-cream cones. The hour ends with visit-Havana tunes accompanying pictures of some Cubans who have been evicted from the United States returning joyously to Cuba and, it says here, to freedom.
 
P.O.V.
Miami; Havana
Channel 31, tonight at 9
Produced by Estela Bravo, Sandy Balfour and Julio Alom; Ellen Schneider, executive producer for "P.O.V."; Ward Chamberlain, executive director for "P.O.V."; Ms. Bravo, narrator.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Mets Need Man With a Green Thumb

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON

 BODY:
THE last time I saw Dallas Green before yesterday was four summers ago, down on the farm. George Steinbrenner had sent him there, with pay, to finish out the 1989 season.
One of Steinbrenner's concocted reasons was a kid named Roberto Kelly, who was nursing his separated shoulder in the Cincinnati Reds' clubhouse yesterday when the subject was raised. 
 "Oh yeah," said Kelly, the Americanized Panamanian who now goes by Bobby. "Dallas put me in center field, told me I'd be hitting ninth, not to worry about driving in runs. Told me, 'Just put the ball in play.' "
By August, Kelly, a minor league .260 hitter, was batting .340. Steinbrenner's "people" were wondering why Green refused to bat the speedy Kelly second or third. "The whole point was that he was learning how to hit in the major leagues," Green said yesterday.
For his banishment from the Yankees, Green actually had a choice of farms, neither in Columbus, Ohio. One was outside Philadelphia, another in a place called Conowingo, Md., a sprawling acreage with an old country house and a slew of cows grazing contentedly like so many veteran Mets shagging late August pre-game flies.
Proudly showing off the Conowingo grounds atop his tractor one afternoon, Green said that the only challenge he could imagine for his old-fashioned self in this economics-driven sport would be the game's equivalent of a field in need of a plowing, a planting and the caretaking of someone with the proverbial green thumb.
"With expansion coming, that's what I'd be interested in," he said. He meant as a general manager, with the kind of control he once exerted over the Chicago Cubs. But expansion came, and Green's phone didn't ring. When the Mets called last spring and asked him back to the dugout wars, he was 59 years old, his Conowingo fields were whipped into shape and, what the heck, it wasn't as if he was returning to the South Bronx.
He had no idea that Shea Stadium was so dysfunctional a neighborhood. Four months into a three-year contract, Green has a team less competitive than expansion level and works a field that must not only be plowed but fumigated as well.
"There's not a damned thing I could do with some of the people that were here, the Colemans, the Murrays," Green said yesterday before the mooing Mets lazed their way to a 4-1 defeat.
The imminent departure of Vince Coleman will merely be a first step toward changing the perception of the Mets as a team collapsing to one that is rebuilding. When that process is further along, the Mets will be fortunate to have the look of the Colorado Rockies and the Florida Marlins, teams with training wheels, Green's field of dreams team. Unfortunately for him, his job won't be to build it.
With Joe McIlvaine returning, Green doesn't even know if he'll be back to manage the Mets. Among the questions he can't answer is whether McIlvaine wants to work with a strong-minded veteran he didn't hire.
More important than Green's status is how McIlvaine will position the Mets. Does he finally admit to New York that 1986 may as well be 1936, that this team must start from scratch? Or does he cling to the flawed policy of the last two years, the position that the Mets are a winter of manipulation from sneaking off with a divisional title.
"It's not impossible to go last to first in today's baseball, and no team proves that better than the Phillies," said Green.
Green and, better yet, McIlvaine, should know that the Mets can't be next year's Phillies. Bad as they were last season, the Phillies had cornerstone players in their lineup, like John Kruk and Lenny Dykstra. They had pitchers with huge upside potential. The Mets have little of either.
After his team's 83d defeat yesterday, Green reiterated that all he is concerned about now is "trying to keep the young kids going to where we can look forward to 1994." Barring some wild and crazy free-agent spree, next year's Mets should rightfully belong to Jeromy Burnitz and Jeff Kent and Ryan Thompson, among others, and they will need a teacher who is honest and unafraid enough to do the planting right.
"If they're smart, they'll let Dallas at least get them going in the right direction," said Kelly, who took his .319 batting average to the disabled list a month ago.
He said he had been depressed because he was on his way to his best season in the majors. "Best for average since '89," he said. "Even though that year, I didn't finish so good."
That year, Kelly was moved from ninth in the order to third the day after Green was replaced by Bucky Dent. He finished at .302.

HEADLINE: Economy Of Stops And Starts

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
In this stop-and-go economy, as soon as one engine starts to rev up, another seems to sputter.
That was borne out in new data released today: Sales of existing homes spurted 5.4 percent in July to the highest level since December, the National Association of Realtors said, but the Commerce Department reported that factory orders for big-ticket items like cars and planes fell an unexpectedly hard 3.98 percent last month. The drop was the sharpest in 19 months and indicated that manufacturing, stuck in a rut for months, was not near a rebound. 
 Factory orders are volatile, and July's drop followed a sharp rise in June. But Charles Waite, associate director for Economic Programs at the Bureau of the Census, said, "The bottom line is that nothing much has been happening to orders since the surge at the end of last year."
 
Orders Up for Capital Equipment
 One bright spot in the orders data was a second consecutive monthly rise in business orders for capital equipment -- now more than 11 percent above the level of a year earlier.
Today's reports suggest that the lowest long-term interest rates in three decades are beginning to stimulate interest-sensitive parts of the economy like housing and investment. But they also suggest that the stimulus may not be enough to overcome the drag from weak export markets, slow job growth and consumers' dismal mood.
"Until you get job gains and a boost in confidence, you're just not going to get robust numbers," said David Lereah, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. "Low interest rates are the only game in town and they're certainly not enough."
The orders report raised the possibility that forecasts by the Clinton Administration, the Federal Reserve and most private economists, all predicting growth of around 3 percent in the second half of the year, may be too rosy.
"The Administration is being way too optimistic," said Brad Roller, president of Swyger Coil Systems Inc., a Cleveland supplier of parts for electric engines. "Business in general stinks, and when I tell people it's pretty good for our company, they always say they're not hearing much of that."
Still, economists are not changing their forecasts yet, saying they will wait for next week's jobs report before tinkering with the numbers, if then. As one Treasury official said: "It's summer doldrums. The data are kind of cloudy right now and we'll have to wait until after Labor Day just to know what the economy is doing now."
For one thing, while the orders report was clearly bad news, most economists said it did not signify that manufacturing was shrinking.
A sharp drop in aircraft orders accounted for more than half of the $5 billion decline in all orders. But because it takes so long to get planes into production, today's low orders are a better indication of production a year or two from now than of production later this year.
A large decline in car orders may not mean much for future production, auto analysts said. Car "orders" really mean showroom sales, which did weaken in July and early August but edged up recently. Inventories are relatively lean and the Big Three are all planning to increase production now and in the fall, even if by less than they said a couple of months ago.
Excluding transportion equipment, orders edged up 1.3 percent. If car production rebounds as expected, economists said, factory output should continue to grow very slowly.
Economists took special comfort in the fact that orders for capital goods other than aircraft edged up in July for the second consecutive month, to an $83 billion annual rate. Such data hint that businesses are continuing to invest, even if at a slower pace than the double-digit rate of the spring.
 
Existing-Home Sales Strong
 Things look better in the housing market, especially in the West and even in the Midwest, where the long-lasting flood was expected to weaken home sales. Sales of existing homes -- which dominate the housing market -- rose to a 3.88 million annual rate in July. Though a bit shy of last December's 4.0 million rate, that's one of the strongest monthly rates since 1979. The Northeast was the only region of the country where sales weakened.
The spurt in home sales, the fourth in a row, is likely to help the economy a bit because new homeowners tend to buy appliances, furniture, drapes and even second cars.
But existing-home sales do not imply gains in home building as they used to, when older and more affluent couples vacated older houses for newly built ones.
"The trade-up guys have taken out big home equity loans and watched housing prices soften, said John Tuccillo, chief economist at the National Association of Realtors, "so existing- home sales have been consistently stronger than new-home sales."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 28, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about the economy's performance in July, as well as a separate article about the credit markets, misstated the decline in factory orders for big-ticket items like cars and planes. Orders for such durable goods fell 3.8 percent last month, not 3.98 percent.

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR INDUSTRY SEEKS INTERIM SITE TO RECEIVE WASTE

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
After decades of pushing for a permanent repository for radioactive wastes from power plants, the nuclear industry is reluctantly concluding that a central temporary storage site will be needed before a permanent one can be ready, and that a pile of money is waiting for anyone who provides the land for it.
The industry, with 110 plants producing electricity across the nation, is paying hundreds of millions of dollars a year into a fund managed by the Department of Energy that can be used for an interim site. 
 Some operating plants are running out of storage space and running into opposition when they try to store more spent fuel. In addition, as plants are retired, utilities are faced with costs of up to $21 million a year for each plant to maintain storage pools for waste at the reactors.
And although the Department of Energy plans to open an underground repository at Yucca Mountain, Nev., in 2010, the utilities have little faith that it will open then.
 
$3.8 Billion Fund for Storage
 Financial experts who study the industry estimate that an Indian tribe or county willing to rent a patch of dry land about half the size of Central Park in Manhattan for temporary storage could collect $50 million a year, and expect a lease of at least 20 years.
In recent years, 29 tribes, counties and other jurisdictions have applied for small grants from the Department of Energy to study whether they would like to enter negotiations to provide a site. But in the last month two tribes, the Mescalero Apaches in New Mexico and the Skull Valley Band of Goshute Indians in Utah, applied for grants of $2.8 million each and said they would like to begin negotiations.
The fund, now with a balance of $3.8 billion, brings in hundreds of millions more each year. The money is primarily intended to pay for a permanent repository for nuclear waste but would be available to pay for interim storage. In addition, the utility companies that own the nuclear plants have strong economic and political reasons to engineer a solution, even a temporary one.
From the Yankee Rowe plant in Rowe, Mass., to the Rancho Seco plant near Sacramento, Calif., shuttered nuclear power plants must spend tens of millions of dollars a year to maintain pumps and emergency systems and to pay control room and security staffs -- costs that would be avoided if the spent fuel were stored somewhere else.
The cost can run as high as $21 million a year for each plant, and dozens of plants are expected to close in the next decade or two.
 
Easing Political Pain
 A central storage site would also spare the industry considerable political pain. In Minnesota, the Northern States Power Company, having wrung conditional permission from the public service commission to build its own cluster of storage casks at its twin Prairie Island reactors, must seek special legislation from the state legislature in February.
In Michigan, the Consumers Power Company fought a bruising battle with environmentalists to be allowed to build casks at its Palisades plant, but the utility still faces a Federal lawsuit trying to stop the making of more casks.
And later in this decade Consumers Power may have to repeat the process at its Big Rock Point plant, which is the oldest operating reactor in the United States.
No one sounds enthusiastic about taking nuclear waste for a few decades, especially since it is not now clear where the waste would go at the end of the period. But the money that is likely to be available is turning heads.
"I've come to the conclusion that the Federal Government and the industry are ready to pour a huge bucket of money over any community that will take the monitored retrievable storage," said Miller N. Hudson, the negotiator for the Mescalero tribe.
The amount of money would be set at a reverse auction envisioned in the Nuclear Waste Policy Act. Under this plan, the Government would attach a higher and higher price tag to the waste, until somebody agrees to take it.
 
Faustian Bargain

Some environmentalists deride the process as a Faustian bargain, but the transaction is ostensibly a rental, not a permanent sale. Among the details to be worked out is what would happen if Washington is no closer to establishing a permanent dump 50 years from now than it is today. In the meantime, though, a lot of money is at stake.
Mr. Hudson, a former telephone utility executive and former state legislator, said $50 million a year would be reasonable. Executives in the nuclear industry described that figure as steeper than what they had in mind but not out of the question.
"I would think $25 million to $50 million shouldn't be a problem, if they'd accept fuel from all the utilities," said Mark D. Luftig, an analyst at Kemper Securities Inc. who specializes in utilities.
At the Edison Electric Institute, the trade association of investor-owned utilities, Julie Jordan, the program manager for an interim waste repository, said such a site could result in "a few hundred million savings to the whole system" over 40 years.
The casks store waste in a dry environment cooled by air, sharply limiting the possibility of corrosion or mechanical failure. Most waste is now stored in pools, which require equipment to circulate water. Such casks already operate in South Carolina and Virginia, and the industry has taken representatives of several Indian tribes to tour plants there.
Because the casks are considered leak proof, the land on which they are temporarily stored would not be contaminated and could be used for any purpose after the waste is shipped to a permanent site.
The pileup of waste is attributed to these unforeseen circumstances:
*Uranium has turned out to be far more plentiful that anyone imagined, while utilities have canceled about half the nuclear reactors they once ordered, destroying the financial incentives for reprocessing spent fuel.
*President Jimmy Carter banned reprocessing to limit the spread of plutonium, a byproduct of nuclear power generation and a bomb fuel.
*Delays in finding a permanent place for the fuel.
As a result uranium pellets in pencil-thin metal tubes, bound together in bundles, are stacking up in storage pools. As long as a nuclear plant is operating, much of the upkeep is simply routine work that must be done anyway. That changes once a plant is shut.
 
Costs of Storing Waste
 For example, the Yankee Rowe plant, in Rowe, Mass., retired in 1992 after 32 years, the longest that any plant has run so far. But the plumbing for the spent fuel pool must be kept running. That means maintaining filters, pumps, cooling systems and water tanks in good repair, keeping the building secure, lit and ventilated, staffing the control room, and paying for a dozen other tasks that were taken care of when the plant was working but are all extras now. The owners plan to decommission the plant, but they cannot do so until they get rid of the fuel; on the current Energy Department schedule, that would be in 2018.
Yankee Rowe will cost $247 million to decommission, William McGee, a spokesman, said, and nearly $60 million of that is to build casks to store the wastes until 2018. Much of that could be avoided if the waste could be shipped away.
Not all utilities are eager to get rid of their fuel. The Sacramento Municipal Utility District, which closed its Rancho Seco plant, near Sacramento, in June 1989, eventually plans to put its fuel into casks and leave it there. One reason, said David Freeman, the general manager, is the problem of shipping.
"There is a lot of public anxiety that has a touch of reality to it about shuttling the casks across the country," he said. "I think it's time to reassess this issue, to see if it isn't best to leave it where it's created, at the power plant site."
Mr. Freeman, whose utility is building windmills and solar plants, said: "We're doing well without nuclear fusses. I don't want to waste my time fooling around with this issue."
 
More Plants to Retire
 Rancho Seco's fuel is still in its pool. The costs for keeping a plant active just to run the pool can be $7 million to $21 million a year, according to the Edison Electric Institute. The number of retired plants is expected to grow steeply in the next few years, as repairing older reactors becomes too expensive.
And some utilities want to ship the fuel away so that they can tear down the plants and dispose of the land. In addition, some environmentalists think the fuel would be more secure in one central location that was designed for permanent storage rather than in scattered places across the country, the pattern that is now developing.
The nuclear industry and the Department of Energy have focused on Indian reservations because many have available land and might reach a consensus more easily than, say, a county government. Public officials in New Mexico strongly oppose that use of the Mescalero Apaches' reservation there, although the Energy Department asserts that under Federal law the decision rests with the tribe.
But Government and industry officials close to the search for a site expect that some of the money, whatever the total, would be given to neighboring local governments or spent in ways that would benefit the economy of the area, thereby softening the opposition.
They also anticipate that much of the money would go into a trust fund. There are 3,200 Mescaleros on the reservation, which means that if the money were paid directly to individuals, it would come to more than $15,000 each. One executive in the nuclear industry suggested, however, that if the tribe came into that much money, "You would find a lot of Mescaleros with roots they hadn't acknowledged before."


GRAPHIC: The nuclear power industry, facing dwindling storage space for spent nuclear fuel and escalating costs for new storage solutions, is working with the Department of Energy to find a temporary storage site that would be shared by scores power plants.
 
THE ORIGINAL PLAN HAD PROLEMS . . .
Chart: "What to Do With the Wastes?"
 Civilian power reactors operate or have operated at 73 sites in the United States, most designed with their own temporary storage for spent fuel. The plan was to cool the fuel rods in pools for five years or so, then truck, them to a reprocessing plant. But reprocessing proved to be uneconomic and was banned by President Carter to prevent the spread of nuclear bomb fuel, a byproduct of reprocessing.
 
. . . A PERMANENT SOLUTION IS YEARS AWAY . . .
 The Department of Energy would like to open a permanent storage site at Yucca mountain, Nevada, in 2010, but the utilities have little faith that it will open then, if at all. Even if it does, it will take many years to truck the spent fuel there.
 
. . . SO INTERIM STORAGE HAS BECOME MORE URGENT
 A tax on electricity generaged by nuclear plants is bringing hundreds of mmillions of dollars annually into a fund intended to finance storage solutions. Industry experts say that an Indian tribe or county that volunteers to take the wastes may be able to collect $50 million a year in rent for a least 20 years.
 Two tribes, the Mescalero Apache tribe of New Mexico and the Skull Valley band of Goshute Indians of Utah, are beginning the third stage of a four-phase project intended to lead to final negotiations with the Energy Department for an interim solution.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Novell Leads Stock Selloff In Software

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Novell Inc.'s announcement of an earnings decline pushed its stock sharply lower today, putting pressure on the shares of other networking software companies and depressing the Nasdaq market.
Novell's stock fell $2.125, to $19.125, in reaction to its release after the market's close on Wednesday of third-quarter results that fell below Wall Street's expectations. 
 More than 13.6 million Novell shares were traded, the most on the Nasdaq, which is heavily weighted with technology stocks. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.27 points, to 731.39.
Nine of the 10 most active Nasdaq issues were software or computer-related companies, and they all fell in price for various reasons. The group included the Oracle Systems Corporation, down $4.375, to $50.375; Sybase Inc., down $6, to $60; Cisco Systems Inc., down $2.625, to $50.375, and the Informix Corporation, down $1, to $20.
Sybase and Oracle fell after William H. Shattuck, an analyst with Montgomery Securities, had lowered his ratings on the stocks from "buy" to "hold." Mr. Shattuck said he felt the data base companies would come under pricing pressure from the Microsoft Corporation, the biggest software maker.
Novell's results for the third quarter included several special charges that caused a net loss. But even without the charges, earnings fell, marking the first time the Provo, Utah-based company's earnings had fallen on a year-to-year basis since the third quarter of 1989.
Adding to investors' concerns was Novell's announcement earlier this week that its chairman and chief executive, Ray J. Noorda, would now share executive duties in an office of the president with Mary Burnside, executive vice president of operations, and James R. Tolonen, senior vice president and chief financial officer. The issue of a successor to Mr. Noorda, who is 69, has been a concern at Novell, but analysts said the latest move did not resolve it.
For its third quarter, which ended July 31, Novell reported a loss of $255.4 million, compared with earnings of $66 million for the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose 12 percent, to $272.8 million from $243.3 million.
The results for the 1993 quarter included special charges totaling $320.5 million from the acquisitions of Unix System Laboratories, Software Transformation Inc., the Serius Corporation and Fluent Inc. Excluding the charges, net income for the third quarter was $62 million, or 20 cents a share, down 6 percent from the period a year earlier. Analysts had expected earnings of about 24 cents a share.
Novell said the third-quarter results included $11 million in revenue from the recently acquired companies, while expenses associated with these companies were $17 million.
On July 26, Novell said earnings would not meet analysts' expectations because of weak European sales. The next day, its shares fell to a 52-week low of $17.625. The shares had touched a 52-week high of $35.25 on March 12.
 
Lower Inventory Requirements
 Paul Johnson, an analyst with First Boston, said the weak European economy was only partly responsible for Novell's reduced earnings. He said the company had moved to lower the traditionally high inventories it required its distributors to carry, and that this had reduced sales growth. Recent consolidation in the distribution channel means that fewer, but more powerful, distributors will not take on large inventories, he said, adding that an anticipated shift to electronic distribution of software requires a rethinking of strategy.
"Novell is waking up and saying, 'We need to get our hands around this,' " he said.
Analysts also said that Novell management, in a conference call after the release of its results, had not been encouraging about near-term growth.
"They gave very little guidance on the call and have not been very available to analysts," said Doug Whitman, an analyst with Montgomery Securities.
"I believe this is the trough and we will see a gradual uptrend for the company," he said.
Analysts were divided over the significance of the creation of an office of the president. Some anticipated that Mr. Tolonen and Ms. Burnside would be named chief executive and chief operating officer, respectively, while others said a successor to Mr. Noorda could be one of Novell's division heads. These division leaders include Kanwal S. Rekhi, who assumes new responsibilities as executive vice president for corporate technology and continues as general manager of the Unix Systems Group. The post could also go to an outsider, analysts said.
"Ray decides," Mr. Johnson said. "He's the chairman; he's still the largest shareholder. It's his company."
Both Mr. Tolonen and Ms. Burnside "are very qualified," Mr. Johnson said.

HEADLINE: General Details Altered 'Star Wars' Test

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
A retired general who helped oversee a disputed 1984 "Star Wars" test says the target missile in the test was artificially heated to make it a bigger target for a heat-seeking sensor on an interceptor missile, and thus easier to hit, but he denies that the action meant the test was rigged.
The retired Army major general, Eugene Fox, then the deputy program manager for the test, also denies that Congress was misled about the experiment, in which the interceptor missile hit the target missile over the Pacific. The experiment was a crucial technological milestone for the fledgling missile-defense program, which had been under attack by scientists and skeptics since its inception in 1983. 
 At the time of the test, Pentagon officials said it was proof that a missile could hit another missile in mid-flight. The former Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, said on Wednesday in a written response to questions on the subject that the test was intended to be "as realistic as possible."
But General Fox said in an interview on Wednesday that the artificial heating made the target 10 times more visible to the interceptor than an actual Soviet warhead would have been, citing a report to Congress on the test published in 1988 by the Office of Technology Assessment, an analytical branch of Congress.
 
'People Can Argue'
 "Clearly, we heated it because we wanted to see it," he said. "People can argue about that, and that's fair. That didn't mean that we were trying to cheat. In the entire concept of this test, people could fault us. My point is what we did was a normal test event." He said he was unsure whether the artificial heating was disclosed to Congress in 1984.
General Fox conceded it was possible, but unlikely, that something more was done to rig the test behind his back. "Could something have happened around me?" he said. "Yes, that's obvious. But I don't think so. I think that test was done fairly."
General Fox said an explosive charge had also been placed on the target missile. "We put a charge on it so that if we just happened to nip it we could see it, and so that visual devices on the ground could see it, and so that visual devices on the ground could pick it up," he said. "It looked like a nuclear explosion."
John Pike, director of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists and a critic of the missile-defense program, said the general's description made it appear that "the test was rigged at least two different ways." He added, "The debate is now not whether the test was rigged, but how it was rigged."
 
Who Made Accusations
 The veterans of the missile-defense program who brought their test-rigging assertions to Congressional investigators this summer said the 1984 test was manipulated when the target missile was equipped with electronic devices that helped the interceptor locate and destroy it. General Fox said he knew of no such device.
These officials also said the manipulation of "Star Wars" tests was part of a deception campaign, intended to fool the Soviet Union, that overstepped its bounds and wound up misleading Congress about the progress of the missile-defense program.
The accusations, first reported in The New York Times last week, outraged senior members of the Reagan Administration, who saw the assertions as a partisan political attack by Democrats in Congress.
Mr. Weinberger called the accusations fairy tales. He said nothing was done to deceive the Congress or the Soviets about the program or the disputed test. Mr. Weinberger also said comments he made last week about the frequent use of deception programs by the Pentagon were not meant to confirm the existence of any deception campaign connected with the program or to suggest that the disputed test had been deceptive.
 
Weinberger's Statement
 "The test was not enhanced in any way," Mr. Weinberger said in his written response. "Various aspects of the test were designed to make it as realistic as possible given the fact that obviously an actual Soviet re-entry vehicle could not be used to test our interceptor."
The charges, brought to Senator David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat and a critic of "Star Wars" contracting practices, led Secretary of Defense Les Aspin to order an investigation last week. On Wednesday, William J. Perry, the Deputy Defense Secretary, asked John M. Deutch, the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and Technology, to write a report in time for Mr. Perry to "resolve the issue in the next two weeks," a Pentagon official said.
Senator Pryor asked the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, to examine the charges three weeks ago. Both teams of investigators lack a crucial piece of evidence: the missiles used in the experiment, which destroyed one another in what appeared to be a scientific triumph.
 
No Evidence to Examine
 "They are in pieces at the bottom of the ocean," General Fox said.
The goal of the $30 billion "Star Wars" program, which began in 1983, was to build systems that could shoot down an enemy's intercontinental ballistic missiles. After 10 years, it produced little in the way of a working system, although its defenders say it contributed significantly to the downfall of the Soviet Union by accelerating Soviet defense spending and thus damaging the Soviet economy.
In May, Mr. Aspin announced "the end of the 'Star Wars' era" and a scaling-back of the missile-defense program.
The accusation that the 1984 test's target and interceptor were "interactive," as one of the accusers put it, was a serious, though not unprecedented, challenge to the scientific integrity of the program. General Accounting Office investigations have confirmed past charges that military officials misled Congress about aspects of the missile defense program.
Last year, the General Accounting Office audited seven "Star Wars" tests between 1990 and 1992. The auditors found that three of the tests were accurately described to Congress. Those three tests were complete or partial failures. The missile-defense program's officials told Congress the other four tests were successes. That was untrue, the auditors said.
 
What an Inquiry Found
 The inaccurate claims included the success rates of experiments, the progress of the programs, the sophistication of the tests, the ability of interceptor missiles to distinguish between a target and a decoy and the missiles' achievement of accuracy and altitude goals, the G.A.O. reported.
"They have lied about certain functions that their missiles are supposed to perform," said a Federal investigator who agreed to speak only if he was not identified. "They've used things to enhance the target. The fact is that you've got something up there solving your guidance problem. And you've got an incentive to deceive. That's how you keep your program going."
A former Reagan Administration official, a nuclear physicist who closely studied the missile-defense program in the 1980's, said it was characterized by "secrecy, greed, self-deception, deception of the Congress and actually even of the President." The former official, who remains a Pentagon consultant and who spoke on condition of anonymity, is not among the accusers in the debate.
Other Reagan Administration officials and Pentagon documents confirm the existence of deception plans attached to the missile-defense program.
 
Top-Level Memorandum
 An April 1987 Joint Chiefs of Staff memorandum entitled "Special Plans Guidance -- Strategic Defense," says the Pentagon should improve and update deception plans covering the missile-defense program's cost and abilities. The memorandum was distributed to the joint chiefs, their top commanders and the director of the National Security Agency, the nation's largest intelligence organization.
Mr. Weinberger said that to the best of his knowledge and memory there was no such program. He would not comment on the memorandum.
The question of whether Congress also was misled has been raised before. In March 1986, the trade journal Aviation Week and Space Technology, reported that the Pentagon had long-standing disinformation programs covering the most expensive weapons programs, including "Star Wars." Quoting Defense Department officials, the journal said that the deception programs were intended to trick the Soviets but that disinformation might be transmitted to Congress.
It remains unclear whether anyone in Congress, including Mr. Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Service Committee from 1985 to 1992, was informed of the overall deception program, or whether anyone in Congress was deceived by progress reports on the missile-defense initiative. Also unanswered is a question put to Mr. Aspin by Senator Pryor: whether "this disinformation campaign may have laid a faulty foundation for what ultimately became a $30 billion program."

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Asks for End to Haitian Oil Embargo

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali asked the Security Council today to lift a trade embargo it placed on Haiti in mid-June in an attempt to force the Haitian military rulers to return the nation's exiled President to power.
The Secretary General's recommendation followed by a day the Haitian Parliament's approval of a new Prime Minister, Robert Malval, who had been the choice of the ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 The Security Council could end the sanctions Friday, after Mr. Malval is sworn in, or by early next week.
By cutting off oil to Haiti and freezing overseas assets of Haitians, the embargo has had a devastating effect on Haiti's already shattered economy. The United Nations embargo was superimposed on an earlier hemisphere-wide embargo called by the Organization of American States.
The Parliament's ratification of Mr. Malval, along with his program and his cabinet, came almost eight weeks after Father Aristide and Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the Haitian military leader who ousted Father Aristide in September 1991, agreed to the priest's return to power on Oct. 30.
After his approval by Parliament, Mr. Malval appealed to the Security Council to lift the embargo.
The United Nations sanctions include a ban on all sales of military equipment. Food and medicine were exempted.
Suspending the sanctions does not end them. Under terms of the so-called Governors Island Agreement, worked out in New York in June between Father Aristide and General Cedras, the sanctions will be formally abolished only when President Aristide, who was the country's first freely elected president, is formally restored to power.
Shoring up the Aristide administration will be a United Nations presence dedicated to modernizing the Haitian armed forces and creating a new police force independent of the Army.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali estimated that more than 1,000 United Nations technicians would be employed on the Caribbean island, training the military and monitoring the new civilian police. Washington has already volunteered to provide many of the technicians. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Premier Flies to Washington
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 26 (Special to The New York Times) -- Prime Minister Malval flew to Washington today for talks with Father Aristide and is expected to be sworn in at the Haitian Embassy in Washington on Friday, officials said today.
The oil embargo, which was placed on Haiti on June 23 after the military refused to agree to restore Father Aristide, hit what was already the Western Hemisphere's poorest country extremely hard, creating gasoline shortages that forced cars off the streets and caused businesses to close, essential services to deteriorate and communications to break down.
Although experts say it will take at lest five days before oil and gasoline supplies reach consumers once the embargo is lifted, there was a noticeable rise in activity today.
Haitians, many of whom supported the embargo as the only way of getting Father Aristide back, said they were pleased the embargo would be lifted but remained noncommittal about the political future.
Optimism is prevalent overseas. International donors have promised to provide Haiti with $1 billion in aid.
In addition to advisory work in areas like road-building and construction, the technicians to be supplied by the United Nations are to help streamline the justice system and retrain the notoriously harsh police force.
The separation of the police and the Army is one of the laws that must be passed before Father Aristide's return. With Parliament adjourning for three months in early September, however, legislators face a race against time to get that and several other bills through, and preparations for Father Aristide's return could be set back.
"It is not going to be easy," the president of the Chamber of Deputies, Antoine Joseph, said, adding that it may be necessary for Mr. Malval to call an extraordinary session.

HEADLINE: PROGRESS IS HINTED FOR MIDEAST TALKS

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 26

 BODY:
When the Middle East peace talks resume in Washington on Tuesday, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators are expected to discuss mixtures of new and old ideas that have senior officials on both sides speaking optimistically about a possible breakthrough.
Perhaps the most talked-about new plan would quickly give the Palestinians authority over the tumultuous Gaza Strip and the quiet West Bank city of Jericho, with Israeli forces pulling back from those areas. More sensitive questions of control over the rest of the West Bank and -- thornier yet -- the future of Jerusalem would be left for later. 
 The "Gaza and Jericho first" idea has been embraced by Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and has qualified support from Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel. But Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin is said to be highly skeptical, and in the end he holds the only opinion in the Israeli Government that counts.
Aides say Mr. Rabin feels that the Gaza-Jericho concept is too broad. One apparent reason is that Mr. Rabin is focused on limited Palestinian self-rule for the two areas, without full Israeli withdrawal, while Mr. Arafat has in mind a "mini-state," a Gaza-Jericho foothold for eventual full statehood throughout Israeli-occupied territories.
 
Hints of Secret Meetings
 Nonetheless, Israeli officials have dropped broad hints of secret meetings with the P.L.O. to produce the outlines of a possible deal. Without spelling out details, Mr. Peres said this week that an agreement was within reach. "I think we have worked out a package deal which is accepted more or less by the Palestinians and us," he said.
Hanan Ashrawi, spokeswoman for the Palestinian delegation, also speaks hopefully about "a new course of events," including the Gaza-Jericho idea, that could breathe fresh life into stutter-start negotiations that have gone nowhere for two years.
But she plays down prospects for an immediate breakthrough. Other Palestinians and Israeli officials caution that the idea of Gaza-Jericho is still only that: an idea, not a formal proposal on the table.
Moreover, while the plan looms large for the Palestinians, it is only one of several themes forming Mr. Peres's "package deal." Other elements are not new, and agreement on them has eluded negotiators in previous rounds.
Under the basic formula for the talks, the two sides are supposed to focus on creating interim Palestinian self-rule in Gaza and the West Bank over the next five years, while Israel retains ultimate control. The territories' final status -- matters like Israeli withdrawal under United Nations land-for-peace resolutions, and a possible Palestinian state -- are to be delayed.
 
Looking for Shortcuts
 But with the talks seriously stalled and with many Palestinians afraid that an interim stage could drag on for many years, negotiators have begun looking for shortcuts.
One idea that the Israelis are promoting hard, dubbed "early empowerment," would hand the Palestinians responsibility almost right away for a range of public services in the territories. But Palestinians view the plan coolly, worrying that it will leave them with routine functions while preserving Israel's military occupation.
Another suggestion, "Gaza first," would rapidly provide Palestinian self-rule in the impoverished coastal strip even while details are still being ironed out for the more complicated and emotionally charged West Bank. (As far as Israel is concerned, Jerusalem's status is not negotiable at all.)
Although offering few details, Israeli officials leave little doubt that their forces would be significantly pulled back from Gaza. The proposal has broad appeal among Israelis who want to get rid of the strip right away, seeing it as a violent anti-Israel maelstrom, strategically insignificant and economically burdensome.
Now, "Gaza first" proposals have turned into "Gaza and Jericho first."
For Mr. Arafat, mired in a P.L.O. leadership crisis but still president of the Palestinians' hoped-for state, Jericho would give him a West Bank stronghold and make clear that he will not settle only for Gaza. In return, he has said he is prepared for now to put aside claims to East Jerusalem and demands for an immediate Israeli pullout from the rest of the West Bank.
 
Arafat Would Move
 A senior adviser to Mr. Arafat, Nabil Shaath, said in Cairo today that the P.L.O. leader would move from his Tunis headquarters to Gaza or Jericho -- a prospect that would probably deepen Mr. Rabin's skepticism.
While officials here suggest that the Prime Minister has not slammed the door on the idea, they say he questions Palestinian seriousness and also fears that with Jericho, the Palestinians would have unacceptable control over bridge links to Jordan.
Many Palestinians in the territories also have qualms about the plan. It may give Mr. Arafat territory to preside over, they say, but they fear that Israeli withdrawal in the West Bank will stop at Jericho. And many of them, including Palestinian delegates to the talks, are not as ready as the P.L.O. to defer negotiations on Jerusalem.
Delegates warn that support for the talks has waned in the territories and that Mr. Arafat's leadership crisis does not help. Still, it seems certain that the P.L.O. and Arab states involved in the negotiations -- Syria, Jordan and Lebanon -- will show up in Washington.
