HEADLINE: Philadelphia Doctors to Be Offered Data on Patients Who Have Sued

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Philadelphia doctors will soon be offered a new service that may have been inevitable in a society in which both lawsuits and computers are commonplace: For $80 a month, they can find out whether a prospective patient has ever filed a malpractice suit against another doctor.
The service, Courtscan, is to begin direct-mail marketing to Philadelphia-area doctors next week, said William J. Benedict Jr., president of Courtscan Services in Greenwich, Conn. 
 Mr. Benedict said the service would be expanded to New York, Chicago, Houston, Los Angeles and Miami within six months. He also said that he planned to offer a similar service to employers, landlords, insurers and others who may be leery of litigation.
Courtscan will offer doctors "litigation histories of patients in 60 seconds or less," Mr. Benedict said. The company's advertisements counsel doctors to "screen new patients you think might be 'malpractice-prone,' so you can adopt necessary defensive cautionary measures."
Litigation records have always been public, but until the advent of computers it was extremely cumbersome to search court records for a person's legal complaints. But now, Mr. Benedict said, his company has a data base of all 802,000 lawsuit and judgments filed with Philadelphia's Court of Common Pleas since 1982.
While there is nothing illegal in compiling or selling such data, some doctors and consumer advocates worry that such a service might do more harm than good, smearing individuals who had filed claims in good faith and creating an increasingly hostile relationship between doctors and patients.
Indeed, the Pennsylvania Medical Society recently refused to run an advertisement for Courtscan in its monthly magazine. "We are concerned about anything that would possibly prejudice a physician against caring for a particular patient," said Dr. Donald Ferguson, the president of the society.
David Vladeck, the acting director of the Public Citizen Litigation Group, a Washington consumer advocacy group, said he was disturbed that singling out those who sue might discourage people from exercising their right to use the courts. Moreover, he said, he is worried that people who had filed several lawsuits might be denied medical care, housing or insurance.
"You can assume that once people purchase the information, they're going to use it as a screening device," Mr. Vladeck said. "I'm horrified by the notion that doctors might start screening patients on the basis of their litigation history."
Many doctors said the whole idea of trying to identify patients who had previously filed a malpractice suit was wrongheaded.
"This fosters an adversarial relationship," said Dr. Lonnie Bristow, a California internist who is chairman of the American Medical Association. "If you view every patient as a potential litigant, you're doomed before you start. I think most doctors realize that the only real protection against litigation is a good doctor-patient relationship."
The idea of helping doctors identify patients who have previously filed a suit is not new. In the mid-1980's, the Docket Search Network, a Chicago-based group, offered a similar service in Chicago, Detroit and Los Angeles, charging doctors a yearly fee of $150, plus $10 a search.
That effort, Physicians Alert, so irritated the trial lawyers in Los Angeles that they retaliated with a service allowing patients to call and find out their doctors' litigation record. Neither service lasted long.
 
'Wasn't Very Useful'
 "Doctors really weren't interested in whether their patients had sued other doctors," said a spokesman for the county medical association. "And the information you could get wasn't very useful: it told you every lawsuit they had filed, including personal injury cases and business disputes, and every thing else that had nothing to do with medical malpractice."
Mr. Benedict, who has spent the last six years working on information-service businesses, said he was not discouraged by the Physicians Alert experience.
"The economics were completely different," he said. "They operated on a mainframe, and it was largely a manual search. The cost of computer equipment and information storage has gone way down since then."
Furthermore, he said, he believed the demise of the earlier business was caused by management problems rather than lack of demand.
But Dr. Steven Sondheimer, an obstetrician-gynecologist at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, said he would be surprised if many of his colleagues bought the service.
"The right approach is to concentrate on providing good patient care, and that's what most doctors do," Dr. Sondheimer said. "I really find it upsetting that people would think litigation is such a big issue in doctors' minds."
 
Potential Clients
 Mr. Benedict said he was convinced that there was a large market for the service, although he said he had not yet signed up any clients.
"Our focus groups and our market research show a lot of interest," he said. "We all know that some people are more litigious than others, and if someone has sued six people already, the odds are much greater that he'll sue a seventh.
"We think landlords will be interested in knowing if prospective tenants were litigious, and employers will be interested in finding out about prospective employees, or employees they were thinking of terminating."
For now, though, doctors are the company's prime targets.
Mr. Benedict said he did not expect that doctors would necessarily treat patients with extensive litigation histories differently from others.
"Not in a million years is a doctor going to make a decision on how to treat a patient solely on this," Mr. Benedict said. "It's just one more piece of information. We're not making judgments for people. We're just providing information that is public."

HEADLINE: Honda's Star Gets Another Sequel

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Since January, when the Ford Taurus eclipsed the Honda Accord as the nation's best-selling car model, the auto industry has been waiting for Honda's counterpunch, the new Accord.
The first public demonstration of that model takes place Wednesday at a Honda assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio. Even rivals concede that the Accord has been the benchmark against which family sedans are measured, raising this question: Can the Accord do it again? 
 Honda says its goal is not to surpass the Taurus in sales but to bring out an improved vehicle that will win acclaim from buyers. The current Accord was initially criticized for unimaginative styling and was ignored by some buyers because it offered only a four-cylinder engine, while the Taurus, Toyota Camry and others offered six cylinders.
 
 
Engine Leader Tries Again
 Though the Accord will have an optional six-cylinder engine within a year, Honda is attempting to persuade buyers that its four-cylinder power plant is exemplary. It will underscore that assertion this year by offering, in some new four-cylinder Accords, a sophisticated fuel and exhaust-control technology called VTEC, which yields greater power while improving fuel economy. Those types of improvements have earned Honda a reputation as a leader in engine technology.
More significantly, though, the new Accord's reception by American car buyers may ultimately answer a larger question: whether expanding automobile production in the United States and buying more parts from American suppliers, as Honda has done, can resolve disparities in pricing and value caused by a strong Japanese currency.
The rise of the yen, to about 104 to the dollar, from 245 yen in 1985, has forced Japanese car makers to raise prices faster than their American rivals have had to. The Toyota Motor Corporation said this week that it may suffer its first operating loss ever in the current fiscal year if the yen stays strong.
Honda's profits are under pressure, too. But to a greater degree than other Japanese auto makers, Honda has built factories in the United States and sought to buy more parts from American suppliers, thereby holding down costs. The company saves money by buying parts with dollars rather than the more expensive yen.
 
 
Holding the Line on Prices
 The new Accord will have more American components than the first three Accord models produced in Marysville. Perhaps because the new model is less costly to build in terms of yen, Honda has been hinting that it will try to hold down price rises, after three increases in the last year. That could help narrow its price gap with American models. Compared with 1989, when a $15,905 Accord LX cost $910 less than a similarly equipped Chevrolet Lumina, the $18,780 Accord LX now costs $1,413 more than a similar Lumina.
"Honda wouldn't be specific, but their people implied that the price of the new Accord would be close to the current model," said Jerry Paul, automotive analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York, who attended a preview of the car two weeks ago with about a dozen Wall Street analysts.
Mr. Paul and several analysts who drove the Accord said they were quite impressed. They described a car that is a bit wider than the current model and is roomier and quieter. The interior has been redesigned and improved, they said, with refinements like those offered in Honda's Acura line of luxury cars.
"I was pleasantly surprised," said John Casesa, automotive analyst for Wertheim, Schroder & Company in New York. "The styling is very distinctive among Japanese entries, very muscular."
Analysts were also impressed by Honda's assertions that many of the Accord's parts were carried over from previous models or borrowed from other Hondas, thereby saving engineering costs. "Some people in Detroit may be surprised that Honda has managed, through intelligent design, to blunt much of the yen's appreciation," Mr. Paul said.
Joseph S. Phillippi, the auto industry analyst for Lehman Brothers, said, "It may be that because of carry-over parts and the fact that factories already have been built at low cost of capital, expected price increases on some models may not happen."
If Japanese car makers manage to hold down pricing, they will almost certainly face more hostility from Detroit; Big Three executives have been complaining that Japanese vehicle prices should be raised higher in conjunction with the yen's appreciation. In February, the Ford Motor Company spearheaded a campaign to file complaints charging that Japanese auto makers were selling cars at illegally low prices; the effort was called off at the last moment when the General Motors Corporation declined to join. The Government bars foreign manufacturers from selling products in this country for less than the manufacturing cost.
 
 
Technically Advanced Engine
 The Accord's price will attempt to recover the cost of, among other features, perhaps the most technically complex and sophisticated multivalve engine ever offered in a standard family sedan. Honda was among the first car makers to promote multivalve engines, which have three or more valves for each cylinder, rather than the conventional two. The innovation can increase power or fuel economy, depending on adjustments. The two intake valves control the intake of air that is mixed with fuel; the two exhaust valves control the release of exhaust fumes.
 Honda then introduced the first VTEC, which stands for variable valve timing and lift electronic control, in 1988 in the Acura NSX sports car and has offered subsequent VTEC engines in certain Prelude and Civic models.
By varying the timing and extent that valves open and close on engine cylinders, depending on how fast the engine is running, Honda's VTEC engines can achieve above-average power, torque and fuel economy from a relatively small four-cylinder engine.
So far, Honda will say only that the Accord's VTEC engine will improve fuel economy by about 10 percent, compared with last year's engine, and increase horsepower and torque by an unspecified amount.
"This engine works very nicely," said Csaba Csere, the editor of Car and Driver magazine and a former Ford engineer. "It isn't a quantum leap, but it's another little step, one more cut."

HEADLINE: China Calls American Sanctions Unjustifiable

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 26

 BODY:
China today branded as "entirely unjustifiable" the Clinton Administration's decision to impose economic sanctions over the sale of ballistic missile technology to Pakistan.
A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Wu Jianmin, asserted that "China has never acted in violation of the principles or parameters of the Missile Technology Control Regime" and added that the Chinese Government "will formally announce its response" to the American decision "very soon." 
 The decision announced in Washington on Wednesday to ban the sale of $1 billion in high-technology equipment for space and military programs at first did not draw any higher level response other than the statement from the Foreign Ministry spokesman.
Still, the sanctions decision together with the continuing American military surveillance of a Chinese freighter in the Persian Gulf believed to be carrying a cargo of chemical weapon ingredients destined for Iran, have increased tensions between Washington and Beijing at a time when China's leaders are preoccupied with internal matters, including an overheated economy and jitters over the health of Deng Xiaoping, the major leader, who is 89.
Evening news broadcasts in China reported on the American sanctions, but the Government's reaction was conveyed in remarks by the Chinese Embassy in Washington, restating China's longstanding contention that its sales to Pakistan do not violate international agreements intended to control the spread of ballistic missile technology.
Mr. Wu's remarks were somewhat understated compared with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen's reaction to similiar accusations last month, which he termed "entirely without foundation" and "simply fabricated."
The Chinese statement today acknowledged that the United States was acting on intelligence reports, but asserted Washington had "reached erroneous conclusions based on its own faulty intelligence."
Pakistan's Ambassador in Washington, Ali Sarwar Naqvi, told The Associated Press that Pakistan had acquired missiles and was trying to convince the Clinton Administration that these acquisitions did not warrant the imposition of sanctions because they did not violate the missile agreement.
From the standpoint of China and Pakistan, the dispute is over the interpretation of the agreement, which bans the sale of missiles and associated technology with a range of more than 186 miles, and payload capacities of 500 kilograms, or 1,100 pounds.
The Chinese M-11 missile, whose technology China has been selling to Pakistan, according to a series of reports from American intelligence agencies, has a range of slightly less than 186 miles, but American officials argue that the missile and its technology should be covered for a number of reasons, including the fact that Pakistan can use M-11 technology to produce longer range missiles with payloads capable of delivering a nuclear, chemical or biological weapon.
American officials have not asserted that Pakistan is developing a capacity to put a nuclear warhead on a missile, which would be a categorically different development in the arms competition between Pakistan and India.
This week's action by Washington represents a diplomatic indictment of Beijing that will test the effectiveness of the missile control policy.

HEADLINE: Stocks Wind Up Mixed on Profit Taking

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed in moderately heavy trading yesterday, as profit taking in blue chips weakened the Dow Jones industrial average and a big decline in technology issues hurt Nasdaq trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 3.91 points, to 3,648.18. It was only the second time in the last eight trading sessions that the index failed to reach a new closing high. 
 The Nasdaq composite index, heavily influenced by technology stocks, dropped 2.27 points, to 731.39. Nine of the 10 most actively traded Nasdaq issues were technology stocks.
 
 
New Highs
 The only indexes that continued to set new closing highs -- barely -- were the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, up 0.91 point, to 461.04, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index, up 0.48 point, to 255.83.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, at 254.07 million shares, down from 301.6 million on Wednesday. Gaining issues outnumbered decliners by 1,029 to 914.
Although interest rates fell again yesterday -- something that had helped stock prices in recent days -- the effect was not evident.
"It is perhaps a mistake to assume the bond market can continue to push the stock market higher," Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for the Kemper Securities Inc., said. "There is a limit to how high the bond market can go. And it is possible that the bond market is testing its limits right now."
A drop in Novell, down 2 1/8, to 19 1/8, undermined the Nasdaq and touched off declines in other companies in the networking software business. Novell is considered the bellwether for this group because of its size.
 
 
Earnings Estimates
 Analysts slashed the company's earnings estimates after the release of a disappointing third-quarter profit report. Analysts said the computer software company was trying to make a transition from selling file and print servers to individual departments of corporations, to selling new network software to entire corporations.
Traders said the heavy selling in major data base companies was prompted in part by William H. Shattuck, a Montgomery Securities analyst who lowered his ratings on two of them. Sybase, which plunged by 6, to 60, and Oracle Systems, down 4 3/8, to 50 3/8, were both lowered to hold from buy.
Another factor that may have damped investor interest in the high-tech sector was the Clinton Administration's intention to ban United States exports of $1 billion in high-technology goods to China as a protest over arms sales to Pakistan.
In other market activity, Autoimmune declined 3/4, to 6. The biopharmaceutical company was told by Schering-Plough that it would not exercise an option to develop the company's arthritis products worldwide. In addition, the companies ended their collaboration on rheumatoid arthritis treatments.
 
 
Philip Morris Is Down
 Philip Morris fell 7/8, to 48. It was the volume leader on the Big Board at 6.3 million shares. The stock of the consumer products company continued to weaken amid disappointment that it did not raise its dividend.
British Petroleum rose 1 5/8, to 58 3/4, and was the second most heavily traded issue on volume of 4.5 million shares. The stock has benefited from dividend-related trading, and favorable oil market fundamentals. Also, British stocks have generally been attracting United States investors.
Texas Instruments fell 1 7/8, to 80 3/8, after announcing that it would redeem 3.7 million of its $2.26 depository shares not previously called.

HEADLINE: Boris G. Moishezon, Columbia Professor Of Math, Dies at 55

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Boris G. Moishezon, a mathematics professor at Columbia University who defected from the Soviet Union in 1972 and came to the United States five years later, died Wednesday. He was 55 and lived in Leonia, N.J.
Dr. Moishezon had a heart attack while jogging and was pronounced dead in Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J., said his wife, Natalia. 
 Dr. Moishezon was among the foremost experts in algebraic geometry. He began his career 30 years ago in Moscow, tutored by the Soviet mathematician Igor Shafarevich at the Steklov Institute of Mathematics. But he made his international reputation at Tel Aviv University and at Columbia.
Born in Odessa, Ukraine, he received a doctorate in physical and mathematical sciences from Moscow State University and became a senior scientist at the Central Institute of Mathematical Economics in Moscow.
 
Emigre Driven by Frustration
 Dr. Moishezon belonged to a growing contingent of young intellectuals who felt their Jewishness barred them from the top echelons, especially in mathematics and physics. He and nine peers signed a public statement in 1972 decrying the high fees for exit visas imposed on holders of doctoral degrees. The fees, as much as $25,000, were intended by the Soviet Government as repayment for the emigres' education.
By then the 10 were in the midst of the complicated process of seeking passage to Israel during the Soviet drain brain of the 1970's. Dr. Moishezon got his exit visa in 1972 and took the post of professor of mathematics at Tel Aviv University. He came to the United States as a visiting professor at the University of Utah in 1977, the year he was appointed a professor of mathematics at Columbia.
Besides his wife, Dr. Moishezon leaves a daughter, Hanna, of Tel Aviv; a son, Tsvi, of Leonia; and a half-brother, Friedrich, of Yalta, Ukraine.

HEADLINE: Key Jobs Report Is Positive

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Fresh signs of an improving employment market emerged today as the Labor Department released weekly jobless figures that showed substantial improvement in a key employment measure.
Although the department said that the number of Americans filing for state unemployment benefits for the first time rose 8,000, to 332,000, in the last week, the running four-week average, a less volatile gauge, dropped to nearly a four-year low. This average fell 4.5 percent, to 331,500 claims, for the four weeks that ended Saturday. That was down from 347,250 as recorded the preceding week, pointing to a strengthening job market, experts said. 
 "We're running at levels consistent with recovery," said James Glassman, money market economist at Chemical Securities.
The overall unemployment claims for the week compared with a revised count of 324,000 for the previous week and exceeded expectations by private economists, who had forecast a total of 329,000 claims.
In another positive sign, the number of people staying on jobless rolls for state benefits declined for the third week. The Labor Department said 2.78 million people filed for continued benefits in the week that ended on Aug. 14, the latest period for which that data is available, down 33,000 from the previous week.
Despite improvement in the jobless picture, however, economists said the monthly employment report for August -- due out next week -- would show relatively subdued payroll growth. "It's not going to be gangbusters," said Anthony Chan, senior economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities.

HEADLINE: Up From the Computer Underground

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26

 BODY:
The bustling Interop computer-network trade show, running here through Friday, was once the sole province of hackers in jeans interested in fashioning ways to make the gear of different manufacturers work together.
But in recent years, marketing vice presidents in suits have become a reliable staple, demonstrating how the Internet -- a global collection of computer networks on which the show is based -- has transcended the techie underground to become one of the world's largest computer exhibitions. 
 Like the personal computer industry, which left its hobbyist roots for venture capital and corporate board rooms a decade ago, the nerdy world of computer networks has finally arrived on Main Street.
The first Interop Workshop, attended by 300 people in 1986, was run almost entirely by volunteers, many with ponytails, who rolled out the cables and programmed the specialized computers that are the backbone for modern data networks.
 
Doubling in Size
 But the exhibition has doubled in size each year since that first gathering. This year, it attracted 65,000 people, few of them with long hair. The show, now a remarkably successful commercial venture, is a forest of green and yellow cables dangling from the high ceilings, linking more than 6,000 computers on the floor.
"Interop is the plumbing exhibition for the information age," said Tom Hargadon, an industry analyst at the Inside Report on New Media in Redwood City, Calif.
Next year the exhibition will have grown too large for San Francisco and will move to Las Vegas, Nev., the site of the nation's largest trade shows.
Interop has exploded, driven by the once-radical notion of its founder, Daniel C. Lynch, that all the industry's data networking gear should communicate. By breaking down the walls between proprietary vendors and forcing them to adhere to a single industry standard known as TCP/IP -- the common language spoken by all computers connected to the Internet -- Mr. Lynch, 52, has helped pave the way for the commercial Internet. An arcane specialty when he started, Internet is now sweeping through new markets ranging from the telephone to cable television.
The service providers and hardware manufacturers that have created Internet make up a $2 billion business, Mr. Lynch said. The Internet itself, which has approximately 15 million users and 1,776,000 computers in 137 countries, has become a powerful political and economic force.
Mr. Lynch sold Interop for an undisclosed sum two years ago to Ziff-Davis Communications the nation's largest publisher of computer magazines, which will merge it with a rival show, Network World, next year. But Mr. Lynch still manages the show as founder and chairman.
When Mr. Lynch founded the show, he was an unemployed computer network engineer. In the 1970's, he managed the computer network connections for SRI International Inc., a Government-oriented research center in Menlo Park, Calif. SRI was one of the original sites for the pioneering ARPAnet, the forerunner of today's global Internet.
On his first day at SRI, Mr. Lynch said, he caught a glimpse of the potential of computer networks, a vision of a national data highway that has since captured the attention of millions of Americans, including President Clinton.
"It gave me a chill," Mr. Lynch said. "I saw computer networks as something that could make society dramatically different."
But in the 1970's and 1980's, networking was expensive and a specialty accessible to only a few computer hackers dedicated to managing the networks.
When Mr. Lynch found himself without a job in the mid-1980's, he struck on the idea of an exhibition as a way to assemble all the data networking companies in one location so that he could look for a job as a marketing vice president.
By the final day of the first conference, he was visibly worried because no one had offered him a job. Then, at one session, he said, someone stood up and said, "We know what you're trying to do, but what you should do is run this conference for the whole industry." Everyone in the room cheered. Mr. Lynch agreed, starting the annual conference with a Mastercard, a Visa and a loan of $50,000.
 "He's a wild man," said Geoff Goodfellow, chairman of the Radio Mail Corporation, a San Mateo, Calif., company that offers a wireless electronic mail service. "He's like a maypole around which all the companies weave their spider web networks."
At this year's Interop, the big news involved some of the nation's largest high-tech companies. The Sprint Corporation, for example, announced that it would begin offering a new high-speed data protocol designed to provide support for future multimedia applications.
In control rooms cluttered with dozens of computer terminals and work stations above the show's floor today, Mr. Lynch acknowledged that Interop had changed dramatically in seven years.
"It's true," he said, as he watched the volunteer engineers maintaining the network he created. "This is the only place at the show where you find people in T-shirts anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Daniel C. Lynch, the founder of Interop's computer-networking exhibition, speaking at this year's show in San Francisco. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Shift in the Psychology of Inflation

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Interest rates continued to plunge yesterday, sending a strong signal that the stubborn inflation expectations of millions of Americans are falling with them.
Expectations that higher prices are lurking around the corner -- a hard lesson of the double-digit inflation era -- have been difficult to shake, despite the fact that inflation has averaged 3.8 percent the last 10 years and could wind up below 3 percent for both 1992 and 1993. 
 But with the yield on the 30-year bond at 6.09 percent yesterday, down from 6.17 percent on Wednesday and off more than a half of a percentage point in just four weeks, attitudes seem to be changing.
 
A Driving Force
 "The most obvious and plausible explanation is that the bond market is telling us that inflation expectations have come down and are still coming down," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence.
Inflation is a driving force in the fixed-income market because price increases erode the returns for investors. So even a sniff of higher prices can send prices falling and yields rising. Prices and yields move in the opposite direction.
The change in inflation expectations is a theme that Mr. Yardeni has been pressing, even earlier this year when the monthly jumps in the Consumer Price Index seemed to indicate that prices might rise more than 3 percent this year.
But data for the last two to three months have painted a different picture, and the Consumer Price Index is now rising at an annual rate through July of just 2.8 percent, a notch below the 2.9 percent pace for all of 1993.
"The economic environment for the past couple of years is not just a transition period" to higher inflation, Mr. Yardeni said. "It is the way things will be for a while."
For the bond market, if Mr. Yardeni is right, there would still be room for interest rates to move lower. With a traditional calculation that real interest rates -- rates adjusted for inflation -- are 3 percent, a 6 percent yield on the 30-year bond is within sight. And given the unexpectedly sluggish growth of the economy right now, the rate of inflation could move toward 2.5 percent, as Mr. Yardeni is is now forecasting, and pull long-term rates toward 5.75 percent and below.
 
Looking at 1994
 Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Securities, was predicting that inflation would rise this year above last year's rate and that would keep Treasury yields well above where they are now. But he has adjusted his outlook.
"There is just nothing to stop it," Mr. Fine said. "Obviously, the bond is going to 6 percent."
On inflation, he said, the important calculation now for expectations is not what will happen this year but what will happen in 1994. "Given the pace of the economy and all the uncertainties around the Clinton Administration and the impact of its programs, like health care, the market is telling you that inflation won't be higher in '94 than '93," Mr. Fine said.
The other force at work in the Treasury market yesterday was portfolio managers and investors taking cash on hand and putting it to work. Some were seeking higher yields than they were getting on short-term investments. Others were hurriedly investing the money that they got back as other investments, like mortgage-backed securities, were paid off early because of home mortgage refinancing sparked by the fall in interest rates.
And there may have been a little extra pop yesterday because the big Treasury auctions of August ended with the five-year note sale on Wednesday and no major new auctions are in sight for another month.
"When you get all that cash coming into the market with relatively light supply, it kind of feeds on itself," said Gregory Erardi, the head of government securities trading at Salomon Brothers.
This buying, and the confidence about inflation, pushed up prices across the board. So short-term interest rates are now at or near their lows for the year. The five-year note, with a yield of 4.78 percent, is at the lowest level in about 25 years.
 
Moves by Brazil
 Another factor that appears to have contributed to higher bond prices yesterday was the rumor that Brazil was buying Treasury bonds for use in the complex debt-reduction deal it has reached with its commercial bankers.
There was also a sharp jump in the price of the 30-year bond futures contract, which often can lead the cash market higher. But much of the buying, which pushed the price up a point, may have been set off by a technical market twist that is forcing investors who sold the bond futures for hedging reasons to buy them back at much higher prices.
In trading in the secondary market, the 6.25 percent 30-year bond due in August 2023 was up a full point, to 1025/32 . The yield on 6.09 percent issue is the lowest since Treasury securities with 30 years to maturity were yielding an average of 5.82 percent in January 1973, according to Salomon Brothers. The Treasury has only regularly sold 30-year bonds since May 1977 and no yield on those bonds has even been this low.
The price of the 5.75 percent 10-year note jumped 18/32 as its yield fell to 5.41 percent, from 5.49 percent the day before and a half percentage point below the July 23 level. The yield is now at its lowest level since 1968.

HEADLINE: Buchanan Joins the Foes Of Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
The tangled politics of the North American Free Trade Agreement became enmeshed in Republican Party politics today, as a former conservative Presidential aspirant, Patrick J. Buchanan, denounced two fellow Republicans who support the agreement and who are seen as front-runners for the party's 1996 Presidential nomination.
Mr. Buchanan, a hard-line rightist, offered an unexpectedly strong challenge to President George Bush last year. Today, he announced that he would form a group to distribute essays and other criticism of the pact. 
 At a news conference this morning, Mr. Buchanan assailed the recently completed labor and environmental side agreements, condemning them as infringements on American sovereignty and unnecessary foreign aid for the Mexican Government.
While criticism of the free-trade agreement by labor and environmental groups has attracted more public attention, conservative criticism worries the Clinton Administration, too, because it is counting on overwhelming Republican support to win Congressional approval of the deal. Among the Democratic majorities in the Senate and especially in the House, there is substantial opposition to approval of the treaty.
 
Buchanan Sees Illicit Alliance
 Mr. Buchanan accused the two other Republicans, Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Bush Administration, and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, of betraying conservative ideals by siding with Mr. Clinton in supporting the trade agreement.
The accord, if approved by majorities in both houses of Congress, would gradually eliminate import tariffs and other barriers among Canada, Mexico and the United States. The side agreements would create three-nation secretariats in an effort to make sure that each country enforced its labor and environmental laws. Mr. Buchanan condemned these bodies as an unwarranted intrusion on American liberty.
The United States and Mexico also tentatively agreed this month to spend at least $6 billion to clean up their heavily polluted border region, a plan Mr. Buchanan denounced as an unnecessary burden on the taxpayer.
The money would be raised by issuing Government-guaranteed bonds. In addition, the World Bank is considering several billion dollars in loans to Mexico for environmental cleanup near the border, where hundreds of factories have been built and operate with little enforcement of environmental regulations.
"Why should the American people be responsible for cleaning up the pigpen that the Mexicans have made on their side of our common border?" Mr. Buchanan asked.
His influence on Capitol Hill is unclear. Representative Duncan Hunter, Republican of California, a conservative whose district includes the border area with Mexico, issued a statement at Mr. Buchanan's press briefing echoing the concerns about national sovereignty.
But several influential moderate Republicans, including Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, who had some of the same concerns, offered support for the pact after the side agreements were completed Aug. 13.
Mr. Buchanan's comments underlined the extraordinary political diversity of the accord's opponents. The consumer advocate Ralph Nader and Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., find themselves on the same side as Ross Perot and a group of libertarian commentators who accompanied Mr. Buchanan today.
Mr. Kemp, Mr. Dole and Mr. Buchanan have all been mentioned as possible candidates in 1996. But while Mr. Buchanan assailed Mr. Kemp in particular several times today, he insisted that he was addressing a national issue rather than maneuvering for personal political advantage.
"It's all going to be decided years before 1996 arrives," he said.
In a joint statement on Monday with other Republicans, Mr. Kemp said the trade agreement would create millions of jobs for American workers and increase American exports. Mr. Kemp is on vacation in California, and his aides said he could not be reached for comment today.
Mr. Buchanan, echoing some Perot concerns, warned, "I think the Republican Party is letting Ross Perot walk off not only with our constituency, but with a variety of our issues."

HEADLINE: 12 School Districts Selected for Work Programs

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Seeking to address concerns that public schools fail to prepare students for the workplace, the New York State Education Department announced today that it has chosen 12 school districts, including 4 in New York City, to develop pilot programs that make work a part of classroom study.
In announcing grants for the pilot program, state officials said they were motivated by growing evidence that high-paying careers were available only to college graduates while most high school students were qualified only for low-paying, low-skilled jobs. 
 "Years ago our education system was well suited for the low-skill, mass-production economy of the industrial age," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said in announcing the grants. "But in today's highly competitive, global marketplace, we not only have to change the way we do business, we have to change the way we teach our kids to meet the economic challenges facing this state and the nation."
 
Scaled-Down Version
 The pilot programs represent a scaled-down version of an ambitious plan rejected earlier this year by the State Board of Regents that would have required all high school students to work before graduating.
That proposal had been developed by a commission led by Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine and was strongly endorsed by Mr. Cuomo, the State Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, and business groups.
The Regents rejected the broad proposal largely because they thought many schools would be unable to find meaningful jobs for students. But they left the door open by approving pilot programs to study the idea.
The 12 pilot programs are to receive grants of between $25,000 and $100,000 to develop or expand programs that teach about careers, provide training in workplace skills and require many students to work as part of their classwork.
The four New York City schools that received grants are Intermediate School 218 in Community School District 6 in Washington Heights in Manhattan; Public School 115 and Intermediate School 68 in Canarsie, Brooklyn; the City-as-School High School in Manhattan, and eight schools in Community School District 9 in Highbridge in the Bronx.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips as Bundesbank Fails to Lower Interest Rate

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark and other currencies yesterday after the German central bank defied market expectations and kept its key interest rate unchanged.
The dollar dropped to 1.6675 marks in New York trading, from 1.6843 marks a day earlier. 
 Leaders of the Bundesbank decided yesterday to maintain its discount rate at 6.75 percent. "The Bundesbank came back from vacation and cracked the whip," said David De Rosa, a foreign-exchange director at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
 
Propped by Corporate Buying
 Higher interest rates lift a currency since investments in that currency earn more. Germany has maintained high interest rates to rein inflation.
Belal Khan, a senior dealer at Bank of Tokyo in New York, said the dollar would have fallen further except that American corporations active in Germany sold marks. "They are really doubting the strength of the German economy" and expect the currency to weaken in the future, he said.
The dollar retreated against other European currencies because of its weakness against the mark and concern about the American gross domestic product figures coming out next week, traders said.
The British pound was particularly strong, following a rumor that an index of business expectations due out Friday would be more positive than expected, traders said. In addition, there were rumors that a large foreign investor was selling gold for pounds, traders said. In New York, the pound traded at $1.5090, up from $1.4819 late Wednesday.
 
Dollar at 104.40 Yen in New York
 The dollar also slid against the Japanese yen, ending at 104.40 yen in New York, down from 105.05 yen on Wednesday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 105.15 yen, up 0.60 yen from late Wednesday.
Mr. Khan said that while the official Bank of Japan was supporting the dollar in Asian trading, no central bank was actively buying it during the later New York session. Investors therefore pushed it down, testing how far it could go before the Federal Reserve would intervene.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.4719 Swiss francs, down from 1.4815; 5.8345 French francs, down from 5.8475; 1,590.00 Italian lire, down from 1,599.50, and 1.3158 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3115.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Reaches 2-Month Low On News of Eased Demand

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Gold prices were pounded in a heavy selloff by speculators yesterday and fell to two-month lows amid reports that demand is slackening.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for delivery in October, the active near-term futures contract, dropped $4.70 an ounce, to $369. Gold for December, the most actively traded contract, also lost $4.70, settling at $370.80 after hitting a low of $367 around midday as speculative funds began to sell steadily. 
 Traders said the selloff followed a report by Gold Fields Mineral Services Ltd., an industry consultant, that in the first half demand by jewelers and other gold users had dropped 5 percent from a year earlier.
Adding pressure was the recent surge in stocks and bonds, which have become more attractive than precious metals as concerns about inflation have abated.
Since soaring to a high of about $414 an ounce on Aug. 2, gold prices have fallen more than 10 percent.
Trading has been very choppy recently as more traders become suspicious that the soaring gold demand for jewelry out of East Asia, which helped feed gold's surge earlier in the year, was running out of steam.
But while some analysts said the recession in Europe and other factors were weighing on demand for jewelry, others saw flat or slightly better demand.
"There's still a good base level of China-related buying," said Jeffrey Nichols, president of American Precious Metals Advisers, adding that there are signs that excess inventories in Hong Kong are being worked off.
 
Pork Contracts Advance
 On other commodities markets, pork bellies closed up their 2-cent limit after the Government announced late on Wednesday that it would buy $19 million worth of pork carcasses in the fall for donation to Russia.
Pork bellies closed up the daily limit in the February-through-May contracts, with February settling on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange at 50.775 cents a pound. October live hogs rose 1.05 cents, to 47.025 cents a pound.
Also on the Chicago Merc, lumber futures jumped the daily limit for the third straight day, as commercial users continued to replenish stocks, providing support to futures. Lumber for September delivery closed $10 higher for a thousand board feet, to $291.30. Today daily limits will be expanded to $15 for a thousand board feet.

HEADLINE: Community Reinvestment Is Right and It Pays

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Fresh Money for Poor Communities" (editorial, Aug. 13) promotes several harmful myths about community reinvestment lending.
First, low-income borrowers are not necessarily "credit-risky." Available data from private mortgage insurance companies suggest that low-income homeowners are far less likely to default on mortgages than high-income borrowers, in part because low-income borrowers view homeownership as shelter, rather than investment. And, after a decade of record losses on speculative investments in commercial real estate, we have yet to see a bank or savings and loan institution go belly up because of too much lending to poor people. 
 Second, notwithstanding a dangerous campaign for "regulatory relief" by the banking industry, the Community Reinvestment Act is not a source of massive paperwork burdens for banks. The act has only three minor technical requirements, and the policy of bank regulatory agencies is that lenders need not keep any special documentation for the act's purposes. A 1991 Office of Management and Budget survey found the act to be the least burdensome consumer protection law on the books.
Finally, the act is not the utter failure you portray. Nearly $35 billion has been lent in low- and moderate-income neighborhoods as a result of the act. Many lenders, working with the very community development organizations you praise, have developed precisely the expertise in community lending whose lack you bemoan. And the best Community Reinvestment Act performers have found that community reinvestment lending is not just good social policy, but good business as well.
Clearly, the act has not met its potential to revitalize neighborhoods. But the real problem is a scandalous record of enforcement by the four Federal banking agencies under 12 years of hostile administrations. Nearly 90 percent of lenders get "satisfactory" grades, and less than a dozen merger applications have ever been denied because of this law, despite abundant evidence of redlining.
As Senator William Proxmire, the author of the act, observed several years ago: "Regulators seem to think that we're all living in Lake Wobegone. Like the children of the fictional village, United States lenders are all above average. Almost all get high ratings year after year, and almost none is ever held back. . . . And I ask myself, how is it that so many neighborhoods are continuing to fail, while so many lending institutions are continuing to pass?" Perhaps the Administration's review of the act will reverse this outrageous record.
Your suggestion that banks be allowed to "buy out" of the act through contributions to community development banks is seriously wrongheaded and smacks of the creation of a "separate and unequal" banking system, one for minorities and the poor, and another for everyone else. Turning the tide of despair in low-income neighborhoods requires more than token charitable contributions from the banking industry. We need mainstream lenders to view community reinvestment as a business proposition and to put the ingenuity of the market to work there.
The Federal Government confers on lenders a host of advantages -- public charters, taxpayer-backed deposit insurance at a discounted price and access to the discount window at the Fed. After having spent hundreds of billions of dollars to bail out these lenders, we have learned that all this public largess is not without fiscal consequence. Surely, the least we can expect in return is a banking system that fairly serves the needs of all Americans.
 
MAUDE HURD
Natl. President, Assn. of Community
Organizations for Reform Now
Boston, Aug. 17, 1993

HEADLINE: Nor Will Trade Pact Aid Mexicans Much

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"The Trade Pact Is Our Best Deal" (Op-Ed, Aug. 17) by Carla A. Hills makes highly questionable assertions in support of the North American Free Trade Agreement. Ms. Hills says that we sold almost $41 billion in goods to Mexico last year and that per capita purchases from the United States amounted to $477 in 1992.
She must know that Mexican trade data, more detailed than our own, paint a totally different picture. Their data show United States exports to the Mexican consumer market constituted less than 20 percent of the total reported exports. 
 Of the $40.6 billion in reported United States exports to Mexico in 1992, according to Mexican data, $14.1 billion were shipped to the "maquiladora" programs of United States plants on Mexican soil, employing Mexican labor at Mexican wages. Details are lacking for the share that went to free trade zones, which perform the same assembly and processing functions as the "maquiladores." More complete Mexican 1990 data show these two account for more than 50 percent of reported United States exports to Mexico. None of the products they produce are allowed to enter Mexico's consumer market.
Mexico also reports that 35 percent of 1992 United States reported exports to Mexico were capital goods. The overwhelming share of these went to United States plants, which assemble United States-made parts. The finished product is re-exported to the United States. Thus, more than 80 percent of reported exports to Mexico represented United States companies trading with themselves.
Mexican trade data for 1992 show that less than $9 billion in United States exports entered the Mexican consumer market. Dividing that figure by 90 million Mexicans shows per capita Mexican imports of consumer goods of less than $90, not Ms. Hills's $477.
 
HERMAN STAROBIN
Research Director, Intl. Ladies'
Garment Workers' Union
New York, Aug. 17, 1993

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Dinkins: Attempting to Build Bridges

 BODY:

ON THE SCREEN. Images of Mayor Dinkins being sworn in, working at a desk, meeting in a conference room, talking to campaign volunteers dressed as police officers on a stoop. Then pictures of children being examined in a clinic, playing baseball, pulling a library book off the shelf. Near the end, Mr. Dinkins is seen leaning forward over a chair, his fists clenched intently, and walking down the street with black, white and Asian campaign volunteers. In final image, he cuddles a baby and flashes a broad smile as a facsimile of his signature appears on the screen with the words "One city. One future."
PRODUCER. Doak, Shrum, Harris, Carrier, Devine Of Washington. 
 THE SCRIPT. Narrator's voice: Along with the oath of office, they gave him a massive deficit, a hostile administration in Washington, and a city at the boiling point. He's balanced four budgets, cut waste, and in a recession, saved jobs by persuading companies like CBS and Prudential to stay in New York City. His community policing has put three thousand more police on the beat - more than at any time in two generations. The New York Times said: "As the plan took hold, crime reports began to fall in . . . nearly all categories."
Strapped by the Reagan-Bush budget cuts, he's launched innovative programs like Communicare -- health centers in 13 neighborhoods. Beacon schools, open at night, to keep kids off the streets and provide counseling and job training for their parents. "Fields of Dreams" -- vacant lots turned into 40 ballfields across the city. Public libraries will soon be open six days a week, for the first time in almost half a century. He's told us the hard truth when our city couldn't afford all we wanted. And in dangerous moments, walked the streets and worked his heart out to hold us together. Mayor David Dinkins. It takes more than tough talk to run a tough city.
ACCURACY. Mr. Dinkins has granted tax breaks and other considerations to keep several big companies in New York, although CBS acknowledged that it had never actually threatened to leave. The Mayor has kept the budget balanced as required by law but state fiscal monitors have repeatedly criticized him for not making deeper cuts to bring spending in line with available revenues. Crime has declined but any correlation between that and more police officers is speculative.
SCORECARD. This ad is full of glossy production values, elaborate graphics, and throbbing music of synthesized strings and bells. It begins with an elliptical swipe at the world, saying "They gave him a massive deficit," and other problems. But who are they? The Koch administration? New Yorkers? Republicans? Whites? People in general? Different listeners will undoubtedly hear that line in different ways. The Mayor's strongest supporters may well agree, and Mr. Dinkins inherited many problems. But since the point of the ad is to list Mr. Dinkins's accomplishments in the face of very tough budget times, this line risks painting him as a bit of a victim, before he even gives his own vigorous defense. By ending with images of Mr. Dinkins walking the streets with an interracial group, it seeks to take advantage of his reputation as a healer, which was a key to his victory last time. The tag lines are both implicit attacks on Rudolph W. Giuliani, suggesting that the Mayor's rival indulges in tough talk and could not lead a united city toward the future.

LENGTH: 691 words

HEADLINE: Good Will and Its Limits in Somalia

BYLINE: By Michael Maren; Michael Maren, a New York writer, just returned from a three-week trip to Somalia.

 BODY:
Four hundred U.S. Army Rangers arrived in Somalia yesterday, bolstering the 25,000 U.N. troops already there as part of a peacemaking effort that will cost more than $1.5 billion this year. At the same time, the U.N. and private development groups are scaling back handouts of free food, replacing them with food-for-work projects that will in turn be replaced with cash-for-work projects.
On the surface, this seems very positive: The food emergency is over. The harvest, largely sorghum but also other produce, looks good. Charity is being phased out. 
 Yet these well-meaning policies will only help to re-create the situation that led to the food shortage in Somalia in the first place. The food that Somali workers will be receiving from agencies like CARE and the Red Cross will be imported wheat, rice and other commodities. And when workers are paid, the funds will have been raised by selling donated food on the open market.
The U.N. euphemistically calls this process "monetization." Whatever it is called it will have the effect of undermining agriculture, hobbling commercial distribution networks and keeping the country dependent on imported food. CARE alone has sold $5 million worth of wheat flour on the Somali market.
A CARE spokesman in Mogadishu told me that wheat is not grown in the country and therefore does not compete directly with the crops grown by Somali farmers. But someone whose belly is full of wheat flour is not likely to spend money on local sorghum. The spokesman conceded that CARE would do better to use cash to pay Somali workers, but he said it's much easier to get donations of food than cash. Food is plentiful and in surplus around the world. Cash is tight. As he was explaining this, U.S. Blackhawk helicopters thundered overhead. The price of one flight: about $2,000.
In 1980, I began one of the earliest food-for-work projects in East Africa. After a year it was obvious the project didn't work. Because the food is free to the donors, its value is debased. Such projects tend to be make-work excuses for giving away food. This seems to be the case in Mogadishu today where food-for-work consists of giving people empty garbage bags and then trading a bag of food for a bag of trash. Much of Mogadishu has been reduced to rubble, but it's fairly clean -- Somalis don't waste much. The project is likely to turn into a scavenger hunt with people looting garbage trucks as they once looted food convoys.
Donors putting up their own cash would probably put more effort into designing projects. They might tend to see their projects as investments, and create enterprises that would produce real income and eventually become self-sustaining -- saving money in the long run. And once the workers themselves see that the projects produce income, they would have a stake in continuing them, even after the donors leave.
CARE now has 5,200 Somalis receiving food and involved in public works projects. None of the projects will lead to full-time employment or become self-sufficient, and none will survive if new fighting cuts off food supplies and forces aid workers out of the country again. Africa is littered with the ruins of such projects. Somalis are paid to do them but have no personal stake in them.
Unfortunately, relief groups are more adept at delivering charity than they are in building institutions. Groups looking for a model of successful development in Mogadishu might take a closer look at the port where they go to collect food from the ships. Eddie Johns, a former chief warrant officer in the U.S. Army and now employed by the U.N., is trying to run the port solely from fees paid by shippers. Mr. Johns employs 450 Somali workers, paying them in cash. His goals are modest: to hand over a self-sustaining enterprise to a Somali government -- someday.
Unfortunately, commercial development in the rest of the country is being crippled by the continued dumping of surplus commodities, adding economic destabilization to the political crisis. And while the U.N. is raising billions for its military operations, it is investing nothing in building Somalia's economy.

HEADLINE: Security for All of Europe, In Seven Tricky Steps

SERIES: STRATEGIC ALLIANCES: First of three articles

BYLINE: By Ronald D. Asmus, Richard L. Kugler and F. Stephen Larrabee; Ronald D. Asmus, Richard L. Kugler and F. Stephen Larrabee are senior analysts at the Rand Corporation. This article is excerpted from an essay in the September-October issue of Foreign Affairs.

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif.

 BODY:
Whether Europe unravels for a third time this century depends on whether the West summons the political will and strategic vision to address the causes of potential instability and conflict before it is too late. A new U.S.-European strategic bargain is needed, one that extends NATO's collective defense and security arrangements to those areas where the seeds for future conflict in Europe lie: the Atlantic alliance's eastern and southern borders.
The end of the cold war wiped away the strategic distinction between Europe's center and periphery. Whereas the potential locus of conflict in Europe in the cold war was along the old inner-German border, Europe's new strategic challenges exist almost exclusively along two arcs of crisis: the eastern arc, the zone of instability running between Germany and Russia from northern Europe down through Turkey, the Caucasus and middle Asia; and the southern arc, running through northern Africa and the Mediterranean into the Middle East and Southwest Asia. 
 While these circumstances are seemingly located safely on Europe's periphery, for a number of reasons conflicts along either arc are in fact central to European security.
First, conflicts in the arcs are increasingly generated by antidemocratic and anti-Western ideologies that threaten the liberal-democratic foundations of Western Europe and the nascent democracies of the former Soviet bloc.
Second, conflict and insecurity in the twin arcs are unlikely to be neatly isolated or contained. Spillover, in the form of political and economic instability and refugees, is a real danger.
Third, while local conflicts may escalate into regional wars, instability in such geopolitically sensitive areas also threatens to draw in one or several major powers who see their own interests threatened.
Finally, and perhaps most important, instability along the arcs threatens to reactivate old fault lines and dormant historical rivalries -- geopolitical competition between Germany and Russia along the eastern arc, or a conflict between the West and Islam in the south.
Western policy makers have been slow to recognize these new dangers and the security needs of these states. Many still cling to cold war distinctions between Western Europe, which is implicitly defined as a vital interest, and Eastern Europe, which is seen as a secondary or peripheral concern. East-Central Europe's lack of a stable security arrangement has already helped to undercut progress toward democracy and economic reform. Now the spread of instability or violent conflict threatens to destroy even that progress achieved thus far.
East-Central Europe's democrats well understand that democracy will succeed only if their states belong to a secure European and Western political, economic and military community. The West, too, previously understood this link -- as demonstrated with the case of West Germany. That nation might never have become a stable Western democracy had it not been accepted into NATO's fold. Similarly, NATO membership helped stabilize democracy and stem authoritarian backsliding in Portugal, Spain, Greece and Turkey.
The obvious tool for this new Western strategy is NATO. The Persian Gulf war and the Yugoslav crisis have shown the European Community incapable of taking on such a task. The remark of Foreign Minister Mark Eysken of Belgium during the gulf crisis -- that the European Community was an economic giant, political dwarf and military worm -- sadly remains true.
The kind of NATO that could respond to Europe's new strategic challenges would bear little resemblance to the NATO of the cold war. It would be based on a new bargain between the United States and Europe, a different set of political and military understandings, as well as a new relationship with the East. This bargain would simultaneously expand the alliance's strategic horizon geographically and find new ways to share responsibilities and burdens. NATO's rationale and mission would be defined anew.
Politically, six steps are necessary to forge a new trans-Atlantic bargain. The first and in many ways most important step is to transform NATO from an alliance based on collective defense against a specific threat into an alliance committed to projecting democracy, stability and crisis management in a broader strategic sense.
The second step must be a new understanding between the U.S. and its European allies that harmonizes the interests of both sides. Europeanization of the alliance is as much in the interests of the U.S. as it is of Europeans. Washington must be willing to accept a stronger European identity, including in security affairs, and relinquish its residual ambivalence toward European integration.
For its part, Europe -- which in this case means France -- must abandon its exaggerated fear of American hegemony. The real issue regarding the future United States role in Europe is not whether Washington will be hegemonic, but whether the trans-Atlantic relationship can be turned into a partnership that fully engages the U.S.
Without French backing to transform NATO, the alliance will crumble. France would then find itself forced to go it alone in a Europe characterized by increasing instability along both its eastern and southern flanks, with an independent Germany and an aloof America.
Franco-American rapprochement can set the stage for the third step -- Germany's strategic emancipation. Germany must finally resolve the confused debate over its role in Europe and beyond. To be sure, residual fears concerning German power still exist. But only a strong Germany can facilitate European integration and NATO's strategic transformation.
While Germany remains preoccupied with the staggering challenge of the political and economic reconstruction of its eastern half, the need to stabilize its eastern flank is Bonn's number one security concern.
Reorganizing the West will set the stage for the fourth step in this process -- a coherent and coordinated Western strategy for the integration of Visegrad countries (Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and possibly Slovakia) into both the European Community and NATO. Opening the E.C. to the East is the best guarantee against a rival of anti-Western nationalism and of stabilizing the process of political and economic reform.
NATO should create the preconditions for the eventual integration of these countries into the alliance by expanding defense cooperation. Such cooperation need not initially imply a full-fledged defense commitment. Conceivably, "association agreements" could spell out the criteria for membership, but not provide explicit security guarantees. This arrangement would give the countries of Central and Eastern Europe the clear perspective they are looking for. It would also provide them time to adapt their military and defense establishments to meet NATO standards.
The fifth step in the new trans-Atlantic bargain concerns Russia. The West has been reluctant to move toward the East more quickly for fear of offending Russia's strategic sensibilities. But it is hard to understand how supporting democracy and stability in Eastern Europe can undercut democracy in Russia.
As it transforms and expands relations with Central and Eastern Europe, the West should also expand and deepen its security dialogue with Russia. Whether NATO's eastward extension becomes a new offer for partnership or a move toward an anti-Russian alliance rests almost entirely on the outcome of Russia's own internal transformation. This process is likely to take years. To hold the future of NATO hostage to the outcome of Russian politics is a recipe for the demise of the alliance.
The sixth step in the new trans-Atlantic bargain requires the West to develop a constructive Ukrainian policy. An independent Ukraine is one of the most important features of Europe's new strategic landscape; it acts as an important strategic buffer between Europe and Russia.
In light of the uncertainties surrounding Russian democracy, it represents the best guarantee against Russian imperial restoration from the point of view of Eastern Europe, especially Poland. The reincorporation of Ukraine into a Russian-led confederation would transform the geostrategic equation in Europe as a whole.
As a final, seventh step, extended collective defense and security means that the alliance must be reorganized militarily. NATO's basic problem is the mismatch between its old mission and Europe's new strategic challenges. It is no longer possible for NATO to concentrate on the strategic luxury of territorial defense. The dividing line between "in area" and "out of area" crises, so clearly drawn during the cold war, has become ambiguous and artificial.
Redefining alliance commitments in both areas, and finding the proper balance between the two, is the fundamental issue facing the alliance. Any new balance, however, must greatly improve NATO's capability to conduct military operations beyond its borders, and eventually allow it to expand its full security guarantees.
American leadership must secure the gains of the cold war and build a new U.S.-European partnership that can project democracy and stability. What is required is political will and strategic vision. By showing both, President Clinton can lay the foundation for a new partnership between the United States and Europe.

HEADLINE: U.S. FORCES TO STAY IN SOMALIA TO END WARLORD VIOLENCE

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
American troops will remain in Somalia until violence is quelled in Mogadishu, Somali faction leaders give up their heavy weapons and the country has a national police force capable of keeping the peace, Defense Secretary Les Aspin said today.
Mr. Aspin's remarks were the Clinton Administration's most extensive explanation of its strategy in Somalia, what it views as its successes and shortcomings, and its plans for future action. In effect, Mr. Aspin said there will be no quick or easy way out of a mission that began nine months ago as a relief operation but has turned into a more difficult and ambitious effort to rebuild a devastated country. 
 About 3,100 American troops now operate in Somalia under United Nations command as part of an international force of 24,000. Some 1,600 more are under American control in support of the international effort.
 
Bench Marks for Somalia
 Although Mr. Aspin laid out bench marks that must be achieved, he did not say when or exactly how the United Nations-led force in Somalia might accomplish the objectives.
The objectives themselves are already raising concerns among some in Congress who fear an open-ended American military commitment on the Horn of Africa. But by laying out the Administration's agenda, Mr. Aspin sought to quiet these fears and give critics in Congress and elsewhere specific standards for measuring American success.
While Mr. Aspin did not specifically say that a goal was capturing or killing Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, a fugitive faction leader who is blamed for the attacks on United Nations troops, Administration officials say quelling the violence in Mogadishu means removing General Aidid.
 
Goals Hinge on Restoring Order
 They said that advancing any broader political or economic goals in Somalia hinge on restoring order in the Somali capital.
"The danger now is that unless we return security to south Mogadishu, political chaos will follow the U.N. withdrawal," Mr. Aspin said in the speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a research and policy organization here.
Indeed, accompanying the 400 Army Rangers that President Clinton dispatched to Somalia this week are elements of Delta Force, an elite counterterrorist unit whose task is widely believed to be to seize General Aidid.
Mr. Aspin sought today to shift attention away from the continuing violence in Mogadishu to some of the operation's successes. The Defense Secretary said, for instance, that the original mission to insure the delivery of food and other aid had succeeded and that emergency food deliveries to Somalia are scheduled to end this month.
But the bulk of his 20-minute address focused on conditions that must be met to restore order in south Mogadishu and to rebuild the country's shattered economy and political structure.
In broad terms, Mr. Aspin listed six steps to reach those goals:
*The United Nations needs to add about 4,000 more troops to reach its authorized level of 28,000. India has pledged to send 4,000 troops, but they are not expected to arrive in Somalia until early October.
*The United Nations must help establish credible police forces in large cities and towns. Currently, about 4,000 Somalis are serving in auxiliary police forces in their hometowns, but these forces are clan-based and subject to rivalries. United Nations officials say they are working to help train, equip and pay a national police force.
*Faction leaders must relinquish their heavy weapons. State Department officials suspect that many of the leaders are still smuggling weapons from Ethiopia and Kenya. "Most of the clan leaders say they will turn in their weapons so long as the others do," a State Department official said. "Even if we could get 70 to 80 percent of the arms, we'd be doing well."
*The United Nations must develop an overarching plan to pull together its economic, political and security activities.
*The United Nations should borrow from the example set by peacekeeping units in Cambodia to form a core group of African nations, and other countries, to speed the economic and political recovery in Somalia.
*The United Nations and the Organization of African Unity should work together to put back on track the national reconciliation process that aims to rebuild Somalia's political framework.
"On economic and political reconstruction of the country some progress has been made but more work needs to be done," Mr. Aspin said. The secretary said some small shops, school and orphanages had reopened in central Somalia, but he said the overall economic condition in the country remain "dire."
A United Nations spokesman agreed with Mr. Aspin's assessment. "The U.N. and the Secretary of Defense see pretty much eye to eye on his six points," said Fred Eckhard, a United Nations spokesman in New York.
Mr. Aspin said the withdrawal of American troops hinges chiefly on the security aspects of these goals. "When the three conditions are met -- south Mogadishu, heavy weapons and police forces in the major population centers -- then I believe that the U.S. quick-reaction forces can come back."
 
G.I.'s May Come Home in Fall
 The Administration initially said the 1,200-soldier Army force might return this summer. Administration officials now say the optimistic goal is for the forces, which include the Rangers, to return later this fall. Mr. Aspin carefully avoided setting any date.
The Defense Secretary said the United States will begin withdrawing the 3,100 American logistics troops under United Nations command when the security situation in Mogadishu permits the large-scale hiring of civilian contractors to replace the soldiers.
The Administration's goal has been to reduce the number of logistics troops to 1,400 by Jan. 1, but officials refused to say again today whether they would be able to meet that target.
"We went there to save a people and we succeeded," Mr. Aspin said. "We are staying to help those same people rebuild their country."
