HEADLINE: Low Birth Rate Is Becoming a Headache for Italy

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Beyond its woes of bombs and corruption, strikes and recession, Italy is slowly coming to acknowledge a far more insidious challenge that will remold society by the turn of the century, creating a land where the old outnumber the young and the big, close families of myth and tradition are gone forever.
The reasons are simple: Italians live longer than most other Europeans, statistics show, and despite the pervasive presence of the Roman Catholic Church and its dogmatic stance against birth control, Italian women now have fewer children than women in any other nation. 
 And so, Italy has moved from a time when the land bred a mom-and-pasta stereotype of large families and frolicking bambini to the present, when figures released this month by the United Nations showed Italian women bearing a statistical 1.3 children each compared with 2.1 in the United States and a world average of 3.3. Overall, Italy's population of 56.7 million has virtually stopped growing.
Behind the figures is a web of demographic shifts -- from countryside to city, from poor south to rich north -- in a postwar period that brought industrialization and dislocation, yielding both wealth and a reappraisal of the family values Mussolini once advocated as part of his drive to build a fascist empire.
Some analysts even argue that Italians no longer dote on children the way they did when mama and papa packed an unruly brood in a 1950's Fiat 500 and headed for the beach.
"There's a cultural hostility toward children," said Giulia Paolo Di Nicola, a sociologist at the Gabriele d'Annunzio University in Pescara. "They aren't wanted in the condominiums, in public places where they can disturb, even in churches."
The statistics, moreover, foreshadow a time when there will be more retirees seeking benefits than younger people working to finance them. The Agnelli Foundation, a research organization run by Fiat, has projected that in the first third of the next century there will be two people drawing pensions for every person paying contributions.
 
Not Enough Pupils
 Two weeks ago, the Government announced that the Italian education system will drop 56,000 classes in schools around the country this year because of the decrease in pupils.
And a survey earlier this month by a private financial services company said Italy's work force of 20 million had already been overtaken by the number of pensions being paid out: 21 million pensions to 15 million retirees, some of whom legally draw more than one.
Italy is not the only European country confronting the repercussions of an aging of society.
But, according to Italian Government figures, the strains are already greater here than elsewhere on the Continent: for every retiree drawing a pension in Britain, for instance, there are 2.3 active workers. In France, the figure is 2.5. In Italy, by contrast, the ratio of contributors-to-beneficiaries has already slipped to around 1 to 1.3, and it is destined to slide further.
 
A Long-Term Problem
 "By the year 2000, Italy will have five million fewer children under the age of 15 than it did in 1970, and five million more people aged 65 and up," said Massimo Livi Bacci, a sociologist who bases his assessment on figures released by a private research institute. The trend, he said, was "manageable in the short term, but untenable in the long term without a profound and traumatic change in the rules" covering social services.
While overpopulation is one of the major problems facing the poor nations of the world -- women in the developing countries bear nearly twice the number of children as women in industrialized countries, 3.6 to 1.9 -- the opposite could become true for the richer nations.
But why the flight from large families?
Some have suggested that, like laboratory specimens, Italians have responded to their ever-more-crowded-suburbs and cramped apartment houses by curbing procreation. Fabrizio Menchini Fabris, a medical specialist at the University of Pisa, said the stresses of modern society have created widespread infertility.
Many more, though, see the reduction of family sizes as the result of an assertiveness among women who, having tasted independence by going out to work, do not want to lose it.
 
Money Over Machismo
 By this account, the men -- who once equated procreation with virility, but now prefer cash in their pocket to children in the crib -- have simply gone along with the women's decision.
What it all boils down to, said Franca Fossati, editor of a feminist magazine called Noi Donne -- We Women -- is that "the women have changed very quickly" after the expansion of schooling and urbanization while "the men haven't" in certain ways.
"So there's very little division of domestic work between men and women," she said. "Working as well as looking after the house makes it virtually impossible to have a family. Having few children is a form of female self-defense."
Angelica Alexander, a 33-year-old married schoolteacher who waited 10 years to have a child -- Ricardo -- six months ago, said much has changed since the days when she grew up.
 
Grandmothers Work Too
 "There's less family support," Mrs. Alexander said in an interview. "The houses are smaller." She noted that grandmothers, who once shared child-tending, work these days too and "there's no one else to look after the children."
As a child, she said, she had her own playroom. Now, although her husband is a highly-qualified computer specialist, they live in a small apartment in Rome that does not offer Ricardo a bedroom of his own.
While Italy's postwar prosperity had played a part in her calculations about having a child, she said, her Catholic upbringing had not.
In Italy, some 97 per cent of the population are baptized Catholics and thus exhorted by Pope John Paul II and other clerics to eschew artificial birth control, an exhortation that many priests privately recognize as futile. Not only is birth control easily available, but Italy has also had legalized abortion since 1978, and an attempt to repeal it in a national referendum in 1981 failed by 2-to-1 ratio.
"Not many of our friends worry about the church," Mrs. Alexander said. "They get married in church and have their children baptized in church, but it's out of tradition, not belief."
 
Travel and Leisure
 Thus, for the first years of her marriage, she and her husband preferred to spend their money on travel and leisure rather than on raising children.
Some Italian women bemoan such materialism among a whole generation that grew to adulthood in the boom years of the 1980's.
"Daughters these days don't want to get married and have children," said Arria Clerici, a high school teacher of Greek and Latin who raised three children. "They'd rather buy a car than make sacrifices."
Tina Anselmi, a veteran legislator and head of the Italian Parliament's commission on sexual equality, tends to agree. "I think there's a culture among many young couples, just to have one child," she said.
"This is a central phenomenon of the greater presence of women in the workplace which has not been accompanied by an adequate creation of services" to support working mothers.
The shift to small families has been going on for three decades. After World War II, Ms. Anselmi said, one out of every two Italians lived in rural societies.
 
Baby Boom Peaked
 In the postwar era, Italy's baby boom peaked, with figures for 1964 showing Italian women having twice as many children as they do today -- a statistical peak of 2.7 children.
Then came the growth of the northern industries that drew millions of Italians to the cities.
Today, only one in nine Italians lives on the land, predominantly in the south where, it seems no coincidence, family sizes are still higher than in the north.
At the same time, however, the cost of living went up, too, and as more women than ever before went to work, so, too, their earnings were needed to support the home budget.
Some contend that what has really changed is not so much Italian women as their myth.
"It's difficult to explain to a foreigner that the Italian woman, seen as a fertility goddess, probably never existed and certainly doesn't exist any more," said Ms. Paola Di Nicola. "The culture of procreation has changed and we are the least prolific nation in the world. So much for cliches."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

HEADLINE: Brewing Efficiency in Argentina

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZARATE, Argentina

 BODY:
At the heart of this new brewery, owned by Quilmes, the largest beer maker in Argentina, is a maze of mirrorlike stainless steel pipes and vats, run by only a handful of workers with little more than computer terminals.
From the blending of the malt, rice, corn and water into hot wort at the brew house, then adding the hops and yeast, to the 15 days of monitoring in the giant fermentation tanks, the clean floors, fresh paint and workers in white frocks create an image of efficiency and competitiveness. 
 After more than two years of economic recovery here, and attempts by Argentine companies to become more competitive, Quilmes Industrial S.A. is the company to emulate.
"Quilmes has the most enlightened management, the strongest balance sheet and is probably the most modern company here," said William F. Truscott, the portfolio manager for the Argentina Fund, a Scudder, Stevens & Clark mutual fund that invests in Argentine stocks.
 
A Narrower Focus
 Christopher Ecclestone, a securities analyst in Buenos Aires, added, "We make no bones about our view that Quilmes is the best company in Argentina."
Unlike many industrial companies here that have bought businesses that seemed only tangentially related to their core businesses, Quilmes has narrowed its focus to beer, soft drinks and, potentially, bottled water.
Analysts have welcomed the company's low profile and lean management, absence of debt and a willingness to take risks. Before the return to a civilian Government in Chile in 1990, for example, Quilmes entered the beer market in Santiago. And despite guerrilla violence in Peru, it has been looking to buy a brewery there for more than a year.
An investor who bought Quilmes stock two years ago at $20 a share, when it first traded on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange, could hardly disagree. It is now trading at around $290 a share, for a market capitalization of almost $1 billion.
That reflects an explosion in the company's earnings, which have risen 240 percent since 1989, to $44.1 million last year, from $13 million.
The success of Quilmes is not only the product of good management. It also reflects an economy in Argentina that has grown almost 9 percent annually and pushed up per capita beer consumption by 50 percent, to about 8 gallons a year.
Norberto O. Morita, the chief executive of Quilmes, said he saw almost unlimited potential growth in Argentina, where beer consumption is a third of that in the United States, and the rest of South America.
"We are experiencing beer shortages in the summer we cannot fill," Mr. Morita said in a recent interview. "When we inaugurated the Zarate plant, we already knew we needed more capacity and were planning a doubling of the plant."
After investing $72 million in the Zarate plant here that produces more than 1.8 million barrels of beer a year, the company last month broke ground on a $56 million sister plant alongside that will double the production capacity to 3.7 million barrels a year. That would bring the capacity of the company to more than 8 million barrels a year, or roughly 20 percent of the beer made last year by the Anheuser-Busch Companies.
Mr. Morita said the company had invested $300 million in Argentina and the region in the last five years, and would invest another $150 million this year.
"And it's all out of our earnings stream," he said. "We have not gone to the markets to borrow money."
Moreover, it represents an investment by a wealthy Argentine family company that had all its properties, including Quilmes, appropriated in the early 1950's.
In 1953, amid surges in nationalistic and anti-Semitic feelings, Gen. Juan D. Peron , the founder of the Peronist Party, seized the holdings of the Bembergs, which included Quilmes, 3.8 million acres of farmland and the family's houses, driving them from Argentina.
Though most of the assets, including Quilmes, were returned two years later after a coup unseated General Peron, the seizure remained a symbol of the capriciousness of Argentine politics and the beginning of decades of industrial decline, corruption and uncontrolled inflation.
The Bembergs control the Quilmes holding company, Quinsa.
The inauguration of the Zarate plant on April 6, almost 40 years later, was a day of symbolic vindication for the Bembergs. The Argentine President, Carlos Saul Menem, whose political patron saint was General Peron, was on hand to give his approval of the industrial progress.
 
New Competition
 While Quilmes has ridden the wave of economic expansion, the boom has attracted competition that some analysts said could cause trouble for the company.
Last year, Brahma, the largest brewer in Brazil, moved into the Argentine market. Miller Brewing imports its canned beer and sells it at discount prices. The Chilean brewing giant, Companias Cervecerias Unidas is discussing investment plans in Argentina, as are Anheuser-Busch and Coors, according to a recent report by Oppenheimer & Company.
Such competition and the recent run-up in Quilmes stock moved Mr. Ecclestone, the securities analyst, earlier this month to recommend against buying the stock.
"We are not losing our admiration for the long-term prospects of Quilmes, nor do we retract our view that the company has the best managment team" in Argentina, he wrote in his weekly newsletter. "However, we have strong suspicions that the stock has been pumped up beyond the potential in the short term to meet expectations."
 
A Four-Part Strategy
 But Mr. Morita, a Japanese Argentine who ran the French subsidiary of Corning Glass before joining Quilmes in 1985, said he was not that concerned, adding that he had a four-part strategy to keep Quilmes ahead.
One part is to take advantage of the declining wine consumption in Argentina and tout the fact that his company's beer has a quarter the alcohol content of wine.
"We think we can appeal to the younger, athletic group by offering a drink that has only a small amount of alcohol," he said.
A second part of the strategy is to continue regional expansion, particularly into Brazil, Peru and Bolivia.
 
Diversification Planned
 He also said he planned to diversify into more soft drinks, bottled water and a nonalcohol beer, and seek alliances with what he called "world class partners," such as Heineken, the Dutch brewing giant. Quilmes imports Heineken into Argentina.
Given the efficiency of the spanking new Quilmes brewery in this city about 60 miles north of Buenos Aires, the strategy seems plausible.
The brewing of beer here requires eight workers a shift. In the bottling operation, there are 34 a shift.
Quilmes has been so successful in appealing to foreign investors that the stock is tightly held by institutions like the Argentina Fund, and often no more than 2,000 shares trade a day.
"Our investment bankers are now saying we should register with the Securities and Exchange Commission and list on the New York Stock Exchange -- no A.D.R.'s," he said, referring to American depository receipts, the certificates that substitute for shares for many foreign companies. "We would be the first Argentine company to do that. They say it would give us added prestige. But we haven't made a decision on that yet."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Aerospace Industry Seeks Weaker Sanctions on China

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Aerospace industry officials said today that they would press the Clinton Administration to soften the blow of trade sanctions announced on Wednesday that bar the sale of American satellites to China.
The officials argue that the satellite sanctions -- part of a broader ban on high-technology exports that the State Department ordered to penalize China for shipping missile parts to Pakistan -- unfairly punished the satellite industry and would stop it from selling goods to China that would not be used for military purposes. 
 One industry official said he hoped the Commerce Department would push the State Department to show some flexibility in banning satellite sales, adding that some Commerce officials told him in private that they were not enthusiastic about the decision to impose sanctions. But department officials insisted today that they were "fully supportive" of the decision to impose sanctions.
"The basic problem is once they determine that China sold parts of a missile, they have no choice but to impose sanctions," said Joel Johnson, vice president for international affairs for the Aerospace Industries Association. "The industry doesn't like unilateral actions and doesn't like sanctions that provide the executive branch with no flexibility."
Several industry officials said they would urge the State Department to find "some wiggle room" to ease the ban. But State Department officials insisted that the satellite ban was specifically required by an overlapping series of export laws.
These officials said satellites were included on the list of sensitive technologies because they contain some sophisticated components that could be used for military production. But officials of the Hughes Aircraft Company, the world's largest producer of satellites, said Chinese engineers never gained access to these components because the satellites remained in Hughes's physical control until they were launched.
David Shea, a spokesman for Los Angeles-based Hughes, said the company feared China would start buying satellites from manufacturers in Britain and France unless those nations imposed similar sanctions. Hughes was negotiating to sell two satellites to China, and China has expressed interest in buying 10 more Hughes satellites by the end of the decade.
 
No Move Against Imports
 Aerospace industry officials criticized the State Department for deciding to punish American exports rather than imports from China. Chinese exports to the United States are not affected by the sanctions. But State Department officials said the law under which sanctions were imposed does not allow for restricting imports from China when missile parts were found to be shipped in violation of the Missile Technology Control Regime. The law, however, allows for imports to be restricted if the Government concludes that China shipped complete missiles to Pakistan.
On Wednesday, the State Department announced that it would impose trade sanctions that would ban $400 million to $500 million in high-technology trade with China over each of the next two years. State Department officials said exports of American satellites would be hit hardest because most military-related exports to China were already restricted after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989.
Satellite exports were also restricted after the Tiananmen crackdown. As a carrot to encourage China to abide by the missile control accord, Washington agreed to grant special waivers to allow satellite exports. In this way, satellites became the main category of sensitive exports still allowed to China. But now State Department officials say they will no longer grant such export waivers for satellites.
 
Confusion Over Restrictions
 Staff members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee said they had asked the State Department for a briefing because they were unsure what high-technology equipment was covered by the sanctions.
Industry officials were also confused. Commerce Department officials said that equipment destined for China that had already received an export license could be shipped. The Government, however, would most likely bar equipment that does not have an export license, even if an American company has a contract to sell it to China.
That means Hughes's contract to sell a satellite and ground station to a Hong Kong company controlled by the Chinese is expected to go through because Hughes already has an export license. CNN plans to lease transponders on the satellite so its broadcasts can reach more of Asia.

HEADLINE: Contract Furor May Stall Efforts To Do New York's Work Privately

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
New York has done less than other cities in turning municipal services over to private companies, and its efforts may be further slowed by the recent trouble involving the Parking Violations Bureau, say city officials and government analysts.
Compared with New York's vast municipal bureaucracy and budget, the work that has been transferred to private companies under Mayor Dinkins has been modest: managing 330 centers for the elderly, custodial services at 99 public schools, and boiler inspections at the city's commercial office buildings. A wide spectrum of New Yorkers say more should be done, from contracting out clerical work to hiring private businesses to run bridge tolls and handle water treatment. The issue unites some members of Mr. Dinkins's staff with business executives and critics of city government. 
 But officials in and out of the Dinkins administration say that the political maelstrom created by the problems at the Parking Violations Bureau may have created new barriers to private work. Mayor Dinkins has scrapped the city's contract with Lockheed Information Management Services, which was to have received at least $150 million to run the parking bureau for five years.
 
Trying to Improve Efficiency
 "Whenever there is a political scandal, people adopt a bunker mentality, and it saddens me," said Harvey Robins, the director of the city's Office of Operations. His office is seeking ways to improve the efficiency of more than 150 city agencies and public services.
"We have not taken a philosophical position that everything should be privatized, but it ought to be part of the package," he added. "Now people are gun-shy; they are risk-averse."
Union officials, among the most vocal opponents of privatization, said city officials had good reason to balk at future proposals.
"How many scandals will it take for the city to learn that privatization is no panacea?," said Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37, New York City's largest municipal employees union. It has for decades opposed almost all attempts to contract out city services.
Although privatization has become a "fashionable buzzword," he said it too often enables businesses to "behave like pigs at the public trough."
More than a dozen services now provided by city workers would be turned over to private companies for the first time under the proposed budget for the 1994 fiscal year. The city would seek a private contractor to replace 85 maintenance, switchboard and vistor transportation workers at the Rikers Island jail, hire a private company to manage a domestic violence shelter, and contract out some clerical work in the Department of Social Services.
Donald D. Kummerfeld, a Manhattan publishing executive, says he is concerned that the problems with the parking violations contract could affect the work of a committee he works on. It is to report to Mayor Dinkins in September on ways the city can streamline its operations.
"There is enough resistance to privatization among public officials already," he said.
Among the recommendations under study by Mr. Kummerfeld's committee are those made in June by the New York City Partnership, a business group, which wants the city to seek competitive bids from private companies to manage the city's water treatment system.
 
Bidding on Buses and Garbage
 Under the Partnership's plan, private companies would also bid on running the city's buses and garbage collection, and the East River bridges would be turned over to a private company that would use electronic toll collection systems. If all its privatization proposals are accepted, the group said, the city could save $16 billion over the next 10 years.
"It would be a tragic loss" if the parking violations furor "delayed New York City from doing what cities like Chicago and Philadelphia have already started -- using competition to improve the delivery of municipal service," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the Partnership.
In July 1992, Philadelphia reached a new contract with its municipal workers, giving it greater freedom to contract out city work. Since then, it has signed a dozen contracts to have bueinesses remove sludge from its water treatment plant, provide museum guards, do landscaping and clean City Hall, among other help.
Privatization "is precisely the kind of thing taxpayers are looking for when they say they want to see the city run like a business," said Dianne E. Reed, director of the Pennsylvania Economy League, a research group that has monitored Philadelphia's campaign to contract out public work under Mayor Edward Rendell, who took office in January 1992.
The result, she said, has been "major public relations dividends."
There have been more tangible dividends as well. So far, the city said, its private contracts are saving it $15 million a year. It plans to privatize 20 to 30 more types of work, and estimates that its total annual savings would be $40 million to $50 million in a city whose general fund budget is about $2.3 billion.
Chicago and Boston are among dozens of cities that have parking violations fines collected privately.
Chicago turned over its collections in 1990 to Electronic Data Systems, a company founded by Ross Perot. It said the company, which it is paying $17 million a year, took in $64 million in 1991, its first full year on the job, almost triple the $22.7 million collected by city workers in 1989.
Boston has contracted with Lockheed Management Information Systems since 1981, when the company was called Datacom. It says it now collects on 85 percent of the city's parking tickets, compared with only 17 percent when city workers did it.
Experts say that smaller cities have the most experience with private contracts because they have simpler budgets and smaller bureaucracies. Private work is greatest in cities in the South and Southwest, in part because their public workers have weaker unions than those in industrialized northern cities.
In San Jose, Calif., a wide variety of public services have been managed by private companies for decades. They include the city's garbage collection and disposal systems, parking violations bureau, street sweeping, airport shuttle and custodial work.
 
Not Without Problems
 Officials there said San Jose's heavy reliance on outside contractors had not been without problems.
"Cost alone should not be considered a sufficient reason to contract out city services, because there will almost always be hidden costs to pay," said Greg Larsen, San Jose's deputy city manager.
Among the "hidden costs," he said, are the expense of monitoring private contractors to guard against overbilling and assure that the work they promise is done. And in tight economic times, cities may find themselves locked into contracts for services they might otherwise reduce. "You do lose flexibility," he said.
Advocates of private contracts say their benefits sometimes spring more from the threat of competition than from actually turning over city work to private companies.
Phoenix, which began contracting out many services in 1980, uses competitive bidding to pit its own agencies against private companies.
 
City Competes, Also
 "When we first got into it, the city agencies lost most of the bids, but we stole the companies' ideas, streamlined services and won much of the work back," said Mark Hughes, a city spokesman.
Despite criticism that it has not moved quickly enough, New York is far from inexperienced in the use of private contractors.
According to a study by the New York City Partnership, more than half the budgets of the city's Human Resources Administration and Departments of Employment, Aging and Mental Health were allocated last year to pay private companies and professionals.
And in one recent experiment, the Department of Parks and Recreation, which has responsibility for pruning and cutting trees on residential blocks, decided last November to compare the work of its crews with that of private companies.
In the end, the department said, its own crews won by a wide margin, cutting down trees at an average cost of $117, compared with the $211 paid to the private concerns.
 
Inching Toward Businesses
 According to advocates of privatization, New York City was inching toward a far greater use of private companies -- or at least the more aggressive use of competitive bidding for public services -- before the parking violations problem, whose impact, if any, is unknown.
"There will always be a built-in tension between the need to protect the integrity of government and the desire to privatize services," said Mr. Kummerfeld, who declined to say what, if any, proposals for privatization his committee would make to Mayor Dinkins in September.
But he added that the troubles with the parking violations contract would remain part of the issue whenever privatization is debated.
"The extent to which this incident dramatizes the danger to government officials cannot be helpful," he said. "It will add to people's fears."
 
 
 
GOVERNMENT: Public Work Done Privately Around the United States
 New York City has been slower than others others in shifting some of its operations to private companies or agencies. The few operations that have been contracted out to private companies has been modest at best. Following is a list of several cities and what services they have contracted out to private companies.
 
New York City:
For decades, has contracted out more than half its social services operations to not-for-profit groups, private counselors and professional firms. Since 1990, it has contracted out management of 330 senior citizens centers, custodial services at 99 schools, and boiler inspection at private office buildings. In fiscal 1993, the city has budgeted $2.8 billion, or 9.5 percent of $29.5 billion budget, for private sector contracts.
 
Chicago:
Since 1990, has contracted out parking ticket collections. Nearly tripled its parking violation revenues, to $64 million in 1991, while paying $17 million a year to its outside collection concern. Also contracts out custodial services, sewer cleaning, landscaping and management of alcohol treatment centers and towing of abandoned vehicles. Estimates its savings at least $10 million to $15 million a year. Mayor Richard Daley has pledged to consider private contracts for every new city service.
 
Philadelphia:
Negotiated new contracts with municipal workers in July 1992, to allow greater privatization. Since then it has contracted out custodial work at City Hall, sludge removal, museum guard services and management of its water transfer stations, a print shop and a warehouse. Mayor Edward Rendell plans to contract out 20 to 30 more services, and says the city will save $40 million to $50 million a year, about 2 percent of its $2.3 billion general fund budget.
 
Pheonix:
Since 1980, has sought competive bids for most city services and encouraged competition betweeen private companies and city agencies. Has privatized trash collection, water bill processing, landfills, water meter repairs, public defenders, dead animal pickup, custodial services, park concessions and landscaping. It estimates it has saved $23.9 million since 1980.
 
San Jose:
For decades, it has contracted out garbage collection and disposal, parking ticket collection, street sweeping, airport shuttle bus service, food services and building maintenance to private companies. No estimate of cost savings is available.

GRAPHIC: Photo: New York has been slower than most cities in turning to private companies for municipal services. Although the pace has been slowed by the city's own difficulties in finding suitable contractors, some critics contend that that is for the best. They cite a study showing city crews were more efficient in cutting down and pruning trees. Workers were on the job Wednesday on 166th Street in Flushing, Queens. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)(pg. 24)

HEADLINE: BOSNIANS CONDEMN U.N.'S PEACE PLAN

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 27

 BODY:
With almost all of their Croatian and Serbian colleagues on the opposite sides of this country's criss-crossing battle lines, members of the Bosnian Parliament, mostly Muslims, today overwhelmingly advocated rejecting a United Nations peace plan. They said formerly Muslim-majority districts must be joined to a proposed Muslim-dominated Bosnian republic.
The peace plan, drawn up in Geneva earlier this month by two international mediators, Lord Owen of the European Community and Thorvald Stoltenberg of the United Nations, would reorganize Bosnia and Herzegovina into a loose union comprising a Serbian, a Croatian and a predominantly Muslim republic. 
 But in the eyes of most Muslims, the plan would reward the Serbs for "ethnic cleansing," create a landlocked Muslim-dominated country with grim economic prospects and pave the way for erasing Bosnia and Herzegovina from the map of Europe and linking the Serbian and Croatian republics in Bosnia with Serbia and Croatia.
 
Vote Scheduled for Saturday
 Parliament is scheduled to vote on the peace proposal on Saturday. At the session today, only one speaker gave the proposal unambiguous support.
"The document we have in front of us is not an agreement but an ultimatum from the strong to the weak," said Ivan Straus, an architect. But he added, "I tell you personally to sign this ultimatum because it will end the war."
President Alija Izetbegovic was one of those speaking to the legislators and several hundred academics, writers, army officers and other public figures who were invited to take part in the debate.
He said the United Nations peace plan could be used as a basis for further discussion but could not be accepted because it rewarded the Bosnian Serbs with at least eight districts that had Muslim majority populations before nationalist Serb militiamen brutally drove them out last year.
"We are experiencing great hardship," said Mr. Izetbegovic, who is scheduled to return to negotiations on the peace plan in Geneva starting Aug. 30. "But this is no time for defeatism."
Mr. Izetbegovic called on the mediators to grant the proposed mostly Muslim republic an outlet to the Adriatic Sea near the town of Neum, which has been a part of Bosnia and Herzegovina since World War II.
The President also called for guarantees, including a United Nations resolution and a show of support from the United States and NATO, that the proposed Union of Bosnia and Herzegovina would remain an internationally recognized country and United Nations member.
 
World Indifference Condemned
 One after another, the speakers took the podium in a stifling hot Holiday Inn banquet hall and condemned the world for turning its back on Bosnia by refusing to lift a United Nations arms embargo that guaranteed Bosnia's nationalist Serbs a vast weapons superiority.
"The international community has decided that in place of law here, the law of the jungle should rule," said the religious leader of the Bosnian Muslims, Mustafa Ceric, who sat in the front row next to the Roman Catholic Archbishop, a Serbian Orthodox priest and a representative of Sarajevo's dwindling Jewish community. "We need unity now as never before."
At a meeting of its own this weekend in the Serbian stronghold at Pale, the self-declared Bosnian Serb parliament is expected to vote to accept the peace plan, even though it requires the Serbs to roll back from part of the 70 percent of Bosnia's territory that they have overrun since beginning the war here 17 months ago.
A similar parliament of Bosnian Croats is scheduled to meet on Saturday in the town of Grude. Miro Lasic, a Croatian member of the Bosnian collective presidency, said no vote by the Bosnian Parliament would be binding on the country's Croatian people.
The Bosnian presidency today ousted Prime Minister Mile Akmadzic, a Croat, after the main Croatian party, the Croatian Democratic Union, withdrew its representatives from the Bosnian Parliament.
The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, threatened earlier this week that the Serbs would press on militarily unless the Bosnian Parliament accepted the peace plan.
The debate today was held in the Holiday Inn because Serbian shells destroyed the Parliament building across the street and none of Sarajevo's other large meeting halls have a secure power supply. Nevertheless, from time to time the electricity went off, leaving the meeting hall nearly pitch black.
 
'A Requiem for Bosnia'
 "This meeting is a requiem for Bosnia," said Stjepan Kljuic, a Bosnian loyalist who led Bosnia's Croatian Democratic Union until he was ousted by the Bosnian Croats' present leader, Mate Boban, who has worked with the Croatian Government's backing to break the Bosnian state apart.
"Izetbegovic and the others can't sign this plan," Mr. Kljuic said during a recess. "It will force the Muslims to cleanse their territory of minorities. What will they do with all the refugees forced from other parts of the republic and out for revenge?"
Just over 100 of the original 240 regular members of the Bosnian Parliament have not withdrawn from the body. About 70 showed up for the meeting today.
The Bosnian Government is seeking the inclusion in the Muslim-dominated republic of eight districts that had Mulsim majorities before the Serbs began to drive them out last year with a campaign of killing and rape known as "ethnic cleansing."
These districts include Visegrad, Zvornik, Foca, Bratunac, Sanski Most, Bijeljina, Kljuc and Bosanska Krupa, said Deputy Foreign Minister Suleiman Sulic.
"Inclusion of these districts in the Muslim state would create the conditions for the return of thousands of refugees," Mr. Sulic said. "I know the Serbs will not give this up. But someone should force them to, because they carried out genocide there. We cannot in principle drop these demands."
But he clearly indicated that the Bosnians would have to accept some version of the peace plan sooner or later.
"The continuation of the war would mean the continued destruction of the Muslim people," Mr. Sulic said.
 
 
 
BALKAN UPDATE
 In SARAJEVO yesterday, members of the Bosnian Parliament, mostly Muslims, urged that a United Nations peace plan be rejected, saying formerly Muslim-majority districts must be joined to a proposed Muslim-dominated republic.
In MOSTAR, Muslims trapped on the east side of the NERETVA RIVER prevented a 19-truck United Nations convoy from leaving for a second day, but peacekeepers were able to evacuate five wounded children. After arriving in MEDJUGORJE by road, they reached SPLIT by helicopter en route to a United States medical unit in ZAGREB, capital of CROATIA.
On Thursday, the trucks brought 175 tons of food and other aid to 55,000 Muslims, some of whom have blocked the convoy's departure in the hope that Serbian forces would hold their fire. But the Bosnian radio reported three people had been killed by tank shells today, and two by snipers on Thursday.
In BELGRADE, the national bank of YUGOSLAVIA announced that it was issuing a 1 billion dinar banknote (or about $3 at the current exchange rate) in an attempt to keep pace with runaway inflation.

HEADLINE: China Protests U.S. Trade Sanctions

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 27

 BODY:
China summoned the American Ambassador to Beijing today and delivered a blistering protest against the Clinton Administration's decision this week to impose sanctions over China's sale of missile technology to Pakistan.
Foreign Minister Qian Qichen and the official New China News Agency said the resumption of sanctions on high-technology exports would cause China "to reconsider its commitment," as the agency put it, to abide by the Missile Control Technology Regime. Under that 1987 accord, the United States and other major powers have been trying to stem the spread of ballistic missile technology. 
 Deputy Foreign Minister Liu Huaqiu summoned the United States Ambassador, Stapleton Roy, for what was described as "an urgent meeting" in which the American was told that his country had ignored "repeated clarifications made by the Governments of China and Pakistan" on their missile technology cooperation and sales.
 
Sanctions Strongly Denounced
 Mr. Liu termed the sanctions a "naked hegemonic act" that "has brutally violated the basic norms governing international relations. "
China did not sign the missile control agreement but has pledged to follow its provisions. The Ambassador and the American Embassy had no immediate comment on the Chinese protest, and Western officials here said it was too early to gauge whether China's threat to disavow the agreement was more diplomatic bluster than genuine threat.
The Chinese press agency said Mr. Liu had emphasized that "China has all along adopted a positive and serious approach toward preventing proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and their delivery systems."
China and Pakistan have argued that any Chinese sales of parts or technology for M-11 missiles to Pakistan do not violate the missile proliferation accord because the M-11's range is less than the minimum of 300 kilometers, or 186 miles, covered by the agreement.
But the United States and other industrial nations that monitor the agreement have amended the rules by which they interpret it. In July they briefed China on the changes in the interpretation and asserted that sales of M-11 technology Pakistan, which they say have been going on for at least two years, constituted a violation.
In a separate statement, Foreign Minister Qian expressed near-indifference to the Clinton Administration action, arguing that the sanctions would do more harm to the American economy than to China's by preventing up to $1 billion in equipment sales from American companies.
In an interview with The Asian Wall Street Journal, Mr. Qian said: "The Chinese market is open. If the United States is restricting itself, we cannot offer it any help."
Western analysts said any attempt by China to disregard international concerns about the spread of advanced weaponry would further isolate Beijing and incite the United States Congress to demand the withdrawal of China's favorable trade status, a move the analysts said would adversely affect as much as 30 percent of China's exports and disrupt the economies of Hong Kong and Taiwan.
"Clearly they would become an international pariah if they started shipping missiles all over the place," said Douglas Paal, who was a National Security Council aide in the Bush Administration.
Speaking by telephone, Mr. Paal, now the director of the Asian Pacific Policy Center in Washington, argued that the Clinton Administration had boxed itself into a negative relationship with China. He said today's statement showed that "China is trying to get our attention" to say "enough is enough" in hopes of opening a more constructive dialogue with Washington.
 
China Charges Double Standard
 Mr. Liu, in his remarks to the United States Ambassador, and Mr. Qian, in his interview, accused Washington of a double standard with regard to controlling arms sales. Mr. Qian, citing a United States Congressional report, said the American global arms trade dwarfed China's, with a value of more than $13 billion annually compared with $100 million.
The Chinese officials said Washington had been unable to explain how it could comply with a decade-old United States-China joint communique sharply restricting arms sales to Taiwan while also carrying forward last year's decision by President Bush to allow the sale of 150 General Dynamics F-16 fighters to Taiwan. The Chinese said the sale violated the terms of communique, which calls for an annual $20 million reduction in American arms sales to Taiwan until they reach zero.
Mr. Bush's decision, made in the midst of the presidential campaign, violated the communique, United States officials conceded, but was consistent with the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act, which recognizes the need to maintain Taiwan's defensive capacity.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks to 'Fix' Mining Provisions of Sea Treaty

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has joined more than 60 countries in a drive to renegotiate a complex and bitterly disputed section of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, a treaty that has been in legal limbo since President Reagan rejected it more than a decade ago.
Negotiators at the United Nations, some of them veterans of the grueling Law of the Sea talks of the 1970's, say there is a widespread feeling that failure to resolve the lingering dispute could seriously undermine future application of the pact, which covers virtually every aspect of human activity on, over and under the ocean. 
 Legal scholars regard the treaty as a milestone in international law. But its density and sheer breadth -- it comprises 320 articles and 9 annexes on everything from navigation and fishing rights to environmental protection and scientific research -- have made it an exotic and rather forbidding subject for the public.
Moreover, its underlying premise -- that the high seas and the deep-seabed are part of the "common heritage of mankind" that must be shared through "a just and equitable economic order," with special regard for the needs of developing countries -- has been a lightning rod for clashes between rich and poor nations. It is also at the heart of the dispute at the United Nations.
 
Share of Mining Benefits
 The talks, which included five days of closed-door consultations here that ended on Aug. 6, are focused on the one part of the treaty that Mr. Reagan refused to accept, and about which developed and developing nations still heatedly disagree: Section 11. It would create a global collective to allow developing nations to share in the benefits of mining the deep-sea floor for minerals like manganese, cobalt, nickel and copper.
Developing nations regard the idea of a global mining consortium not only as a source of funds to help their economies, but also as a symbol of good will by the industrialized countries.
But the concept was rankling to President Reagan and many members of Congress, who at the height of tensions with the Soviet Union, saw the mining provisions as an effort by developing nations to impose Soviet-inspired market restrictions on American efforts to mine strategic metals. The Administration also denounced the idea that the United States would have to share not only its profits, but also its seabed mining technology.
Thomas A. Clingan Jr., the American delegate when the Law of the Sea was opened for signature in Montego Bay, Jamaica, on Dec. 10, 1982, had instructions to sign a companion document recalling the history of the negotiations, but not the pact itself.
 
Hoping to Fix Section
 Administration officials caution that President Clinton shares many of the same reservations about the wisdom of the mining provisions as his Republican predecessors. But they believe that if the seabed section can be "fixed," as one put it, a universally recognized treaty that balances the needs of all countries would be in the best interests of the United States -- especially from a military perspective.
Pentagon officials like Rear Adm. William L. Schachte Jr., the Defense Department's representative for ocean policy, say the treaty's provisions upholding the right to conduct high-seas military maneuvers and freedom of passage through strategic sea routes are vital to United States security. Moreover, he and other experts say, the treaty is itself a readily recognizable symbol of international order.
"If you look at the Persian Gulf situation, for example, we didn't have problems with Iran or Oman in using the Strait of Hormuz, because they recognized that the language of the treaty was clear," Admiral Schachte said. "By the same token, we don't deal with Spain or Morocco when we go through Gibraltar."
Although a total of 159 nations -- most of them developing countries -- have signed the Law of the Sea, the agreement has yet to come into force, largely because 45 nations, including industrial powers like Britain, Germany and Italy, decided to follow the American lead and refused to ratify it.
Despite this, the Law of the Sea has been widely treated as if it was legally enforceable, or "customary" under international law. It is, for instance, the basis for decisions by the International Court of Justice in The Hague, which handles many maritime disputes.
 
Guarantee Against Changes
 Administration officials and nongovernmental experts on the Law of the Sea assert that while the treaty is useful in its present form as customary law, an agreement approved by the United States Senate and a broad mix of industrial and developing nations would be far preferable because it would be impervious to sudden changes in the international political and economic landscape.
Former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson, who served in the Kennedy, Nixon and Ford Administrations before he became President Jimmy Carter's chief sea-law negotiator in 1977, said the Pentagon's most compelling reason for favoring universal application of the treaty has been the tendency of many coastal nations -- most of them friendly to the United States -- to impose unilateral restrictions on navigation in their territorial waters, a phenomenon he and other experts call "creeping jurisdiction."
"The reason the Pentagon is so concerned that the Law of the Sea be universally set down is not because we lack the military muscle to force our way through waters that have become subject to exaggerated jurisdiction of territorial seas," said Mr. Richardson, who has been promoting acceptance of the treaty. "It is because most of these waters are controlled by friendly countries, and we don't want to have to use muscle to exercise our rights where friendly countries are concerned."
Negotiators from both developed and developing countries say there is no better time to discuss revisions in the mining provisions. With the Soviet Union gone and world metal prices in decline, there is recognition that the treaty language on mining, which includes a call for a global mining collective, needs to reflect the global shift toward market-driven economies.
They also acknowledge that the issues are more abstract than ever, since the seabed mining business -- which seemed like a multi-trillion-dollar boom waiting to happen when the treaty was being negotiated two decades ago -- is unlikely to make any economic sense until well into the next century, when land-based sources of strategic minerals like nickel and manganese are expected to dwindle.
 
Urgency Is Seen
 There is an element of urgency surrounding the talks, diplomats say. With the treaty just 4 short of the necessary 60 ratifying nations, the Law of the Sea may finally become legally binding sometime in 1994. But if there is no agreement on the seabed provisions before then, the disputed mining section will become law as it stands, and the task of ever finding a compromise on Section 11 will become trickier, since the procedures for altering a treaty in force are far more difficult.
Moreover, without a seabed mining compromise, control of the process involved in altering the treaty would be in the hands of developing countries -- some of them, like Iraq and Cuba, openly hostile to the United States.
Many diplomats say they are optimistic that agreement can be found when the talks resume in November. "I think we are headed for a satisfactory solution," said Satya N. Nandan, a Fijian whose consensus-building during the earlier talks has helped make him a key figure again two decades later.

HEADLINE: Banks Said To Be Freer In Lending

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
In a strong sign that the credit crunch may be easing, banks have become noticeably more willing to lend to businesses, including small companies, the Federal Reserve reported today.
Bank executives surveyed by the Fed said they had relaxed their terms and requirements for a wide variety of loans. Even as standards for commercial real estate loans stayed restrictive, the bank executives reported what the Fed called a "fairly significant net easing" of standards and terms for commercial loans.
 
A Broad-Based Shift
 About a fifth of the respondents in the August survey eased standards for approving loans for medium and large businesss. And about 12 percent eased standards for small borrowers. 
 What is more, banks lowered the cost of loans to businesses, according to the Fed's quarterly survey of lending officers at 78 domestic and foreign banks with branches around the country. From 30 percent to 40 percent scaled back the cost of credit lines for medium to large companies; 15 to 20 percent did so for small ones.
Banks' lending to businesses shrank sharply toward the end of the 1980's and has stayed low, a trend that many experts cite as one reason for the sluggish recovery from the recession. While bankers generally said that they had had little demand for loans in a soft economy, business executives, especially those in New England, contended that credit had been hard to get since tough lending standards took hold after the banking industry's difficulties in the 1980's.
 
'An Enormous Change'
 "We've been sitting on the edge of our seats waiting for this to happen, and it's finally happened," Harvey Rosenblum, research director at the Dallas Federal Reserve, said of the survey's findings. "It's an enormous change."
Noting that the survey in May had suggested a change in attitudes was under way, Frank N. Newman, the Treasury's Under Secretary for Domestic Finance, said, "Having a second quarter confirming a general direction in lending attitudes is important."
Federal Reserve officials attributed the shift in bankers' psychology to changes in the economic and banking environment.
"The economy is on a slow upward track, property values have stabilized and there's more equity available for small businesses to make the hurdles," said Marvin Goodfriend, research director at the Richmond Federal Reserve. "Also, bank capital positions have improved, and they are no doubt in a better position to take on new loans."
When interest rates were coming down, banks poured billions of dollars into government securities. That has become one catalyst for the attitude shift, Mr. Rosenblum said, because a pending rule will require banks to use market-value accounting for their investment portfolio, forcing them to revalue their assets frequently to reflect changes in the value of bonds.
"It makes the true underlying risk of investing in government securities manifest," Mr. Rosenblum said. "As a result it narrows the perceived risk spread between lending to a small-business customer on the one hand and investing in a 7- to 10-year Treasury note on the other."
The other striking finding in the Fed's bank lending survey is that the White House initiative in March to break the credit crunch, the Credit Availability Program, seems to have had little to do with the shift in lending attitudes and practices.
"The survey responses suggest that the C.A.P. has not had a substantial effect on the supply of credit to small and medium-sized businesses, although many respondents expect it to do so in the future," the Fed reported.
One reason: Just 4 banks out of 48 eligible to participate in the initiative's so-called minimal-documentation loan program have done so thus far.
 
Other Influences Cited
 The apparently tepid response to the overall program came as no surprise to the many analysts who maintained that the weak economy, the fragile capital position of banks and the poor financial condition of many small businesses -- rather than overzealous regulation -- was to blame for the lack of business lending.
But Mr. Newman, who worked with the Federal Reserve last spring to draft the initiative, said: "The great impact of this program is still to come. Some of the important regulatory revisions weren't issued until June. It takes time for bankers to receive them, analyze the changes and put them into effect."
Most banks have not yet gone through a bank examination cycle under the new regimen, Mr. Newman noted. "As each bank gets its examination report, it will see a reflection of the revised regulations in concrete terms," he said. "In the real world, that's got to be part of the psychological effect."

HEADLINE: Stabbing, a Motorcycle Crash And a Young Murder-Suicide

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARFIELD, N.J., Aug. 27

 BODY:
He was 20 and she was only 17, bound together by a friendship that started in Poland, their native country, and grew into a trans-Atlantic romance.
Only hours before the young woman was to return to Poland to resume her high school studies, the relationship ended, the authorities say, in a murder-suicide early today. 
 Did the deaths grow out of sorrow or anger over the young couple's impending separation? "We have no idea what the motive was," said Frank Puccio, the First Assistant Bergen County Prosecutor.
What they do know, he said, is that Renata Bioas was stabbed to death in a converted apartment above the garage at her boyfriend's home. Mr. Puccio said she was stabbed several times in the neck and upper body, between 1 and 2 A.M. today.
 
Motorcycle Slams Into Wall
 About 2:30 A.M., her boyfriend, Tomasz Szczech, died instantly when his motorcycle slammed into the brick wall of a two-story apartment house on a curve on River Street about a mile from his home.
Mr. Puccio said county detectives believed that Mr. Szczech killed his girlfriend and then intentionally crashed the motorcycle into the wall.
No suicide notes were found in the apartment where Ms. Bioas was slain or in the home of Mr. Szczech's parents on Orchard Street, he said. Mr. Puccio also said the authorities were trying to learn about their activities in the hours before their deaths.
Ms. Bioas had been visiting at the Szczech home in this blue-collar city in southwestern Bergen County since July 14, Mr. Puccio said. It was the second trip she had made from Poland to see Mr. Szczech after his family moved here in early 1991, Mr. Puccio said. Mr. Szczech had traveled to Poland to see her once, he said.
Mr. Szczech graduated from Garfield High School in June. He was unemployed and planned to seek a job after the summer, Mr. Puccio said.
The young man's father, Eugene, discovered Ms. Bioas's body shortly after 6 A.M., after he awoke, noticed the door to the garage apartment ajar and went to investigate, Mr. Puccio said. She was found in a bedroom off the apartment's living room. Two kitchen knives believed to be the murder weapons were found in the apartment, Mr. Puccio said.
At that point, Mr. Szczech was unaware his son had been killed in the motorcycle crash a few hours earlier, Mr. Puccio said. Moments after he called the Garfield police headquarters to tell them of the murder, other officers arrived at his home to tell him of his son's death, Mr. Puccio said. His son's identity had been traced through the motorcycle's registration.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines as Traders Test Fed's Will to Support It

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen yesterday as investors tested how far the American currency would drop before the Federal Reserve intervened in the market.
The dollar also fell against the German mark. 
 In New York, the dollar ended at 103.85 yen, down from 104.40 yen on Thursday. It also ended at 1.6640 marks, down from 1.6675 marks.
Gold prices recovered somewhat from Thursday's losses. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for October delivery, the active near-term futures contract, gained $1.30 an ounce, to $370.30. It had fallen $4.70 on Thursday. In New York, the Republic National Bank quoted spot gold at $369.25 an ounce, up $1.25.
The dollar weakened against the yen during Asian trading despite intervention by the Bank of Japan to try to halt the yen's rise. Later, the dollar strengthened in New York trading after David Mullins Jr., the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, said the American central bank would not let the dollar slide sharply.
"That got the market all excited," said Mike McKeever, assistant vice president of Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York. But, he added, investors soon realized that Mr. Mullins was speaking in general terms and was not indicating any imminent action. They began to sell dollars again and buy back yen.
Traders said the dollar was being sold because investors were testing how far it could fall, and because many traders were looking to get rid of dollars because of weakness in the American economy.
The dollar continued to fall against the German mark a day after the Bundesbank of Germany surprised the markets by not cutting its key interest rate. The mark was pushed up yesterday when the Bundesbank's chief economist, Otmar Issing, said he foresaw no change in German monetary policy.
Al Jirkovsky, managing director of Continental Bank in Chicago, said, "It got people feeling, 'Well, all right, in the short term the marks are strong.' "
The dollar did strengthen against the British pound as investors sold pounds to lock in profits from the currency's rise on Thursday. In New York, the pound slipped to $1.5035, from $1.5090 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Consumer Optimism Reported Up Slightly

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Consumer optimism about the economy rose slightly in August from July, according to the University of Michigan's monthly survey, released yesterday. But the gain was small -- from 77 in July to 77.3 in August -- and economists said it did not represent the beginning of a trend.
William Dudley, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the rise did not mean "the cloud covering the economy has been removed." 
 An increase indicates consumers are becoming more optimistic about the economy. Two weeks ago, the university reported a preliminary August reading of 75.4.
Last December's index was 91. The base is 100, set in 1966. The record high, 101, was set in March 1984 and the record low, 51.7, in April 1980.
The university also reported that its August index of consumer expectations, which measures how people feel about their future, rose to 65.8 from 64.7 in July. The early reading was 64.5. But the August index of current economic conditions fell to 95.1 from 96.2 in July. The preliminary reading had been 92.5.
Through the first two quarters of this year the economy was growing at an average annual rate of 1.2 percent; last year's average quarterly rate was 3.1 percent.
Economists expect the Commerce Department next week to revise second-quarter gross domestic product growth to about 1 percent from 1.6 percent reported earlier.

HEADLINE: Wetlands: Will Clinton Be Bush?

 BODY:
Land-use issues are always contentious, none more so than that of wetlands. The Clinton Administration's new wetlands policy is not without unnerving flaws, including a misguided provision to turn some enforcement duties over to the Department of Agriculture. That needs to be reversed, but otherwise the new policy makes good sense on both environmental and political grounds.
It keeps most of the important protections for the 100 million or so wetland acres that scientists agree are genuinely worth saving. And by striking a reasonable balance between preservation and economic growth, it is likely to remove some of the heat from an issue that led to doctrinal warfare within the Bush Administration and nearly made a liar of Mr. Bush himself. 
 "Wetlands" is a broad term applied to ecosystems ranging from prairie potholes to vast tidal marshes. For most of America's history, wetlands were treated as disposable assets to be diked, drained, drilled and turned into cropland, shopping malls, subdivisions and oilfields. The result was the destruction of more than half the 230 million wetland acres that the first settlers found in the 48 contiguous states.
In 1972, Congress finally got the message scientists had been sending for years: Wetlands are valuable, virtually irreplaceable biological systems deserving protection. They filter pollutants, replenish water supplies, nourish organisms vital to the food chain and provide habitat for wildlife. The Clean Water Act, passed that year, required anyone seeking to fill a wetland to obtain a permit from the Army Corps of Engineers and submit to review by the Environmental Protection Agency.
The law slowed the loss of wetlands. But it suffered from indifferent enforcement and the failure of various agencies to agree on what a wetland was. In 1987 Government experts finally arrived at a common definition: A wetland is any ground that has mucky or peat-based soils, nourishes specified plant life and is saturated at least seven days a year. Mr. Bush pledged in the 1988 campaign to stick with that definition, and actually improved on it with a slightly stricter definition in 1989.
At which point the farmers, developers and oil interests rose up in protest and dispatched their lobbyists marching to the White House. Facing re-election, Mr. Bush caved in, allowing Vice President Dan Quayle's slapdash Council on Competitiveness to issue a definition of wetlands that, taken literally, would have removed parts of the Florida Everglades from protection. Only the resistance of William Reilly, the E.P.A. chief, saved the day.
The Clinton policy reaffirms the 1987 definition. If administered uniformly and strictly -- always a big if with the Corps of Engineers -- that should be enough to hold the line against further erosion until the National Academy of Sciences produces a comprehensive definition next year. Sensibly, the White House has also reversed a last-minute Bush order exempting 1.7 million acres of fragile Alaskan wetlands from protection.
Meanwhile, the plan preserves a Bush Administration exemption for 53 million acres of wetlands that were drained and converted to farmland before 1985. Much of the political uproar came from legitimately aggrieved farmers who feared they would be forced to give back to nature lands they had already cultivated.
But that's enough of a bow to agricultural sensibilities. One dangerous part of the Clinton proposal makes the Soil Conservation Service the lead Federal agency for identifying wetlands on agricultural acreage. The service's specialists do know a lot about soil, but the department they work for, Agriculture, has a bumpy environmental record. The department's Forest Service, for example, has only now begun to control its appetite for ravaging the national forests. Mr. Clinton should redirect the responsibility for agricultural wetlands to the Corps and the E.P.A.
The package includes an Executive Order pledging "no net loss" of wetlands. Those were George Bush's words, too. Let's hope Mr. Clinton's resolve is more durable.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: 'The West' Is Only a Flag of Convenience

SERIES: STRATEGIC ALLIANCES: Second of three articles

BYLINE: By Owen Harries; Owen Harries is editor of The National Interest. This article is excerpted from an essay in the September-October issue of Foreign Affairs.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Recent proposals that NATO should make guarantees or grant membership to the new states of East and Central Europe reflect a philosophical inertia, an unwillingness to jettison old concepts and modes of thought in the face of utterly changed circumstances.
Proposals for what amounts to a new NATO are based on a most questionable premise: that "the West" continues to exist as a political and military entity. Over the last half century or so, most of us have come to think of "the West" as a given, a natural presence and one that is here to stay. It is a way of thinking that is not only wrong in itself, but is virtually certain to lead to mistaken policies. 
 The political "West" is not a natural construct but a highly artificial one. It took the presence of a life-threatening, overtly hostile "East" to bring it into existence and to maintain its unity. It is extremely doubtful whether it can now survive the disappearance of that enemy.
The countries of the West share vast commonalities: history, culture, and political values and institutions. It is in this -- the glory that was Greece and grandeur that was Rome, Christianity, the Renaissance, the Reformation, the Enlightenment, the French and Industrial revolutions, representative democracy, the rule of law, the market economy -- that many find the basis of Western unity.
But all these common features had existed long before the cold war, yet they had never created or sustained a united West before the appearance of a shared and formidable enemy. A common civilization is one thing, political unity is another. In fact, relationships among the countries of the West have been marked by division and by particularly bloody internecine conflicts throughout their history.
Something approaching a united "West" has been spoken of only three times in modern history: in 1917-18, 1941-45 and the cold war years. In the first two instances, the term is a complete misnomer, since the enemies -- Germany and Austria-Hungary in the first case, Germany and Italy in the second -- were full-fledged members of the West. The conflicts could more accurately be described (and sometimes have been) as Western civil wars.
But if one stretches the point and allows all three as examples, it becomes clear that the notion of a political "West" is one that has been attractive to Europeans only when some or all of their countries have been in great and imminent danger. Desperation and fear have been its parents, not natural affinities. They have been the forces that have driven Europeans to unite among themselves and to associate with the U.S. under the banner of "the West."
In the absence of an overriding threat that one is incapable of handling on one's own -- and sometimes even in the presence of such a threat -- the inclination on both sides of the Atlantic has been to emphasize not unity, but the difference and incompatibility of Europe and America. Thus, even before final victory in 1945, the prevailing model of the political world had become that of the "Big Three," with Franklin Roosevelt more suspicious of Britain and its empire than of the Soviet Union. Immediately after victory, Harry Truman abruptly ended lend-lease aid to Europe without any obvious concern for the overall well-being of "the West."
As it was at the beginning of the cold war, so it was at the end. Two years ago, when the Soviet Union disintegrated, what we immediately started to hear propounded on both sides of the Atlantic -- and what we were still hearing from President Clinton during the July Tokyo summit -- was a tripartite or tripolar version of the world, with Europe, the U.S. and Japan. Once free of a Soviet threat many Europeans immediately began anticipating, often with ill-concealed glee, a post-Maastricht United Europe that would supplant the U.S. as the dominant economic, and ultimately political, force in the world.
Subsequently, of course, the momentum toward European unity has faltered and Maastricht has become a divisive rather than uniting symbol. The European economy has gone into what looks increasingly like a prolonged structural recession.
As all these things have happened, and as Europe has proved embarrassingly incapable of dealing with the Bosnian crisis, European confidence that it can dispense with U.S. leadership and operate as an independent force has drained away, and we have been hearing more, again, of "the West." But if and when things improve significantly for Europe, we should anticipate another reversal.
If European needs and insecurities constitute one condition for the continuation of "the West," there is also an obvious second condition: U.S. willingness to respond to those needs. That, too, has in the past required a deep sense of danger -- danger to American interests -- to overcome America's moralistic distaste for European power politics.
In 1917 it took a lot of German provocation before the New World finally did come in to redress the balance of the Old. In 1941 it took Pearl Harbor and Hitler's foolish declaration of war on the U.S. to produce a decisive, if involuntary, intervention. And from 1946 to 1949 the rapid spread of Soviet power into Central Europe provided the incentive, after the U.S. had initially responded to the end of World War II with instant and comprehensive demobilization. Absent a sense of danger, America's aloofness has been as marked as Europe's assumption of independence.
The most powerful argument for substantial American withdrawal from the kind of serious, sustained and expensive participation necessary to maintain "the West" as something more than a reassuring fiction is the urgent pull of domestic matters, long neglected or relegated to subordinate status during the cold war. One does not have to be an isolationist or a "declinist" to believe that the time has come to alter the country's priorities in favor of domestic concerns.
To the extent that such attitudes prevail and such advice is taken, they are inimical to a united and purposeful "West," which requires an active, outgoing and engaged America. There is good reason to believe that in the Clinton era such attitudes will prevail. President Clinton has an ambitious domestic agenda and little interest in or feel for foreign policy. He has equipped himself with a team that, to put it mildly and politely, is unlikely to press him hard to adopt ambitious, activist policies abroad, except in the area of trade.
If Bosnia is any indication, one can expect that in Mr. Clinton's Washington "the West" and the U.N. will be used as devices not to facilitate action but to justify inaction. The U.S. wants to take decisive action, it will be claimed in various situations, but it must be multilateral action and a proper international mandate must be given. If these conditions cannot be fulfilled, then the U.S. will, regrettably but justifiably, do nothing.
In practice, whenever it has looked remotely as if the Europeans might agree to a U.S. proposal on Bosnia, there has been a rapid backing off on Washington's part. After the character in Dylan Thomas's "Under Milk Wood," this rationalization of passivity might be labeled the "Nogood Boyo" approach to foreign policy: "I want to be good, but nobody'll let me."
The concept of "the West" is likely to revert to what it has been for most of the past: a concept of last resort, held in reserve for when things go seriously bad and individual countries or restricted alliances are unable to cope on their own. One must assume -- unless one has come to accept the fatuous nonsense that war as an institution is dead -- that such circumstances will again return to haunt us one day, perhaps sooner rather than later.
If those who speak of the "Clash of Civilizations" (Samuel Huntington) and of "the West and the Rest" (Kishore Mahbubani) are right, the idea of a political "West" may achieve greater authenticity in the struggles of the future than it did even in the days of the cold war. But meanwhile the notion has lost much of its definition and raison d'etre.
W. H. Auden once wrote of Brussels, the city that subsequently became the headquarters of the European Community and NATO, and thus of the West:
Its formula escapes you; it has lost
The certainty that constitutes a thing.
For the time being, at least, these words can properly be applied to the West itself.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed; Series

Rankings reflect sales figures, for the week ending Aug. 14, at 3,050 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 28,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. COMING UP DOWN HOME: A Memoir of a Southern Childhood, by Cecil Brown. (Ecco, $24.95.) Mr. Brown's story, redolent of the sights and sounds of rural North Carolina at midcentury, tackles as well the relations, until recently little explored, of black fathers and sons.
CRAZY IN ALABAMA, by Mark Childress. (Putnam, $22.95.) Southern American humor yet again, but in a novel that pounds every convention of the genre into submission; not even the dead bodies interfere with the funniness.
"DADDY'S GONE TO WAR": The Second World War in the Lives of America's Children, by William M. Tuttle Jr. (Oxford University, $30.) A historian finds that some "home front children" still feel indoctrinated in fright and hate, while others believe the war enhanced their understanding of this country and its culture.
EPSTEIN: Artist Against the Establishment, by Stephen Gardiner. (Viking, $35.) This polemical book defends at every point a major artist who all his life defied bourgeois conformity yet managed to die the proprietor of a knighthood.
FOXFIRE: Confessions of a Girl Gang, by Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $21.) A dark and troubled epic of women who revenge themselves on men, set in the slow-witted 1950's, before female bonding had been discovered.
THE KOMMANDANT'S MISTRESS, by Sherri Szeman. (HarperCollins, $17.50.) A powerful novel, forged from refractory materials: the personal narratives of a death camp commander and the Jewish woman he chose as his mistress.
SADE: A Biography, by Maurice Lever. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) A life of the French aristocrat and novelist (1740-1814) so wicked they renamed wickedness in his honor, so to speak.
SECOND SIGHT, by Robert V. Hine. (University of California, $20.) A splendid, highly literate personal account by a historian who slowly lost his eyesight and suddenly got it back.
SIGNS OF DEVOTION: Stories, by Maxine Chernoff. (Simon & Schuster, $19.) Smart, antic short stories in which people understand new experiences by recalling old ones, and the trivial is examined until its importance transpires.
THEIRS WAS THE KINGDOM: Lila and DeWitt Wallace and the Story of the Reader's Digest, by John Heidenry. (Norton, $29.95.) A hugely detailed, engagingly written history of a single bright idea and the preacher's kids who ran that idea into a multibillion-dollar global enterprise.
TRANSLATE THIS DARKNESS: The Life of Christiana Morgan, by Claire Douglas. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) This remarkable woman plumbed the depth of her unconscious as a member of the Jung circle in the 1920's, discovering, Ms. Douglas argues, a recognizable protofeminist inside.
THE WRESTLER'S CRUEL STUDY, by Stephen Dobyns. (Norton, $22.95.) Probability has no place in this entertaining post-modern novel, governed by the presence of a wrestler's manager who talks and thinks like Nietzsche.
