HEADLINE: Streetscapes: Central Park's 'Hooverville';
Life Along 'Depression Street'

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
PERHAPS the character of shantytowns, and the homeless who occupy them, change little over generations. But the episode of the encampment at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge, demolished by the city on Aug. 17, recalls the "Hooverville" of shacks housing more than a score of homeless people in the emptied Central Park Reservoir in 1931-1933.
The stock-market crash of October 1929 occurred just as the large rectangular reservoir in Central Park north of Belvedere Castle was being taken out of service. In early 1930, the reservoir was drained, preparatory to its transformation into what is now known as the Great Lawn. But a slowdown in construction and excavation made clean fill scarce. 
 According to "The Park and the People: A History of Central Park" by Roy Rosenzweig and Elizabeth Blackmar (Cornell University Press, 1992), by late 1930 a few homeless people had set up an informal camp at the reservoir site, but were evicted by the police.
As the Depression set in, public sentiment became more sympathetic. In July 1931 a judge suspended the sentences of 22 unemployed men sleeping in Central Park -- apparently in various locations -- and gave each one $2 out of his own pocket.
In November the Municipal Lodging House set a record in sheltering 3,853 men in one night. Other accounts indicate that the homeless colony had again established itself in the empty reservoir, and in December a New York Times reporter described six shacks, one with a stove, housing nine men.
"We work hard to keep it clean, because that is important," said one man. "I never lived like this before." The next day seven of the men were arrested as vagrants, but the charges were dismissed.
In September 1932, 29 men were arrested "with apologies and good feelings on both sides" in what the Parks Department itself described as "Hoover Valley." At the time, there were 17 shacks along "Depression Street," all with chairs and beds and some with carpets. One was even built of brick with a roof of inlaid tile by umemployed bricklayers who called it "Rockside Inn."
"They repair in the morning to comfort stations to shave and make themselves look presentable and keep their shacks as clean as they can," reported The Times. A health official said that "unless the city should see fit to install running water and sewerage facilities, the camp will have to go."
But it was still open Oct. 3, when Patrick McDermott, an unemployed bricklayer, was given six months in jail for dancing and singing along the top of the reservoir wearing "less clothing than deemed proper." He earlier reported that he had collected $47 from 3,000 visitors who had come to see the shantytown.
"The Park and the People: A History of Central Park" says there were 1.2 million Americans homeless in the winter of 1932-1933; 2,000 of these were New Yorkers who managed as best they could on the street. Ted Houghton, a spokesman for the Coalition for the Homeless, says 25,000 people a night are now in similar circumstances.
The reservoir settlement could not have been popular with the tenants of the new Fifth Avenue and Central Park West apartments, but they mounted no protest. There were other such settlements in New York -- one with 80 shacks between Ninth and 10th Streets on the East River. But the Central Park shantytown was the most famous. It disappeared sometime before April 1933 when work on the reservoir landfill resumed.
The issues raised in the the 30's are like many replayed in our own time. Millions were raised privately in relief funds, and there was great sympathy for those without homes and jobs. But this was tempered with concern that perhaps they were just "hoboes" -- a term describing vagrants.
THE shantytowns simultaneously attracted admiration and censure: people admired the resourcefulness of the individual inhabitants and the extent of their efforts and yet were threatened by the implicit disorder of such colonies.
Government could seem benign but also cruel. When the East River colony was cleared in 1933 (with 10 days' notice) "old John Cahill" told a reporter: "Nobody's askin' us where we're goin'. There's not a soul thinkin' about us."
Then, as now, there were many homeless people who refused to accept the officially sanctioned help. When their camps were broken up, they moved peacefully on, with only mild protest and certainly no revolt. And in the end, as everyone else seemed to hope, they just sort of disappeared.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shantytown in empty Central Park reservoir, now the Great Lawn, in 1932. (Culver Pictures)

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
Fairfield's Large-Space Market Revives

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
FOR the first time in more than three years companies from Manhattan, Westchester and Connecticut are looking for large blocks of office space in Fairfield County.
To meet the demand, office buildings that had been constructed as corporate headquarters but have been mostly vacant in recent years are shedding their white elephant skins and entering the competition. 
 Two recent leases are considered a giant step toward a resurgence of the one-large-floor market. Instead of the 2,000- to 20,000-square-foot leases that have been the norm in the last three years, the Witco Corporation of Manhattan took 258,000 square feet in Greenwich and Dun & Bradstreet, also of Manhattan, took 94,048 in Westport.
Those two deals alone, signed in June, did much to break a persistent mid-to-high-20-percent vacancy rate countywide, knocking it down to around 22 percent.
And following three years of zero office construction in Fairfield, Duracell, which rents several buildings at the Berkshire Industrial Park in Bethel, will break ground there next January for a $60 million, 300,000-square-foot corporate headquarters. It is the first single-occupant venture the real estate community has witnessed in a decade and the only one on the immediate horizon.
Variances have been obtained from Bethel's Planning and Zoning Commission and site plan approval will be sought within the next few months. Construction is expected to be completed by the fall of 1995, accomodating 650 employes and 700 cars on 43 acres.
"With the limited availability of major blocks of Class A space," said John Rostenberg, partner at Rostenberg Doern Realtors in Stamford, "sooner or later a company will not be able to find a building and it will build to suit itself. We won't see the same kind of extravagance, but we will find corporations building with more function and productivity in mind."
As for a renewal of demand for large spaces, "I'm seeing over a million square feet of active prospects in various stages," said Jay Hruska, a Cushman & Wakefield broker who represented the landlord, Greenwich-American Center, in the Witco lease, "and I'm considering this a trend."
The refrain was repeated by the Manhattan real estate marketing firm of Delmhorst & Sheehan, which represented Nyala Farms, landlord in the Dun & Bradstreet lease.
"We specialize in large properties," said John E. Sheehan, a partner, "and we have a number of large users looking for space."
CONNECTICUT is working hard to attract that business, with money, in-kind assistance and concessions.
"We looked in New Jersey and Westchester," said Carl Soderlind, vice president of corporate affairs at Witco, which makes chemical and petroleum products. "We saw comparable locations at comparable prices, but we got an $8 million grant from Connecticut and a reduced rate for utilities. The Governor's staff was there for us. It was refreshing and it made all the difference."
Renovations begin in November for completion next April.
"Dun & Bradstreet got a $7.2 million grant and a utility-rate reduction," said Joseph Cohen, spokesman for the State Department of Economic Development. "There is a two- or three-year payback to the state in personal and corporate income taxes and general spending through hundreds of new jobs these companies bring in."
Job training, loans below market rate, and what Mr. Cohen described as "a smorgasbord" of incentives are available.
"After ignoring economic development for the entire decade of the 'Who, me worry?' 80's, we have come around 180 degrees to improve the business climate," he said.
Witco's 20-year lease at Greenwich-American Center, formerly Primerica, is believed to be the largest in square footage since 1983. The 605,000-square-foot building on 154 acres was built in 1970 by the American Can Company, with numerous amenities to compensate for its location in an isolated, rural corner of Greenwich.
With several dining areas, a guest house, a manmade lake for fire protection and recreational and service facilities for up to 3,500 employes, it set the stage for the wave of office construction that overwhelmed the county in the 80's. Around 290,000 square feet are still available at asking rents of $20 to $25 a foot a year, less than half 1988 levels.
Witco will close its headquarters in Manhattan and an office in Woodcliff, N.J., but retain manufacturing sites in several other states. About 600 of 800 employes invited to relocate are expected to do so, with the shortfall to be hired locally. The headquarters will employ 800 people.
Dun & Bradstreet's move to Nyala Farms, the former Stauffer Chemical Company headquarters on 54 acres in Westport, is scheduled for October. The two-year lease will end concurrently with the completion of renovations of its 129,000-square-foot permanent headquarters in Wilton.
Nyala Farms will have 16,000 square feet vacant out of 378,000 when the lease begins.
To prevent increased traffic and urbanization, Greenwich and Westport zoning officials for several years refused to allow more than one tenant at Nyala Farms and three at Greenwich-American Center. Unable to attract tenants to such large quarters, the owners appealed to the State Supreme Court in 1988. Settlements reached in 1991 allow 20 tenants at Nyala Farms, and an unlimited number at Greenwich-American provided the number of employees does not exceed 18 per acre, or around 2,700 people.
What remains of Union Carbide's complex of 1.2 million square feet and 650 acres on the outskirts of Danbury has been less successful in attracting tenants. It was sold in 1986, with Carbide taking a 20-year leaseback of the 15 buildings and 100 acres.
BUT because the company requires less space than anticipated, 150,000 square feet of vacant office space in 1986 has grown to 450,000 square feet today, of which 9,000 square feet was leased in July by Comstock/Spie Group, an international construction firm.
A major inducement to relocate to Fairfield County was and still is that many company executives already live there. Recently, an executive who lives in Greenwich and works in Manhattan was scouting Greenwich locations for his company.
"An office site he liked was near his home," said James Sandy, Greenwich's town planner. "He is an inveterate equestrian, and he was intrigued with the idea of going to work on horseback."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Witco has leased much of Greenwich-American Center in Greenwich. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Auctions;
An Old Way of Selling Takes on New Respectability

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
ON Sept. 20, people from all over the world will gather at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and bid on commercial properties scattered across New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. They will get a chance to buy a couple of warehouses, an office complex, an apartment complex, a research building, even a department store on Brooklyn's Fulton Mall.
Some of the properties are for sale, others have potential for lease takeovers. They have just one thing in common: Their owners, the International Business Machines Corporation and the Prudential Insurance Company of America, think they have a better chance to get a decent price for those properties at auction than through a conventional sale.
"An auction brings all the buyers together in one room and that gives you a definite read on the market," said John Gorham, vice president of equity investments for the Prudential Realty Group. 
 Commercial property auctions, common for centuries in England, are finally taking hold in the United States. Kennedy-Wilson, an auction company based in Santa Monica, Calif., and Jones Lang Wootton, a London-based concern, have auctioned off $750 million worth of commercial properties in the last three years in joint-venture auctions in the United States. Grubb & Ellis/Ross-Dove has moved about $1.5 billion in commercial properties since 1989. And Sheldon Good & Company, the Chicago-based concern that will run the Sept. 20 auction, has moved $3.5 billion in commercial properties since 1964 -- the bulk in the last few years.
"Just like residential auctions became routine in the 1980's, commercial auctions are becoming routine in the 1990's," said Steven L. Good, president of Sheldon Good.
One reason for the lag has been bureaucratic fear. Unlike most residential buildings, commercial properties are usually owned by banks, pension funds, corporations or other institutions. Traditionally, institutions would rather hold onto a cash-draining property than reflect a loss from the sale on their books or face criticism that they used an unproven method to unload it.
"Prudential has not done many auctions because we didn't know how people would react to a traditional company using this newfangled method," Mr. Gorham said.
But the many property auctions that the Resolution Trust Company and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation have held over the last few years has lent respectability to the process. Moreover, desperation for buyers has emboldened portfolio managers to try new techniques, while growing sophistication on the part of buyers has made them more comfortable bidding for properties on an as-is, no-recourse basis.
Those factors, combined with the insistent prodding of commercial auction houses, have induced more institutions to test the waters. Over the last couple of years Chemical Bank, Citibank and Metropolitan Life have all auctioned commercial properties. And auctioneers say real estate executives who once did not return their calls now call them.
"It takes something major to make an institution change, but the depression in the real estate market over the least few years has been major enough," said Simon Milde, who just left Jones Lang Wootton to become president of Kennedy-Wilson.
Corporate pressure on occupancy costs has also boosted auctions' popularity. Corporations have often auctioned off plants and equipment, so the concept is not new to them. And many are recognizing that unneeded real estate can be a nice source of cash.
I.B.M., for one, concluded that it was better off selling a three-building office complex it owns and occupies in Dayton, N.J., and leasing it back for five years or so. Recognizing that such a short leaseback period might put off conventional buyers, I.B.M. is trying the auction route.
"IF we don't get our price, it won't be a disaster," said Anthony Canonaco, an I.B.M. real estate manager, who says the property is carried on the books at less than $10 million. "We really are checking to see if the auction process works well."
Auctioneers say that a growing number of new clients are citing similar reasons.
"Sellers get frustrated when buyers sit on the sidelines trying to figure out when prices are going to bottom," said Charles N. McKinney, an executive of Grubb & Ellis, which will try to auction off 71 properties from 25 owners, with a value of about $500 million, in Dallas on Oct. 7. "In an auction, both buyers and sellers know that the other party is committed to closing the sale."
Not surprisingly, brokers, who lose a potential sales commission every time a building is auctioned, are looking for ways to cash in on the trend. Edward S. Gordon, for one, has gone in with Sheldon Good as a split-fee partner in the Sept. 20 auction.
"Sheldon Good has the marketing distribution network, but we provide the client access, the institutional relationships and the real estate expertise," said Stephen B. Siegel, Edward S. Gordon's chief executive.
No one suggests that auctions are appropriate for all properties. Tiny properties are not likely to glean a high enough selling price to justify the auction house's fee (usually 2 percent to 5 percent of the sale price). And the field of buyers for huge, expensive ones is so small that an auction does not make sense.
Moreover, most buyers willing to pay top dollar for a property want to negotiate financing and other deal terms behind closed doors. On the rare occasions that a large property is put up for bid, it is usually through a sealed-bid process, as was the case when Morgan Stanley successfully bid $176 million for 1585 Broadway, the 41-story tower near 48th Street, this month.
But companies looking to unload properties in the $5 million to $15 million range are finding auctions worthwhile, especially in a real estate market like this one, where no one is certain whether an uptick is imminent.
"It's a psychological thing," said Barry F. H. Graham, vice president-investments for Toronto's Confederation Life Insurance Company. "When you're in a real estate market that's seen better days, you just don't want to make an offer without knowing how others value the property."
Mr. Graham should know: He had tried, without success, to sell an asbestos-laden office building in Calgary for about $200,000. At an auction last November, four bidders bid the property up to $250,000.
"Part of it was the reassurance of seeeing three other guys who also felt the property was worth something, and part of it was the sheer love of the chase," he guessed.
BUYERS say he probably guessed right. After fiercely competitive bidding, Anthony E. Malkin, president of the Manhattan-based property management firm W&M Properties, bought a 70,000-square-foot block of retail space on East 9th Street at auction in March, for $19.527 million.
"We probably paid more than we would have had to pay in a conventional sale, but the auction forces you to pay what the market thinks the property is worth," he said.
For sellers, auctions offer other financial boons. For one thing, auction houses offer marketing economies that few companies could duplicate on their own. Many have offices throughout the world -- Jones Lang Wootton alone has offices in 23 countries. Most distribute glitzy brochures describing the properties and hold preauction previews to answer questions.
Because the auctions generally include buildings owned by several institutions, the cost of the marketing -- normally about half a percent of the lowest price the company will accept for the building -- is distributed among the companies.
"These properties wouldn't merit such marketing attention if we were selling them on our own," said Prudential's Mr. Gorham.
The wider reach, coupled with satellite technology that enables foreign bidders to participate without flying to the auction site, has certainly attracted buyers. A Taiwanese group bought the Minneapolis Doubletree Club Hotel at auction from Chemical Bank, and a group of Mexicans bought the San Diego Kona Kai Inn from First Interstate.
"An auction is not just a sales forum," said Mr. Milde, who estimates that foreigners bought half of the properties that Jones Lang and Kennedy-Wilson have auctioned. "It is a global exchange for real estate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Part of the office complex in Dayton, N.J., that I.B.M. plans to auction and then lease back. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Is Economic Integration A Constitutional Right?

 BODY:
With regard to your article on the Yonkers Housing situation ["Years After Bias Ruling, Yonkers Still a House Divided," Aug. 15], no one has as yet addressed the most important point of the housing issue: Is economic integration a constitutional right? If it is, why do not all Americans have the same right? If it isn't, why are some Americans afforded this as a right while others are not?
Some people have called attention to the fact that these Americans have suffered greatly and have been severely wronged and so we are making an exception to make amends. 
 That answer is not satisfactory. Besides the fact that I do not believe an exception can be made to the Constitution without a constitutional amendment, I do not recall any ethnic group that has come to America, that has not been subjected to persecution, prejudice, bias and many other ills. Somehow they have all managed to overcome the bias and have earned their way to acceptance in American society, in some instances still fighting against existing prejudices.
Can anyone contend that it is legal for a "minority" family with an income of up to $67,000 a year to be subsidized, while a white family with the same income, is not?
It has always been my belief that anyone who can afford to live in any community is entitled to purchase a residence there without any problem. Despite the many charges made against southeast Yonkers (I have lived here for 34 years), our community is totally integrated. Blacks, Hispanics, Asians, Indians, Arabs, Irish, Italian, Jewish -- all live side by side. We have never had any cross burning or other hateful incidents.
With the introduction, however, of 200 units of low-income housing and an additional 800 units of subsidized housing, I am very much concerned with tipping the community, with the resultant middle-income family flight, as occurred in southwest Yonkers, thereby creating the segregation we do not now have. Since we are already racially integrated, it is obviously not racial integration but economic integration that is the motivation.
I would appreciate someone justifying the continuing of an action that most people would consider unconstitutional and, in effect, reverse discrimination, since the economic integration only applies to so-called "minorities."
I personally would be enchanted to live on Sutton Place or on some magnificent estate up north and to be subsidized to live there.
It is beyond comprehension why Judge Leonard B. Sand has refused to recognize the tremendous racial integration of this community since 1980, since ostensibly that was his goal.
One further thought -- social acceptance cannot be legislated. It must come about gradually and naturally through mutually earned respect.
 
MOLLIE F. KATZ
Yonkers

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: At Work;
The Employee Side of Health Care

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON no doubt bowed to political reality two weeks ago when he announced that employers would be the linchpins of health care reform. His alternatives were to ask people to buy health insurance on their own, a turkey sans wings, or to institute a national health plan, which surely would have snapped back into reality anyone who thought anti-Communism was dead. The "employer mandate," as the plan is known in its current form, simply makes the current voluntary system a mandatory one, bringing into the fold employers who, for whatever reason, decline to pay for "fringe" benefits like health care.
No one can say how many policy mutations will occur before the Administration delivers a proposal next month, much less how nibbling by Congress will reconfigure it. The debate will likely be driven by the anxieties of small-business proprietors, who have learned the value of paying dues to leather-lunged organizations that bear their standard in Washington. Companies of all sizes are helping to float the impression floating over the debate -- which resembles a raucous graduate-school seminar -- is that employers will simply eat the cost of increased benefits and deduct the total from the bottom line. Bad for profits, bad for competitiveness and bad for growth, if true. 
 Companies could just quietly absorb the cost, and monkeys pecking randomly on keyboards could eventually write "The Bridges of Madison County." But they -- the companies, not the monkeys -- would violate the First Law of Economic Self-Interest: costs that can be passed on will be. Once the dust settles and the chickens roost on reform, employees will almost certainly feel a nip and tuck somewhere in their compensation packages. Some experts think there will be out-of-pocket costs; some are simply expecting higher taxes. But no one thinks the burden will fall alone, or even most heavily, on companies. "Employees will have to pay," said Arthur Drechsler, a senior vice president at the Segal Company, the benefits consultant.
That may be fair or unfair. There is no shortage of experts who think consumers don't pay enough for their health care choices. The tooth fairy, who has emerged as a major policy player, doesn't pay for health care. As Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told a House subcommittee earlier this year, employees are under the impression they don't pay much for health care. They're wrong. A C.B.O. report last fall put it succinctly:
"At first glance, the employment-based system seems to provide workers with insurance at exceptionally low costs, since employers generally pay most of the premium. But a careful analysis shows that in the long run employers' costs are largely shifted back to workers in the form of lower real wages and reduced nonmedical benefits."
The fact that many companies pay 80 to 90 percent of health benefits looks like generosity but is in reality just good business. Both employers and employees receive tax incentives for benefits -- employers in the form of deductions, employees in the form of untaxed income. (The Employee Benefit Research Institute estimates the Government is letting $138 billion in revenue slide this year by not taxing benefits. About $43 billion of the total figure is for health care.)
Wages and benefits have been the twin threads in total employee compensation packages for decades. During the World War II-Korean War era, when wage increases were controlled by the Government, companies used benefits to compete for workers. The strategic decision by the labor movement, even after wage controls were lifted, to muscle pensions into the collective bargaining arena cemented the employers' role as the conduit for certain social benefits provided by government in other countries.
OVER the years, benefits have become an increasingly important part of compensation, rising, according to data from the United States Chamber of Commerce, to 36.2 percent of wages and salaries in 1987 from 17 percent in 1955. The rise has occurred as wages have stagnated, in part because of increases in the cost of health care itself. Since 1973, the higher cost of health care and other benefits absorbed about half of the real gains in compensation for full-time employees, according to the C.B.O. report.
"This squeeze on real wages, of course, has meant that workers have less to spend on everything else, and have felt their circumstances quite strained," the C.B.O.'s Mr. Reischauer told the House Ways and Means health subcommittee in March.
There is no question that employers have absorbed some of the increased costs of health care, but they have also gained flexibility by containing salary costs, which become institutionalized, while increasing benefits, which can be adjusted more easily. In the 1980's, the growth in benefits slowed, and increasingly companies are requiring their employees to make a direct contribution to help pay for their insurance.
The fact is that even in the downwardly mobile America of the future, where we can all expect to huddle over Sterno cans, companies will still need to compete for workers, and they will probably do it mainly on wages and benefits. But companies have been pushing the competitive baseline back for a decade now. It seems likely that the cost of health care reform will erode the baseline further, a point being lost in the predictable cacophony about assaults on small business and an American way of life.
 
 
 
WHITHER THE LOW WAGE?
 EMPLOYERS unable to pass on the costs of health care to workers -- that is, employers who now pay the minimum or near-minimum wage -- are not without options. They could, for example, rethink their low-wage strategy. "If firms face higher wages, they are forced to raise the productivity of workers. That's good," said Edith Rasell, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. Employers have raised productivity recently by paring workers, but they could do it by reorganizing work or buying new machinery. "Employers are not helpless," Ms. Rasell said.
Much is not known about the details of the Clinton health care reform plan, but it is clear that the wounded cries of low-wage businesses are having an effect. Federal money for benefits may be available, which means that in effect the Government will be subsidizing the low-wage strategy that traps many workers in poverty.

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Woman, Computer Nerd -- and Proud

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER; Katie Hafner, a writer living in Austin, Tex., is co-author of "Cyberpunk: Outlaws and Hackers on the Computer Frontier" (Simon & Schuster).

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
INTRODUCTORY computer science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is called 6.001, or "double-o-one" for short. It is to aspiring computer scientists what anatomy is to first-year medical students. One of M.I.T.'s most demanding courses, 001 is the initial filter for students bold enough to embark on electrical engineering/computer science, the most popular major at what is arguably the most difficult science school in the nation.
The class, which starts again when M.I.T. opens next week, frightens many students, women in particular. Indeed, fields like computer science and engineering have never attracted many women. 
 But 001 and classes like it didn't intimidate Stephanie Winner, Ellen Spertus or Megan Smith. They breezed through M.I.T. and have since gone on to promising careers in computing. Ms. Winner, 29, now designs custom chips that allow the creation of three-dimensional graphics on a computer. Ms. Spertus, 25, is a graduate student at M.I.T. who writes programs that translate code into language a computer can understand. Ms. Smith, 28, is a mechanical engineer who has helped design the new generation of hand-held computers.
The three are not female Einsteins. But they represent a new generation of talented women who are being taken seriously in a field dominated by men. In their undiluted sense of who they are rather than who society says they ought to be, they have spent their lives turning a stereotype -- that women don't belong in technical fields -- squarely on its head.
While the three women differ in many ways, they share at least one thing besides smarts: Each was bolstered early on by family and teachers who instilled in them a sense that they could do anything.
But in the end, they remain the exceptions in a pile of discouraging statistics. While women receive more than half the bachelor's degrees in the United States, they are awarded fewer than a third of the degrees in science and engineering disciplines, and still fewer advanced degrees. In 1990, 13 percent of the Ph.D.'s in computer science went to women. And though women make up nearly half the nation's work force, they account for just 15 percent of employed scientists and engineers.
For a nation increasingly obsessed with its economic competitiveness, these are distressing numbers to ponder as the new school year begins. In effect, the computer industry never sees nearly half its potential talent pool.
Here are the stories of three women who have defied the odds.
 
Stephanie Winner
 Stephanie Winner never had any doubts about what she wanted to become.
She was a natural at math and science. In the eighth grade, she had her father sign a contract agreeing to send her to M.I.T. or Harvard. Her father, Edward Scheidler, is an electrical engineer turned physician. He had two girls and taught them things he would have taught a pair of boys. He showed them how to wire a house and fix the plumbing. Their mother, Bobbie, a homemaker, taught them to cook. On a trip abroad, he gave 10-year-old Stephanie the job of tracking the currency exchange, calculating mileage and devising a budget.
Throughout high school in Traverse City, Mich., she competed with her boyfriend, another math whiz. When she arrived at M.I.T. in 1981, she couldn't help thinking she'd been accepted because she was a female from the Midwest, or worse, that that's what everyone else was thinking about her. The smart, cocky kids from high schools like Bronx Science and Stuyvesant intimidated her. She was terrified of 001, but she did well in the course.
She knew early that she would major in electrical engineering, which focuses on the computers themselves, as opposed to computer science, which focuses on the software. Specializing in the hardware is unusual for a woman. But being outnumbered by men never bothered her. Petite, freckled and strawberry blond, she got a lot of attention -- and enjoyed it. "There was never a problem finding a lab partner," she says.
After she got her master's degree she married another M.I.T. graduate, Jeff Winner, and they settled in Silicon Valley. Ms. Winner started out designing custom chips at Schlumberger, then was hired by Apple Computer.
She works in Apple's Advanced Technology Group, made up of 180 or so researchers. She designs three-dimensional graphics chips, the engines driving some of the hottest areas in computers: virtual reality (computer simulations of real-world environments), computer-aided design (for molecular and industrial modeling, for example) and medical imaging. Blowups of her chip designs, resembling colorful and intricate maps, cover Ms. Winner's office wall like so much found art.
Ms. Winner designs a computer chip much as an architect might conceive a house, or a poet a poem. She starts with a general sense of what it should look like and what its function should be. "I'll know the high level, the chip's overall character or personality," she says. Then she maps its details, figuring out where to place the hundreds of thousands of transistors so that they do their job most efficiently. It is a task that requires an extremely ordered, systematic and patient mind -- and the creativity to find new ways to improve the product.
Designing computer chips doesn't have the immediate feedback that working on software has. If there's a debilitating bug in software, the programmer knows about it pretty quickly. It takes months to produce a chip design, and after that it has to be "taped out" -- sent for fabrication and testing. It's a tense two-month wait. Just when her most recent chip was due back, Ms. Winner went into labor with her second child. As soon as she was out of delivery she called the office to see whether the chip worked. (It didn't -- but the problem was easily fixed.)
Her time at Apple has been revelatory. She has been mistaken for an area associate -- Applespeak for secretary. If she has a meeting with engineers who don't know her, she makes a point of wearing her Brass Rat, the M.I.T. class ring.
Now she has two children, Erin, 2, and Zoe, 1. Like a lot of women who choose to have both a career and children, she has had to change the way she works. She doesn't necessarily work less, but she definitely works more efficiently.
Ms. Winner attributes her success to two factors: her competitiveness and her perfectionism. "Good engineers are always striving to find the best, most innovative solution," she says. "Mediocre engineers just find a solution."
 
Ellen Spertus
 In her scuffed jacket and T-shirt that says "Masochistic Institute of Technology," Ellen Spertus easily fits the "nerd" mold. She is the first to admit that she isn't like a lot of women. She can program circles around most M.I.T. students, and for that she has gained a lot of respect in a male-dominated community where people are judged not by how they look, what they know or who they know, but by the sophistication of the code they can generate.
Ms. Spertus loved 001. She got an A. Handily. She also loved 004, a course in which students build a computer from a "nerd kit" of circuit boards and chips.
It is for people like Ellen Spertus that Gerry Sussman, an M.I.T. computer science professor who lectures in 001, has nurtured the Nerd Pride movement at M.I.T. While outsiders use the word nerd in a derogatory sense, at M.I.T. the generally accepted definition is someone interested in absolutely everything, except dress. It definitely isn't your Doc Martens crowd.
Professor Sussman had thousands of Nerd Pride buttons made and gave them away. "My idea is to present an image to children that it is good to be intellectual, and not to care about the peer pressures to be anti-intellectual," Professor Sussman explains. "I want every child to turn into a nerd -- where that means someone who prefers studying and learning to competing for social dominance."
Ms. Spertus had been intrigued by M.I.T. for a long time. Her father went there and he encouraged her to apply. Growing up in Glencoe, Ill., a Chicago suburb, she admired the institute for its legendary hacks -- technical pranks that usually had nothing to do with computers but that gave computer hackers their name. Great hacks at M.I.T. have included placing a functioning telephone booth atop the campus's Great Dome and fooling students at a Harvard-Yale football game into holding up giant cards that spelled M.I.T.
Philip Spertus describes the day his daughter was accepted at M.I.T. as "the happiest day of our lives."
Ms. Spertus spent her formative years oblivious to words like "barriers" and "discrimination." That she has come as far as she has says as much about her tunnel vision as it does about her brilliance. She gravitated to computers when she was 6. Her father, who runs a picture-frame manufacturing business, kept a computer terminal in the recreation room that was connected to a computer at his office. (Her mother, Sylvia, was a homemaker at the time.) Ms. Spertus ignored the Playskool kitchen in favor of the ungainly piece of hardware. She started out programming in Basic language, and when she got to junior high school she learned Pascal.
She was bored at regular summer camp, so when she was 12 her parents sent her to a computer camp. She was unfazed by the fact that seven out of every eight campers were boys. Quickly singled out as one of the most gifted young coders, she programmed mystery games and music-generating software.
The person who influenced her most was her older brother, Michael, whose mathematical gifts are legendary at New Trier High School. He taught her math when he was 12 and she was in kindergarten. But more important than the math itself was the love of math and computers he conveyed. He told her stories of Archimedes and of the supercomputer designer Seymour Cray. He took her out to play video games. He taught her to play Adventure, a computer-based world of mazes, dragons and trolls. He introduced her to the math club. And like him, she scored a perfect 800 on the math part of her S.A.T.
For a long time, Ms. Spertus assumed that girls were, for the most part, pretty stupid, that she was a genetic accident. So she made friends with boys. It was boys with whom she competed in math class, and on the math team. She gauged the difficulty of a class by looking around the room: the fewer the girls, the more rigorous the class must be.
Her way of interacting with others is perhaps best described as unfiltered. She seems untouched by concerns -- generally associated with females -- of making certain not to offend or of worrying about whether people will like her. Some might say her spontaneous honesty is antisocial. But there is also something fearless about her.
During her undergraduate years, Ms. Spertus again found that she fit in better with the guys, this time at Tech Square, home to M.I.T.'s computer science department. But gradually she came to see that women weren't intellectually inferior at all. Much of this realization came from attending a class taught by a sociology professor, Sherry Turkle, on women in computing. Ms. Spertus saw for the first time that there were barriers to women excelling in science that had nothing to do with intelligence.
Indeed, being a female nerd is far more difficult than being a male nerd. As early as junior high school, girls who pay no attention to their appearance are pariahs. "Appearance is more central to a girl's self-esteem," says Myra Sadker, dean of the School of Education at American University and co-author of "Failing at Fairness: How America's Schools Cheat Girls," due out next year. "Girls get self-esteem by being pretty. You don't open Seventeen Magazine and see nerds. Boys can get away with it more easily by being considered just wacky, or weird."
Few American girls receive the encouragement, either from teachers or from parents, to nurture a scientific bent. Social scientists argue that in adolescence girls lose any sense of being gifted at math or science.
In dozens of ways, teachers unwittingly collude in this. Math and science teachers have been found to seek more eye contact with boys, to call on them more often. If a girl gives the wrong answer, it's wrong; if a boy does, the teacher coaxes out the right one.
For Professor Turkle's class Ms. Spertus wrote a paper on the obstacles women face in getting into computer science. She expanded her paper into a 100-page study titled "Why Are There So Few Women in Computer Science?" The research opened her eyes. Women told her of bias both subtle and not, of difficulty in finding a mentor, of sexual advances that had to be fended off, of problems in getting men to take their work seriously.
Ms. Spertus's paper caused a small stir around Tech Square. It encouraged M.I.T. to take a harder look at courses like 001. Critics of the course say that its aggressive, competitive approach to programming is more geared toward male students, that women prefer more teamwork, less one-upsmanship.
Ms. Spertus is taken seriously because of the quality of her work. Her specialty is the compiler, a program that translates code written by a human into language a computer can understand. The goal is to generate the most streamlined machine-executable code. Ms. Spertus first became interested in compilers in junior high school.
At M.I.T. Ms. Spertus writes compilers of new languages for a novel computer called the M.I.T. J-Machine, which uses many processors working in parallel to compute. She has spent several summers working at the Microsoft Corporation, most recently on compiler research. Once she receives her Ph.D., she'd like to remain in research, either at a company or as a professor.
People who know her agree that what makes her a true computer scientist is her passion for the computer as a thing in itself, as opposed to a mere tool, a means to an end. She considers herself a hacker, in the time-honored Tech Square sense. "A hacker, as opposed to J. Random Programmer, knows the ins, outs and idioms of the machine and languages," she explains.
Ms. Spertus is now in a "tenure-track relationship" with another software engineer. Things are going well. They've yet to encounter the "Two Body Problem," an allusion to a phenomenon in physics called the N Body Problem, which discusses the motion of bodies in a field of force. In academic circles it's a way of describing the problem of a couple looking for jobs in the same city.
 
Megan Smith
 Since Megan Smith was 4 and her mother saw her in the back yard building an ornate scarecrow from sticks and tin foil, her life has been a succession of creative adventures.
In grade school in Buffalo, her role model was Harriet the Spy, the consummate tomboy of children's literature. She and her sister organized a Spy Club. In the seventh grade she and her friends played "Star Trek." Which is not to say she shunned dolls. But young Megan had a lot of other things she wanted to do. She was science-fair champion several years in a row. As a senior she got the school's top prize in math and science.
Encouragement from her parents counted for a lot, Ms. Smith says. Her father, Merle, a public-housing consultant, built science-fair projects with her, and he encouraged her to do a lot of watching, to see a bicycle being repaired, to observe a construction crew at work. (Her mother, Joan, is a teacher.)
By far the biggest influence was her teachers at City Honors, a school for gifted children. Ms. Smith recalls their names the way a gourmand recalls the date, location and menu of a memorable meal.
And they all remember her. Vividly. "Megan was a student who possessed a joy of learning that you read about, and actually see every 30 years," says Barry Soffin, Ms. Smith's favorite math teacher. "She always had this humongous smile on her face. Nothing discouraged her. If you said, 'I don't know the answer,' she'd go dig it up."
After taking Woodie Flowers's mechanical design course at M.I.T., Ms. Smith knew she wanted to be a mechanical engineer. Her obsession was with building objects, especially objects with moving parts.
She may have the brains of a nerd, but she carries herself with an easy grace. There is nothing tentative about her. She is tall, with an athlete's limbs. In fact, she is an outstanding athlete.
Ms. Smith has a way of looking spaced out and thoroughly engaged at the same time. Anything the wind blows her way, Ms. Smith thinks is "cool." Her enthusiasm prompts those around her to want to have something to do with whatever she is doing.
Sports, she thinks, played a large role in building her confidence. She ran cross-country track in high school, and at M.I.T. she rowed and swam competitively. Athletics taught her fortitude and discipline, and the ups and downs that come with competition.
Her computing talent came in handy when she started working at the M.I.T. Media Lab. While there, she completed her master's degree with a project on tactile simulation. She designed a joystick with motors underneath to produce a variety of tactile sensations -- bumpiness, slickness, grittiness. While getting her master's she decided to sit in on the infamous 001 course. "It was cool stuff," she says. "I think I wouldn't have been intimidated like other people."
That is, if she had stayed in town. Instead, she and other M.I.T. students built a solar-powered car and raced it across Australia.
Soon after she completed her master's in 1988, Ms. Smith went to work for Apple Computer's office in Tokyo. Two years later, she joined General Magic, a new company in Mountain View, Calif.
General Magic isn't just any start-up in Silicon Valley. It's the start-up. A spinoff of Apple, it was conceived to build a wireless, hand-held device that combines a computer, fax, beeper and phone. General "Magicians" talk about making history. But there is so much talent at General Magic -- its top engineers supplied the brains behind the original Apple Macintosh -- that one is inclined to forgive them their arrogance.
Ms. Smith thinks General Magic is doing "a really cool thing," but not any cooler than, say, building a solar car, winning a swim meet or working with a bunch of local high school kids. Her first job there was to lead a small team in designing prototypes for the device. Ms. Smith was in charge of the device's human interface -- everything the user would see, hear and feel, such as the touch screens and the speaker.
Ms. Smith and her team sawed, drilled and milled their way through three dozen prototypes. But after that initial design phase came what some of her colleagues describe as her drift away from engineering. She thought it might be fun to work with General Magic's corporate partners -- Sony, Motorola and Philips -- in more of a management role. She now spends weeks at a time in Japan and Europe, working with top executives at the partner firms to coordinate the final design and function of the device.
General Magic cultivates a certain techno-machismo, and Ms. Smith finds it disheartening at times. Engineering a way through a problem often involves confrontation and intellectual jousting. She becomes furious when male engineers at General Magic refuse to include her. "You shouldn't have to become a boy to be an engineer," she says.
She occasionally feels guilty for leaving the technical fray. "It's really, really difficult to let it go because you're a pioneer, an example for younger women, and you need to stay in it," she says. "But then you feel drawn into this other stuff."
 
Beyond the Pioneers
 Sheila E. Widnall is living proof that getting drawn into the "other stuff" can bring great rewards. Dr. Widnall was one of 20 women in a class of 900 when she entered M.I.T. in 1956. "People would stop me in the hall and ask, 'Why are you here?' " she says. She became an aeronautical engineer and associate provost at M.I.T. Last month, President Clinton named the 54-year-old Dr. Widnall as Secretary of the Air Force, making her the first woman in charge of one of the military services.
Dr. Widnall has written and lectured extensively on women in engineering. She thinks that girls who show scientific promise in adolescence need a great deal of encouragement. If it doesn't come at that stage, "it takes you much, much longer to reach a level of autonomy and ability," she says.
Researchers who work with teachers to encourage girls to use computers have seen interest rise dramatically among the girls in those classes. "Even with small, haphazard programs there's a remarkable change," says Dr. Sadker of American University.
If the change proves sweeping enough, women like Stephanie Winner, Ellen Spertus and Megan Smith will someday be far from the only ones who consider it a compliment to be called a nerd.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1071 words

HEADLINE: Profile: Jan Thompson;
Mazda's Hard-Driving Saleswoman

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

DATELINE: IRVINE, Calif.

 BODY:
JAN THOMPSON created quite a stir on her first day of work at the Chrysler Corporation 20 years ago. She was the first female management trainee at the big auto maker's field services division, and the workers there almost tripped over each other to get the lowdown on her.
"I'll never forget that first day," she said. "People were staring at me, car dealers were calling, the regional managers were stopping by the office, all wanting to know what it was going to be like having a woman out in the field. At the time, I was oblivious to the whole thing. It was just a job to me." 
 Two decades later, all eyes are once again focused on the 43-year-old Detroit native, named vice president of sales last week by the Mazda Motor Corporation in a heavy reorganization of its troubled United States operations. The appointment followed the dismissal of five top executives and the announcement of plans to cut 175 employees from Mazda's 500-person headquarters staff here.
The appointment of a woman to such a high position was virtually unheard of among Japanese and even the Big Three auto makers until Ms. Thompson came along. Although she thinks such opportunities are expanding for women worldwide, she is, at the moment at least, arguably the most prominent female executive in the auto industry.
Ms. Thompson said that a ranking female executive is such a rarity in Japan that when she recently had tea with colleagues at a Tokyo coffee house, the waitresses pointed at her, whispering and giggling.
Industry executives and consultants who have worked with Ms. Thompson describe her as a tough, aggressive manager who has a proven track record in marketing, sales and advertising. She is credited with enhancing Mazda's image and with assembling the marketing team that devised the highly successful slogan, "Mazda. It just feels right."
"She's a capable individual who understands how to put together a winning product, and Mazda was very smart to hold onto her," said Christopher Cedergrem, senior vice president for the Auto Pacific Group, a consulting and market-research firm based in Santa Ana, Calif.
J. Ferron, senior partner for J. D. Power & Associates, the automobile consulting firm, called Ms. Thompson a "no-nonsense, extremely intelligent workaholic who has a lot of credibility with Mazda dealers."
"She is not afraid to tell it like it is, which appeals to dealers," he said. "I don't think she suffers fools."
In an interview last week at Mazda headquarters in this community south of Los Angeles, Ms. Thompson spoke about life as an executive for a Japanese company.
"The Japanese don't expect me to walk 10 paces behind them, and chances are that I would already be way ahead of them because I often run down the hallway in a hurry," she said. "These Japanese guys respect good analysis and good opinions and I don't think they really care anymore if it comes from a man or a woman."
But sometimes things can get a little awkward. In Tokyo recently, Ms. Thompson found herself the only woman in a karaoke bar full of auto executives. "I've got the microphone in my hand, and I'm singing in front of all these men, 'Love me tender, love me true,' and I'm thinking to myself this is really weird," she said. "But it's the sort of thing you have to do when in Rome."
In her new role at Mazda, Ms. Thompson will oversee United States sales operations, including marketing and distribution to dealers. "Essentially, her job will be to insure that the right products get to the right customers by coordinating and integrating marketing, ordering and production," Mr. Ferron of J. D. Power said.
This will be no easy task. Japanese auto makers are now facing very tough market conditions. For example, Mazda's United States sales are down 6 percent from last year, hurt by soft demand and a strong yen that makes Japanese cars and other exports more expensive here.
Mazda is taking several steps to deal with these difficult conditions. Besides the dismissals announced last week, Mazda cut 200 jobs last February, and it has initiated a number of cost-cutting measures.
These cutbacks are painful but necessary, Ms. Thompson believes. "Already we have seen that our communications are faster because the organization is streamlined, and that makes us more competitive."
On the sales side, Ms. Thompson said that a top priority will be to supply dealers with cars that are in high demand in order to reduce dealer carrying costs and to raise sales.
"The key to selling product quicker is getting the right product to the dealer, not necessarily a bigger rebate," she said. "We can't continue to afford bigger rebates, so I would like to saturate market demand first." To do so, she must identify which models are the hottest sellers in which regions, and then speed up production and delivery of those cars to the appropriate dealers.
Ms. Thompson will also place heavy emphasis on selling the 626 and Mx6 models, which are built in the United States and are not subject to the fluctuations of the yen.
ALTHOUGH she arrives at the office at 7 A.M. and does not leave until 12 hours later, Ms. Thompson denied that she is a workaholic, saying that work is just what she enjoys most.
Still, the executive finds time to jog three miles a day, and is an avid golfer and serves on the board of the Ladies Professional Golf Association.
Ms. Thompson said she picked up golf out of necessity as a young district manager for Chrysler in 1974. "I called on a dealer one day and he said, 'Girl, do you play golf?' I said that I could hit it, and he said, 'If you want to make it in this business you have to play golf.' So I learned."
Ms. Thompson began her career at Chrysler after receiving a B.A. in marketing from Western Michigan University in Kalamazoo, and an M.B.A. from the University of Detroit.
She worked at Chrysler for 12 years in various field positions in Detroit, Denver and Los Angeles, leaving in 1984 for Toyota, where she held a number of marketing and advertising positions, the last as national marketing manager for the Lexus division. She has served as Mazda'svice president of marketing from 1988 until her recent promotion.
Ms. Thompson, who is single, said her favorite pastime is taking her white Miata convertible out for a spin on the Pacific Coast Highway, with her musician of choice playing on compact disk. Her current favorite: Kenny Loggins.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/August 22-27

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Will the Bulls of August Hibernate Come October? 

Anyone out there superstitious? Six Augusts ago, stock prices soared to record levels, and you know what happened two months later. Last week the Dow, like a sprinter on steroids, kept knocking off records, hitting 3,652.09 on Wednesday before retreating slightly by the end of the week. Why such bullishness? Interest rates, of course. With bond yields almost invisible, where else to put money besides stocks? But one investment strategist had another reason: "Congress and the President are on vacation, so they can't possibly do any damage until after Labor Day." Can't argue with that. Does this mean stocks are teetering on a cliff? Maybe. The worriers say that in search of yields, investors have taken on too much risk in stocks. But note that in 1987 the Dow rose 44 percent from Jan. 1 to its August peak, while this year it has crept ahead just 10 percent. So the answer is . . . well, check back in October.

Economy's Up, Economy's Down
 
Confused about the economy's health, as good news alternates maddeningly with bad? Take heart: clarity is on the way. "We'll have to wait until after Labor Day," a Treasury official said last week, "just to know what the economy is doing now." The official was commenting on the latest pair of seesaw numbers, a 5.4 percent jump in existing-home sales in July, balanced by a 3.8 percent drop in factory orders, the sharpest in 19 months. The rise in home sales is understandable, given bargain-basement mortgage rates, but factory orders show that manufacturing remains sickly.
 
Phone Concerns Win on TV . . .
 
Telecommunications. It's a household word, but it's certainly not spoken in many households. Not yet. In the home of the future, all our overlapping gadgets could be banished in favor of a "telecommunications set," used to make calls, get news, order pizza, watch movies, pay bills -- and do things not yet dreamt of. It's coming: Last week a Federal court ruled that phone companies could deliver their own television programming, paving the way for a pitched battle, or new cooperation, with the cable folks. The ruling was a victory for Bell Atlantic, which plans 384 channels in Alexandria, Va., and, some say, a victory for consumers: competition could mean lower prices. But 384 channels? It makes the head spin.
 
 . . . but Cable Wins One, Too
 
A high-stakes game of chicken between network television and cable operators ended as the last network gave in. Networks had the right to demand fees for the use of their signals, but cable said, "Forget it: we'll just drop the networks." So the choice would have been cable without networks or networks without cable, either one of which sounds vaguely un-American. But cable's bluff was apparently the more terrifying, for one by one the networks blinked, with CBS last week joining its colleagues in dropping demands for fees.
 
'Star Wars II': A Trip to Mars?
 
The apparent failure of the Mars Observer could put the Government in the recycling business. As hope dwindled last week for renewed contact with the wayward spacecraft, ideas started cropping up at NASA and at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., about new, cheaper ways to get a peek at the elusive planet. One idea that will surely appeal to enemies of Government waste: modifying small, inexpensive "Star Wars" satellites and hurling them toward Mars. ("Inexpensive," of course, does not mean $29.95; more like $75 million, but that's a far cry from $1 billion for the Mars Observer.) And another idea would be closer collaboration with Europe and Russia. We're in this together, after all.
 
Wetlands: There's a Timely Topic
 
Wetlands are always a hot issue, especially in their role as wildlife habitats, but they also play a role in flood protection -- a timely topic. Last week, even as the boss was getting wet with the Kennedys, the Administration put its stamp on wetlands policy, and ended up in the soggy middle of the road. It did protect more Alaska wetlands and closed some loopholes for developers. But some environmentalists said it just opened other loopholes. One commitment remains, though: no further net loss of wetlands. The Government estimates that in the 48 states, wetlands have shrunk from 230 million acres to 100 million since the Europeans waded ashore.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
City Hall, Maybe, but Wal-Mart?
 
There was a certain tilting-at-windmills quality to a court battle joined last week in Arkansas. Local druggists say Wal-Mart tried to drive them out of business by selling goods below cost. But could the clock really be turned back? Much as one may lament the passing of "It's a Wonderful Life"-era druggists, the Wal-Mart Age is undeniably here. You can't keep 'em down on the farm once they've seen a superstore. And are "loss leaders" anything new? Groceries from Mom & Pop to Stop & Shop have used them for years.
 
You Don't Even Need a Ladder
 
Going to Toys "R" Us is, well, awesome. A stark warehouse with endless canyons stuffed ceiling-high with every toy imaginable -- and some beyond imagining. If parents think their children have a lot of toys, the staggering volume quickly trims those thoughts down to size. But wait -- does a restful oasis loom? Toys "R" Us said last week that by October, 170 of its stores will have Books "R" Us departments -- carpeted, low-rise pockets of child-friendliness that will even have (gasp!) salespeople. Since children "don't typically want to go to a bookstore," a company executive said, this was a perfect opportunity.
 
Lashing Out at Health Fraud
 
Health care fraud is definitely a big-ticket item on this nation's balance sheet; any tinkering with the system will mean little unless abuse can be tamed. Last week the Feds took on what they see as a prime culprit, raiding offices and hospitals run by National Medical Enterprises. Officials said National Medical had conspired to defraud patients and insurers, and the company is already being sued by a dozen insurers and 130 former patients. And they're not talking about painless number-juggling; many lawsuits contend the unthinkable: that patients were held in psychiatric hospitals unnecessarily.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Getting Tough With China
 
With China, politics and commerce often collide, and something's got to give. President Clinton, after promising toughness on human rights, extended China's most-favored-nation status. But last week, in American eyes, the offense was more severe. Accusing the Chinese of selling missile technology to Pakistan, the United States said it would ban almost $1 billion in high-tech exports to China. That, of course, hurts companies like Hughes Aircraft, which has contracted to sell China a satellite and a ground station for $80 million.
 
Japan's Humbled Auto Makers
 
Is mighty Japan really losing its magic on the world auto stage? Consider last week's news: Mazda dismissed its top American executive and said it would cut its headquarters staff in California by 35 percent. Honda continued its startling nosedive by posting quarterly earnings off 62 percent; it's got a lot riding on a new Accord to be unveiled this week. And Toyota, announcing a 26 percent profit drop for its fiscal year, suggested the unthinkable: a loss next year if the yen stays strong. It would be the first operating loss ever. And the exchange rate is not Toyota's only enemy: even in Japan sales were off 7.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Brick Sidewalks And the Test of Time

 BODY:
I was pleased to see the Aug. 1 article "Preservation Battle Over a Firehouse." While the Ridgewood Firehouse issue has many pros and cons, may I take a moment to refer to another aspect of Ridgewood that most people would probably feel is a positive step in the revitalization of downtown Ridgewood: new sidewalks.
The use of a red brick border motif gives a unique character to an otherwise prosaic project -- mundane sidewalks. While the laying of a concrete sidewalk exhibits a high level of industrial art, the proper placement of red bricks reflects pure artistry. 
 Others may only see the denotation of the red bricks in terms of their practicality: something to walk upon. I, however, see the connotation: the intregration of downtown Ridgewood into a unity of expression rather than a diverse assemblage of old "taxpayer" buildings.
Now comes the blow. The question may well be asked as to how long the red bricks will survive.
About five years ago, while visiting Salem, Mass., I walked about Pickering Wharf, where new red brick sidewalks had been hurriedly laid. Within a few years, they were already upheaving and cracking.
I also walked in the older area of Salem, where huge homes were set back from the curb, similar to what we see on many Ridgewood streets. The homes were lined up in a manner that reminds one of well-trained soldiers in serried, straight-as-an-arrow ranks. The unifying motif of these streets was the red brick sidewalks, which have lasted 200 years.
Will Ridgewood's red bricks also stand the test of time?
 
JOSEPH P. MCMANEMIN
Ridgewood

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Failed Stores Now a Cabaret

BYLINE: By David J. Wallace

 BODY:
LATE next month, a 300-seat cabaret is scheduled to open here in what once was an 8,000-square-foot The Limited clothing store in a failed retail center known as Newmarket.
The first production by the cabaret's owners, Shelly Gross and Allen Shore (the latter was an original co-producer of "Driving Miss Daisy"), will be "Forever Plaid." Mr. Gross would discuss neither the terms of the five-year lease nor the cost of the renovations. 
 "There's been a need for a really nice off-Broadway kind of theater in Philadelphia for some time," said Mr. Gross, who owns the theaters in the Valley Forge Music Fair in suburban Philadelphia and the Westbury Music Fair on Long Island. "We'd like to see a series of art galleries, boutiques, and food there and redevelop the whole Newmarket property.'
Newmarket's owners, Gloria Levin and Michael diPaolo, spent about $8 million to acquire the three-acre site near the thriving Delaware River waterfront in 1986 and expect renovations to reach $7 million. Ms. Levin said the renovation financing would come from public and private sources.
The site was named in 1745 as the city's second open-air produce and food market. Several 18th-century structures were retained in a modern retail and restaurant project that opened there in 1975 with 50,000 square feet, 40 percent of which was devoted to restaurants.
The property covers Front Street to Head House Square -- which replaces Second Street -- between South and Lombard Streets.
Ms. Levin conceded that the image of Newmarket for many younger people was that of a dormant retail center.
"Whenever there's a project that's had problems, it's always a tough sell," she said. "But there's tremendous proximity to all the shops and restaurants in the South Street area and we're close to the waterfront."
A 500-seat theater is planned in a new 10,000-square-foot structure, contingent on getting a tenant, she said. Several restaurants, galleries and shops are proposed to serve both tourists and the dense residential population nearby.
Communty opposition to a parking garage, as well as the recession, delayed Newmarket's revival, she said. A 245-space parking lot proved the compromise.
Early this year, South Street merchants formed a special services district for street cleaning, security and joint promotions for the area. Property owners and commercial tenants will pay a 7 percent assessment this year to raise $256,000 for the group.
The district is bounded by Front Street on the east, 11th Street on the west, Lombard Street on the north and Bainbridge Street on the south.
"South Street stores are probably 95 percent full right now," said Harris Eckstut, chairman of the district and owner of the Montserrat restaurant there. "South Street's been here for nearly 300 years. We are looking forward to another 300 years."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Making Japan Cheaper For the Japanese

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
PRIME MINISTER MORIHIRO HOSOKAWA finally brought his campaign for sweeping change to Parliament last week, only to get heckled, then challenged for being vague in his prescriptions for giving the long-suffering consumer a break from Japan's famously high prices. But if there was a lesson in this bruising start, it was that the best place to watch for real reform may not be the imposing Parliament building but Yukio Higuchi's liquor stores.
Mr. Higuchi runs that rarest of Japanese companies, a discounter. He also relies heavily on imports, and so the soaring value of the yen recently has been a godsend, allowing him to undercut domestic spirits producers and the legions of stodgy retailers who refuse to pass along the benefits of the strong currency to their customers. 
 The price of a bottle of Chivas Regal scotch at his stores, Kawachiya Shuhan, has tumbled from 3,500 yen last September to 2,690 yen, or the current equivalent of $25.90, while Early Times bourbon now runs 1,490 yen a bottle, or $14.35, down from 1,980 last fall.
There are a growing number of such agents of change here these days, retailers trying to deliver what even American trade negotiators are demanding, a welcome for imports. They are also delivering the sort of savings Mr. Hosokawa and his new Government have advocated in their efforts to turn four decades of economic policy on its head; he wants the Government to favor corporate Japan less and its consumers more.
But Mr. Higuchi's entrepreneurial instincts have run smack into the most conservative force in Japan, the bureaucracy.
It is almost impossible to obtain new liquor licenses in Tokyo, so Mr. Higuchi has been purchasing small shops and expanding their premises to produce the sales volumes he needs to thrive. It seemed a clever way to build the business until the Finance Ministry's tax authorities laid a snare. Last month they issued a "guidance," an informal dictate restricting his ability to buy and expand stores. "This guidance is just intended to crush discounters," Mr. Higuchi howled. "But my hopes are high for Mr. Hosokawa."
Mr. Hosokawa's Government faces many tests, such as cleaning up the electoral system and meeting President Clinton's economic demands, but the most decisive may be whether it can deliver relief to a people who have started to realize that it may not be essential to the nation's health for its consumers to pay among the highest prices in the world.
As bad as price differentials have been in the past, they are worse now because the yen has risen to record levels on currency markets. (The dollar closed Friday in New York at $103.85 yen.) In dollar terms, many Japanese prices have gone from outrageous to ridiculous.
A movie ticket here costs the equivalent of more than $17, compared to $7.50 in New York. A Big Mac at McDonald's is $3.66, 20 percent more than the New York version. And the average price for an apartment -- whose average size in Tokyo is 680 square feet -- was an astounding 50.66 million yen, or $488,000.
Economists say that in most instances these differentials are a product of Government policies, such as tax laws, or a byzantine distribution system that inflates prices. And then there is the bureaucracy.
 
Protection or Intimidation?
 Toshio Miyaji, who owns several chains of stores that discount electronic appliances and other consumer products, said the Health and Welfare Ministry all but prohibited him recently from selling famous foreign brand name cosmetics because he refused to place a label on the goods identifying the importer. The ministry says the rule is for consumer protection. Mr. Miyaji suggested it was a ruse to flush out importers who defy the usual retail system by selling goods to discounters, and thus amounted to a subtle form of intimidation.
"This is like fighting against the Berlin Wall," he said. "I'm determined to keep up my efforts until it comes down."
One of the most telling aspects of Mr. Hosokawa's stated ambition to tear down this economic wall is that he had to mention the need to pass along the benefits of the stronger yen to consumers. In a market economy, the theory goes, clever businessmen will undercut retailers who refuse to reduce prices on imports. Open-minded consumers, of course, will flock to those stores.
The mind-set opposing such a tactic is so ingrained here, though, that it is taking an initiative from the nation's leader to spread the message that price competition is a good thing.
An important factor helping Mr. Hosokawa is that big corporations have started to jump on the deregulation bandwagon, even though they benefited from the Government's big-business orientation in the past. With the strong yen hurting exports and a recession stifling growth, companies are looking to a freeing up of domestic markets as a way to generate new sales.
"I think deregulation efforts haven't borne any fruit yet because the system remains stiff," Isao Ichikawa, vice chairman of the Nikon Corp., said in a newspaper interview. "I'm afraid the Japanese economy will sink unless we take more steps to decontrol and deregulate."
And the business establishment has been weighing in with reports to encourage the trend. The Japan Research Institute, which is affiliated with the Sumitomo Bank, said last week that a package of broad deregulation would create nearly 12 trillion yen of new economic activity, or the equivalent of $120 billion.
"The changes are already started," insisted Haruo Shimada, an economist at Keio University and an adviser to the new Government. "Each step may be small, but if you take 2,000 such steps things start to happen. The bottom line is that market forces are penetrating."
Even the Finance Ministry has responded to Mr. Hosokawa's call for each ministry to draw up a list of regulations it is willing to streamline quickly. The Finance Ministry thought it over and said that it had decided to relax the regulations on obtaining licenses to open liquor stores.
