HEADLINE: County's Anti-Gay Move Catches Few by Surprise

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARIETTA, Ga., Aug. 27

 BODY:
There are not many counties in America more conservative than this one, where the main stretch of interstate highway is named for a former John Birch Society president who represented the area in Congress and where the town of Kennesaw made national news a few years back by enacting an ordinance that required all residents to keep a firearm and ammunition at home.
So it was not entirely out of character when the Cobb County Board of Commissioners passed a resolution this month condemning homosexuality, and then decided to cut off all arts financing rather than have to decide what art offended community values. 
 But even those appalled by the emotional showdown over values that played out here say the dispute in this prosperous suburb, one of the fastest-growing counties in America, reflects a lot more than Cobb County's eccentricities. Cobb County may be more conservative than most places, many residents say, but both the suburban good life that draws people here and the economic and social unease in the air fit very much into the national mood.
 
'Fear and Frustration'
 "I don't think that Marietta, Ga., is so unlike the rest of the country," said Michael Horne, a co-founder of the local Theater in the Square, whose mainstream fare somehow set the flap in motion. "I think some well-meaning people have been incited by a few politicians nurtured by a fringe element of the population. But I think there's so much fear and frustration out there that no matter where you live this kind of thing could exist."
The five-member Board of Commissioners capped a month of controversy on Tuesday by unanimously deciding to cut out the $110,000 in arts financing in its 1994 budget, rather than decide which art was in keeping with community values.
Two weeks earlier, after one resident wrote a commissioner to complain about references to homosexuality in a play at Theater in the Square, the commissioners passed a resolution supporting "the traditional family structure" and condemning "the life styles advocated by the gay community" as incompatible with Cobb County standards.
The furor here partly reflected the desire of commissioners to make a statement in opposition to neighboring Atlanta, where officials recently agreed to grant domestic partnership status to the partners of gay city employees.
But Cobb County has a long tradition of vociferous conservatism and a climate in which those at the outer edge of right-wing politics have felt at home.
 
2 Cobb Counties
 This is where J. B. Stoner, convicted of the 1958 bombing of a black church in Alabama, mounted a white supremacist run for lieutenant governor in 1990.
But fringe extremists aside, for the most part there are two Cobb counties, both of them largely white and conservative and very much apart from Atlanta on the other side of the Chattahoochee River.
There are older towns like this one, with its rustic town square, proud Southern sensibilities and disdain for the more urban, largely black world in Atlanta. And there are newer generic subdivisions in East Cobb full of corporate transplants and suburbanites looking for cheaper housing, less crime and better schools than they expect to find in urban America.
The county has grown explosively in recent years, its population increasing by 50 percent between 1980 and 1990, to its current 470,000. In 1950, the population was only 61,830. The number of jobs in the county more than doubled between 1980 and 1990, in part because of the growth of the military industry. The largest employer is the Lockheed Aeronautical Systems plant, which is building F-22 fighter jets.
 
Little Gay Presence
 But Cobb's success has only heightened the desire of some leaders to differentiate the county from Atlanta. Gordon Wysong, the Commissioner who led the push for the two resolutions, said Cobb was standing up for the values of "ordinary citizens."
"People are fed up with having the gay agenda crammed down their throat and told that they can't articulate their position because it's not politically correct," he said.
There is very little visible gay presence in Cobb County, but Mr. Wysong and his supporters cited issues like homosexuals in the military and school curricula that they say is sympathetic to homosexuals as reasons to express their opposition.
He said calls to the county had been overwhelmingly supportive of both resolutions. Making a statement against homosexuality seems entirely natural and appropriate to many people here.
"I'm a Christian, and I don't want my children taught that homosexuality is an acceptable life style," said Letha Faulkner, who was watching her toddler play on the toy train on the square here.
 
'This Is a True Embarrassment'
 But many residents, particularly in East Cobb, think the last month has seen a sort of hysteria that was more representative of the views of religious extremists than of the community as a whole.
"This is a true embarrassment, because I know most of my friends don't feel this way," said Suzi Bass, an actress who moved to the county 15 years ago from Lexington, Ky. "You will find Cobb countians to be loving and giving, educated, feeling, sensitive people."
Still, the emotions are not the only muddled thing in Cobb County.
The cutoff of the tiny arts spending (the $123,000 being spent this year is part of a $142 million budget) was not a particular surprise in view of the anti-tax sentiments its residents share with people in many places in the country. On the other hand, Common Cause, the public interest group, reports that Cobb, largely because of aerospace spending, receives more Federal money than any other suburb except Arlington County, just outside Washington, and Brevard County, Fla., home of the Kennedy Space Center.
And despite the county's phenomenal growth, there is widespread concern about jobs and economic security, particularly with cuts in military spending.
 
'Lot of Insecurity'
 "Look at them," said Jack Landers, who owns a check-cashing business, pointing to a group of elderly people. "You know they're wondering about Social Security, will it be cut back or cut off? There's a lot of insecurity around. You wonder if you'll be able to afford the same life style in five years that you have now."
Just as Mr. Wysong has a Rush Limbaugh magnet on the light switch in his office, there is no question Cobb County is much closer to the national mainstream than it used to be. When the former John Birch Society leader, Larry McDonald, represented the area in Congress until his death in 1983, he was a fringe figure in Washington. Now 70 percent of the county is represented by Newt Gingrich, who is the House minority whip.
And, as a raft of resolutions and ballot proposals around the nation indicate, Cobb is not the only place where homosexuals have become a focus for powerful emotions.
"We no longer have to fear the Communists, we no longer have to fear Russia, but there's always got to be somebody to generate negative emotions toward," said Cherry Spencer-Stark, chairman of the Theater in the Square. "There's always got to be the low man on the totem pole. And right now, in this country, it happens to be lesbians and gays."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 31, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about a resolution in Cobb County, Ga., condemning homosexuality referred incorrectly to findings of a study on the county's share of Federal spending. Common Cause magazine found that Cobb had received more Federal money than all but two suburban counties per capita, not in total.

LENGTH: 1653 words

HEADLINE: Football at Monmouth College: It's a Whole New Ball Game

BYLINE: By ARTHUR Z. KAMIN

DATELINE: WEST LONG BRANCH

 BODY:
THE first game is not until Sept. 11, but the advent of intercollegiate football at 60-year-old Monmouth College has already gripped this picturesque 125-acre campus with an excitement seldom felt since the protest days of the 1960's or since the filming of "Annie" here in the early 1980's.
Since Aug. 15, 87 members of the Hawks, as the new team is known, have been hard at work in the shadow of a $250,000 stadium under construction. Their first opponent ever will be Stonehill College in North Easton, Mass. Four home games and two other away games will follow. 
 While the enthusiasm is palpable here, pigskin fever hardly erupted from unanimous love for the sport. Some early skeptics were concerned about the costs of starting a major program, and others wondered if it would send the wrong signals about the college's academic standards.
But Monmouth officials are blunt when they predict that football will help pad the college's $12.3 million endowment and add perhaps $500,000 to $750,000 to the college's annual fund drive, which usually brings in about $215,000.
"Football might just be the spark that we need," said Sara E. Smith, the vice president for institutional advancement.
Officials also suggest that their Division I-AA, nonscholarship team can help give their school a kind of brand-name recognition that is akin to buying prime-time advertising.
So no wonder that the cheerleading squad, a fixture at Monmouth's basketball games, has a new part-time director who is preparing the squad to lead football cheers. A pep band is being formed, and Monmouth fight songs are being written. Students are lining up for jobs as ushers, ticket and program sellers, food vendors and parking attendants.
The stadium, which will seat 3,000, is expected to be ready for the home opener against Sacred Heart University of Fairfield, Conn., on Sept. 25.
The alma mater, now played only at commencement and convocation ceremonies, is being dusted off to be sung at games. Mary Anne Nagy, the acting dean of campus life, said there would be practice sessions to teach students the words, which were written 10 years ago by a Monmouth music professor, Dr. William A. Wollman. "We need more school spirit," Ms. Nagy said.
Plenty of that certainly seems at hand: Monmouth's seven fraternities and five sororities are preparing to welcome alumni on homecoming weekend amid plans for a bonfire, a concert, a reception for parents and a student king and queen contest. The homecoming game, against Hartwick College of Oneonta, N.Y., will be on Oct. 23.
Thomas P. Zambrano, the college's 33-year-old police chief and a 1986 alumnus, is drawing up parking, traffic and crowd-control plans for all the games. He is also getting out the word that the local and campus police will be on the lookout for postgame drunkenness by fans either toasting victory or drowning their sorrows after defeat.
 
Opposition From Some
 Not everyone agreed from the start that football would be a good thing to add to college life here. The board of trustees approved a football program in June 1992 only after the Select Committee on Intercollegiate Athletics, which had studied the idea for nine months, recommended the program. It did so despite opposition from some faculty members, students and environmentalists who predicted that football would drain resources from already struggling academic programs.
An editorial in the student newspaper, The Outlook, said, "This school should embark on the longer road of building a reputation based upon scholarly achievements."
Even so, the board's approval put the football program on a lightning-fast track, and now there is hardly a corner of this campus that has not been touched.
 
16th Varsity Sport
 Monmouth, which had humble beginnings during the Depression as a junior college housed in nearby Long Branch High School, is now a private four-year, comprehensive regional college offering more than 45 degree programs and concentrations. Its student body has grown to 3,000 undergraduates and 1,500 graduate students. Football is its 16th varsity sport.
The team members -- 75 freshmen and 12 transfers and upperclassmen decked out in new gear -- are being guided by a new coach, an assistant coach and six part-time assistants. Their practice sessions are drawing visits by the new college president, Dr. Rebecca Stafford.
Dr. Stafford, the first woman to be Monmouth's president, took over on July 1. Although several college trustees recalled that she had some misgivings about the new program, they said she has became a strong supporter.
Dr. Stafford, a Radcliffe graduate who fondly recalls attending Harvard games, said that the program here would raise awareness of Monmouth's name and that football would "help create a greater sense of community" and involve alumni in new ways.
She also said she was impressed by the academic quality of many on the team. "They are going to add an important dimension as well to our student life program," she said. "I'd say it was courageous to start football at this time."
At the same time, she said she would be monitoring the program closely to make certain it "maintains high standards" and "pays its own way."
 
Players Called 'Pioneers'
Upholding those criteria will be the job of the program's new head coach, Kevin Callahan, 38, who arrived at Monmouth from Colgate University, where he had served as defensive coordinator for eight years.
"These players are pioneers," Coach Callahan said. "They're here because they want a good education and the thrill of being part of a program that is brand-new and started from scratch. We are beginning a new tradition."
Rich Bargloski, a 5-foot-11-inch, 180-pound quarterback who was an honor student at Lacey High School, agrees. He said he could have attended any of three other colleges but chose Monmouth because of its coach, its academic quality and its campus. In addition, he described the financial aid package the college put together for him as "the best of any school."
Chris Colon, a 5-foot-8-inch, 185-pound running back who earned a B-plus average at St. Joseph's of the Palisades High School in West New York, liked the idea of being close to home and part of a program that gave him an oportunity to play immediately as a freshman. Grants, loans and work-study aid will take care of most of his college costs. Because Monmouth football is a nonscholarship program, the financial aid packages are tied to need.
Tuition at Monmouth is $11,300 a year, with room and board at about $5,000 a year.
 
Increase in Enrollment
 The college expects a freshmen enrollment of about 495 this fall, about a seventh of whom will be on the team.Last year there were 434 freshmen.
"For a school that counts on and is driven by tuition revenue, this added enrollment is very important to us," said Robert J. Mika, executive director of enrollment management.
Ronald J. Wronko, the editor in chief of The Outlook, said he had been one of the first to voice skepticism about starting a football program in uncertain economic times. But he said the open campus dialogue on the issue had helped to sway him, as did a student referendum in which the program was supported by a 338-to-81 vote.
Richard M. Schwartz, the senior vice president for finance and administration, who is overseeing the program, said the program's startup costs were $130,000. This year $400,000 has been budgeted for football, including coaches' salaries and $35,000 in added insurance costs.
 
Donations Received
 Mr. Schwartz said $130,000 had been donated to the program by corporations, alumni and friends of the college, including an anonymous gift of $10,000.
The stadium is being paid for with a $250,000 donation from John H. Kessler, chairman of J.B. Hanauer & Company of Parsippany, a securities brokerage concern, and his wife, Henni Kantor Kessler, a former president of Shoes Plus. The donation includes money for an electronic scoreboard, a ticket gate, goalposts and field equipment. Not surprisingly, the new stadium will be called Kessler Field.
Mrs. Kessler, a 1968 graduate who was a cheerleading captain, is a college trustee. Mr. Kessler, who graduated in 1969, played baseball and is on the college's board of visitors. They live in Verona.
 
Benefit to Bookstore Seen
One of the first beneficiaries of the football program has been the college bookstore, which has gross sales of about $1.6 million a year. William T. Rainey, the store's manager, predicted an increase of about $30,000 to $40,000 in sales relating to football shirts, hats, banners and other regalia.
Last year, a hastily created Monmouth football polo shirt went on sale after the trustees made the football announcement, and the stock sold out in weeks, Mr. Rainey said. He plans to pitch a tent satellite store near the stadium during home games.
"I think we're going to do very well," Mr. Rainey said.
For the first home game, Prof. Lauren K. Woods, who teaches theater and speech, is trying to get Jeff Keller, an alumnus who is a member of the Broadway cast of "Phantom of the Opera," to sing the national anthem. Professor Woods said Mr. Keller was seeking to arrange his schedule to attend.
On Oct. 2 at home the Hawks will play their only New Jersey opponent, St. Peter's of Jersey City. Other games are on Oct. 16, in Loretto, Pa., against St. Francis College; Nov. 6 at home against Wagner of Staten Island and Nov. 13 in Reading, Pa., against Albright.
And thanks to football, no longer will there be any questions about what is the correct shade of school-color blue, Mr. Schwartz said. It's always been a guessing game.
From now on, there will be a Monmouth blue, a combination of navy and royal with a dab of gray to lighten it up. And the block M, used on shirts and book covers and notebooks, is also being standardized.

HEADLINE: The Hunt for the Tourist Dollar

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
THE firefighters' parade here had brought people onto the streets, so there was quite a crowd on hand last Sunday when four enormous air-conditioned tour buses wound through the downtown area. There were also a lot of surprised faces. The buses held more than 300 tourists from New York City and New Jersey who were being ferried through town as part of a daylong outing to two Historic Hudson Valley sites. They had taken a boat cruise up the Hudson River from Weehawken, N.J., and Manhattan to Tarrytown, and then boarded the buses for visits to Philipsburg Manor, a working Dutch Colonial farm, and Sunnyside, the home of Washington Irving.
"I noticed the local people were looking at us like 'Why are they here?' " said Christina Chiang, who with her husband, Matthew, came from North Bergen, N.J., to take the tour. "But I think it's very nice here, very romantic and natural. We like to travel, especially to places that have an interesting history."
 
One-Day Tourists to Conventions
 Increasingly, the county is being marketed as a tourist destination, surprising residents who see their communities as just places to live. The Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau, a partnership between the county and the Westchester Chamber of Commerce, coined the term "the Golden Apple" more than a decade ago to promote what they say is the county's unique charm: an appealing balance of bucolic countryside and suburban sophistication. 
 "I think we have to aim for everything from the one-day tourist to the convention visitor," said Andrew P. O'Rourke, the County Executive. "Money spent on tourism is well spent. There are a lot of advantages and truly no disadvantages, because the money that is spent comes from out of town."
The Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau, whose mission is to attract all kinds of visitors to the county, is financed by part of the 3 percent county hotel room tax. Mr. O'Rourke said he hoped to raise the hotel tax to 5 percent. The Visitors Bureau said it received $282,600 last year from the hotel tax. Mr. O'Rourke added that tourism also represented a "soft-sell economic development possibility" because visitors to Westchester are potential clients who might move into the county for housing or to set up a business.
 
The Dollars Add Up
 Eager as they are to show off Westchester's attractions, those active in promoting tourism here are primarily interested in the dollars it brings into the county. According to the Visitors Bureau, 72,000 tourists have been attracted here since its establishment in July 1990 until last June. The visitors spent $36 million while here, with $4.8 million spent on lodging and $31.2 million on meals. Those expenditures generated $1.6 million in hotel room and sales taxes.
The figures do not include tourists who arrived independently of the bureau's promotions, said Harold E. Vogt, the bureau's chairman and president and chief executive officer of the County Chamber of Commerce. Further, he said, the United States Travel Data Center estimates that for every dollar spent for lodging in the New York City area, an additional $1.80 will be spent for other items. Also, leisure or day visitors to the county will spend an average of $50.70 for meals, admissions to attractions, shopping and various other purchases.
In Westchester, tourists belong to two main groups: the leisure traveler -- in the county for a day or two to enjoy the local sights -- and the business visitor.
 
Going to the Beach Gets Old
 Those who took the Hudson cruise, basking in the sunlight as the boat navigated its way north, were thinking about escaping the city for the day or just doing something novel, not about the county's economy.
"Going to the beach gets old," said Kimberly Hull of Manhattan as the boat approached the George Washington Bridge. "We wanted to get out of the city for the day, but we didn't want to rent a car, so we did this. It was kind of spur-of-the-moment. It's nice to have something else to do."
Betsy Brody of Manhattan said: "This is something different instead of just going out and eating brunch and going to a movie. I love historic sites, and it's nice to get away from Manhattan. Westchester is so close but it's so pretty and different. It feels far away."
The boat tours, which are run by Port Imperial Ferry Service of Weehawken, began in June and will run through Oct. 9. Ferries leave from Weehawken, pick up more passengers at 38th Street and 12th Avenue in Manhattan and then travel up to Tarrytown on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. The outing represents the kind of tourism that county officials say they hope will be a growing trend.
 
'They Are Going to Spend'
 "We have one of the most beautiful valleys in the world and promoting it and the Hudson River for tourism is the project of the future," said Evelyn Carnicelli, director of the county's Office of Tourism. "Tour boats dropping people off -- this is going to be one of the biggest economic home runs for Westchester County. Not only are we going to promote the idea of people visiting the river, but also going into those little towns. And you know what people are going to do when they get off the boat? They are going to spend money."
Other local historic sites being promoted for tourism include the Van Cortlandt Manor in Croton-on-Hudson, Teatown Lake Reservation in Ossining, Lyndhurst in Tarrytown and the John Jay Homestead in Katonah. The Visitors Bureau and the County Office of Tourism jointly issued a "Summer Fun Pack" book of discount coupons for all of those places, for museums like the Neuberger Museum of Art at the State University at Purchase and the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, and for attractions like Caramoor in Katonah, the North Salem Vineyard, and Playland in Rye.
The other half of the tourism equation -- business travel -- is the bread and butter of Westchester's recruitment efforts. The county has almost 5,000 hotel rooms, and one of the main goals of the Visitors Bureau is to fill them with people by booking meetings and conventions here.
"Suppose you have 300 dentists from Idaho and they want to go to New York City for their association meeting, they want to go to Broadway and they want to see a show," Ms. Carnicelli said. "This is where we come in and say: 'Look, we've got the best of both worlds. We're 30 minutes from Broadway, our hotels are half the price, we're safe, and we're clean. You can go into the city and come back here at night.' "
The next day, Ms. Carnicelli said, they might not want to return to the city but to tour the Hudson Valley instead. Either way, they've paid for a hotel room and breakfast in the county.
The difficulty is that few dentists in Idaho or visitors from other distant states have heard of Westchester, and this is where the Convention and Visitors Bureau does its work. Mr. Vogt, the bureau's chairman, said that the bureau has worked with 68 meeting and convention groups since July 1990. Competition from other areas for conventions and meetings is tough, and the bureau has developed package deals on hotel room charges, meeting rooms and activities for business visitors. From July last year to June this year, the county had 24,726 overnight convention visitors. They spent $2,472,600 on rooms and $4,450,680 on additional items.
 
'Nice Place to Visit'
 But the people who strolled leisurely on the grounds of Sunnyside on a beautiful afternoon recently did not have these facts and figures on their minds. Raquel Gray from Edgewater, N.J., had just finished touring Washington Irving's house.
"We're so close to Westchester and we'd never been up here," she said. "It's like living next to the Empire State Building and never going up it. Now that we're here it's really pleasant."
Rochelle Bronson, who lives in Short Hills, N.J., grew up in the Bronx. She said that when she was young her family used to visit Westchester to shop and get a change of scene.
"Even now, though I live out of the city, I've always maintained that feeling about Westchester -- the greenery, the houses, the peace," she said. "It's a nice place to visit."

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1735 words

HEADLINE: County Westchester Still a Destination

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
JOHN CONCANNON, the stocky, white-haired owner of Morley's Supermarket, points with pride to three large hand-colored photographs from 1962 that hang on a wall in his store -- long an institution on Yonkers Avenue, one of the main thoroughfares of this city. "That's my uncle, the original owner of Morley's," he said. "And that's me, the young man holding up the bananas."
Mr. Concannon's uncle has since died, and the years are beginning to show on the current proprietor's face. The market itself, though, looks much the same as it did 31 years ago -- the main difference being that a new generation of Irish immigrants is helping customers nowadays as they pick over bins of vegetables and fruit outside Morley's front door or order cold cuts and soda bread inside at the deli, where the affable Mr. Concannon presides. 
 It is a highly trafficked store, thick with the accents of customers and employees, who share a common heritage. Copies of the Irish Echo and Irish Voice, two large-circulation Irish-American weekly newspapers, sell briskly at the checkout counters.
Since immigrating to the United States from County Mayo in Ireland more than three decades ago, Mr. Concannon has married, raised a family and prospered in this city, becoming part of the fabric of a large and still growing Irish-American community in Westchester.
 
'The Great Assimilators'
 In the 1990 census, 62,402, or 7 percent, of the county's residents listed their major ancestry as Irish, with another 145,000 -- close to 17 percent -- saying that at least some of their forebears were Irish, said Mary R. Carlson, a research planner for the County Planning Department in White Plains. The Irish are second only in numbers to the Italians, the largest nationality represented in the county, she said.
Throughout two centuries, Irish immigrants have been "the great assimilators," said County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, a second-generation Irish-American. Along with the Italians, the Irish have been part of every major building program in the county -- including construction of the Croton Dam in Ossining and the Kensico Dam in Valhalla. Their numbers have been represented on police forces countywide and they have "trickled into politics here," much the way they have in other parts of the United States, the County Executive said.
And since last year, Westchester, like others parts of the nation, has witnessed a relatively large, and legal, influx of Irish -- in contrast with the previous decade, when, according to immigration officials, many who settled here did so by slipping past the authorities, overextending the stays of their temporary visas and living as undocumented aliens.
Legally or without the proper immigration papers, most Irish come to Westchester for economic reasons. Like Michael J. Morley, 42, who owns the other Morley's Supermarket in this city, on Lake Avenue, , the Irish-Americans who were interviewed for this story said there was little opportunity for gainful employment back home, in a country where the unemployment rate has been 19 t0 20 percent for almost a decade.
 
In Ireland for the Weekend
 Mr. Morley was born in the same stone farmhouse as Mr. Concannon, his first cousin, on lush farmland near the Atlantic Ocean. But only one son in each generation -- usually the first born -- has been able to stay on to work the land, which is able to support just one family, Mr. Morley said.
"They would have a series of Irish 'wakes,' farewell parties, as each one left," Mr. Morley said. "Lots of stout, whisky, brown bread and tea, and then the final goodbye."
"Years ago, it really was goodbye forever," he said. "Now there's no such thing as leaving for good. Many of us fly back home even for a weekend, so we just say 'See ya' when we leave."
Mr. Morley came to America in 1973, obtained a green card and started working for his uncles at Morley's Supermarket on Yonkers Avenue. He then purchased his store in 1986 on Lake Avenue, in an area on the northwest side of the city that is still known as Irish Hill. He also owns a pub and restaurant next door, Morley's Steak and Seafood, where fresh pints of Guinness stout are served along with Irish music on some nights and traditional Irish dinners like corned beef and cabbage.
 
'Cream of the Crop'
 Not only in recent years, but also throughout a succession of immigration waves -- including an exodus in the 1840's after potato crop failures -- the overriding factor driving the Irish to American shores has always been economics, immigration officials for the New York City area said. They said that Ireland in the 1990's, which is still largely an agricultural country, continues to lose many of its young adults.
Mr. Morley described the young Irish who are immigrating today as "the cream of the crop, the very well educated with the best degrees who can't find a job."
And although the recession in the United States has driven some Irish home again, many have found Westchester's unemployment rates, which have hovered at less than 6 percent in recent months, not all that daunting by comparison.
Traditionally, Irish women entering the country take jobs as nannies and waitresses, and the men start businesses as painters, plasterers and movers, hoping eventually to find work in the professional fields for which they trained.
 
Adventure and Sunshine
 To a lesser degree, Irish immigration has also been motivated by what Edward A. Sheeran, a hotel and golf course developer in Yonkers, called "a matter of adventure and a desire to see the world in the land of the free and the home of the brave."
"America in the movies is the land of continuous sunshine, which is very appealing to people living in a country like Ireland," said Mr. Sheeran, who came to the United States in 1960 with little more than his identification papers and a promise of room, board and a job from an uncle.
The United States now allows 48,000 residents of Ireland to immigrate under a three-year program that began in 1992 and will continue through next year. Selection has been made on the basis of a lottery and in addition to allowing new Irish immigrants, the program was also designed to provide legal status for the many undocumented Irish aliens already living in the United States.
In the 26-year period from 1965 to 1991, the immigration laws gave preference to those with immediate family members in the United States who would sponsor the new arrivals. This worked against the Irish, who emigrated in fewer numbers and many of whom actually returned to their homeland during this period on hearing news of better economic times there. Many immigrants during this period came from countries like Pakistan, the Philippines and Mexico.
 
16,000 a Year
 Under the program, an Irish immigrant needs only a letter guaranteeing employment, in contrast with the normal procedure, which requires most immigrants to be sponsored by an immediate family member who already lives in the United States, explained Sean R. Benson, executive director of the Emerald Isle Immigration Center in Woodside, Queens. Because Ireland's population is only about 3 million, Mr. Benson called the current Irish immigration wave "substantial."
The most recent immigration numbers, however -- about 16,000 a year -- pale in comparison with trends in the 19th century. From 1851 to 1860, for example -- during the years following the potato famine -- 914,119 Irish came to the United States, according to statistics from the Immigration Center.
About half of new Irish immigrants settle in the New York City area, where it is estimated that 5 million live. Others migrate to Florida, where the cost of living is lower and where there are more job opportunities in the construction industry.
 
Cultural and Sports Center
 For those who have settled in the New York City area, Mr. Sheeran is spearheading an effort to establish an Irish-American cultural and sports center in Briarcliff Manor, which would draw from surrounding communities in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.
Mr. Sheeran, a member of the Ancient Order of Hibernians and Grand Marshal of the 1990 St. Patrick's Day Parade, is president of the proposed center, known as Tara Circle. Tara was the name of an ancient royal seat and a meeting place of scholars, poets, athletes and musicians.
Tara Circle, the founding organization, is negotiating to purchase the 58-acre King's College site in Briarcliff Manor, along with its seven buildings, a gymnasium and tennis courts, for $14 million.
Among other things, the center would offer hurling and Gaelic football games (similar to soccer) and classes in Irish heritage and dance. In addition, the center would house a library of Irish writings and a genealogy service.
"It is to mark and save what has gone before -- our roots," Mr. Sheeran said.
 
Opposition to Center
 Many of the newest immigrants, like 22-year-old Lorna King from Tipperary (a county in southern Ireland), who works in Mr. Morley's store, said they miss the culture of their homeland. They often have to travel to the Catskill Mountains to attend Gaelic festivals, where they can participate in traditional dances, games and singing. Ms. King, who is waiting to hear if she will be granted permanent status under the lottery system, said she would welcome an Irish center close to home, where she could meet friends and attend events.
But the future of the proposed center is uncertain, because it has generated stiff opposition from a group called the Residents for the Future of Briarcliff Manor. The group's 400 or so members say they are worried about traffic and noise and the increased demands on police and services, among other things.
Mr. Sheeran, who will present an environmental impact statement to officials in Briarcliff Manor, said he was concerned that some of the opposition might be from residents who see the Irish stereotypically as heavy drinkers and rowdy.
Niall O'Dowd, publisher of the 55,000-circulation Irish Voice, said, "That's like seeing Jews as being mean, or blacks as eating watermelon. It's all just stereotyping, like Irish getting drunk all the time and falling over."
Tara Circle has raised $1 million toward a down payment on the college property, through individual and organizational investors. It is also seeking financing from county and state agencies.

LENGTH: 1341 words

HEADLINE: Boonton Journal;
Antiques Shoppers or Corporate Development?

BYLINE: By GENE NEWMAN

DATELINE: BOONTON

 BODY:
PLANS to revitalize Main Street here to take advantage of a new stretch of highway that could speed antiques shoppers into town are facing an uncertain future under a new administration that will take office in January.
The opening of the final section of Interstate 287, which could come as early as November, will link this Morris County town of 8,300 with the New York Thruway. Community leaders say the opening will provide an important opportunity to attract new customers to the antiques stores and specialty shops along Main Street, a half-mile shopping district that winds up a hill past turn-of-the-century buildings. 
 Steps have been taken to retain the street's old-fashioned charm through the establishment of a historical commission and the efforts of a volunteer group that works to preserve and beautify the community.
"Main Street is the key to Boonton's future," said Mayor Robert Depue, who will leave office at the end of the year. "This is the last great chance for Boonton."
The town, he said, was an "isolated hamlet" before Route 287 reached it in the 70's, coming from its southern terminus at the Garden State Parkway near Perth Amboy. The highway now passes through Boonton and ends a mile away in Montville; its final section will connect it with the Thruway at Suffern, N.Y., 21 miles from Boonton.
"This is the end of the road if we can't find a way to take advantage of the completion of Route 287," said the Mayor, who did not seek re-election. "If Main Street dies, the town will not realize its potential."
 
'There Are Other Streets in Town'
 Daniel Gregory, who won the Republican mayoral primary in June and will run unopposed in November for a two-year term, said: "Main Street revitalization is fine. We need to do everything we can for Main Street, but there are other streets in town also."
Mr. Gregory, a land surveyor and planner, has held posts in town as an alderman and a member of the Planning Board and the Board of Education. During his successful primary race against Alderman Ronald Rubino, a political ally of the outgoing Mayor, Mr. Gregory spoke against the current administration's approach to enhancing the economy. All the town's aldermen are Republicans; the Democrats are offering no candidates in this year's election.
Mr. Gregory said that while he did not oppose revitalizing Main Street, he would place a high priority on reducing the property tax rate by attracting more commercial development. "I have to be cognizant of helping the whole town," he said. "The whole town elected me."
Mr. Gregory said he hoped to see development of the vacant tract where the Pacific Vegetable Oil Corporation had a factory that closed in 1987 because the company went bankrupt. But first the site's contaminated soil must be cleaned up.
Mayor Depue has argued that the cleanup faced an extensive delay because the company was bankrupt and involved in litigation with the state over the pollution.
The town cannot count on finding additions to the tax rolls, Mr. Depue said. "There are less than two and a half square miles in this town," he said. "So we should have found them by now."
In an effort to help Main Street, Alderman Rubino, whose term expires next year, said he was working on a plan to remove the street's parking meters for a six-month trial. Parking now costs 25 cents an hour there.
 
Free Parking With One-Hour Limit
 Under Mr. Rubino's plan, they would park free, but with a one-hour limit. Police officers would keep tabs on parkers, giving tickets to violators. The fine for overtime parking would remain at $7. In addition, 88 spaces in the nearby Plane Street lot would be available for 50 cents a day, Mr. Rubino said.
He said that it was impossible to tell how much of the town's annual meter income of $64,000 is from Main Street meters, but that with stepped-up enforcement he did not anticipate a revenue loss.
Some merchants say the one-hour parking limit is too short for antiques browsers. "Customers don't mind paying parking money, but they need at least two hours, " said Marjorie Tyndale, who owns a fine-arts and antiques store on Main Street with her husband, Hal.
More debate has been generated by the creation this year of the local Historic Preservation Commission, which will regulate architectural changes to 102 buildings, almost all of them on Main Street. The seven-member commission will enforce an ordinance that calls for preservation of the "original character" of the street.
The drive for the ordinance was "a holy war that went on for months," said the commission vice chairman, Mark Middleton. "And it affects mostly the store owners, 60 percent of whom are nonresidents."
"There is a real struggle in town," said Mr. Middleton, a computer software representative who moved to Boonton six years ago. The battle, he said, pits those who want to fix up Main Street to give it the elegant character of neighboring Chester against those who want to leave the street alone and seek tax-producing development elsewhere in town.
When the results of the June primary are verified in the November election, Mr. Middletown predicted, the governing body will be 6 to 3 against the type of changes sought by the present administration.
Louis J. Masterbone, an ally of Mr. Gregory who won nomination in the primary as an alderman, said, "I am going to go out and ask a lot of questions and then form an opinion" on the Main Street issue. Mr. Masterbone, a resident of Boonton for 18 years, is a detective sergeant in the Morris County Sheriff's office.
On Main Street, Mr. Tyndale, treasurer of Boonton U.S.A., an association of antiques dealers who pool advertising funds, said the group's membership has dwindled to 7 from 23 in recent years. He called the historic preservation ordinance "a step in the right direction," but said that a proposed ordinance to regulate the size, color and lighting of store signs was coming too late.
"A couple of years ago, a good salesman came here selling garish red and yellow signs," he said. He said the ordinance would probably allow existing signs to remain.
Elizabeth Lee of Elizabeth's Antiques and Fine Imports, a retailer in Boonton for 13 years, said ordinances to revitalize Main Street should have teeth in them. "If it's just rhetoric and political, what's the use?" she asked.
 
Doubts About Revitalization
 Felix Pagan, owner of Tiajuana Willie's restaurant, said: "Revitalization? I don't think it's working." He said there were more vacancies on Main Street than he had seen in his five years there.
Rona Jonnard, owner of Boonton Antiques for 21 years, said Route 287 would bring New York and Connecticut customers to Boonton in 45 minutes. The town, she said, is "one of the best-kept secrets" in the antiques world, with dealers from New York and Pennsylvania buying wares here by the vanload.
Several retailers spoke warmly about a volunteer group called Bounce (Boonton's United Community Effort) which has worked to improve parks and historic sites and has initiated flower and tree plantings, house tours and applications for community development grants.
"The main thing is to improve the quality of life in Boonton," said the group's president, Gail Yorkston, a teacher whose husband, David, chairman of the Historic Preservation Commission, ran unsuccessfully for an alderman nomination in June. "If that can be done with the revitalization of Main Street, we support it. If it can be done within increased ratables, we might support that, too."
Mrs. Yorkston said that 10 percent of the town's residents were contributing members to the 11-year-old organization. It is printing a directory of Main Street shops and restaurants and will distribute 10,000 copies to visitors' centers and hotels throughout the state, she said.
While calling her group apolitical, Mrs. Yorkston said, "Bounce has worked very closely with the current administration." She added: "Our plans mesh with theirs. I don't know if that will be true next year."

HEADLINE: Health Planners at White House Consider Lid on Medicare Costs

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
Less than a month before President Clinton is to unveil his proposal for a national health insurance program, disputes have broken out among Administration officials over how to finance it and how tightly to limit overall health spending.
Officials said that the White House, seeking to avoid new taxes, was seriously considering a proposal to squeeze more than $100 billion of additional savings from Medicare, the Federal health program for the elderly, by holding down increases in the program through the year 2000. The savings, along with a possible increase in the tax on cigarettes, would help pay for Mr. Clinton's promise of guaranteed coverage for all Americans. 
 In addition, some White House officials have proposed setting tight limits on the growth of all health spending, public and private, so that by 1997 it would grow no faster than the economy as a whole. Health spending is now growing more than twice that fast.
Under the Clinton plan, a new Government agency, the National Health Board, would establish a limit on the average yearly health insurance premium to be paid by employers and workers.
The proposals have provoked fierce debate inside the Administration, with some Presidential appointees arguing that the swift imposition of such limits is politically unrealistic and economically unfeasible.
"It's not an ideological argument," one Cabinet officer said. "We agree on Clinton's general approach to health care reform. It's an argument about what is possible -- how fast we can pound down the growth of health spending, how tight the caps on such spending should be, how big the cuts in Medicare will be. A hundred billion dollars in Medicare cuts are not politically possible."
 
Conclusion and Challenge
 Ira C. Magaziner, who has coordinated development of the health plan, argues that substantial cutbacks in Medicare and the proposed limits on health spending are feasible and realistic. But several Cabinet officials have challenged that conclusion, including Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services; Robert E. Rubin, assistant to the President for economic policy; Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
Mr. Clinton has promised that his plan will not require any new broad-based tax. This vow has forced him to intensify his search for other ways to pay for his proposals, whose exact cost is not yet known.
Medicare finances health care for 36 million elderly and disabled people. The budget bill signed by Mr. Clinton on Aug. 10 cuts $55.8 billion from the projected growth of Medicare over the next five years, mainly by curbing payments to hospitals and doctors and increasing beneficiaries' premiums. Despite these cutbacks, which account for nearly one-fourth of all spending cuts in the budget bill, the cost of Medicare is expected to soar, to $239 billion in 1998 from $129 billion last year.
 
Fear of Unintended Effects?
 Health policy experts warn that further cutbacks could have unintended effects. Doctors and hospitals, they say, would try to offset the loss of Medicare income by raising prices to privately insured patients, thwarting Mr. Clinton's effort to restrain health spending -- unless the Government prevents such cost shifting by enforcing limits on all health spending.
Most of Medicaid, the Federal-state program for low-income people, would be folded into the new system under Mr. Clinton's plan.
The White House says Mr. Clinton intends to unveil his health plan before a joint session of Congress on Sept. 22 or a few days later.
Administration officials have said that under the plan all Americans will be entitled to a comprehensive package of health benefits. To help hold down costs, Mr. Clinton will propose a nationwide system of health insurance purchasing groups to bargain with doctors, hospitals and insurance companies for the best coverage.
 
The Basic Questions
 But interviews with Administration officials suggest that some basic questions remain in dispute.
The President's plan would require employers to pay at least 80 percent of the cost of health premiums for their employees. Workers would generally be expected to pay the remainder, up to 20 percent of the premium; the money would be withheld from their pay.
Employers could pay part or all of the employee share. The Government would still incur heavy costs because it would subsidize insurance for low-wage workers and for small businesses that employ such workers.
White House documents show that subsidies would be available to employers with fewer than 50 workers if their average wage was less than than $24,000 a year.
Subsidies would also be available to families with incomes up to 50 percent above the official poverty level (up to $21,514 for a family of four) to help pay the patients' share of medical bills, including deductibles.
As a Presidential candidate, Mr. Clinton said he would set "a national health budget" to impose an overall limit on costs. He now proposes to do that by limiting the annual increase in health insurance premiums and health spending by corporations for their employees.
 
Equal Cost Controls
 The White House documents say that Mr. Clinton's proposal, the American Health Security Act, would bring "projected growth in health-care costs in line with growth in gross domestic product by 1997." Kevin Anderson, a White House spokesman, said "cost controls will be applied equally" to private health spending and public programs.
Initially, under the Clinton plan, premiums could increase no more than the average of the increase in gross domestic product for the three previous years, White House documents say.
Mr. Clinton would impose stricter limits on medical spending after the first two years of the new health system.
"Thereafter," the documents say, "the inflation factor equals the three-year average of the increase in the per capita G.D.P." The increase in the per capita figure is smaller because it takes no account of economic growth attributable to the increase in population.
Over the last four years, health care spending grew an average of 11 percent a year. The gross domestic product grew 5 percent a year, while per capita G.D.P. rose 4 percent a year.
 
'Smells Like Big Government'
 The Administration is shying from explicit price controls on doctors and hospitals. But some Administration officials say the limits on health spending may be so strict that the effect is almost the same.
"Ira would like the caps to be very tight," one Cabinet officer said. "When you go to tight caps, you are going to something like price controls."
The Cabinet officer, a lifelong Democrat, called the plan is "heavily regulatory -- it smells like big government."
The National Health Board, to be composed of seven Presidential appointees, would compute the cost of the package of health benefits to be guaranteed to all Americans and would calculate the "national per capita premium" needed to cover the cost.
Using this number as a reference point and adjusting it for regional variations in health spending, the board would calculate a "per capita premium target" for each of the health insurance purchasing groups set up across the country through which most Americans would get their insurance coverage. In this way, the board would set a yearly budget for each such group.
Here are other details of the Clinton plan, as described in documents from the White House and the National Economic Council:
BIG CORPORATIONS. By Jan. 1, 1996, each state must establish one or more of the large purchasing groups, known as regional health alliances, for its residents. All Federal, state and local government employees must obtain coverage through the purchasing group in the area where they live. People who are self-employed or unemployed will also get coverage through regional alliances unless they qualify for Medicare.
But big corporations with more than 5,000 employees may run their own health plans, serving as their own insurers or buying coverage from a private insurance company.
These corporate health plans, to be known as corporate alliances, would have to meet Federal standards regulating the scope of benefits, financial reserves and the prudent use of money held in trust for workers. "Employees in corporate alliances are not eligible for public subsidies," the document said.
Employers operating their own health plans would have to pay "a premium surcharge of 1 percent of payroll" to help cover the cost of the new health-care system.
Corporate health plans would have to comply with "cost-containment goals" set by the National Health Board. These limits would be slightly stricter than those for the regional health alliances. Large employers that exceed these spending limits would lose the privilege of running their own health plans and would be "required to purchase coverage through regional alliances."
FEE SCHEDULES. Most consumers would get care from health maintenance organizations and other networks of doctors and hospitals. But each insurance purchasing group would also have to offer a traditional health plan, under which consumers could consult any doctor and doctors could charge a fee for each service.
Each state would establish a fee schedule for doctors serving these patients. A doctor "may not charge or collect from a patient a fee in excess of the rate schedule." This prohibition represents a big change. Under current law, the Government generally does not regulate doctors' charges to their privately insured patients.
ENFORCEMENT. The Treasury Secretary could impose a monetary penalty on anyone who failed to enroll in a health plan by a specified date. The documents do not say how severe such a penalty would be.
The Federal Government would enforce health-care budgets for three years, from 1996 to 1998. Regional health alliances must submit proposed premiums to the National Health Board for approval. States would be responsible for enforcement after 1998.

HEADLINE: Long Island Drive-In May Play Its Last Reels

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 26

 BODY:
At one time, it was just another outdoor movie theater in suburbia, a vast, bumpy blacktop where children snoozed through the second feature in the backs of their parents' station wagons, and animated hot dogs danced with hamburgers across a screen 80 feet high.
In those days, there was not much to distinguish the Westbury Drive-In from the dozens of others that were a mainstay of cinematic life in New York's suburbs. But today, the Westbury, with its marquee missing light bulbs and its asphalt scarred by potholes, is distinctive in one respect: It is the last of the great outdoor picture shows in the metropolitan region. 
 And now it, too, may go dark. The company that has run the drive-in for 40 years wants to close it and replace it with a multiplex, a type of moviehouse the company says is far more in tune with the times and the wide range of entertainment choices available to the public.
It would not be the first time that a drive-in would be supplanted by a multiscreen theater: movie exhibitors learned long ago that outdoor theaters took up too much space and had too few screens to justify the expensive tracts they occupied.
But the plan to transform the Westbury -- which town officials in Oyster Bay are expected to vote on in the fall -- is more than a commentary on the economics of the entertainment industry. As a relic of the postwar boom in the suburbs, where the landscape was re-imagined with the automobile in mind, Long Island's last drive-in is a symbol of the passing of an era.
"We have to grow with the times and accept the fact that Long Island is changing," said Howard Hogan, a town councilman in Oyster Bay whose family co-owns the land under the Westbury. He is embroiled in a battle with residents of the area who oppose the multiplex, chiefly on the ground of the additional traffic that they say would be generated by the theater and a wholesale shopping club also planned for the site. "The habits of people change, and the forms of public entertainment have changed, and we have to be prepared to meet that," Mr. Hogan added.
Although the drive-in era is fading fast all across America -- from a peak of more than 4,000 outdoor movie screens in the 1950's, there were just 899 remaining in 1991, according to the most recent survey by the National Association of Theater Owners -- the drive-in experience has not changed all that much over the years. And neither has the Westbury. The posts with the soundboxes that motorists draped over their windows to hear the movies are gone, replaced by sound systems broadcast to car radios; the playgrounds have been dismantled and the theater charges by the person, not the carload.
But children still arrive at the Westbury in pajamas, and teen-agers still arrive in pairs.
On a recent weekday evening, a steady stream of cars passed through the old tollbooths at the entrance to the drive-in. By the light of a shimmering half-moon, the moviegoers maneuvered their vehicles over the rutted blacktop, on the prowl for the perfect place for a night of film-watching al fresco.
Among them were Michael and Mary Stein of New Hyde Park, who backed their van onto one of the bumps and off-loaded chaise longues, crayons and children. The Steins are drive-in sentimentalists: Mr. Stein came to the Westbury as a boy, took his future wife here on dates when they were teen-agers, and now brings the whole family, including daughters Kerianne, 6, and Kimberly, 3, each year to celebrate the couple's wedding anniversary.
This evening, to mark the anniversary, they were all here to see "The Fugitive," although Mrs. Stein predicted that Kimberly would be fast asleep in no time. "We come on our anniversary and at least one other time each summer," Mrs. Stein said, as her daughters colored in the moonlight on a table that her husband, a New York City firefighter, had set up at the edge of the van. "It would be a shame if they shut this place down."
The operators of the Westbury, United Artists Theater Circuit Inc., once had a string of drive-ins from one end of Long Island to the other. One by one they flickered out. But no one at the company, which also operates 17 indoor theaters on Long Island, could explain precisely why the Westbury has endured the longest. It may have been a case of survival of the fittest, for on summer nights when it shows blockbuster flicks like "Jurassic Park," the Westbury packs them in as tightly as any viewing chamber in the cinema 1-2-3-4-5.
 
Three Screens on 24 Acres
 It is a sign of how irrelevant an artifact the theater has become that the fight over the site has little to do with drive-in nostalgia. Still, it is a well-known landmark on Brush Hollow Road, next to a bowling alley and down the street from the Westbury Music Fair. "It's been a good neighbor," said Leonard Gutterman, president of the West Birchwood Civic Association in nearby Jericho and a leader of the opposition to the multiplex. "It has not been a problem."
The Westbury, built in 1953, occupies 24 acres and can handle a total of about 1,000 cars at its three screens, which form a semicircle around a brightly lighted concession stand. It is open 365 days a year, and nothing short of an act of God stops the show. On the day a hurricane passed through several years back, the Westbury was up and running that evening. "Rain, fog, wind, you name it, we're here," said the Westbury's manager, Stanley Friedman, who pointed to a sign near his desk: "No Refunds Due to Weather."
There are many, of course, who do not mourn the passing of the drive-in, moviegoers who prefer the reclining seats and Dolby sound and sleek efficiency of the airport terminal-style multiscreen complexes of the 1990's. The drive-in, after all, was marketed in its heyday as a practical, if less than ideal, alternative to indoor theaters: "Come as you are in your family car," went the slogan.
"In the early days, if a family wanted to get out of the city and see a movie in the suburbs, about the only place they could go was a drive-in. And they'd put up with a lot of inconveniences: the mosquitoes, the heat," said Sumner Redstone, whose father was a pioneer in the business, running some of the most successful drive-ins in the country, outdoor movie meccas like the Whitestone in the Bronx and the Sunrise in Valley Stream.
 
'Passion Pits'
 But the drive-in still has its constituency, a small, devoted assortment of nostalgia buffs, fresh-air enthusiasts and baby boomers-turned-parents who come to expose a new generation to a type of entertainment that might not be around much longer. There are the regulars, said Mr. Friedman's assistant, Daniel Boyd, like the old couple that parks their Hyundai at the tollbooths one night each weekend at around 6 P.M., assuring that they will be the first ones in for the movies that typically begin two hours later.
"I used to live down the block," said Mr. Boyd, a movie fan who has worked at the Westbury since 1986. "I remember seeing 'The Swiss Family Robinson' here when I was 10."
 
Something to Remember
 And it remains a magnet for teen-age and other surreptitious lovers, a reminder of the time not too long ago when drive-ins were referred to with a snicker as "passion pits." On a recent evening in the concession area, Mr. Friedman recalled, "a guy walked up to me and asked me if we sold condoms." (They don't.)
As the sun dipped below the Long Island Expressway, and the sky faded to magenta and black, the last cars took their places for the start of the movie on Screen 2.
In one of the rows closest to the screen, Stanley and Elizabeth Olenyk of Levittown sat on lawn chairs with their 9-year-old son, James. Longtime fans of drive-ins, the Olenyks, too, had been going to outdoor movies for years, and wanted James to share their pleasure.
"We wanted him to experience it before they close it down," Mr. Olenyk explained. "It's something from the past that is an important, tangible thing to remember."
United Artists officials say they are not sure what they will do with the Westbury if the multiplex proposal is not approved. There is some talk, in the interim, of trying to cash in on drive-in nostalgia by staging marathon horror movie festivals.
Gail McCaffrey, the company's regional division manager for Long Island, says that would be fine with her. Having got her start in movie exhibition working at the renovated vaudeville houses and vast drive-ins of the Midwest, she has a soft spot for the weather-beaten old dinosaur on Brush Hollow Road.
"On the last day," she said, "I couldn't stand to be here."

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Companies
Thinking Machines will name a new president and chief operating officer, Richard P. Fishman. The corporate lawyer has represented the supercomputer maker in Washington and has worked closely with Sheryl Handler, the chairman and chief executive. His appointment comes amid rumors of controversy and shake-ups at the technology company. [Page D1.] 
 Trammell Crow has survived a crash in commercial property values, but two-thirds of its partners have lost their ownership interests and nearly that many have left the company. Once the nation's top developer, Trammell Crow has shrunk and split into two parts. [D1.] Some departed partners contend that the company took advantage of them. [D10.]
The United Automobile Workers will announce today which auto maker it has made its "target" in contract negotiations. [D1.]
The Westbury Drive-In is the last of the great outdoor picture shows in the New York area. Now it, too, may go dark. [A1.]
 
The Economy
Mortgage lenders are opening their doors a little wider to poor people and members of minority groups seeking home loans. They had been shamed by Federal Reserve data on their poor records. [D1.]
Clinton aides are pondering how to keep the creation of universal coverage from costing low-wage workers a pay cut or even their jobs. [A14.]
Machine tool orders slid in July for the third straight month as large automotive orders continued to level off. [D4.]
 
International
German and U.S. officials begin talks today aimed at salvaging an aviation agreement. The Clinton Administration must contend with a growing group of countries that believe U.S. airlines carry more than their fair share of international traffic. [D1.]
The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development has had difficulty finding large private companies to support in formerly Communist Eastern Europe. This has been the case even in Hungary, where foreign investment came early and strong. [D5.]
 
The Media Business
CBS's move to build a late-night franchise around David Letterman has brought plenty of attention and is almost certain to pay off in profits, television and advertising executives say. Bill Carter: Television. [D8.]
Drugs. Sex. Jobs. Guys. Hair. Dad. A new campaign for YM, focusing on issues confronting the magazine's young women readers, is edged with what its creator calls "a rawness, an honesty." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]
Elle is trying to regain some lost ground with a broader range of features and some new executives. [D8.]
A new business magazine, Fast Company, seeks to combine the managerial insights of the Harvard Business Review with the writing and jazzy graphics of Rolling Stone. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Small-Time Gold Miners Scrape By

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEAVERVILLE, Calif.

 BODY:
Mickey Rees, an independent gold miner working on the Trinity River, ignores the people who lean out of their speeding cars to shout mockingly, "Get a job."
But when tourists pull over to photograph him, shirtless and smoking on a floating dredge the size of a limousine, the 43-year-old miner and Vietnam veteran takes out binoculars and stares back. Though he may seem like an anachronism, Mr. Rees says he is not ready to become a souvenir. 
 Since 1979, when he quit his job as a foreman at a Long Beach construction company, Mr. Rees has made a living "taking money out of the river," as he and others call gold mining. But now small-time miners say they fear it is only a matter of time before they become extinct.
Ever since gold was first discovered here in 1848, it has been part of the state's folklore, the unofficial natural lottery that people play while on vacation in Northern California. Those who fall for the grungy romance of a miner's life and try to eke out a living in the rivers say the pleasure is in the pursuit, when an ore streak glimmers in the water after a series of barren days.
 
Life Style Vanishing
 But independent gold miners may be a dying breed. One reason is economics. The price of gold has gone from above $800 an ounce in 1981 to less than $400 this year. And although there is still gold to be had by panning and suction-dredge mining, it becomes more difficult to find as miners move from claim to claim.
What will probably deliver the death blow to the miners' endeavor, however, are pending changes in state and Federal regulations. State wildlife officials, concerned about the declining numbers of salmon and steelhead fish in the rivers of Northern California, may close off portions of the rivers to the miners and restrict the kinds of machinery they use.
And on the Federal level, legislation has been introduced by Representative Nick J. Rahall 2d, Democrat of West Virginia, that would force all miners, big and small, to pay the Government an 8 percent royalty on all the gold they find; now they only pay taxes on their profits.
Although Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt supports stringent controls of mining, "he is aware of small miners and wants to take care of them so they are not made extinct," said Stephanie Hanna, a spokeswoman for the Interior Department.
But as he took a break after a day of work, Mr. Rees said he held out little hope. "This kind of life is being phased out," he said. "Most of us are broke. We don't lobby. We don't make money. We don't make anyone else money. We're an easy target."
Since California's first gold rush, when miners settled counties like Trinity, the five major rivers and their tributaries in the north have been picked over twice more, first by Chinese laborers at the turn of the century and then by people out of work during the Depression.
Since then miners have developed high-tech gold panning methods. Wearing heated wet suits with sot masks and 60-pound belts, they dive under water and sweep the river's bedrock with devices called suction dredges. With an eight-inch nozzle like an underwater vacuum cleaner, they suck up riverbed gravel, which is flushed over a large grate to separate the gold.
Gold fever usually begins on vacations, and minor successes with a spoon and a pan can lead to purchases like a small suction dredge, which costs $800. The bigger dredges, used by the serious miners, cost $10,000.
The number of people mining has declined from 13,000 in 1980 to 5,000 this year. Some are recreational miners but one-third are working alone or with a partner trying to make a living finding gold, said Hal Cribbs, a political consultant working on mining issues in Sacramento. Mr. Cribbs said about 1,500 work on the rivers year-round.
The serious say river mining is not an easy way to get rich. On good days, a suction dredger can pull an ounce out of the river, which can get a miner anywhere from $270 to $370 either at a jewelry store or at a smelting operation. But weeks can go by when the miner does not hit any gold.
But the miners say the appeal is not the money, but being their own boss and living with the unexpected.
"There are no assurances," said Mr. Rees, who lives in a 37-foot Ford bus and earns an average of $10,000 a year. "Your wife has left you, you have lost your home, your body hurts, all for the hope of finding something."
"It's not the gold," said Lynn Gunn, 38, who has mined for 10 years with her husband, Dan Morrison. "It's finding the gold."
 
Rallying Support
 Over the past year, Ms. Gunn, who worked as an electrician in Silicon Valley before mining, has tried to bring the miners' concerns to state and Federal officials. But she has had little luck in organizing the miners. Spread throughout Northern California, miners by nature are loners who distrust government, she said, making it hard to inspire them to come to meetings.
She has produced a pamphlet, The Miners Survival Kit, which recommends greeting rafters, kayakers and fishermen because "these people vote, and there's more of them than us." It also asks miners to collect lead, copper and mercury accumulated in the dredge to present at local public hearings as proof that dredging actually picks up pollutants from the rivers.
Some miners have decided to stay out of the conflict, hoping that it will go away. But if it does not, what the miners will do next is unclear. Trinity County already has 14.7 percent unemployment, five percentage points higher than the state rate. Many miners talk about leaving the country for South America, where they say the gold is more plentiful and the regulations are few. Others, like Mr. Rees, plan to return to the blue-collar jobs they had before they got gold fever.
Charlie Fitch, who as a ranger for the Forest Service must enforce Federal rules dealing with issues like the equipment miners can use, says he has found his job difficult.
 
'Taking Away Their Dreams'
 "Miners are dreamers," Mr. Fitch said. "Those are a tough people to work with because you are taking away their dreams."
Joe Valdez, 43, who has also been mining in Trinity County for 10 years, said he got gold fever after panning on weekends while working in Sacramento doing odd jobs.
"You go in the water, and you don't know if you will come out with $6,000 or nothing," Mr. Valdez said. Yet, once he finds gold, it loses its appeal. "When you are in gold, it becomes just a job," he said.
Todd Steele is one of those miners who is resigned to making a career change. This summer, he and his wife, Jeanne, an artist, are making jewelry with gold they have already mined instead of looking for more.
"There's something unbeatable about going to a river in the morning and that is your office," Mr. Steele said. "You fight the weather, you don't know where the gold is but it is you against yourself and Mother Nature. And that's enough. But when you have bureaucracies breathing down your neck, that's too much."

HEADLINE: Health Care Quandary: Will Coverage Cut Jobs?

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
The Clinton aides finishing up his health plan are wrestling with a devilish quandary: how to keep the creation of universal coverage from costing low-wage workers a pay cut or even their jobs.
At first glance, it would seem that these workers would be the plan's biggest winners. Domestics, farm workers, sales clerks and others with modest earnings account for most of today's 16.3 million uninsured workers. 
 A policy paid by employers that is as good as that offered by Fortune 500 companies would be the equivalent of a raise of several thousand dollars, seemingly just what is needed for workers who, as a group, have seen their pay and benefits shrink for nearly two decades.
But labor economists in the Administration and academia are acutely aware that unless the requirement for employers is balanced by potentially large Government subsidies, it is those low-wage workers, not businesses, who are likely to wind up footing the bill as employers seek to compensate for increased costs.
 
Lost Jobs or Wage Cuts
 "You'd expect to see fewer low-wage jobs because it would be more expensive to hire less-skilled workers," said Barbara Wolfe, a labor economist at the University of Wisconsin. "There's reason to be very concerned and very cautious."
Daniel Hamermesh, a labor economist at the University of Texas, said: "Either there are going to job cuts or wage cuts or, more likely, a combination of both. It's got to be one or the other."
Ira C. Magaziner, the President's top health care adviser, recently called worries about job losses "crazy." But economists involved in the planning process have been raising the issue all along.
Administration officials are aware of the problem, although they are under strict orders not to discuss estimates of potential job losses. "We're studying the issue intensively so that our plan has the largest possible job creation impact," said Gene Sperling, deputy assistant to the President for economic policy.
 
Estimates Vary Widely
 Potential job losses depend, among many other things, on the cost of coverage and how much of the direct cost of employing low-wage workers would increase. Administration officials say potential job losses for low-wage workers, in the absence of a subsidy, is likely to be 200,000 to 700,000.
Some academics outside the Administration, maintaining that universal coverage is likely to cost more than the Administration now realizes, believe the potential lost jobs could be two or three times that large, ranging up to three million.
Labor economists say that when the Government requires employers to provide a benefit, most of its cost is eventually shifted to workers, through cuts in their cash wages or other benefits. But since it is difficult to squeeze the pay of workers who earn close to the minimum wage, employers have often cut jobs, substituting machines for people and, more often, more skilled workers for less skilled ones.
"Many workers will be totally unaffected, but it will have a serious effect on low-wage workers," said June O'Neill, a labor economist at Baruch College who says job losses are potentially very large.
 
Effect Is Concentrated
 The overwhelming majority of the uninsured are low-wage workers in a handful of industries like restaurant service, retail sales, construction and farming. Because they are not scattered throughout the economy, their employers face potentially large increases -- in the double digits -- in payroll costs.
Some Administration officials say they are confident that new hiring by high-wage companies like auto makers, which are expected to see a decline in health care costs, will offset losses, if any, at the bottom of the job ladder. Thus, the Administration's plan could reinforce a host of trends that have been bearing down on the least-skilled, least-educated Americans for the last two decades and add to the schism between the fortunes of low-wage and high-wage workers.
To limit the impact on low-wage workers, health care planners have suggested that the requirement be phased in over five to seven years and that the amount small businesses would have to pay be limited to 3.5 percent of payrolls, about half what larger companies pay. They have also recommended that employees' contributions be capped based on their income and that the Government provide subsidies.
Subsidies to business would grow or shrink with the actual number of jobs lost, but they are very difficult to design and could wind up stimulating accounting games if not outright deceptions by businesses. That could swell the Federal budget deficit, a very risky step given the public focus on it, not to mention the Administration's own push to cut its growth. The official line is that the subsidies will be small and can be financed by "administrative savings" or, at most, a tax on smokers, but most economists are highly skeptical.
 
Heavy Burdens Seen
 In a study released recently by the Employment Policies Institute, a research organization backed by business, Professor O'Neill and her husband, Dave M. O'Neill at Baruch College, both highly regarded labor economists, concluded that the problem was potentially far bigger than the Administration has been saying.
The O'Neill study assumed that the average cost of a policy for a single worker would be $2,400 and the average cost of a family policy would be $5,900, about the average cost of covering workers today, and that because of seniority considerations, employers would not be able to cut pay below $8.50 an hour. From this they calculated that, while overall labor costs in the entire economy might rise just 2.5 percent, certain industries, restaurants, for example, would face potential increases in their labor costs of 16 percent.
Economists involved in the health care planning process, on the other hand, assume that the plan will cost roughly $2,000 for each worker, far less than the average businesses pay now -- and that businesses will be able to cut more from low-wage workers' pay and wind up cutting fewer jobs.
Other labor economists consider the O'Neills' estimates credible.
"I think her estimates could be fairly conservative," said Finis Welch, a labor economist at Texas A&M University.
"The reason people are uninsured in the first place is that they were unwilling to have their wages cut and they wanted their jobs," Professor June O'Neill said. "It seems fairer for the public to pay for the poor than for the poor to pay in the form of lost jobs."
