HEADLINE: A School Board and State

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MERIDEN, Conn., Aug. 27

 BODY:
In four separate votes, the Board of Education in this blue-collar town has refused to institute a state-mandated free-breakfast program at one of its elementary schools.
Cost is not the issue because the state and Federal governments say they will pay for the program. Instead, the board says it is standing on principle, fighting state mandates, the intrusion of big government and the ever-expanding welfare state. 
 "The feeling I get is they're fed up with all these mandates, and enough is enough," Mayor Angelo R. D'Agostino said, adding, "I think people have had it."
The board seems unwilling to change its mind, even in the face of a threat by the State Attorney General to take Meriden to court.
Robert E. Kosinski Jr., who, at 23, is Meriden's youngest school board member, says the issue symbolizes the problems he sees in society today.
"I was brought up in a Catholic family," Mr. Kosinski said. "My parents worked very hard to provide for their family. Young parents look for the freebies. It's too easy for them to not want to take the responsibility."
Gerald I. Adelman, a board member who supports the breakfast program, said everyone agrees that parents should be feeding their children at home. But children do come to school hungry, and he said board members should have chosen another issue to take a stand on.
"It's awful that the children are the ones who suffer, that people decide to draw the line in the sand over feeding young kids," Mr. Adelman said. "This debate has done nothing to help the education system in Meriden, nor to promote the public image of the town."
 
Improved Attendance
 Nutritionists and educators say research has shown that children who begin participating in a school breakfast program may improve their attendance and their academice performance.
As of last year, 14 states -- including New York and Massachusetts -- had laws requiring that school breakfasts be offered in schools that have large numbers of students from poor families. New York, which had mandated school breakfasts in its five largest cities in 1976, this year expanded its law to all districts that have schools with needy children. In Connecticut, 102 schools, including John Barry Elementary School in Meriden, fall under the state's 1993school-breakfast law, which applies to elementary schools where at least 80 percent of students enrolled in the lunch program received a free or reduced-price lunch.
The Connecticut Anti-Hunger Coalition started pushing for a mandate after many districts remained reluctant to begin breakfast programs, even though Connecticut began offering grants to supplement Federal subsidies in 1986, said Laura I. Cohen, the group's director.
But school districts also worry that breakfast will cost money, disrupt bus schedules and cut into classroom time, Ms. Cohen said. "Somehow those issues seem to miraculously disappear a month after the program takes effect," Ms. Cohen said.
Bridgeport, which began offering school breakfasts in January 1992, was among the last districts to adopt a program -- and only started it because of the 1991 state law. Michael C. Bisciglia, president of the Bridgeport school board, had vehemently opposed the program, yet now admits many of his fears never came true.
A study of 2,400 children participating in the Bridgeport breakfast program shows that their attendance improved over the previous year -- to 95.3 percent, from 92.7. While academic achievement did not go up enough to be considered statistically significant, school leaders say it may be too soon to know.
Meriden first fell under the state mandate in September 1992, when John Barry Elementary School, with about 600 students, reached the 80 percent eligibility level.
The city successfully challenged a glitch in the initial law, which based its mandate on the percentage of students in the entire school rather than on those enrolled in the lunch program. The measure was revised this year to its current language. Meriden now threatens to challenge the law again, although Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said they have no basis for a challenge.
"If there's no compliance with the law," he said, "we will seek a court order telling the Meriden Board of Education to start a breakfast program." He has asked for an answer by Tuesday.
Mayor D'Agostino, though he is sympathetic to the school board's stance, said he thought that because the state is pressing the matter, the board should comply with the law.
 
A Working-Class Backlash
 Those on both sides of the issue in Meriden say that the outrage against the program is a backlash against state mandates at a time when a poor economy continues to hurt the working-class people who make up so much of Meriden's population.
Frank R. Kogut, school board president, said residents are tired of expensive mandates that they don't agree with. And the state and Federal grants that proponents say will cover all the costs of the program -- an assertion that Mr. Kogut challenges -- is still taxpayer money, he said.
This sentiment, Mr. Adelman said, is aggravated by the recession.
"I've talked to a lot of hard-working people, who aren't ones to write letters to the editor, who feel, this is one too many," Mr. Adelman said.
Ms. Cohen of the anti-hunger coalition understands those sentiments.
"No one disagrees that the ideal situation is to have kids eat at home," she said. "But while we adults debate the root causes and solutions to the problem, a whole generation of kids is slipping away, and we're all going to pay for that in the end."

HEADLINE: Leading Contender for a Schools Job Few Want

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29

 BODY:
A continent away from the bustle of New York City, where the months-long search for a schools chancellor may soon be over, Ramon C. Cortines enjoyed the simple pleasures of a weekend by the bay and pondered the ultimate question:
Why would a man who has already run three school districts, who quit his job as head of the San Francisco schools last year because of a grinding work schedule and a painful ulcer, eagerly await a summons to New York and a thankless job that has bowed several distinguished educators before him?
 
'I'm Not Willing to Give Up'
 "Attempting to make urban school districts work challenges me," said Mr. Cortines, a 61-year-old Mexican-American who is now the top choice of the four-member majority on New York's Board of Education. "People say New York can't be done. Well, I'm not willing to give up on our big cities." 
 Mr. Cortines emerged as the top contender for the New York job at a private closed meeting of the Board of Education on Friday. He won the support of the faction that forced the ouster of Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez earlier this year. The board is to begin final deliberations on its choice on Monday.
Despite his optimism, nothing in Mr. Cortines's background could truly prepare him for running a system the size of New York's, with its $7 billion budget, its enrollment of nearly a million students and its recent history of brutal political battles over teaching about homosexuality and distribution of condoms in the schools.
"I recognize that and it scares me a little," he said. "I'm so results-oriented and I know there will be no instant Cream of Wheat with this job."
But he says he has solved complex problems at each stop in his career, and his middle-of-the-road attitudes about education will most likely hold him in good stead with the majority on New York's Board of Education, who represent a more conservative constituency in the boroughs outside Manhattan.
In Pasadena, with 24,000 students, where Mr. Cortines was hired, fired and rehired over the course of 12 years by a fractious board, he carried out a court-ordered desegregation plan. In San Jose, with 30,000 students, he was again the architect of a desegregation plan, and also restored solvency to a district that had declared bankrupcy under the previous administration.
In San Francisco, as the state slid into financial crisis, Mr. Cortines's primary task was cutting $50 million in costs. During his tenure here, from 1986 to 1992, he was widely credited with trimming staff and reducing programs while raising test scores and improving attendance in the 62,000-student district. At the same time, he led a successful ballot campaign for a half-cent sales tax dedicated to the city's schools and attracted thousands of dollars of corporate money to classrooms.
 
'He Actually Delivered'
 "It wasn't promises, promises; he actually delivered," said Libby Denebeim, who retired as a school board member in January. "In a budget-cutting time, it was simply remarkable."
Several of Mr. Cortines's pitched battles were with San Francisco's strong gay community. He objected to a plan for a school-based counseling program for gay and lesbian youth, saying at first that the district had to be "careful about enticing young people as it relates to their sexual orientation." Later, he said the word "entice" had been a poor choice. Mr. Cortines designed an alternative program that included a half-time counselor, a phone line and staff training.
Mr. Cortines also offended many gay advocates by his intial objections to the distribution of condoms in high schools. Again, Mr. Cortines said, it was the details of the plan that bothered him, not the concept. He insisted on a way for parents to keep their children from participating and a plank about abstinence. Then condom distribution began.
The current president of the school board, Tom Ammiano, said that Mr. Cortines is "definitely more conservative than San Francisco is" and said he doubted the Superintendent felt real commitment to either condom distribution or gay counseling.
 
'Gimmicks of the Year'
 "If there was enough pressure, he would accede," said Mr. Ammiano, who is gay. "Ray thought schools were for reading, writing and arithmetic, and maybe that philosophy was good for the 50's. But we need to expand what a school does in the community."
Mr. Cortines agreed that he was usually more conservative than the left-leaning constituency here and not much interested in the "gimmicks of the year" that he said were popular with liberal educators.
"I'm a product of my middle-class value system," he said.
Ms. Denebeim said that San Francisco's "ingrown" politics left Mr. Cortines exasperated. "He thought special interests got in the way of running the district," she said. "Groups based on ethnic background, groups based on life-style choices."
Mr. Cortines is now awaiting confirmation as the assistant secretary of education for intergovernmental affairs, but he has made it clear he would take the New York job if it were offered to him. After his nomination he stirred a brief controversy by endorsing the concept of government subsidies of private education through school vouchers, a politically charged idea that the Clinton Administration opposes.
 
European Surroundings
 Mr. Cortines is a man who defies easy categorization. He is a Mexican-American, but he speaks no Spanish and was raised in the European surroundings of the couple who adopted him from his unwed mother.
In an interview in his Pacific Heights apartment, stacked with books about art and architecture and decked with bold modern paintings and delicate potted orchids, Mr. Cortines talked about his family and upbringing. His adoptive father, once the salad chef at the Plaza Hotel on Union Square here, came from Castilian Spanish roots. His adoptive mother was of English ancestry, with a compound name. They were not well-educated, Mr. Cortines said of his parents, who are both dead, but they dragged him "kicking and screaming" most weekends to museums and concerts.
"That's the kind of world I grew up in, and that's the kind of world I want these children to have," Mr. Cortines said.
As such, Mr. Cortines is impatient with educators who want to make excuses for poor and immigrant children. "You can't drag your cross around forever," he said. "Instead of using the straw men of poverty, family situation, linguistic ability and immigrant status, let's do something about it."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%);

HEADLINE: Bosnia Aides Ask U.S. Guarantee As Peace Talks Are Set to Resume

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 29

 BODY:
As Bosnian Serb, Croat and Muslim negotiators prepared to resume peace talks in Geneva on Monday, the leaders of Bosnia's Parliament called today on the United States and NATO to enforce any peace agreement that might come from the negotiations.
Late Saturday, the mostly Muslim Bosnian Parliament rejected the latest United Nations peace proposal, which calls for reorganizing this country into a loose union of three ethnic republics. They said the plan would legitimize the takeover of more than half of Bosnia's territory by the nationalist Serbs' militia. 
 Parliament demanded that the peace plan be amended to provide for the return from Serbian military control of at least eight districts that had Muslim-majority populations before the Serbs forcibly expelled them and for the attachment of these districts to a proposed Muslim-dominated republic. Parliament also demanded, among other things, an outlet to the Adriatic Sea at the town of Neum as well as international guarantees that the plan would actually be carried out.
"We are asking for firm guarantees that a final agreement will be respected and implemented, and there can be no such agreement without the participation of the United States and NATO," said the President of Bosnia's Parliament, Miro Lazovic. "We are asking for both their political and military support if necessary."
 
Serbs Want Sanctions Lifted
 The Bosnian Serbs' self-styled parliament agreed to the peace plan on condition that the United Nations lift economic sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro, news reports from Belgrade said.
The Bosnian Croat parliament in effect rejected the peace plan, demanding that additional territories be attached to a proposed Croatian republic.
The Bosnian Serbs in May rejected the original United Nations peace proposal, known as the Vance-Owen plan, because, among other reasons, it would have required them to hand back a larger amount of territory.
The co-chairmen of the United Nations peace conference on the former Yugoslavia, Lord Owen of Britain and Thorvald Stoltenberg of Norway, backed away from the original plan within a matter of days and supported a Serbian and Croatian proposal for partitioning Bosnia, which was a multi-ethnic patchwork before the Serbs, and later the Croats and Muslims, began ethnic-cleansing operations.
Bosnian leaders acknowledged there was almost no chance that the international community was prepared to force the nationalist Serbs to surrender the formerly Muslim-majority districts, and they privately expressed fear that the 17-month-old war, which has already claimed more than 150,000 lives, will take on a new momentum.
 
Serbs' Aggression Condemned
 Despite United Nations Security Council resolutions condemning the Serbs' aggression against Bosnia, the United Nations has maintained an arms embargo against Bosnia's Government as well as the other factions, guaranteeing the Serbs a vast weapons' superiority.
The Belgrade newspaper Politika today reported that the Bosnian Serb parliament had linked acceptance of the peace plan with the lifting of the United Nations sanctions against the rump Yugoslavia, which comprises only Serbia and Montenegro.
The Security Council 15 months ago imposed economic sanctions on Yugoslavia and tightened them this year because of Belgrade's support for the Bosnian Serb nationalists.
Mr. Lazovic said at a news conference today that Bosnian leaders had not decided on the composition of the negotiating team that is scheduled to be in Geneva on Monday for the resumption of the peace talks.
While fighting has remained on a low level in Bosnia for the last three weeks, United Nations military officials said fierce fighting is continuing in the towns of Tarcin and Gornji Vakuf between mostly Bosnian Army forces and Croatian militiamen.

HEADLINE: U.S. Tries to Restore the Once-Friendly Skies

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
German and United States officials will meet today in Bonn to begin talks that they hope will salvage their threatened aviation agreement. This is the first of many tests in coming months for the Clinton Administration as it contends with a growing list of countries that believe American airlines carry more than their fair share of international traffic.
It is widely believed that the outcome of the talks will set a precedent for those with other countries -- including Japan, France and Australia -- that have signaled a desire to slow the rapid expansion overseas by United States airlines like American, Delta, United and Northwest. 
 "The manner in which these talks are resolved will have some impact on some other bilateral discussions we are having," said Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena.
If negotiators for the United States do not find common ground with those countries, American travelers may face less frequent flights and higher fares to some overseas destinations.
 
Defining the U.S. Strategy
 Airline officials and aviation analysts are also watching Bonn closely for a clearer sense of the Clinton Administration's strategy for dealing with these recent objections to long-standing aviation agreements, which have been reached with one country at a time.
The national commission appointed by President Clinton to study the airline industry has recommended that the United States pursue so-called multilateral agreements with groups of countries. Groupings by trading blocs are a popular notion, and that idea appears increasingly ripe for the airline business, particularly in light of a proposal by KLM, Swissair, Scandinavian Airlines System and Austrian Airlines to explore a merger.
Any movement toward multilateral agreements, however, would require that the participants not feel threatened, as many do now, by the United States. Thus, industry experts suggest that the United States balance firmness in maintaining short-term access to countries for American carriers, while resolving current disputes diplomatically with an eye to the future.
"It's a bit of a tightrope walk," said Jon F. Ash, a managing director of Global Aviation Associates, a Washington consulting firm.
 
Bilateral Accords Questioned
 The talks now pending between the United States and other countries underscore why bilateral agreements are becoming obsolete. Roughly 1,200 international agreements dating from 1944 dictate where and how often airlines can fly to foreign countries. But the rise of international marketing alliances, like the one between Northwest Airlines and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, and the potential for multinational mergers, has complicated the issue.
"Pretty soon we won't know who we're negotiating for," said Patrick V. Murphy, Acting Assistant Secretary of Transportation.
Bilateral agreements have also come under fire in many countries because the global aviation recession has prompted all but a few carriers to look for ways to stem heavy losses. One way to do that is to fight for a larger share of the many passengers flying to and from the United States. By the end of the year, the losses since 1990 of the world's major airlines -- many of them state-owned or supported -- are expected to total $13.5 billion, according to the International Air Transport Association, a trade group.
Despite their own losses in recent years, the largest United States airlines continue to push into international markets to position themselves for a global economic recovery. Even though American carriers are being drubbed domestically by smaller carriers like Southwest Airlines, they are feared abroad because deregulation has forced them to pare operating costs to 30 to 50 percent below those of most European and Japanese carriers, according to a study by Mercer Management Consulting.
"There is a growing realization that the success of U.S. carriers is threatening their continued success," said Kenneth P. Quinn, a Washington lawyer and former chief counsel to the Federal Aviation Administration.
 
Shift in Traffic
 Officials at foreign airlines note that when the bilateral agreements were written, most international passengers were American. That is no longer true, so the agreements are not relevant, they say.
When the United States signed its bilateral agreement with occupied Japan in 1952, for example, there was no Japanese airline that flew international routes. Now the number of Japanese flying to the United States is more than three times the number of Americans flying to Japan, but American carriers lay claim to 69 percent of the traffic.
Susumu Yamaji, chairman of Japan Airlines, traveled to Washington in May to lobby for a new accord with Japan that offered 50-50 sharing of routes. The two countries' relationship is likely to be further strained by what American officials say is a Japanese effort to limit access by United States carriers to a new airport in Japan scheduled to open in 1994.
A similar market-share imbalance prompted France to renounce its 46-year-old pact with the United States in May. The United States airlines share of flights to France has grown from about 45 percent in 1978 to about two-thirds now.
 
Germany Opposes Added Flights
 Relations with Germany were strained earlier this year when Northwest Airlines added flights from the United States to Germany through Amsterdam on planes operated with Northwest's partner, KLM.
The German Government decided that Northwest-KLM flights represented additional United States traffic that was not authorized by the two countries' agreement. Lufthansa, a carrier that is majority-owned by the German Government, won an order from a Frankfurt court demanding that Northwest stop advertising the connecting flights as seamless trips from the United States to Germany.
The dispute turned on a technical point. The German Government argued that Northwest did not have formal approval to operate the shared flights; Northwest contended that nothing in the agreement required it to get approval.
This argument has resulted in two letters from Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany to President Clinton insisting on a new agreement that would limit the growth of American carriers' access to German cities and beyond. Lufthansa, a high-cost carrier, would benefit from such limits.
But many industry analysts say a marketing alliance between Lufthansa and either United or American Airlines is imminent, and that could broadly influence the German Government's negotiating stance. Such alliances generally push negotiators to pursue a more open agreement.
If no progress is made in the current talks, Germany may renounce its bilateral agreement. Should that occur, both sides would have a year to work out a new agreement. Failing that, they would be expected to negotiate on a flight-for-flight basis so that service was not halted.
 
British Talks Considered Crucial
 In contrast to the talks with Germany, in which American officials worry that they will be asked to cede ground, the United States is expecting to plow new territory with British officials in talks in October.
With British Airways' investment of $400 million in USAir earlier this year, and its desire to invest another $450 million, British officials are seeking a relaxation of rules that limit foreign carriers' investment in American airlines to 25 percent voting equity and 49 percent total equity.
In return, British aviation officials have said they will discuss a more open aviation agreement when negotiators meet.
Secretary Pena said that the message the United States wanted to send other countries as it pursued multilateral agreements would emerge from its talks with the British Government. That message will undoubtedly be aimed at European Community officials, who have adopted measures this year that limit air fare cuts and access by United States carriers.
"What we do now will set the stage for what I hope wil be multilateral dicussions in the future," Secretary Pena said. "Our job is to convince all governments that what is best for consumers is to have competition."

HEADLINE: Religious Leaders Hold A 2d World Parliament

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 29

 BODY:
With two hours of invocations and blessings that should have roused the heavens -- or possibly created stupor there -- religious leaders from every corner of the globe and virtually every imaginable faith opened a once-in-a-century Parliament of the World's Religions this weekend.
On Saturday, Buddhist monks, Hindu swamis and Muslim imams, along with Sikhs, Zoroastrians, Bahais, Theosophists and goddess worshipers, joined more familiar religious figures like Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, to begin eight days of prayer, meditation and dialogue with 6,000 participants at the Palmer House Hilton Hotel. 
 Among the world's ills that the international Who's Who of religious leaders in attendance hope to heal are some, including violence, caused by religion itself. The leaders are also asking whether their religions can unite to deal with issues like AIDS and violence against children.
The meeting is the centennial of the 1893 World's Parliament of Religions, held as part of the Columbian Exposition here. That first gathering, held on the site of what is now the Art Institute of Chicago, was a landmark in American religious history.
 
Swami as Star of 1893
 Besides signaling a place for Catholicism and Judaism in the American religious mainstream, the 1893 Parliament introduced Eastern religions like Hinduism, Buddhism and Bahai to a wide public, aiding their growth on these shores.
Thousands of fascinated Midwesterners observed a crimson-robed James Cardinal Gibbons, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Baltimore, offer an opening prayer amid Eastern Orthodox prelates in unfamiliar black robes, a Shinto high priest in flowing white, a turbaned Hindu in saffron, and Confucian and Buddhist leaders in Chinese and Japanese dress.
It was a scene somewhat like this weekend's but startling to a public that like the great majority of the 400 official delegates, was overwhelmingly Christian. The star of the 1893 assembly was Swami Vivekananda, a 30-year-old spokesman for Hinduism.
"Do not care for dogmas, or sects, or churches, or temples," he preached. "They count for little compared with the essence of existence in each man which is spirituality." It was a message that struck chords in an America where schoolchildren encountered similar thoughts in the writings of Ralph Waldo Emerson and Thomas Jefferson.
 
Gloomy Prospects
 Swami Vivekananda denounced the sectarianism that "has filled the earth with violence, drenched it often and often with human blood," and he called for "the death knell to all fanaticism."
This week, too, appeals for an end of religious warfare are present and have become a virtual litany, while major sessions are also devoted to environmental issues and political and economic injustices.
Today, participants heard a report arguing that the "old dream had failed" and that the earth could not sustain unlimited economic growth. The report was delivered by Dr. Gerald O. Barney, a physicist who directed a similarly gloomy "Global 2000 Report" for President Jimmy Carter in 1980.
"We are now a species without a vision," Dr. Barney said, appealing to the religious leaders to grapple with the scientific and economic realities and "dream a new dream" for the planet.
 
'A Global Ethic'
 The Parliament will close next Saturday when the Dalai Lama speaks in Grant Park and a group of religious leaders meeting here issue a "Declaration of a Global Ethic." The Rev. Hans Kung, a Swiss Catholic theologian and frequent object of Vatican censure, oversaw the drafting of the 5,000-word document.
The Vatican itself is represented here by Archbishop Francesco Gioia of the Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue.
Other participants in the Parliament include Russell M. Nelson, one of the Council of Twelve Apostles of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints; Thich Nhat Hanh, a Vietnamese Buddhist monk, and Imam Mustafa Ceric, a leader of Muslims in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Two prominent black American Muslims, the Imam Warith Deen Mohammed, a Sunni, and Louis Farrakhan of the separatist Nation of Islam will make presentations.
So will major Jewish leaders, including Sir Sigmund Sternberg of England and Rabbi Emil Fackenheim of Israel.
 
Wide Participation
 The National Council of Churches will be represented by its president, the Rev. Syngman Rhee, and its executive director, the Rev. Joan B. Campbell. Homi Dhalla, world leader of Zoroastrians, has come from India, and Abdullah Omar Nasseef, secretary general of the World Muslim League, from Saudi Arabia.
Feminist spiritual movements centered on goddess worship will be represented by writers like Riane Eisler and Charlene Spretnak, among others.
Mother Teresa canceled her scheduled appearance because she is recovering from malaria.
But even within the religious world, there is disagreement about the Parliament's merits. The Southern Baptist Convention, for instance, is among groups that declined to send a representative. Many evangelical and fundamentalist Christians believe that such gatherings are at best a distraction from spreading the Gospel and at worst a confusing compromise of their belief that Christianity is the only way to salvation. Conservative and fundamentalist believers in many other religions hold similar positions.
 
'Same Desire for Peace'
 "We have the same desire for peace and reconciliation as 100 years ago," said Dr. Daniel Gomez-Ibanez, the executive director of the group that organized this year's Parliament. "But then there was a mood of optimism in the United States. Today there is a mood of anxiety all around the world."
Besides the change in mood, a comparison of the two Parliaments reveal other telling changes in the United States. The handful of people representing Hinduism and Buddhism in 1893 or the sole Muslim -- an American convert -- would today find at least tens of thousands of fellow believers in the Chicago area alone.
There are more than a dozen Hindu places of worship around the city and suburbs, 28 Buddhist organizations and scores of mosques.
Leadership in organizing the current Parliament was taken five years by local Hindus, Buddhists, Bahais and Zoroastrians as well as some sympathetic Christians. For several years it continued on a shoestring budget, almost collapsing entirely in 1991.
Eventually more than 125 religious groups joined in the group that organized the Parliament, which is financed by grants from foundations and donors and registration fees. The overflow number of registrants will have a choice of more than 700 lectures, panel discussions, workshops and exhibits of religious art, music and dance.

They began eight days of prayer and dialogue intended to heal some of the planet's ills. (Paul Meredith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Development Bank Shifts on Hungary

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
When the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development started doing business in Hungary two years ago, privatization was humming along and the bankers who were sent to make investment deals thought their task would be relatively easy. It has not worked out that way.
Begun by Western countries as a way of helping Eastern Europe convert to a market economy, the development bank has had difficulty finding large private companies to support. This has been the case even in Hungary, where foreign investment came early and strong and where the Government was eager to sell off business assets. 
 "It's one of our frustrations," said Paul Dax, the bank's representative here. "Our opportunities are limited in the private sector. Privatization is going haltingly. It is more difficult than everyone expected."
The bank, which is owned by 56 countries and international agencies, began with the premise that 60 percent of its investments in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union would be in private enterprises, with the remainder in public projects.
 
Loans in Public-Sector Areas
 But in Hungary, a country that many called the showcase of privatization, the largest loans and investments have been in four public-sector areas: roads, urban transportation, agriculture and phones.
The bank has committed a total of $627 million to Hungary so far, the most it has invested in a single country, with $454 million in the public sector and $187 million in the private sector. The bank's investments are made in European Currency Units, a weighted basket of 12 European currencies.
By comparison, the development bank has committed $590 million to Poland, a country with 40 million people, four times the population of Hungary, and $93 million to the Czech Republic, a country with a population about the same size as Hungary's.
In investments in 11 private Hungarian concerns, the amounts have been small by the bank's standards. Indeed, in one of its earliest Hungarian investments, a computer company, Microsystem, the bank decided to break its minimum exposure rule of 5 million ECU's (or about $6 million) and invested 2.4 million ECU's ($2.8 million).
But the bank's biggest investment in the private sector has been a loan of $72 million to a joint venture by General Motors with Hungarian partners, an investment that posed questions about why a big American company needed such a loan.
After a fast start in 1990, the pace of large-scale privatization in Hungary has slowed. About 20 percent of state-owned enterprises have been sold since 1990, but relatively few companies have been sold since the first half of last year, Hungarian and Western economists said.
A number of factors have contributed to the decline, economists said. The collapse of Hungary's markets in the former Soviet Union occurred much faster than expected. At the same time, Western Europe moved into a recession as Hungary -- along with Poland and the Czech Republic -- was trying to develop markets in the West. Hungary's exports were down 27 percent for the first five months of 1993, compared with the period a year earlier.
At home, the State Property Agency, the institution created by Hungary to sell the state's companies, is short of workers and has been overwhelmed by the number of transactions it must handle, local and foreign investors say.
And as Hungarian nationalism has increased, right-wing political parties have been questioning why Hungarian assets should be sold to foreigners.
"Two years ago, I would have said pharmaceutical companies, the tourist industry and banks would have been our clients," said Peter Reiniger, a senior banker who specializes in Hungary at the bank's London headquarters. One plan to enter the tourist sector -- the reconstruction of the 19th-century Grand Royal in Budapest into a four-star hotel -- has been held up because of a dispute over property ownership.
In the pharmaceutical business, one of Hungary's strengths, only one of the five state-owned companies has attracted foreign investment -- from France.
Bank officials said they were trying different approaches to Hungary. The bank board recently approved involvement in a state holding company that would take over a portfolio of Hungary's big troubled companies -- particularly in pharmaceuticals and chemicals -- and try to turn them around in three or four years.
"We would be working with the public agencies, but the aim would be privatization with the objective to sell," Mr. Dax said.
Mr. Reiniger said he hoped that by being more flexible, the bank would have greater success in Hungary.
"Maybe we were in a euphoric mood when we started and the politics had changed," Mr. Reiniger said. "But in the economy, a revolution is unacceptable; evolution is acceptable."

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Down for July

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
The machine tool industry learned again last month that what Detroit giveth, it can also taketh away.
Machine tool orders slid for the third straight month in July as large automotive orders continued to level off, the Association for Manufacturing Technology reported yesterday. 
 Net new orders reached $250.8 million in July, down 20.1 percent from June's $313.7 million, which was a smidgeon lower than May's $315.8 million. The July figure is 28 percent lower than the $348.3 million reported in April. Until May, the industry was enjoying a banner year.
Some analysts cautioned against jumping to conclusions because summer is traditionally slow for manufacturers who buy machine tools. They note, for instance, that the July figure was still 22.1 percent higher than the $205.4 million of July 1992.
"Your next real window into what is taking place inside Corporate America won't take place till the fall," said Eli S. Lustgarten, Paine Webber's machinery analyst.
 
Slower Gains Foreseen
 He nonetheless agrees with others that the bulge of automotive orders has run its course. "You're beginning to see a normal level of business," he said. "The rate of gain that we saw in the first six months was not sustainable and is expected to slow in the second half."
Machine tools, the cutting and forming devices that enable manufacturers to make metal products, are ordered months before they are actually put to use and are sometimes followed as a barometer of the nation's manufacturing sector.
Auto makers, by far the largest buyers of machine tools, often account for one- to two-thirds of all purchases, according to William G. Copeland, a Stamford, Conn., economist who tracks the business.
In its press release, the association, which releases monthly statistics, chose to stress that orders were running at $2.02 billion, up 37 percent for the year. All the big gains were posted in February, March and April; the last three months have worked to whittle down the percentage rise.
Moreover, July's decline occurred despite a 39.9 percent spike in exports, partly a result of a weak dollar that makes American products more attractive abroad, and despite a 43.9 percent gain in metal-forming devices. Both exports and metal-forming tools make up relatively small fractions of the total industry.
Dale Norton, vice president of planning and business development for Giddings & Lewis, a large supplier to the automotive industry, called July "a reasonably decent month for us" and said the company was encouraged by activity "in the automated technology area where we are selling large machine tools."
But Christopher Cole, vice president for machine tool products for Cincinnati Milacron, said there had been "a major downturn in commercial sales and military programs, and it's a worldwide problem."
 
Outlook Held Bright
 Over all, many analysts say the industry's outlook remains bright. While labor talks this fall may encourage car makers to put their capital plans on hold, they are eager to use the lull in capital spending by Japan to improve their own products and pick up share.
"There is still a gap there," Mr. Copeland said. "So we would anticipate that Detroit's relative success this year will allow them to continue to be a big machine tool buyer in 1994 and 1995 as they continue to recapture market share."
Plus, other manufacturers like Caterpillar and Deere are still talking about making big investments in their plant and equipment, as are some energy companies, a factor that might offset the slowdown in automotive orders.
Caterpillar, for instance, had said it would spend about $485 million in 1993. It has since lowered that estimate a bit, but still has a long way to go to reach anything close to that figure, according to Mr. Lustgarten of Paine Webber.
"If you believe their capital spending budgets," he said, these cautious spenders may be stepping up their orders soon.

HEADLINE: Job-Market Gains Found

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
While the job market remains far from robust, there are signs that it will continue inching back to health in the fourth quarter, according to a survey of American employers released yesterday.
Manpower Inc., the big temporary-help concern, said 22 percent of the nearly 15,000 businesses it had polled planned to add employees in the last three months of the year. About 11 percent said they planned to cut jobs, 3 percent said they were not sure about their job plans and the rest indicated that employment would remain the same. 
 "Hiring strength is running behind the comparable periods of the 1983-84 recovery period, but it is making progress," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, president of Milwaukee-based Manpower, which conducts the quarterly employment outlook survey.
Prospects were brighter for job seekers in the July-September period this year. About 25 percent of the companies expected to add jobs and 8 percent were eliminating them, Manpower reported. Economic activity usually slows at year-end, the company noted.
The Manpower survey indicated that hiring would be below the national average in the Northeast and West, about average for the Midwest and sharply above average in the South.

HEADLINE: Somalia: Time to Leave?

 BODY:
A humanitarian mission to deliver food to millions of starving Somalis is degenerating into an obsessive search-and-destroy operation against supporters of a single warlord, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid. U.S. soldiers, once welcomed with smiles, now worry about snipers and booby traps.
Americans have not just a right but an obligation to demand that the Clinton Administration explain what compelling national purpose justifies such risk to the lives of U.S. soldiers and Somali civilians caught in the crossfire. 
 Senator Bob Dole and Representative Ron Dellums, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, have tried, responsibly, to press for answers. But until last week, the Administration deflected all challenges with stale cold war rhetoric about resolve, credibility and tests of will.
In a speech on Friday, Secretary of Defense Les Aspin at last offered a serious response. He spelled out the goals that the Administration seeks to achieve before withdrawing U.S. forces.
Secretary Aspin's speech is a step toward more reasoned debate. But military developments in Somalia, especially the disturbing dispatch of a U.S. military hit team to Mogadishu, threaten to overwhelm Mr. Aspin's theoretical exercise.
The humanitarian mission that President Bush announced to popular acclaim last November was largely accomplished by the first months of this year. The Clinton Administration then moved to turn the Somalia operation back to the United Nations. An ambitious Security Council resolution in March defined long-term objectives of restoring order and rebuilding Somalia's economic and political structure.
For the first time, Washington agreed to put U.S. troops under U.N. command. Hopes ran high for a path-breaking experiment in collective security. But the U.N. has made some bad mistakes.
The worst came after a June 5 ambush and killing of Pakistani peacekeepers. The U.N.'s top man on the scene, Adm. Jonathan Howe, posted a price on the head of the ambush's presumed author, General Aidid, thereby shutting him out of political negotiations. Until then the general's participation had been considered crucial to a settlement.
Admiral Howe's misjudgment quickly changed the character of the U.N. mission. U.N. forces continue to do much good in other areas of the country. But in south Mogadishu, General Aidid's stronghold, casualties have mounted and relief efforts have been set back.
America's role has been particularly distorted. In addition to the 3,100 U.S. troops under U.N. command, a smaller U.S.-commanded contingent of quick-reaction forces bears the brunt of anti-Aidid combat. It was to sharpen the urban commando capabilities of this contingent that the Pentagon dispatched 400 Army Rangers last week.
Secretary Aspin tried to soften the focus on these anti-Aidid operations. His criteria for declaring victory and withdrawing included establishing "reasonable security in south Mogadishu." But he put his main emphasis elsewhere, on generalized reductions in heavy weaponry and the early creation of a Somali police force that could reduce clashes between U.N. forces and civilians.
Even better would be a renewed effort to engage General Aidid or other members of his clan. The Clinton Administration stiffly asserts that the U.N. can't talk to people who kill peacekeepers. But of course the U.N. does just that all the time, from Cambodia to Bosnia.
U.N. reconstruction is very different from classic warfare. But more than 40 years of cold war thinking has traumatized official Washington. Military and foreign policy professionals sometimes have trouble distinguishing between bush-league bandits and real threats. Today's local warlords no longer serve as proxies in some larger competition. The only way General Aidid could damage important U.S. interests would be for America to let itself be obsessed by him.
The present U.N. mandate in Somalia expires Oct. 31. Perhaps, in the intervening two months, U.N. leaders can find their way back to the constructive course they slipped from in June. If not, then it may be time for Americans to leave.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The U.N. Entraps Clinton

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
More than 10,000 American troops, drawn mainly from the First Armored Division in Bad Kreuznach, Germany, were on the verge of being sent as part of a NATO force to Bosnia to impose the wrong peace in the wrong place at the wrong time.
Had the Bosnian Muslims bowed to Western pressure to accept the latest surrender terms proposed by the U.N. -- a humiliation that Bosnia's Parliament unanimously rejected over the weekend -- American forces would have become guarantors of a Munich-style sellout that would have created a gulag of ghettos and encouraged future ethnic cleansing. 
 How did the Clinton Administration stumble to this brink?
First, by cravenly caving in to the French and British reluctance to arm the Muslims and to suppress Serbian-Croatian firepower from the air.
Second, by reacting to this allied rebuff with a foolish commitment to use our forces in NATO to support any surrender terms that the U.N. could work out.
Third, by abdicating operational authority to the U.N., thereby undermining our threats to use air power to stop the Serbian shelling of civilians -- at a moment when the only incentive to negotiate came from the possibility of our air attacks.
Fourth, by limiting our involvement in the peace negotiations to occasional expressions of distaste, as if to dissociate the U.S. in advance from betrayal of principle -- and then, behind the scenes, to urge the Muslim Bosnians to swallow the repugnant terms because American protection would not be forthcoming until they gave up.
No doubt the Bush acquiescence two years ago in the U.N. cutoff of arms to the Bosnian Muslims was a diplomatic blunder. But this year's false starts belong on Bill Clinton's doorstep, and his apparent willingness to use American troops to enforce a U.N.-sponsored surrender will lead to Clinton's Balkan Mess.
People of my strategic persuasion favored a hunkering-down of U.N. humanitarians on the scene while Western powers gave Serbian irregulars a taste of their own medicine. Such sustained bombing of artillery positions, supplies and bridges, combined with an increased blockade of Serbia and Croatia, would have set the stage for a partition that would not have left Bosnia an economic basket case, its survivors the world's wards.
Instead, what we have now is the undenied appearance of the promise of American ground troop involvement in the American-led policing of a surrender that the American people had no say in and want no part of. American lives would be at risk in a protracted entanglement where American policy never came into play and American diplomatic muscle was never applied.
No, thanks. The inept Clinton Secretary of State has given a blank check to the U.N.'s Boutros Boutros-Ghali: You decide what the policy is to be and how much it will cost in lives and treasure, and the U.S. will obey. Is America to be a payer but not a player? Even unreconstructed hawks get off the train at that stop.
When Mr. Clinton finally gives a speech wrapping himself in the glories of multilateralism, he will not be able to sell the U.N.-brokered surrender as remotely honorable, especially considering the U.N.'s one-sided disarmament. If he continues tacitly to endorse the U.N. deal, he could only plead that slow strangulation in ghettos would be better than quick death in war.
Such argument would draw derision from across the spectrum because America will not defend with its lives what it cannot defend with its conscience. The problem is not the Bosnian unwillingness to submit to hopelessness, like good victims; the problem is the Serbo-Croat demand for Muslim humiliation and the Western powers' lack of backbone.
What can Mr. Clinton do now? He can get on the hook to Mitterrand and Major with changes of the U.N. terms to give Muslim Bosnia some territorial contiguity and undisputed control of its capital of Sarajevo. He should arrange swift, certain NATO retaliation for any aggression during negotiations. He should set the terms for the participation of American forces in NATO peacemaking, not make our troops pawns in U.N. hand wringing.
Time is running out, Mr. Clinton. Avoid the U.N. trap. Send Europe the message: Bosnia alive or NATO dead.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Anyone Could See Japan's Steady Change

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"For Japan, the Old Slurs Are the New Party Line" (The Week in Review, Aug. 15) shows little historical perspective and considerable condescension in reporting "a complex about-face" in Japan in recent weeks. 
 The kind of about-face you attribute to Japan -- denial followed by admission, "speaking frankly about the terrible mistakes of World War II and about the dynamics of its economy" -- is observed with distressing frequency in the United States (and most likely elsewhere) as well.
Aside from that, to suggest there was no debate in Japan on the business-Government relationship -- "this collusive structure" -- is absurd. For nearly two decades prominent Japanese businessmen have questioned Japan's approach to the trade surplus, and a call for change in international business practices began more than a dozen years ago.
Your observation that "change in Japan often seems glacial" -- now a cliche among some Americans -- is fallacious and condescending, based on the notion that society must always change or else deserve sneering condemnation. It also assumes that the United States changes all the time, but Japan doesn't.
True, calls for "change" are now as deafening in Japan as they were in the 1992 United States Presidential campaign. But this by no means proves that Japan has remained stagnant. Even during the 38-year sway of the Liberal Democratic Party the country more than once changed course abruptly and thoroughly in both Government policy and national life.
 
HIRO SATO
Director, Research & Planning
Japan External Trade Organization
New York, Aug. 20, 1993

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

 BODY:
In celebration of this week's beginning of the United States Open tennis championship at Flushing Meadows, Queens, the Women's Tennis Association is honoring its founder, Billie Jean King, at a benefit dinner tonight at the Marriott Marquis Hotel.
The organizers of the honor say it is supposed to be a surprise -- as long as Ms. King does not read the newspaper, and as long as Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert, who are scheduled to join the festivities, do not tell her either, all of which appears to be a long shot. 
 Ms. King, 49 years old, founded the association 20 years ago to make careers in professional tennis economically feasible for the ever increasing number of women players. The dinner will benefit the New York Special Olympics.
The association's president, Pam Shriver, said the proceeds from the benefit will "encourage more athletes with mental retardation to train and compete in tennis." The Special Olympics president, Anthony Adamo, said the money "will go far to help us reach out to even more people with development disabilities and enrich their lives."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Young Perspective on Management

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 27

 BODY:
When Alan Webber and William Taylor were editors at the widely respected but staid Harvard Business Review, they thought of the publication as the "bran muffin of magazines: good for you but hard to swallow."
So Mr. Webber, 44, and Mr. Taylor, 34, decided to create a new business magazine that would combine the managerial insights of the Harvard publication with the writing and jazzy graphics of Rolling Stone. 
 The result is Fast Company, a publication aimed at a new generation of business people in what the editors call the new economy, where the competition is global and work processes are constantly changing. The magazine begins publishing in October as a bimonthly with a goal of becoming a monthly.
Most successful in this new economy, Mr. Webber said, are senior managers who are often younger, better educated and more knowledgeable about information technology than those "even in their 40's, who are dead from the neck up." Many of these managers have not embraced such publications as Fortune, Business Week or Forbes, he said.
"There's a generational power shift going on in big companies," Mr. Webber said. "These people are affecting the substance of business and managing."
The magazine's target audience would be in their late 20's to late 40's. However, Mr. Taylor added, "It's partly demographic and partly attitudinal -- if Sam Walton were alive, for example, he'd get this magazine."
Fast Company has an eclectic group of a dozen investors from the United States, Canada and Japan. They include Tom Peters, a management consultant and co-author of "In Search of Excellence"; Regis McKenna, a Silicon Valley publicist and venture capitalist, and John Doerr, a partner in Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, an investor in high-technology start-ups.
"It's hardly a breakthrough idea to say something phenomenally new is happening in the world economy," Mr. Peters said. "But who is covering this transition? The Harvard Business Review is seldom out in front of the power curve. Inc. focuses on start-ups, and you get bits and pieces of management coverage in Fortune and Business Week. But nowhere do you have a place focusing on the intriguing people doing interesting things from a management perspective."
Roger Black, a magazine designer who has worked for The New York Times, Newsweek, Esquire and Rolling Stone, is designing the publication. Mr. Taylor said each issue would offer a lengthy piece on management, called "The Big Idea," along with interviews, photo essays, profiles of individuals and companies, and regular columns. Mr. Webber said the publication would strive to offer "articles that start conversations."
The first issue will feature a "Big Idea" essay called "Business as War," in which Mark B. Fuller, chief executive of the Monitor Company, a management consulting firm, describes the new rules of doing battle. The issue will also have a humor column by Karen Karbo, a novelist in Portland, Ore., and a profile of Tommy Boy Records, a rising rap label.
Initially, Fast Company will be distributed free to 30,000 targeted readers from a data base the editors created themselves. The first issue's 35 ad pages were also given out free.
Mr. Taylor said the magazine's eventual cover price had not been determined, but that he hoped to reach profitability, and a paid circulation of 100,000, in three years. The magazine will soon begin a direct mail campaign to draw subscribers.
 
A Hot Market
 Marshall Loeb, managing editor of Fortune, said the business magazine market was hot, and "there's always room for a new magazine with a compelling idea behind it." But he said he believed that Fortune already covered the subject area well.
Rich Karlgaard, editor of a new Forbes business publication called ASAP and the founding editor of Upside, a high-technology business magazine, said Fast Company's premise sounded "fuzzy."
"The idea of HBR meets Rolling Stone doesn't tell me what the focus is," Mr. Karlgaard said. "Crucial to making a new magazine work is having a focus and a clear position. They can easily consume $5 million to $10 million in the first year just building circulation."
Mr. Webber said the magazine's name reflected both "business dynamism and a certain attitude."
"The notion that you are in fast company," he said, "is both a business term and an old notion about people who are racy, willing to take risks."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1160 words

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Clinton's September Agenda: A Month of Policy Overload?

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30

 BODY:
Nobody expects the health care overhaul to be easy. Nobody expects the struggle over the North American Free Trade Agreement to be neat. Both measures require an enormous amount of public education, some delicate coalition-building and a hard and complicated sales job in Congress.
Now, a capital that has barely recovered from the battle over President Clinton's economic plan is watching with some wonderment as the Administration begins to tackle both these issues in a single month. Plus, by the way, Vice President Al Gore's proposals to "reinvent Government." September, in short, may be the quintessential Clinton experience, the month of policy overload. 
 Administration officials say they have little choice in the matter. They say they must begin the push for the free trade agreement now for it to stand a chance of passage before the end of the year. At the same time, they are adamant about not postponing the unveiling of the health care plan once again, although actual votes on it are not expected until next year.
 
Communications Strategy
 Moreover, aides say, the President is intent on moving ahead with both measures, as well as with Mr. Gore's proposals to make the Government more efficient, while also responding to an ever-present Ross Perot and a Congress supposedly still hungry for budget cuts.
As a result, after much jockeying in the Administration between the forces of health care and the champions of free trade, the White House has developed a carefully sequenced -- and jam-packed -- communications strategy for September.
Mr. Gore's drive to streamline the Government will be highlighted the week after Labor Day, the push for the free trade pact will take the Presidential spotlight soon thereafter, and the Clinton health plan will probably be presented to the nation on Sept. 22, with a flurry of health-related events before and after.
This is a great deal to ask of the body politic, a number of officials acknowledge.
"We learned in the budget debate that it is hard for the country to take on more than one debate and issue at a time," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader. "You lose the edge and the focus. But we don't live in a perfect world, and it's not always possible to get the big debates isolated."
The fear, of course, is that the early days of the health care campaign will be forced to compete with a messy, bitter fight over free trade.
The synergy between the two issues could be particularly complex because in some important respects they have cross-cutting constituencies. Organized labor, for example, will be leading the opposition to the trade agreement, but is expected to be among the principal advocates for overhauling the health care system.
"It's not a pleasant feeling, going in one door and fighting on the one hand, walking in the other and saying this is what we're for," said Robert M. McGlotten, legislative director for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
 
Signs of Tensions
 There was no clearer sign of the tensions in this Democratic base constituency than in the commemoration on Saturday of the 30th anniversary of the march on Washington and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I have a dream" speech. The crowd, which was heavily drawn from the ranks of organized labor, was a sea of anti-Nafta signs, interrupted by placards calling for changes in the health care system.
The Congressional maneuvering is equally Byzantine. Much of the House Democratic caucus, including many of its leaders, will be working against the free trade agreement. At the same time, the Administration will be counting on those same Democrats to begin selling the health care plan. Most professional politicians are accustomed to shifting between coalitions as they move from one issue to another, but neither health care nor Nafta falls under the category of business as usual. Both issues are extremely emotional.
"There's just so much angst that the country and political people will be willing to deal with at one time, having just come over a very high hurdle on the budget," said Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the House majority whip who is an opponent of the trade agreement.
"Health care is what he got elected on," Mr. Bonior said, referring to Mr. Clinton. "It certainly wasn't Nafta. And that ought to be the focus in the fall."
Much of the complaining over the timing of these proposals has been considered somewhat suspect, since it often comes from opponents of the trade agreement. Postponing consideration of Nafta could help build opposition to it. But other analysts, particularly advocates of overhauling the health care system, worry about overloading the public agenda.
It is axiomatic that the early weeks of presenting the health care plan will be crucial if the plan is to pass. By the rules of modern politics, and by the grim lessons for the Administration from the budget battle, he who defines a proposal first may not necessarily prevail but will certainly have the upper hand.
Many political analysts agree that making the case for overhauling health care, which accounts for a seventh of the nation's economy, will be one of the great challenges of modern politics.
"The policy networks have been chewing on health care for years, and the options are clearly understood by the people focusing on that," said Bruce Buchanan, a professor of government at the University of Texas. "But the people who are not brought up to speed are the ones who will have to support it and finance it, and that is the voters. It took the policy networks years to get to this point, and now the public's supposed to absorb it immediately."
 
Connecting the Issues
 Administration officials respond that the President sees all three of these issues as connected: making the Government more efficient; revising the health care system to provide more personal security and to make the economy more competitive by controlling the growth of health costs; and opening up new markets through the free trade agreement.
It is also possible that Nafta, which will require the Administration to rely heavily on the Republicans, will set the stage for bipartisanship on the health care plan. And such bipartisanship could foster a public education process that could lead to a slow building of consensus, as was the case with the tax overhaul in 1986.
But it is just as plausible that Mr. Clinton could end up in a two-front war -- on one side accused of costing America jobs because of the free trade pact, and on the other, accused of costing America jobs because of new requirements that small businesses provide health insurance for their employees.
Even within the White House there are doubters. "It's going to be a terrible mess," one White House official said. "And we've all told him that." But Mr. Clinton, refreshed by the ocean breezes of Martha's Vineyard, was back in Washington today, prepared to plunge ahead.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: The First Step;
More Realism Will Be Needed Before Pact Between Israelis and P.L.O. Is a Done Deal

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30

 BODY:
The draft agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization is the Middle East equivalent of the fall of the Berlin wall -- seemingly irreconcilable foes, who demonized one another for decades, suddenly breaking down a barrier to peace few thought would ever be breached.
But as with the fall of the Berlin wall, this agreement is just the beginning of the reconciliation process, not the end of it. It is a triumph of realism over fanaticism and political courage over political cowardice, but it cannot stand on its own. Even more realism and courage will be required to translate this agreement in principle into a detailed and sustainable structure. 
 This is not a done deal yet. The big question is whether this delicate Israeli-P.L.O. understanding, reached secretly in the serenity of Norway, can survive the light of day and the political heat of the Middle East.
 
Culmination of Pressures
 The reason it might succeed is that this accord was no fluke. In many ways it was the culmination of a series of international, regional and domestic pressures, which have forced Israeli and P.L.O. leaders to do the unthinkable.
For the P.L.O., the end of the cold war and the crumbling of the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact deprived Yasir Arafat of the international diplomatic support, the military aid and the training grounds for Palestinian students and guerrillas that had been a key prop for his leadership and influence on the world stage. At the same time, his miscalculation in supporting Iraq against Kuwait in the Persian Gulf war has led to the impoverishment of the P.L.O. as an organization, as all the Arab gulf governments withdrew their financial support.
Additionally, the slump in oil prices made even the P.L.O.'s few remaining Arab friends less able to pay it the tithe of old that had enabled the P.L.O. to reject Israel in comfort. The P.L.O.'s backing for Saddam Hussein also cost it politically and morally in the West. It was no longer the darling of many Western liberals, and with the emergence of Bosnia on the world stage the Palestinians were replaced by the Muslims of Sarajevo as the preferred underdogs.
All of these factors forced Mr. Arafat to deal on Israel's terms -- agreeing to start with autonomy in Gaza and Jericho, postponing the issue of who controls Jerusalem and accepting a continued Israeli security presence.
For the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, the decision also grew from a variety of pressures: the inability of the Government to provide internal security for its citizens without some progress on the Israeli-Palestinian front, the conviction of Israeli leaders that Israel could never play the economic and political role it aspires to in the post-cold war world without some kind of understanding with the Palestinians, and the sheer exhaustion of an Israeli public too long at the barricades and desperate for some normalcy in their lives.
Finally, there was the rise of a much more dangerous alternative to the P.L.O. in the occupied territories -- Hamas, the Palestinians' Islamic militant movement. Hamas, with its commitment to the destruction of Israel, made the more secular P.L.O. look moderate by comparison.
 
A Seat at the Table
 All of this forced Mr. Rabin to dispense with the long-held Israeli notion that they could negotiate a settlement with "good" local Palestinians and without the involvement of the "bad" P.L.O.
In return for P.L.O. concessions, Mr. Rabin had to offer Mr. Arafat the one thing that he had long been denied and wanted more than anything else: a formal, acknowledged role in the process. What drove the P.L.O. over the years more than any single factor was its organizational imperative -- the desire to be accepted and recognized by Israel and Washington.
Pressures also forced Mr. Rabin to accede to Mr. Arafat's demand that as part of any transition agreement Palestinians had to be given political authority not simply over such matters as health care and education but over actual territory.
Even with all these pressures and incentives, however, this accord will not go down easily in the Middle East. Israel's opposition to dealing with the P.L.O. in any way has been a cornerstone of Middle East politics since the 1960's. As a result, many key actors in the region have built their politics on the assumption that Israel and the P.L.O. would never reconcile.
 
The New Reality
 Syria, which always wants to speak for the Palestinians and spearhead any peace effort, counted on this fact; Jordan, which always assumed it would be called in to deal with Israel on the P.L.O.'s behalf, also counted on it; Israeli settlers, who always assumed that the P.L.O. would never accept any sort of compromise with Israel, counted on it, and Israeli and Palestinian hard-liners, opposed to any peace settlement, counted on it.
Now all of them must adjust to this new reality, and these are not the sort of parties that adjust to fundamental changes easily -- or nonviolently. They toss grenades, not leaflets; they write death warrants, not Op-Ed pieces. If this accord moves ahead, the potential for civil war in both the Palestinian and Israeli camps is very real.
Already Ahmed Jabril, the Syrian-sponsored radical Palestinian guerrilla leader, has issued a statement threatening Mr. Arafat with the same fate as Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, who was felled by an assassin's bullet. Unidentified Israeli hard-liners threw a grenade Sunday night at the home of a Cabinet minister. American Jewish groups, which for years have made opposition to American talks with the P.L.O. one of their central preoccupations, are now struggling to figure out what their public positions should be.
These are just the tremors; earthquakes to follow.
Clinton Administration officials acknowledge privately that they were taken by surprise by this understanding and are also trying to figure out how to adjust to it. Top Administration officials were aware of the secret Israeli-P.L.O. talks, but they tended to dismiss their potential. In part this was because of they tended to dismiss the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, as a grandstanding statesman, and in part it was because of their even lower regard for Mr. Arafat.
On the one hand, American officials do not want to pour cold water on the accord, since, in principle, this concept of quickly empowering the Palestinians by giving them a real, but limited, opportunity for self-rule, is something Washington has been pushing for. But at the same time, American officials are clearly wary of throwing their support behind a concept that might not be fully baked. "It is too soon to be overly euphoric," said a senior American official who has been through the Middle East peace process.
Prime Minister Rabin asked Mr. Peres to fly to California and brief Secretary of State Warren Christopher, say Israeli officials, because Mr. Rabin wants American endorsement of the plan in order to help him sell it at home and because he wanted a "reality check" from Mr. Christopher about what Mr. Peres had produced.
The Palestinians and Israelis also want American backing because only Washington has the money, and the influence with wealthy Arab oil states, to produce the money that will be required to sustain an autonomous Palestinian entity in Gaza and Jericho. Both sides also feel that they need the Americans to be the guarantors of any understanding they reach -- guarantors of both its substance and its timetable.
American officials say their general view is that the Washington-based peace talks, which resume on Tuesday, should be the vehicle through which the parties try to translate their agreement in principle into an agreement in reality -- a process that will take some time.
"The Americans should greet this with enthusiasm and now assert leadership, in two ways," said Stephen Cohen, of the Center for Middle East Peace, a group based in Montreal.
"One is through direct contact with all the parties, including the P.L.O." The other, Mr. Cohen said, is by promoting a similar breakthrough on the Israeli-Syrian front.
There is a simple three-way equation at the core of the Middle East peace process. If Israel and Syria are making progress, the Palestinians will try to scuttle it in order not to be left behind. If Israel and the Palestinians are making progress, the Syrians will try to scuttle it in order not to be left behind.
"Middle East peace cannot stand on two legs," Mr. Cohen said. "It must have three. That is the American role, to make sure the third leg is there. Without it, this Israeli-Palestinian understanding won't survive."

NEW YORK CITY
 
CORTINES IS CHOSEN TO HEAD SCHOOLS
The Board of Education, divided 4-3, decided to appoint Ramon C. Cortines, the former Schools Superintendent in San Francisco, as the city's next Schools Chancellor. Mr. Cortines is planning to fly to New York today. A1.
Six months after a bitterly divided Board of Education ousted Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, the chief policymaking body for the nation's largest school system seems as divided as ever. B3.
 
TENTATIVE AGREEMENT ON TEACHERS' PACT
Mayor Dinkins and the leaders of the union representing 65,000 teachers said that they had reached a tentative agreement on a new four-year contract calling for raises averaging 9 percent over the length of the deal. The tentative settlement, reached on the eve of both a new school year and the general election campaign, could help Mr. Dinkins win the endorsement of the powerful union, the United Federation of Teachers. B3.
 

A TOUGH TIME IN SLOGANEERING
New York is a tough town, and it takes a tough media strategy to win a mayoral race in it -- so tough, apparently, that even your campaign slogan can be turned against you. Mayor Dinkins took to the airwaves Friday with commercials portraying him as a caring steward of a troubled city and ending with the tag line: "It takes more than tough talk to run a tough city." Within 24 hours his opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, agreed. B2.
 
2 VIEWS OF TAPES IN TERRORIST CASE
At a bail hearing for one of the defendants in the case of the foiled plot to terrorize New York City, defense lawyers and prosecutors offered a prelude to the kind of battle that is likely to rage throughout the trial: scrapping over the meaning locked in transcripts of secretly recorded and sometimes elliptical conversations between defendants and a Government informer. B4.
 
RIDING A BEAT, TALL IN THE SADDLE
As a girl in Brooklyn, Kathy E. Ryan loved anything and everything having to do with horses. Now, when she can leave her office at 621 West 42d Street, she rides the streets of Manhattan. She is the commanding officer of the New York City Police Department's mounted unit. B4.
