LENGTH: 1418 words

HEADLINE: The N.A.A.C.P. Means Business

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30

 BODY:
Officials of Hughes Aircraft were stunned this month when the N.A.A.C.P. publicly lambasted the aerospace contractor for what the group called a dismal record of hiring members of minorities.
But more shocking than the accusations, Hughes officials said, was the way the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People made them: at a news conference, without first giving the company a chance to defend itself. 
 And despite an informal agreement between the two parties to work together, the N.A.A.C.P. has continued to berate Hughes in the press for what it says is widespread mistreatment of minorities.
Such hard-nosed tactics are part of a decade-old expanding agenda by the nation's largest civil rights organization to provide new economic opportunity for members of minorities by pressing Corporate America to hire more of them.
 
A New Battle Plan
 Under the Rev. Dr. Benjamin J. Chavis, who became executive director last year, the N.A.C.C.P. has pursued that agenda with new aggressiveness in recent months. The civil rights group has held demonstrations on Capitol Hill, picketed the headquarters of Government contractors it says do not comply with affirmative-action requirements and negotiated a $1 billion agreement with the parent of the Denny's restaurant chain to increase black employment, management and equity.
While the N.A.A.C.P. had persuaded 70 companies to sign similar agreements -- including McDonald's, General Motors, Pacific Bell, Safeway, Walt Disney, United Airlines and Coors -- none have reached the scope and magnitude of the Denny's pact, which has set the tone for such agreements in the future.
"Our approach to Corporate America is not so much to ask for special compensation or for entitlement," Dr. Chavis said. "But we want to raise the question: Does it not make good business sense for companies to redefine their relationship with a multiracial society?"
Dr. Chavis said that black Americans spent about $380 billion on goods and services in the United States last year and that companies that were the beneficiaries of black consumerism had a responsibility to address the needs of that community.
Officials of the association say they are closely scrutinizing other companies, particularly those that do business with the Government or that have a large number of customers who are members of minorities, including aerospace and other military contractors and the entertainment industry. The group says it will take action against companies that have poor affirmative-action records.
Asked whether the N.A.A.C.P. risked alienation by employing such tough tactics, Dr. Chavis responded: "We are not trying to stage a media stunt here. We are taking something that is potentially polarizing and negative for these companies and using it to build bridges."
Behind the association's new emphasis on economic empowerment are growing concerns in the black community that despite decades of civil rights gains and increasing black political power, blacks still remain outside the economic mainstream and under-represented in the work force and management of large corporations.
Another motivating factor, N.A.A.C.P. officials said, was lax enforcement of the Federal diversity policies through 12 years of the Reagan and Bush Administrations. Clinton Administration officials said they were reviewing the policies of the Labor Department's Office of Federal Contract Compliance, which is responsible for enforcing affirmative-action guidelines for Government contractors and that they believed some changes were in order.
Over all, the N.A.A.C.P. said it was seeking to negotiate so-called fair-share agreements, in which companies promise to hire more members of minorities as employees and contractors and to foster management and ownership among minorities within these companies.
 
Agreement Over Denny's
 Last month, the association announced the largest such fair-share accord of its kind with the Flagstar Companies, the parent of Denny's. The pact provides for an increase in black employees at Denny's and black ownership and management of restaurants and use of black subcontractors. The benefits of the agreement for black Americans have been put at $1 billion.
Jerry J. Richardson, Flagstar's chief executive, said the N.A.A.C.P. did not put pressure on him to sign the fair-share agreement and that ultimately the pact made good business sense because it would result in new customers and new ideas.
To be sure, the fair-share agreement was a marketing coup for Flagstar. The move was intended to salvage the company's already fragile image after being hit by a flood of lawsuits, charging that several Denny's restaurants had refused to serve black customers, required some to pay a cover charge or insisted that they pay for their meals in advance.
Mr. Richardson said that he became convinced that the fair-share agreement was appropriate after spending several hours with Dr. Chavis. "I think that over all Ben Chavis is a man of courage and conviction and that he wants to create a harmonious atmosphere not one of confrontation," Mr. Richardson said.
The chief executive said he hoped Flagstar's agreement with the association might serve as a model for other corporations.
"Signing a billion-dollar agreement with Flagstar sent reverberations throughout the business community," Dr. Chavis said. "Some people thought that it would jar other companies from talking with the N.A.A.C.P., but the opposite has happened. We are getting calls from corporate leaders in the oil industry, autos and high-tech who are seeking to make changes."
Dr. Chavis, 45, is seen as a radical departure from the traditional N.A.A.C.P. leadership, which used the courts and pressed legislation to address the problems of black America. A veteran of the civil rights movement, Dr. Chavis is known for his activism.
Dr. Chavis was one of the so-called Wilmington 10, who were arrested and convicted in 1972 of charges of conspiracy and inciting a mob to fire-bomb a white-owned grocery store in North Carolina. After four years in prison, the protesters were freed when an appeals court ruled that the evidence against them had been falsified.
A ordained minister in the United Church of Christ, he has a bachelor's degree in chemistry from the University of North Carolina, a Master of Divinity degree from Duke University and Doctor of Ministry from Howard University.
 
Five Goals
 The fair-share pacts have five basic goals: aggressive affirmative action, advancement of minorities into management, utilization of companies owned by members of minorities, philanthropic support for minorities' causes and minorities' participation on corporate boards.
Fred Rasheed, the association's national director of economic development, said most companies that the N.A.A.C.P. focused on were very receptive to the idea of fair-share agreements.
The agreements often provide companies with added benefits, like a strong political ally in Washington, where the N.A.A.C.P. is likely to pursue legislative agendas that are in the companies' interest, Mr. Rasheed said.
The N.A.A.C.P. estimates that between 1986 and 1990 fair-share agreements generated about $47 billion in economic benefits to the black community, including entrepreneurs, professionals and employees who benefited from upward mobility at the companies.
Safeway Inc. said that a 1984 fair-share pact, which required the supermarket chain to substantially increase the number of minority suppliers, has provided the Oakland, Calif., company with a variety of new business opportunities.
"It's been good for minority suppliers, the N.A.A.C.P. and for Safeway," said Brian Dowling, a Safeway spokesman. "We have gained access to new products and new ways of doing business."
 
Seeks Improvement
 In the case of Hughes Aircraft, company officials say they have one of the best records of work force diversity in the aerospace industry and that they are in full compliance with affirmative-action guidelines.
Nonetheless, Hughes Aircraft officials are negotiating with the association and a meeting is being arranged between Dr. Chavis and Hughes Aircraft's chief executive, C. Michael Armstrong.
"The N.A.A.C.P. is an important organization in this country," said Dave Barclay, Hughes's vice president for work force diversity. "Even though we are in compliance with Government regulations, we are interested in knowing how we might improve."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We want to raise the question: Does it not make good business sense for companies to redefine their relationship with a multiracial society?" the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr. of the N.A.A.C.P. said. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Global Mutual Funds Set Sales Record in July

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Foreign stock mutual funds are all the rage, but the domestic variety seems to be attracting less money, according to figures released yesterday. And while bond funds are taking in record amounts of money, market timers appear to be growing worried that interest rates may begin to rise.
"Investors are on vacation from U.S. equities and are traveling abroad," said Bruce Speca, a spokesman for the TNE Fund Group. "The international equity market is just exploding." 
 At T. Rowe Price, the net cash flow into foreign stock funds in August is up 84 percent from July, said Rowena Itchon, a spokeswoman. But she added that sales of equity funds that invest in the United States were about even with July's level.
 
Heavy Flow of Cash
 Those observations came as the Investment Company Institute reported that foreign-oriented stock funds took in $3.1 billion in July, the largest ever for the category. But funds that invest primarily in the United States took in a net $6.6 billion in the month, down from $6.9 billion in June and the lowest for any month since October.
Bond funds took in a record $12.95 billion in July, breaking the old mark of $10.7 billion set in January. Part of that rise was a surge in global bond fund sales, to $891 million, or the largest since late 1991. But domestic bond funds also set records.
There was a sign that some who time markets are doubting that rates will keep falling, pushing bond prices higher: investors who move money among different types of funds were net sellers of bond funds in July, taking out $464 million. It was the third month in the last five that they took money out. With bond rates continuing to fall, the timers have so far not been proved right.
Fund groups without a strong foreign presence generally have seen net sales rise only a little or even dip. At the Janus Group, whose best products are domestic stock funds, "it was the slowest month of the year," Chrissy Snyder, a spokeswoman, said about August.
At Fidelity Investments, the largest fund organization, however, August has been the best month ever, with a net $2 billion pouring in, said Neal Litvack, an executive vice president. He said that most of the money had gone into relatively conservative domestic stock funds, but that the money that went overseas tended to concentrate on volatile areas like Latin America and Southeast Asia.
Some fund groups, among them State Street Research and Putnam Investments, reported gains in all categories in August. "People are just looking for a place to park their money in this low-interest-rate environment," said Don Webber of State Street.
The cash flow figures include new sales less redemptions, as well as money transferred among funds, but do not include reinvested dividends.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Guess Names Specialty-Store Chief to Lead Its Retail Unit

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Guess Inc., the apparel company that brought fashion to the jeans business, said yesterday that Bernard Zeichner, president and chief executive of the specialty store chain Contempo Casuals, would join the company to oversee retail operations.
Mr. Zeichner will join Guess on Sept. 13 as president of the retailing division, the first such formally designated head for the unit. 
 "His job is going to be to run the entire retail business," Maurice Marciano, chairman and chief executive of Guess, said. "The retail business is part of our growth strategy, and it needs full attention and he has the experience it takes."
Maurice Marciano took the helm of the company last week, after he and his brothers Paul and Armand bought the 40 percent stake held by their brother Georges.
Mr. Zeichner, whose background is in store operations, has more than a decade's experience in running a specialty-store chain. He joined Contempo in 1982 after working in various jobs at Joske's, a Texas department-store chain.
He built Contempo into a 300-store chain with revenues of $323.4 million last year, catering to the same young fashion-conscious customers who buy Guess clothing. Contempo has prospered despite the weak economy in California, its home state, by increasing private-label sales.
"He is a retailer first, but he also understands manufacturing because such a big part of their business is private-label," Mr. Marciano said.
Guess is planning to expand its retail business, which accounted for about 19 percent of its sales in 1992, and Mr. Zeichner would oversee that growth. Mr. Marciano said the chain, now at 38 stores, would probably not grow beyond 100 outlets.
Sales to the department stores that are the major buyers of Guess products have declined slightly during the last two years, since the stores have striven to keep inventories lean.
Deciding how to offset its dependence on department stores split the family that built Guess into a marketing and sales phenomenon. Georges Marciano, the former chairman and chief executive who founded Guess in 1981 with Maurice, believed the company's potential was limited by slow growth in department-store sales. He felt the company should begin making products for discount stores like Kmart and Wal-Mart, where sales of apparel are increasing.
But Maurice and the two other Marciano brothers, Armand and Paul, wanted to keep distribution limited to department stores while increasing the company's own retail operations. Unable to resolve their differences, the company and Maurice, Paul and Armand raised $220 million privately and through a bridge loan to buy Georges's stake.
Maurice Marciano said yesterday that the brothers were also considering a public stock offering.
Presumably, Mr. Zeichner would also attempt to reverse the sales slide at Guess's retail stores, which are mostly in California, Arizona and Texas. Sales per square foot in Guess retail stores have slipped from $550 in 1990 to $385 last year. "Twenty-six of our stores are in Southern California, which had an impact on business over the last two years," Mr. Marciano said. "But we are finally seeing a light at the end of the tunnel. Sales were up 5 percent in July."

HEADLINE: New York Seeks Ruling On Taxes

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Aug. 30

 BODY:
New York State will ask the United States Supreme Court to decide whether the state can tax cigarette sales on Indian reservations, a move the Indians say would violate their treaties.
The State Department of Taxation and Finance has asked Attorney General Robert Abrams to petition the nation's highest court to hear the case, officials said today. 
 In June, the State Court of Appeals outlawed a state plan intended to help the state collect taxes on the sale of gasoline and cigarettes by Indian retailers to non-Indian customers. The state would be asking the Supreme Court to overturn that ruling.
A similar dispute has been going on in Connecticut, where state officials have been trying to shut down a tobacco shop run by members of the Golden Hill Paugussett tribe on a reservation in Colchester.
A New York State Tax Department spokesman, Paul Rickard, said New York only wants to tax sales by Indian retailers to non-Indians, who save as much as 25 percent by buying gas and cigarettes on reservations.
 
$90 Million in Lost Taxes
 Sales to non-Indians on reservations cost New York $60 million a year in lost taxes on cigarettes and $30 million a year on gasoline, Mr. Rickard said.
Larry Ballagh, a member of the tribal council of the Seneca Nation of Indians on the Cattaraugus and Allegany reservations south of Buffalo, said New York's efforts to tax Indians have repeatedly been struck down by the courts.
"The courts keep saying 'no.' I really can't understand what part of 'no' they don't understand," Mr. Ballagh said. "Either they are awfully slow or their education is sadly lacking or they just outright do not believe in the rule of law."
Tax officials said they would like to negotiate a settlement in which taxes would be collected but the money would remain with the Indian tribes. The Indians say they will not negotiate.
Joseph Crangle, a lawyer for the Senecas, said any tax would destroy business for Indian retailers.
"What they're asking for is the Indians to sign their own economic death warrant," Mr. Crangle said. "I don't care if you call it a Seneca tax or a New York tax. Why would anyone go to the reservations if the Indians are no longer competitive?"
 
An Unfair Advantage?
 Non-Indian retailers, who say their business has been devastated by Indian competitors, have been lobbying the state to appeal the case to the Supreme Court.
Robert Reid, a spokesman for the Independent Petroleum Marketers of New York, said the Indians' tax-exempt status gives them an unfair advantage over non-Indian businesses. Many of those are small, family-owned shops that have lost most of their customers to Indian businesses, Mr. Reid said.
"We don't believe that a small group of individuals should bear the entire burden for what the white man collectively has done to the Indians over the years," Mr. Reid said.
New York tried to begin the cigarette taxes in 1989. Milhem Attea and Brothers, which supplies cigarettes to Indian retailers, sued to block the taxes.
Joseph Zdarsky, a lawyer for Attea Brothers, said most of the company's business comes from sales to Indian retailers. If taxes were imposed, it could put Attea Brothers out of business, he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
$725 Million Merger for 2 H.M.O.'s

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Health Net, the largest for-profit health maintenance organization in California, said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with Qual Med Inc., a Colorado-based H.M.O., in a deal that analysts valued at $500 million in stock plus $225 million in debt.
Roger F. Greaves, chairman of HN Management Holdings Inc., Health Net's parent company, will share chief executive duties in the merged company with Dr. Malik M. Hasan, a London-trained neurologist from Pakistan who is Qual Med's chairman. 
 Mr. Greaves heads a group of 38 Health Net executives who paid $2 million for all the voting stock and 20 percent ownership last year, when the company was taken private.
The new company will have 1.2 million H.M.O. members in the hotly contested California market, which one analyst called "the Vietnam of American health care" because of the bloody battles for market share.
 
 
A 50-to-1 Windfall
 Analysts estimated the Health Net executives' stake would be worth $100 million. But they cannot pocket their 50-to-1 windfall until 1997, under restrictions imposed last year by the California Commissioner of Corporations.
Dr. Hasan owns 30 percent of Qual Med, which he started in 1985, and will have 10.5 percent of the new company.
Under the merger, which is subject to approval by Federal and California regulators, each Health Net common share will be exchanged for 3.34 shares of the new company. Qual Med shares will be exchanged on a 1-for-1 basis.
Qual Med, which is based in Pueblo, Colo., closed yesterday at $15.50, up $1.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
 
Lawsuit Is Withdrawn
 In a related action yesterday, Qual Med withdrew lawsuits against Health Net's top executives, whom it had accused of taking the Los Angeles-based company private last year "at a price below its fair market value" to realize personal gain.
Health Net "basically said they'd rather switch than fight," said Thomas E. Hoddap, an analyst at Robertson, Stephens & Company.
Qual Med, which owns H.M.O.'s in six Western states and has managed health care discount networks in 16 states, had accused Health Net of reneging on a $400 million purchase agreement in July 1992. In a deal approved by the state, Health Net instead awarded 80 percent ownership, without voting rights, to a new foundation headed by Mr. Greaves. The Health Net management group obtained 20 percent and all the voting stock.
Because of California restrictions on nonprofit entities converting to for-profit companies, Health Net endowed the Wellness Foundation with $75 million in cash and $225 million in i.o.u.'s, or $100 million less than what Qual Med said it had bid.
Mr. Greaves, who declined to confirm analysts' valuations, said Health Net's customers included "the biggest companies in California."
Many of the accounts are shared with the nonprofit Kaiser health plans, the country's largest H.M.O., which has five million California members.
Mr. Greaves said the merger would help Health Net follow its customers, many of whom are fleeing the California recession, to neighboring states where Qual Med already operates. "With health reform, we have to be bigger and more visible and multi-state," he said.
Michael M. LeConey, an analyst at RAS Securities, said the merger was "a major event in the industry." He said Qual Med shareholders were acquiring a company that had had "pretty uneven earnings" and had been accused of being "a price cutter." California is "a very tough market," he said.
But Dr. Hasan said that "most of our profits have been coming from California," where Qual Med had acquired three Northern California H.M.O.'s.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Jump on Housing Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury prices surged yesterday as yields flirted with new lows after an unexpectedly sharp decline in housing sales contributed to evidence that the economy remained stuck in low gear.
The report added to the optimism among investors in fixed-income securities ahead of key economic reports this week, including employment statistics for August due out Friday. 
 Investors, who have recently poured money into bonds, are betting that a slow-growth economy will dissuade the Federal Reserve from pushing interest rates higher. Higher rates hurt the value of investments with a fixed rate of return.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond, which dropped 3/4 point Friday, rose 3/8 point yesterday, or $3.75 per $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.11 percent, from 6.14 percent Friday.
The bond's record low yield of 6.09 percent was set last Thursday. It was the lowest since the Treasury began regularly selling 30-year bonds in 1977.
 
 
Light Volumn
 Yesterday's price rise came on light volume as many investors took a long vacation ahead of the Labor Day weekend. Many traders adjusted their positions to weed out riskier moves in anticipation that reports this week might generate price volatility.
But the market's dominant tone was bullish as investors remained confident that interest rates generally were headed lower in the current economic climate of slow inflation and anemic growth.
"We have a lot of data this week that could show pockets of adjustment," John Costas, head of government securities trading at First Boston, said. "But at the end of the day, the migration to lower yields will continue."
The Government is scheduled to revise its second-quarter gross domestic product figures today, the National Association of Purchasing Management will issue its report on industrial activity tomorrow, and the employment report will be released Friday.
 
 
New-Home Sales
 Yesterday, the Government reported new-home sales fell 5 percent in July to the lowest level since March, prompting investors to buy bonds and pushing their prices higher. Many economists expected a smaller decline in housing.
"The market seems to be driven by the perspective that the Fed will never move to raise the Federal funds rate, and this data helped to fuel that kind of thinking," Alan Levenson, money-market economist at UBS Securities, said.
In the Government's weekly bill auction, the Treasury sold $12 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.02 percent and a yield of 3.08 percent.
An additional $11.9 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.11 percent and a yield of 3.20 percent.
Yields are the interest bonds pay by maturity, while the discount is the interest at which they are sold.
Short-term Treasuries rose 1/8 to 5/32 of a point, and intermediate maturities rose 9/32 to 7/16 of a point, according to the Telerate financial information service.
Lehman Brothers' daily Treasury bond index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.99, to 1,328.62.
 
 
Secondary Trading
 In secondary trading, yields on three-month Treasury bills were lower at 3.07 percent as the discount dropped 0.02 percentage point, to 3.01 percent. Six-month yields were down at 3.18 percent as the discount fell 0.02 point, to 3.10 percent. One-year yields were lower at 3.35 percent as the discount fell 0.03 point, to 3.23 percent.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 31/16 percent, up from 3 percent late Friday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 1043/32 , up 1/8 from late Friday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.61 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Limited Inc. to Close and Scale Back Stores

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The Limited Inc. has had enviable success building specialty-apparel chains -- so successful that the chains eventually began competing for the same customers.
Yesterday, moving to address those problems, the Limited announced that it would close as many as 100 Lerner New York stores and shut, scale down or remodel 260 of its Limited stores. 
 It also said it had re-evaluated the earnings and sales potential of some Limited, Lerner and Henri Bendel stores and other assets, and would record a charge against earnings to reduce their value to "an amount considered realizable in future periods." The company said it would take a $200 million pretax charge this year for the closings, remodeling and revaluation.
That charge will be offset by the sale of a 60 percent interest in the company's Brylane mail-order catalogue division, for $285 million. The Limited will realize a $203 million pretax gain from that sale to Freeman Spogli & Company, a Los Angeles-based merchant banker.
The Limited, with headquarters in Columbus, Ohio, operates 12 specialty-store chains and the mail-order business. It said yesterday that it also planned to buy back as much as $500 million worth of its stock as market conditions warranted.
"Going forward, we believe this effort will bear fruit as we emphasize our best-performing stores and shed those assets that do not perform to our expectations and standards," Kenneth B. Gilman, Limited's vice chairman, said in a statement.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Gilman said the company would only close stores that were operating at a loss and were in locations unlikely to recover from the economic slump. There are more than 900 Lerner stores and about 650 Limited stores nationwide.
He said that as much as possible, employees affected would be offered jobs elsewhere in the company. The Limited plans to have 110,000 employees by the end of the year, compared with 100,000 at the end of 1992, and Mr. Gilman emphasized that its restructuring was not the usual kind -- that after it was done, the company would have more people, not fewer.
Analysts agreed that the move to eliminate stores showing poor financial performance was a positive step.
Heidi R. Steinberg, a retail analyst at Lehman Brothers, commented: "They're over-stored in the women's specialty-store business, and the divisions aren't differentiated enough. This is a move to correct some of that. In a time when the apparel business is especially competitive, I think it's positive that they're rethinking their strategy."
Another analyst, Jennifer Black Groves of Black & Company in Portland, Ore., said: "It shows they're putting an emphasis on their new businesses and slowly, gradually, closing the businesses that aren't performing well. It's an excellent move."
She added that the company now expects its square footage to increase about 7 percent this year instead of the 10 percent increase it had tentatively projected. She expected most of the new space to be given to fledgling businesses like Limited Too, which sells girls' clothes, and Bath & Body Works, a toiletries and cosmetics business.
The company made the announcement yesterday after the close of stock trading, in which its shares gained $1.375, to $23.675.
Both the Limited and Lerner New York chains have struggled in recent years, and to some extent the company's success has been its problem as well. The Limited lost many of its fashion-conscious younger customers to Express, another of its divisions, and has never quite succeeded in repositioning itself as a specialty store catering to career women. Lerner New York, once the specialty store of choice for women seeking inexpensive clothes to wear to the office, has tried with little success to reach out to shoppers with higher disposable incomes.
Structure, a young men's store, also took sales away from the older divisions.
Adding to the Limited's woes has been a broader decline in apparel sales, which has hurt many specialty-store chains.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Mixed Showing; Gold Prices Move Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted against other currencies in quiet trading yesterday as investors awaited several Government reports on the American economy.
In New York, the dollar slipped against the Japanese yen, ending trading at 103.80 yen, down from 103.85 yen on Friday. But the dollar rose to 1.6719 German marks, up from 1.6640 marks. It also posted gains against the British pound. 
 Gold prices rose yesterday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for October delivery, the active near-term futures contract, gained $1.20 an ounce, to $371.50. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $370.25 an ounce, up $1.
Currency traders said activity was limited since markets in Britain and Hong Kong were closed for holidays and many brokers were finishing their vacations. Dealers said trading was in a narrow range, mostly set off by technical factors.
"People are sitting back and waiting for the numbers at the end of the week," said David Durst, assistant vice president of Credit Lyonnais in New York.
Among the economic reports this week are the statistics on second-quarter gross domestic product, due out today, and the August employment figures, coming out on Friday.
Dealers said Japan's central bank bought dollars to support the American currency during Asian trading yesterday, as it has done repeatedly in recent weeks.
The British pound was quoted at $1.4930 in New York, down from $1.5035 on Friday.
Lisa Pazer, a currency specialist at MMS International in New York, said the pound retreated on expectations that British interest rates were about to drop. Declining interest rates usually weaken a currency, since investments in that currency earn less.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with those on Friday, included: 1.4725 Swiss francs, up from 1.4668; 5.8480 French francs, up from 5.8255; 1,600.75 Italian lire, up from 1,594.00, and 1.3218 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3183.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
3 Japan Auto Makers' Debt on Credit Watch

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 30

 BODY:
The Standard & Poor's Corporation placed more than $25 billion of debt of the top three Japanese auto makers on credit watch with negative implications today, in a move that could eventually raise the borrowing costs for the Japanese automobile industry.
S.& P.'s move was further verification of the deteriorating financial position of the Toyota Motor Corporation, the Honda Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, which have been hurt by the soaring value of the yen and sharper competition from Detroit's Big Three auto makers. 
 Moreover, the agency's action was a stunning turnaround for an industry that has been dominated for several years by negative ratings for Big Three debt securities. The ratings of Big Three auto makers, though not completely restored, have improved in recent months.
Japan's auto makers could decide to raise more capital in equity markets if the interest rate for future borrowing rises too high or if the ratings agencies put pressure on them to strengthen their balance sheets. But so far, the review is in an early phase and the companies' financial conditions, though diminished, are not in critical condition.
The stronger yen, which has risen about 17 percent in value over the last few months, has forced the Japanese auto makers to raise prices or suffer losses of market share. Last week, Toyota said it could suffer its first operating loss in the current fiscal year if the yen stays strong; Nissan posted a loss in its 1993 fiscal year ended in March, and Honda's profit in its first fiscal quarter ended in June was off 62 percent.
S.& P.'s credit watch covers $19 billion of Toyota's long-term debt and $6.5 billion of Nissan's long-term debt. The credit watch also covers the short-term obligations of all three auto makers, though the amount was not specified.
Besides losing ground in the United States, Japanese auto makers are facing weak demand in Japan and in Europe.
Seth Petok, a spokesman for Nissan, said. "While we are disappointed, our liquidity and ability to fund operations should not be affected negatively." Nissan's senior debt is rated A; the company's short-term rating for various financial subsidiaries is A-1.
James Olson, a Toyota spokesman, said the action would "have negligible effect on our cost of borrowings." Mr. Olson said he "presumed the credit watch is because of the projection of an operating loss." Toyota's long-term debt is rated AAA; the company's short-term debt is rated A-1-plus.
Honda, whose short-term debt is rated A-1, did not respond immediately to S.& P.'s announcement.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Drop Unexpectedly Steep 5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30

 BODY:
Sales of new homes declined an unexpectedly steep 5 percent in July, the Government reported today, as the housing industry continued to perplex analysts with its erratic moves despite the lowest mortgage rates in more than two decades.
Some analysts contend that low consumer confidence in the economy and uncertainty over Federal policies are curbing housing activity, which otherwise might be stimulated by the low rates. 
 "It's not as if these numbers are weak, but they just don't have the snap one would like." said Robert G. Dederick, economist of the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "People continue to be concerned about whether they can meet their financial obligations."
Sales totaled 629,000 at a seasonally adjusted annual rate in July, down from a revised 662,000 a month earlier, the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development said. Activity declined in every region.
 
Lowest Since March
 Many analysts had predicted a dip of just 1 percent, saying the 3.3 percent jump in June could not be sustained. The decline, the fourth this year, pushed sales to the lowest level since they stood at 602,000 in March.
But Leonard Miller, chairman and president of the Lennar Corporation, a large home builder with headquarters in Miami, noted that even with the drop, sales during the first seven months of 1993 were 6.8 percent higher than those of the corresponding period last year.
He also said the inventory level of new homes for sale -- a 5.5-month supply at the current sales pace -- is historically low for this time of the housing cycle and should spur both sales and housing starts. Starts fell in both June and July.
And, Mr. Miller contended, sales of previously owned homes, which rose in July for the fourth straight month, "typically are a leading indicator of what's to be expected in the new-home market."
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.21 percent in July, down from 7.42 percent in June and the lowest since the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation began tracking rates in 1971.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Trade Deficit Widens
 WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The United States trade deficit widened to $34.4 billion in the April-June quarter, the largest in five and a half years, as exports were swamped by record-high imports, the Commerce Department said today.
The gap was 17.3 percent bigger than the first-quarter deficit and marked the fourth deterioration in five quarters.
If the trade gap continues to widen at the pace of the first half, it will total $127.4 billion for the full year. That would be up sharply from $96.1 billion last year and the worst performance since 1987, when the trade gap peaked at $159.6 billion.
Analysts said growth in exports had virtually stalled because two prime markets for American goods -- Western Europe and Japan -- were in recession. At the same time, productivity-minded United States businesses have been turning abroad to buy computers and other equipment to hold down costs.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Broken Ankle in Final-Day Saratoga Spill Ends Krone's Year

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30

 BODY:
Julie Krone suffered multiple fractures of the right ankle today during a violent spill on the final day of Saratoga's racing season and was not expected to ride again for the rest of this year and possibly longer.
The 30-year-old jockey, a tiny dynamo who has won riding titles at Belmont Park, Monmouth Park, Atlantic City and the Meadowlands, also suffered severe cuts and bruises on her left elbow. She underwent surgery at Saratoga Hospital to stabilize the ankle joint and will undergo more surgery in New York City to repair the fracture. 
 Krone was injured in the third race on the last day of the five-week season at Saratoga Race Course, a season that reached record levels of attendance and betting and saw the rise of new standout horses. One of them, the 2-year-old filly Strategic Maneuver, won her third straight race today when she took the Spinaway Stakes for juveniles. Meanwhile, Mike Smith won the riding title, beating Krone by four races, 40 to 36. And Bill Mott trained the most winners, 12, edging Leo O'Brien by 1.
But the festive mood of closing day at the 126-year-old country track was darkened by the injury to Krone, the 4-foot-10-inch, 100-pounder who has become the most successful female jockey in racing history and a national star. In June, she became the first woman to win a Triple Crown race when she captured the Belmont Stakes aboard Colonial Affair.
It was her second spill of the season here, and the worst she had suffered since she fractured her left arm four years ago at the Meadowlands in New Jersey. After that accident, she needed eight months to recuperate before resuming her career with seven aluminum screws and a metal plate in her forearm.
She tumbled this time while riding the filly Seattle Way as they were rounding the turn into the homestretch on the outer grass course. Another filly crossed into their path, and Seattle Way clipped her heels and buckled, flinging Krone to the ground. Seattle Way then regained her balance, but lurched to the left and collided with Holly North, turning her into the hedge and throwing Jean-Luc Samyn onto the turf.
Samyn rolled to his feet and was unhurt, and the two fillies continued running with empty saddles. But Krone lay on the ground complaining of pain in her left arm and right leg, and then was taken to the hospital.
Dr. James Gallagher, the surgeon who performed the initial surgery, reported later: "She suffered a severely fractured right ankle, with fractures of both the tibia and fibula involving the ankle joint. She also has severe contusions and lacerations of the left elbow."
Neither he nor racing officials here would speculate on the damage to Krone's career. But she seemed certain to miss several months, with the likelihood that she would not return to racing before early next year.
 
$3.7 Million a Day Bet
 The injury overshadowed the booming business report issued as the curtain fell at Saratoga. On-track attendance rose by 3 percent and on-track betting by 8.7 percent, while the total betting handle at simulcast sites across the state soared by 9.2 percent.
During the 30 days of racing here, attendance averaged 26,176 at Saratoga and 7,145 at Aqueduct in Queens, where the upstate races were relayed by television. More than $3.7 million a day was bet at Saratoga, and more than $112 million for the five weeks. And the Saratoga races generated $322 million in bets on Saratoga races both at the track and elsewhere.
The star of the season, the juvenile colt Dehere, who swept three major stakes here in 32 days, was joined in the spotlight today by Strategic Maneuver, who won the opening-day Schuylerville Stakes to go along with the closing-day Spinaway and left town as the queen of the young fillies.
Strategic Maneuver, who is undefeated in her young career, was kept back in fifth place today by Jose Santos for half a mile but then kicked into gear as they turned into the stretch. She outran Astas Foxy Lady to the wire by 1 1/2 lengths, with Delta Lady nearly a length back in third. The 6-5 favorite, the previously unbeaten Cat Attack, retreated in the stretch and faded to fifth.
The winner, owned by Phil Teinowitz of Chicago and trained by Scotty Schulhofer, ran the six furlongs in 1:10 1/5 and paid $14 for every $2 bet. And she banked $120,000 of the purse of $200,000.
Schulhofer said that he would aim his prize filly for the Matron Stakes at Belmont on Sept. 18, a race that would extend her range to seven furlongs.
"She's got stamina," he said, "and she can go far, hopefully as far as a mile and a sixteenth."
 
FINISH LINES
 If five weeks is so successful, why not six? JERRY LAWRENCE, executive vice president of New York's major tracks, said that he doubted the Saratoga season would be expanded. "My gut feeling is we'll stay with five weeks next year," he said. "Why tamper with a good thing?" He also said that the business records set this summer were "tremendous," especially "with the unemployment in the Hudson Valley and with Indian-reservation gaming only 90 miles away."

HEADLINE: Science Takes a Lesson From Nature, Imitating Abalone and Spider Silk

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY

 BODY:
INCREASINGLY, scientists designing new materials are looking to nature as a source of inspiration. In their search for ways to make substances that are harder, stronger, lighter and more durable, they are mimicking nature and enhancing it.
Some scientists have discovered how to "petrify" wood to make it more resistant to pests, while others are duplicating the multilayered structure of seashells to make new ceramics that are tough without being brittle. Still other researchers have recently made fundamental discoveries about spider web silk, capping decades of study and raising the hope of mass-producing threads stronger than Kevlar, the substance used to make bulletproof vests. And scientists have begun studies of reindeer antlers to see why this tough, light material absorbs shock so well. 
 The use of natural materials as models for new ones is revolutionizing material science itself, many researchers say, and expanding interest in the field among scientists in previously unrelated specialties like genetics, geology, botany and biochemistry.
"Material science has expanded in the last 10 years to become a cross-disciplinary area, with many specialties that you normally wouldn't think of merging into making new materials," said Dr. Ilhan A. Aksay, a professor of chemical engineering at the Materials Institute at Princeton University. "This collaboration will become more common in the next decade." The institute, he noted, now includes eight departments at the university.
A growing number of materials scientists are becoming involved in the field of biomimetics, the study of the structure and function of biological materials as models for artificially created ones. Researchers are taking two approaches to borrowing nature's designs. Either they want to understand the underlying biological processes in order to artificially re-create or improve them using other materials and techniques, or they want to duplicate the techniques organisms use to make desired substances.
Despite years of work and numerous recent advances, proponents of biomimetics caution that most practical applications may not come soon. The Federal Government has made materials science a priority, as part of its plan to bolster the country's economic competitiveness, but even though more money is becoming available for research, most of it is going to traditional endeavors, like producing new substances from exotic chemical mixtures or forging materials under high heat and pressure. Dr. Aksay and others said most of the fruits of biomimetics could be years, even decades, away and cautioned against unrealistic expectations.
The military, with its interest in developing tough but light materials for armor, clothing and other uses, has supported studies on biological materials for many years. Early this year, for example, the Defense Department agreed to spend up to $2 million over five years on ceramics and polymer research at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, Princeton University and the University of Washington in Seattle. Their work will include studies of seashells and reindeer antlers.
"Nature has taken millions of years, producing literally millions of prototypes, to develop optimized structures with unusual characteristics," said Dr. Wilbur C. Simmons, a materials scientist at the Army Research Office in Research Triangle Park, N.C., which commissioned the new studies. "We need strong, lightweight, thin materials, and it makes sense to sponsor basic research that includes looking at natural materials."
Dr. Eric Baer, a professor of micromolecular science at Case Western Reserve University who heads a team that has begun examining reindeer antlers, said the material had the stiffness of bone but was tougher and more shock-resistant. Scientists say that antlers, which can grow an inch a day, get their unique properties from a complex layering of proteins and minerals. The researchers have an agreement with the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo to obtain antlers from its reindeer colony as they are shed.
"By studying the composite structure of antlers, we are trying to create synthetic material that is even better," Dr. Baer said. Antlers are prone to drying out and becoming brittle, so just reproducing antler material is not the goal of the research. "We can use synthetic components that are both water-insensitive and thermally more stable than the materials found in nature," he said.
Dr. Baer said natural materials exemplified an extremely precise control over their structure and composition at every scale, from the molecular level to the level that people can see and feel. He added that researchers must learn to understand this complex, hierarchical system of various-sized components, in which different characteristics relate to one another, if they hope to improve upon nature.
"We have to look at it from a systems point of view and not just look at individual components or characteristics," Dr. Baer said. "Then we will have more opportunities to make smart materials that have the desired properties we want."
 
From Shells to Advanced Ceramics
 Understanding materials formation at the microscopic level and below has enabled researchers to study the shells of sea animals and begin to make copies of these unusually tough structures. Dr. Aksay at Princeton and Dr. Mehmet Sarikaya, a visiting professor there, have found that abalone shell is made of micro-thin plates of calcium carbonate, the powdery component of chalk and antacid tablets, held together by a mortar of protein and sugars.
Using powerful transmission electron microscopes to study the structure in detail, the researchers found that the inner part of the shell -- the shiny mother-of-pearl section called nacre -- was made up of extremely thin layers of laminate. Microscopic stacks of overlapping, six-sided calcium carbonate bricks bound by an organic glue make the nacre as strong a material as the most advanced synthetic ceramics, Dr. Sarikaya said.
"Here we have chalk, but it is highly organized," Dr. Sarikaya said, noting that the shell's structure is 30 times stronger and tougher than the ordinary calcium carbonate made in the laboratory. Using the shell structure as a guide, the researchers said, they made layered materials using carbon, boron and aluminum mixtures that are 1.3 to 1.5 times as tough and strong as other ceramics made of these components. "We know we can do better than this, but we don't have the technology to make the layers of material as thin as they are in a sea shell," Dr. Sarikaya said.
Dr. Clement E. Furlong, a medical geneticist at the University of Washington, is working with the Princeton researchers on the protein "glue" that binds layers in abalone and nautilus shells together to form ceramic-polymer composite materials. Dr. Furlong is attempting to identify the proteins in the mortar and their structure, work that could lead to cloning the protein and making bacteria that could produce it in quantity. "We would also like to make antibody to the protein to see how the protein is organized in the shell matrix," he said. "You could do this by tagging the antibody with gold particles and when it attached to the protein, the gold particles would show up in the electron microscope and reveal the protein's structure."
Dr. Furlong said one reason he had started to collaborate with materials scientists was that their work with shells and other materials could increase the understanding of how human bone, a composite of organic and inorganic materials, is mineralized. "Not only are there potential applications to physiology and medicine, but some of the imaging equipment used in materials work might be adapted for human research," he said.
Another area of materials science that originated with nature is research into wood-ceramic composites, which are made by incorporating minerals into the structure of wood to impart hardness, strength or durability. The initial models for this research proved to be petrified wood and teak.
 
Making Stronger Wood
 Scientists, including some at the University of Washington and at Princeton, have been looking at ways to strengthen poor-quality woods to make them usable in areas of construction requiring durability or strength. Many new woods, genetically engineered to grow fast, are good only for pulp because their larger-than-normal cell sizes reduce their strength, researchers said.
Teak, long recognized for standing up well under saltwater and for its resistance to wood-eating organisms, has been known for centuries to contain silica and other minerals, which it absorbs through its roots and deposits in the walls of its cells. Silica, the main ingredient in beach sand, is one of the world's most common minerals.
"A number of trees and grasses, including teak and bamboo, have silica particles in them naturally," said Dr. Daniel M. Dabbs, a research scientist in chemical engineering at Princeton. "Teak and petrified wood gave us ideas about what could be done." Although petrified wood is mineralized, he said, researchers had not explored it extensively because the process of forming it took too long and they were looking for something that would work quickly.
The researchers tried feeding trees and grasses different mineral solutions to see if they would absorb them, but they also developed a more direct way to make wood tougher. They put it into a pressurized container and injected it with mixture of silica and alcohol. Many wood preservatives coat the surface of cellulose cells in wood, but the scientists found that their process forced the silica into the cell walls and hardened the wood throughout. The reinforced wood is up to 120 percent stronger than the original, scientists said. In addition, they said, tests show that if the wood was used for flooring, it did not dimple under foot traffic like the original soft wood.
"We also found that if we remove the organic component of this composite by burning away the wood at high temperatures, we get a ceramic skeleton left behind that has the structure and appearance of wood, except that it's bone white," Dr. Dabbs said. This ceramic "wood," which, he said, has the grain pattern of the original and can be stained and worked much like the original organic material, might be developed into fire-resistant building material or used to make dock or pier pilings that would resist water rot and the pests that bore into wood.
One of the most extensively studied natural materials has been spider silk. Researchers worldwide, including Dr. David Kaplan and his colleagues at the Natick Research, Development and Engineering Center of the Army in Massachusetts, where the gene for producing spider silk was cloned, have shown that the web threads are stronger than steel and more durable than nylon. For years, scientists have known the ingredients and composition of the water-soluble web fluid produced by spiders, but they say many mysteries remain to be solved before this knowledge can be translated into new materials.
 
Lessons From Silk
 "We are still in a fundamental stage of research and haven't learned to translate what we know into an artificial material yet," said Dr. Christopher Viney, a materials scientist at the University of Washington in Seattle, "but the silks are teaching us about the molecular architecture needed for attaining strength and toughness in a material."
Dr. Viney, working with Dr. Kaplan and others, recently discovered that silk secreted by silkworms and spiders gains its unusual strength by temporarily becoming a liquid crystal. After spiders squirt their water-based web solution through a hole in their back, the researchers found, the liquid goes through a crystalline phase in which its molecules are pulled into rod-like shapes that point in the same direction. This molecular alignment continues as the silk dries and the material solidifies into a water-insoluble fiber.
"Spiders produce silk using water as a solvent in the open air, at ambient temperatures and pressure, and it goes through all these stages to become a stable, water-resistant web of great strength," Dr. Viney said. "Yet to produce a tough fiber like Kevlar, you have to make it under high pressure using concentrated sulfuric acid. We have a lot to learn."

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
And Reeves Re-created the Giants in His Image

BYLINE: By MIKE FREEMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 30

 BODY:
Talk about shaking things up. Dan Reeves took hold of the Giants today, turned the team upside down and inside out, and when the smoke cleared a few notable veterans were packing their bags. The biggest name was Pepper Johnson, a Pro Bowler who has been to two Super Bowls. He found out today that when you battle the coach, the coach pretty much always wins. He is no longer a Giant and almost surely will never be again.
Today was cutdown day as the Giants trimmed their roster to 47 players. But this was actually more than a trimming of the roster, this was Reeves beginning to shape the team in his own image. It was simply one of the most amazing and stunning days in recent Giants history. 
 Said Johnson: "Everything has changed. It's the New Jersey Broncos."
Well, not quite. But Reeves definitely made some drastic changes today. In all the Giants cut 12 players, some of whom will be back when the roster, trimmed to 47 today, expands to 53 Tuesday. The players released were: running back O. J. Anderson, center Bart Oates, offensive tackle Jeff Novak, kicker Matt Bahr, wide receivers Joey Smith and Eric Weir, defensive linemen Eric Dorsey and Mark Flythe, Johnson, safety Lamar McGriggs, tight end John Brandes and cornerback Perry Williams.
 
'We Never Talked'
 The biggest shock was Johnson. "I felt it kind of building up," said Johnson, who has been with the Giants for eight seasons. "I read stuff in the paper about how Coach Reeves and I weren't getting along. I don't know if we didn't get along because we never talked.
"So I guess they just said, 'Let's kill the headache right now.' "
And that's apparently what the coaching staff thought Johnson was -- a migraine. So rather than ingesting Extra-Strength Tylenol they cut the ties -- and made a former Buffalo linebacker, Carlton Bailey, the starter in Johnson's place. A smart move? Certainly a gutsy one by Reeves, who doesn't like selfish players and apparently believed Johnson to be just that. Recently, Johnson had criticized the coaching staff for taking him out on passing situations.
"You have to make decisions based on what you think is best for your football team," said Reeves when asked about Johnson. "These 12 decisions are based on what we think is best. Certainly that decision was one of the ones along with six or seven other ones that were really more difficult because of the contributions they made here in the past and because of their ability to still play in the league. In order to move forward we have to make some of those types of decisions."
Reeves said he was sure that some of the cuts came as surprises to the players involved. "They wouldn't be the players that they have been if they didn't have a great deal of confidence in their own abilities," the coach said. "That's what makes it difficult and also doesn't make it right. For our sake, hopefully we are making the right decisions."
"You could tell they were down on me," said Johnson. "Watching film in the meetings, I would get criticized more for petty stuff." About some of his more flamboyant comments regarding the coaching staff, Johnson said: "I felt like no one knew what Pepper Johnson was capable of. So I certainly stayed in the coaches ears. Maybe I just complained too much."
 
Overrated and Critical
 The coaching staff believed that Johnson was not only overrated as a player but also overly critical of some of the staff's decisions. The team had attempted to trade Johnson all preseason -- with talks picking up last week -- but Johnson's contractual situation was holding up any possible deal. He was scheduled to make $1.2 million this year, but the sticking point was that he was going to be an unrestricted free agent after this season. Teams were afraid of picking him up and then having to negotiate with him next year; Johnson is also his own agent, which doesn't help.
"Coach Reeves said he tried to trade me but no one really wanted to take me because I'm in the last year of my contract," said Johnson.
Johnson is not likely to remain unemployed for long. One of the teams the Giants were talking trade with was Cleveland. He could well end up there with former Giants defensive coordinator and current Browns coach, Bill Belichick. The Browns' owner, Art Modell, said today that acquiring Johnson was something they were considering.
There is also the possibility of Bill Parcells and the New England Patriots picking him up, or even the Washington Redskins.
"If you were to tell me a month ago that I'd be here and Pepper wouldn't," said linebacker Steve DeOssie, who made it, "you'd have to check me into an asylum."
 
Others Will Return
 Some of the other players cut today are likely to be back with the Giants, and that's where it gets complicated. In addition to their 47-man rosters, all National Football League teams will get an additional six spots on Tuesday for a total roster of 53 players. Teams will also have a five-player developmental squad consisting of rookies and first-year players.
One player who definitely will be back is Oates. Williams will likely be back as well. The chances of both Anderson and Bahr returning are about 50-50. But Johnson, Dorsey, and McGriggs are done as Giants.
Since Anderson, Bahr, Williams, Oates, Dorsey, Johnson and Brandes all have at least four years in the league they are all unrestricted free agents and free to negotiate with any team.
"Talk to me tomorrow," said Bahr. "I'll either be putting my shoes on or packing them up."
"Surprised, yeah I was surprised," Oates said of being released. "I didn't expect it. I was playing pretty well. We had a discussion. I was encouraged by it. There's a legitimate shot at me being back. Then again, there are no guarantees in life."
Dorsey has been sidelined with hip problems for most of camp and has done next to nothing. A first-round draft choice in 1986, Dorsey started all 16 games last year but, again, the past means little to this administration. McGriggs, who appeared to have tears in his eyes as he walked to the parking lot after being informed, mysteriously went from competing with Myron Guyton for one of the safety spots to no job at all.
"He just said it was a tough decision and he hoped it didn't come back to haunt him," McGriggs said of Reeves. "He just wants everything brand new, I guess."
Johnson's tenure has been a rocky one under Reeves, but he has been a great player for the Giants, leading them in tackles four of the past five seasons. But Johnson feels his dismissal has as much to do with Bailey's three-year, $5.2 million salary (Bailey will get $3 million this year) as his outspokenness.
"They don't want to look bad," said Johnson. "If they pick up Bailey for all that money he's got to play."

Pepper Johnson won't be one of them. Comments by Mike Freeman. (Photograph by Ben Van Hook for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Air Force Drawing Flak Over 'SWAT Team' Plan

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOUNTAIN HOME AIR FORCE BASE, Idaho

 BODY:
As part of its reorganization after the cold war, the Air Force is creating a set of quick-response wings to dispatch to world crises on a moment's notice.
But Congressional auditors say the new units will cost $200 million to field and add little in combat ability. They have called on Defense Secretary Les Aspin to halt the plan until the Air Force conducts more studies. 
 At issue is how the Air Force can reorganize its warplanes to respond to emergencies faster and with more firepower. In the past, the Air Force has assigned one or two types of aircraft to a base to achieve economies of scale. Fighters were assigned to one base, bombers to another, and all were pulled together from around the country to form a composite wing when a crisis arose.
 
An Airborne SWAT Team
 But at this base on the high-desert plateau 50 miles southeast of Boise, the Air Force has permanently assigned a total of 55 planes -- F-15 and F-16 fighters, B-52 bombers and KC-135 refueling planes -- in an experiment that planners envision as an airborne SWAT team.
"Our mission will be to get in place fast, deter an attack or be prepared to fight for about seven days," said Brig. Gen. David J. McCloud, commander of the 366th Wing here.
As United States forces withdraw from overseas bases as part of the overall reduction in troops, commanders are reorganizing air and ground forces in particular to respond more quickly to crises around the world from bases in the United States.
The Air Force is planning three composite wings made up of dissimilar aircraft: the "air intervention" wing here and two others that would be coordinated with Army troops, one at Pope Air Force Base in North Carolina and the other at Moody Air Force Base in Georgia.
 
More Analysis Urged
 But the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, says Air Force fighters, bombers and refueling planes already practice fighting together in regular exercises. In a report last May, the auditors contended that the Air Force "did not conduct sufficient analysis" before deciding to create the composite wings.
The idea of composite wings is not new. The Navy stations fighters and bombers aboard aircraft carriers. The Air Force had a composite strike force from 1955 to 1973 and sent it to Lebanon in 1958 to help preserve Lebanese independence. The strike force was discontinued because of budget pressures and opposition within the Air Force.
The latest version is the brainchild of Gen. Merrill A. McPeak, the Air Force Chief of Staff. General McPeak has shaken up the Air Force in several ways, from redesigning its uniforms to pushing generals out of Pentagon desk jobs and back into the field.
"There is a complex set of things going on in the Air Force to make it more relevant to new security challenges, and composite wings are only one such change," General McPeak said in a recent interview in Washington.
The General conceded that the composite wings might require some initial construction and equipment expenses, but he disputed the Congressional auditors charges that they would cost more to operate than a conventional wing. While he was careful not to claim too much credit for the combat abilities of the composite wings over conventional wings, he said their value might be even greater as training devices.
The wing here assembles a group of planes with disparate abilities. One type of fighter plane, the F-15C, for example, is a dogfighter, engaging enemy fighter planes at close quarters. The F-15E is typically used to drop laser-guided bombs at night, and the F-16 to bomb by day. The wing's B-52's, which train with the wing but are based at Castle Air Force Base in California, are even bigger bombers.
On a clear day recently over the bleak, wind-carved high desert of southern Idaho, eastern Oregon and northern Nevada, the fighters teamed up with a KC-135 to practice refueling.
In the back of the KC-135, a military version of a Boeing 707, Staff Sgt. Opie Flax lay flat on his stomach and peered out a triple-paned window to guide a 40-foot-long fuel boom nozzle into the open gas tank of a F-15E keeping pace just below him. The KC-135 can carry 23,000 gallons of jet fuel and pumps about 312 gallons a minute.
During combat missions the unarmed KC-135's fly on the outer edge of hostilities, acting as a flying gas station for the fighters, which typically carry about a two-hour supply of fuel.
In good weather, refueling at 330 miles an hour some 22,000 feet above the earth is a gracefully choreographed procedure. But at night, in stormy skies, the task can be grueling. Typically, tanker planes do not train regularly with the same group of fighters or bombers.
"We fly day to day like we'd fight in a war," said Sergeant Flax, a 27-year-old native of Turin, Iowa, as a topped-off F-15E peeled away from the tanker's disengaged boom.
Nonetheless, the composite wing still has shortcomings and extra costs. Maintenance buildings here for the new aircraft have had to be renovated. The one squadron of F-16's has the same advanced testing equipment that three squadrons would share in a conventional F-16 wing elsewhere.
The wing is also experiencing growing pains. It held its first major training exercise in June in Wisconsin, but the biggest test will be a four-week exercise in November. About 30 planes and more than 1,000 troops here will fly to an undisclosed Middle East country to deal with a mock crisis.
"Our biggest challenge is determining what we need to take with us," said Col. Robert L. Hart, the wing's logistics commander.

HEADLINE: With Gambling Expert in Capital, a Casino Rolls

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 25

 BODY:
As a boom in legalized gambling rolls across America, no politician has stepped up to the table with more prescience and gusto than Gov. Edwin W. Edwards, a rather fabulous crapshooter who likes to risk $5,000 a roll in the casino and far more in the statehouse.
"Sounds like I won again," the gray-haired Governor declared with Cajun ease in his office this week. He had just learned that his threat to throw the gambling issue back to the machinations of the Legislature had prodded an end to a profit-sharing dispute among gambling entrepreneurs, clearing the way for the world's biggest casino to be built in New Orleans. 
 It will be a high-rise casino with 200,000 square feet of gambling space. Even more, it will serve as Mr. Edwards's personal monument and as a beacon for the future of urban American casinos as legislatures across the country feel the pressure to tap into the flow of gaming revenue by legalizing high-volume casinos before neighboring states do.
Legalized gambling has been feasting on the nation's hard economic times. Revenues tripled in the last decade and grew 12 percent last year to $29.9 billion. The New Orleans venture brings a new level to the competition, in which casinos on riverboats and Indian reservations have been spreading and putting pressure on state and city officials to open gaming halls.
"In my opinion, in the next 20 years every major metropolitan area in America with a population of a million or more will have some form of a casino," Governor Edwards, part seer, part crapshooter, declared in an interview during his jockeying to complete the New Orleans profit-sharing agreement. It calls for a temporary hall to be open for gambling by January while the high rise is being built.
The Governor's casino expertise is not easily doubted. For not only did his last tax return list three days' winnings of $185,000 from playing craps at Nevada casinos, but Mr. Edwards also shocked the state in broaching the New Orleans casino proposal seven years ago. That was a time when few politicians would take aim at the traditional American taboo against gambling.
But Mr. Edwards is a scarred, swashbuckling politician in the tradition of Louisiana's populist Long dynasty. He is silvery and courtly at wheeling and dealing, liltingly announcing, "A casino agreement has been confected," as if he were discussing a praline recipe.
At the age of 65, he has been such a hard-eyed victor in bare-fisted political showdowns and in racketeering trials of his own integrity that after 40 years of being on the stump and in the dock, he seems to exult in taking on "the drum beaters and the Bible thumpers," as he terms the opposition.
"I bet as much as $5,000 on a roll of the dice," said Mr. Edwards, speaking of his personal gambling habits that greatly fuel the opposition's warnings that the New Orleans project will cause new refinements in Louisiana's political corruption.
The Governor insists that it is illegal gambling that can corrupt politicians and that New Orleans's depressed economy will rebound with the help of the jobs at the casino, whose games, he says, will be well run -- of the sort he has patronized for decades in Nevada and, he boasts, has won at.
 
A Way With the Dice
 "I'm comfortable with telling you that if I put every nickel I lost in one tub and every nickel I won in another, the winning tub would be fuller than the losing tub," the Governor said. Yet he also cautions that his success is the exception in gambling and that he would not consider gambling a positive form of economic production if it were not for the state's need for revenue.
His two tubs of nickels would be huge. The Governor's way with dice was detailed in trials six years ago in which Mr. Edwards was twice accused but not convicted of racketeering. Federal prosecutors sought to show he owed $2 million in gambling debts, but casino officials testified that Mr. Edwards was a successful crapshooter who averaged $50,000 in winnings a night in 10 trips to one casino.
The Governor has vowed never to shoot craps at the New Orleans casino. "If I lost, people would think I was an idiot," he explained. "If I won, they'd think it was fixed."
Fool and fixer were some of the kinder criticisms heard last year when Mr. Edwards, out of office after three earlier terms, returned from political oblivion to defeat David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader who polarized the state. Flush with fresh political chips, the Governor quickly revived the casino proposal, and his timing was perfect as neighboring states were busily launching a flotilla of riverboat casinos that have alarmed New Orleans tourist officials.
 
Counting the Money
 Under the approved plan, New Orleans is to get an annual rent of $30 million to $50 million from the casino, which is to be built in three years on the 6.5-acre site of the sparsely used Rivergate convention hall on the waterfront. The state is guaranteed a minimum of $100 million a year, but the Governor hopes the true value could exceed $300 million a year when sales and hotel taxes are figured in.
A high-stakes stalemate among the city, an independent state casino board and rival developers was settled this week when the Governor finally stepped in. The agreed-upon split of ownership was one he had previously advocated -- a one-third share each for Harrah's Casino Management, for the developer, Christopher B. Hemmeter, and for a group of city and state business leaders.
Until the agreement, the dice-loving Governor, bombarded in editorials, had made such a good-government show of standing aloof from the final selection of casino managers that some citizens got restless as the stalemate grew. "Well, if this is what we get when Edwards embraces good government, let us bring back the crook," wrote James Gill in The New Orleans Times-Picayune. "It's important."
Bluenoses were scandalized when Mr. Edwards showed up at the Nevada craps tables weeks after campaigning on self-reform promises. But to his fans, Fast Eddie remains admirably unapologetic about his taste for risk and his respect for money. "Money is money, and whether you lose it in a craps game or it falls out of your pocket, it's gone. It's not a good idea to lose money."
He remembers his first killing at craps in Las Vegas, Nev., in 1957. "I won $35," he said with a faint smile and steady gaze that might do well at a poker table. "I thought I was a king, and I've gone at least once a year ever since and my level of gaming has gone up consistent with my personal assets. I no longer get any enjoyment in winning $35, but I would be hurt if I lost $35.
"My father was a stern Presbyterian who hated tobacco, alcohol and gambling. And I took his advice on two of them. My mother's a Catholic girl and enjoys a drink or two, although she's 86 years old. She smoked when she was a younger woman and loves to play bouree, a Cajun card game similar to bridge, a trump game, at two cents, a nickel, something like that," he added, looking proud that she appreciates cash stakes.
He describes himself as a very disciplined gambler. He shoots craps perhaps four or five times a day for no more than 30 minutes a sitting during Nevada visits that are now limited to New Year's vacation time.
Looking delighted with life's many turns of chance, Mr. Edwards invites others to try their luck soon at the New Orleans tables that he first envisioned. "It was one of the many times I was able see things that were unfolding in advance," the Governor said with the immodesty of a gambler on a roll.

HEADLINE: Move Over, Gutenberg, for the Electronic Book

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I would like to amplify the observations of Lee van Laer in "Computers Alter the Job Market Forever" (letter, Aug. 16) about computers and their impact on publishing.
Twenty years ago I worked at a typesetting house just as "cold type" was vanquishing legions of linotype operators using the "hot type" method. At our house, a typewritten manuscript from a publisher's editorial department would pass through an assembly line of typists, proofreaders, page makers and camera operators. About 50 people, including management and secretarial staff, were churning out a much larger volume of type at a much lower cost than a similar-size staff using hot type. 
 A few years later, electromechanical phototypesetters automatically set type in place on the page. Now a few programmers could do tasks that had required dozens of page makers working at drafting tables. The higher speed and improved automation of the machines meant that only one or two operators were needed to run several machines to set the type that just a few years earlier had required many times the equipment, time, floor space and staff.
In the last decade, rapid advances in personal computer hardware, desktop publishing software and telecommunications have reduced staff needs even more dramatically. In other words, the number of people involved in transforming a manuscript into typeset pages ready for the printer has gone from scores of employees working in a small- to medium-size production facility, to a single freelancer working at home with a personal computer.
This one person can match all the services, if not the volume, of a large operation. Capable of receiving manuscripts electronically over the phone from book publishers, the freelancer can edit and typeset the manuscript, then forward the final pages, again electronically, to a printer. And the future? If authors are computer-literate and use increasingly sophisticated software that checks spelling and grammar, why send the manuscript through the extra step of the freelance copy editor-typesetter?
To go a step further, if authors are someday aided, as I am certain that they will be, by expert system software that offers editorial, business and marketing advice, why go through a publisher?
Finally, if the electronic superhighway becomes an easily accessible link to millions of others worldwide, why go through a printer, distributer and bookstore?
We are in the midst of a revolution no less historic -- economically, socially and politically -- than the one Gutenberg started when he worked out the major bugs in movable type 500 years ago.
 
CHARLES F. MARTIN
Tarrytown, N.Y., Aug. 19, 1993
