HEADLINE: Take Firmer Line With China on Missiles

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"U.S. Determines China Violated Pact on Missiles"(front page, Aug. 25) details the impending imposition of United States sanctions on China for its sale of M-11 missile technology to Pakistan. Your report refers three times to the Missile Technology Control Regime as a "treaty," although it is actually an agreement that is not legally binding upon the nations that subscribe to its terms. 
 Because of the Missile Technology Control Regime's odd legal status, each participant to the agreement makes its own determination about what constitutes a violation.
Whereas the M-11 does not violate the Missile Technology Control Regime's restrictions on payload and range (a missile cannot be transferred if it can carry a warhead with a payload of 1,340 pounds a distance of at least 186 miles), the M-11 could be armed with a nuclear warhead, thus bringing it under the scope of the technology agreement.
In contrast to the business-as-usual posture the Bush Administration took toward China, the Clinton Administration has acted aggressively to discourage the proliferaton of Chinese missiles. However, by failing to impose the harshest sanctions because "the Chinese had not shipped actual missiles, but rather technology that would allow Pakistan to build M-11 missiles," the Clinton Administration exhibits the same shortsightedness as its predecessor did.
Technology transfers such as these will in the long run do more damage to United States security interests by increasing the number of proliferaters. Of course, to echo John Maynard Keynes, in the long run we'll all be dead anyway.
 
MARK S. STERNMAN
Disarmament Campaign Organizer
Peace Action Education Fund
Washington, Aug. 26, 1993

HEADLINE: Teachers Approve a Tentative Contract

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins and the leaders of the union representing 65,000 public-school teachers said yesterday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a new four-year contract calling for raises averaging 9 percent over the length of the deal.
The tentative settlement, reached on the eve of both a new school year and the general election campaign, could help Mr. Dinkins win the endorsement of the powerful union, the United Federation of Teachers. Mr. Dinkins was elected four years ago with the enthusiastic support of the union, which also represents 20,000 guidance counselors, teachers' aides, secretaries and other employees of the New York City school system. 
 Sandra Feldman, the president of the union, which spent $1 million on television commercials last winter and spring that were very critical of the Mayor, said there was no political quid pro quo with Mr. Dinkins on the tentative labor accord.
But the contract would end more than two years of difficult and sometimes bitter negotiations -- the teachers' last contract expired on Oct. 1, 1991 -- and if the rank and file ratify it, the union leadership is likely to feel more inclined to support Mr. Dinkins.
 
Ratification Expected
 The proposed contract will go to the union's delegate assembly for a vote tomorrow, said Ron Davis, a union spokesman. A vote by the union's full membership has not yet been scheduled, but will take place after the start of school, Mr. Davis said.
"I believe the contract will be accepted and will be ratified," Ms. Feldman said at a City Hall news conference.
Despite occasional efforts by union leaders over the last year to suggest that they were considering endorsing the Mayor's Republican-Liberal opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, many politicians have speculated that the teachers' union would withhold an endorsement in the mayoral race if its disappointment over the stalled contract talks prevented it from supporting Mr. Dinkins again.
The tentative agreement announced at midday yesterday at City Hall is similar to other recent municipal labor contracts, particularly one reached last January with a coalition of 19 unions that represents most of the city's civilian employees other than the teachers.
That settlement called for a raise of 8.25 percent over 39 months for about 180,000 workers. The teachers' contract would be for a longer time -- 48 and a half months -- and provide a raise averaging 9 percent.
By tentatively accepting a longer contract and by agreeing not to have all teachers share equally in the raise over the contract's final nine and a half months, the teachers' union won a long-sought concession from the Dinkins administration: The top scale for the most experienced teachers would rise much more quickly than average teacher salaries.
 
Top Salaries at Issue
 The union has argued for the last few years that the top teachers' salary -- now $52,750 a year -- was much smaller than top salaries for teachers in many other school districts in the metropolitan region. The maximum salary would rise to $60,000 a year in April 1995 under the proposed contract. By comparison, the top teacher salary in Yonkers was $60,000 for the 1992-93 school year, and will rise to $63,000 this year.
Starting salaries in New York, which increased sharply in the last few teachers' contracts, would rise much more slowly. The beginning salary, which is now $26,375, would increase to $28,749 in 1995.
To qualify for the top salary, teachers must have 20 years' experience, a master's degree, and have earned 30 additional credits beyond a master's. City officials estimated that about 14,000 to 15,000 teachers would qualify for the $60,000 maximum salary.
The tentative contract has other features similar to those in the contract reached with the coalition of civilian unions. The teachers' contract, which would be retroactive to October 1991, would contain no raise for the first 18 months, a concession to the city's difficult fiscal condition.
The teachers would then receive a series of raises, the first of which would be retroactive to last April. The contract would expire on Oct. 15, 1995.
Senior mayoral advisers said that the accord would not have an immediate effect on the current year's city budget, which already anticipates a teachers' contract similar to the other contracts negotiated this year.
"This agreement," Mr. Dinkins said, "is a responsible economic settlement both in terms of fairly compensating public school teachers for the important work they do and remaining within the fiscal parameters we have established for all recent labor settlements."
 
'Not a Bad Settlement'
 Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit group that monitors the city's fiscal affairs, called the accord "not a bad settlement," one that on average would likely be close to the rate of inflation.
"It's reasonable fiscally," Mr. Horton said. "It doesn't get to the key issue of labor productivity, but neither have any of the other labor settlements."
The talks had been stalled for months, eventually going to mediation and then nonbinding arbitration, because the United Federation of Teachers had sought a better financial package than the one accepted by the other civilian unions.
The city had sought to reduce the number of preparation periods allotted to teachers, to increase teaching time and to eliminate sabbatical leaves. The union had sought salary increases significantly higher than those won by other municipal unions.
The agreement would give teachers in about 200 elementary schools five preparation periods a week, two more than they have now. The union also agreed to join the city in supporting proposed state legislation to extend the statue of limitations for disciplinary cases involving elementary and junior high school teachers to three years from the current six months. The limit is now three years in the city's high schools.
The accord also would eliminate the accrual of sick leave by teacherson sabbatical and allow for more involvement by parents in school-based management teams. Under the previous contract, the majority of the team members had to be teachers.
 
Pressure for a Deal
 There was considerable pressure on the Mayor and union leaders to reach the tentative agreement. Mr. Dinkins, of course, hoped to settle with the union in time to win their endorsement for his re-election, and Ms. Feldman and other union leaders did not want to start another school year without a contract. The union's members voted last June to authorize a strike at an unspecified time after school resumed in September.
The Mayor denied that politics had motivated the timing of the accord. "If it had been politically motivated, I certainly would have agreed to it long before the U.F.T. spent $1 million in a month of ads against me," he said. "Sandy Feldman and her people did what they thought was best for the teachers, and I respect them for it. And I did what I thought was best for the seven and a half to eight million people of New York."

HEADLINE: The President of Visa U.S.A. Resigns in a Surprise Move

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
In a surprise move, the president and chief executive of Visa U.S.A., H. Robert Heller, said yesterday that he had resigned from the credit card organization.
Mr. Heller, 53, had been widely seen as the successor to Charles T. Russell, the president and chief executive of Visa International, who is 63. Visa U.S.A. is one of the five regional organizations under Visa International, which is based in San Mateo, Calif. 
 Visa said yesterday that Carl Pascarella, the president of its Asia-Pacific region, would take over Mr. Heller's post at Visa U.S.A. The changes followed a meeting of Visa U.S.A.'s board in Dallas.
Mr. Heller said in a statement that he was leaving to pursue other interests, but several credit card industry experts said it was more likely that Mr. Heller was forced out because the board of Visa was dissatisfied with his leadership.
"Bob Heller didn't do the wrong thing; he just didn't act," said Allen DeCotiis, president of Payment Systems Inc., a Tampa, Fla., research company. "Visa was concerned they were losing position in the marketplace. Mastercard was taking the initiative, and Visa didn't want to stand by and let them catch up."
Mr. Heller was a governor of the Federal Reserve Board until he joined Visa in 1989. Before that, he was chief economist for the BankAmerica Corporation.
Visa is an association that allows its member banks to issue credit cards with its name on them, and it runs a vast electronic network to process credit card transactions.
Visa has long been the leading brand of credit cards in the United States, but recently it has lost some market share to Mastercard International, which is also an association of banks.
Mastercard has been eager to work with nonbanking companies like A.T.& T. and General Motors that want to offer credit cards tied to their other products. Visa, which is more closely aligned with the big banks, at first fought this trend, but has recently done an embarrassing about-face.
Visa, however, has significantly outpaced Mastercard in getting banks to offer its version of a debit card, which enables customers to make purchases with money drawn from their checking accounts.
Some bankers thought Mr. Heller did not have the leadership skill to draw together the fractious association that, after all, is made up of banks that compete with one another.
"It's never been more important for Visa to communicate with its membership in a warm yet strong manner, and there is a feeling that some other executive might better serve the association," said David Robertson, president of the Nilson Report, a credit card newsletter.
In particular, the emergence of debit cards puts a premium on salesmanship, because banks generally will pick the debit card program of one of the two associations. In credit cards, most banks issue both Visa and Mastercard cards.
Mr. Pascarella, 50, is widely considered one of Visa's ablest managers, managing rapid growth of its Asian card base.
"When he started, Visa was behind Mastercard in Asia," Mr. Robertson said. "By the time he left, it was ahead. He was able to find ways to keep the membership happy and to pump out the Visa cards." Indeed, he pushed Visa into linking up with merchants in Asia even as the association was fighting that trend in the United States.
Mr. Pascarella was considered to be a leading candidate for the Visa U.S.A. job several years ago, but he was passed over for Mr. Heller, an outsider who was seen as having greater stature. But Mr. Heller kept the detachment of an economist, in the view of many Visa members, and he did not exhibit a passion for the marketing or other details of the payment business.
The move back to the United States makes Mr. Pascarella the leading candidate to replace Mr. Russell, industry experts said.
Before Mr. Pascarella joined Visa in 1983, he was vice president of the international division of Crocker National Bank of San Francisco.
A Visa spokesman said that Mr. Heller, Mr. Pascarella and Mr. Russell were not available to comment last evening.

HEADLINE: Where Politics and Poverty Intersect In Nicaragua, Signposts Are Missing

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA ESPERANZA, Nicaragua, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Like any Nicaraguan who is 73 years old, Juan Mayrena has known an unusual amount of revolution and war. He says it is always the same.
"They kill the boys, then they come and dump their bodies here," he said.
But Mr. Mayrena says he has never seen things as cruel as they have gotten on the sprawling hacienda that gives this hamlet its name, which means hope. 
 The cotton crops have disappeared as prices have dropped below the costs of production. There is no work in the nearby city of Leon, because tens of thousands of people have already been laid off by failing companies and the shrinking state bureaucracy. Mr. Mayrena and his large family now eat little more than sorghum tortillas, and the children look skeletal.
 
The People Are Tired
 After the 1979 Sandinista revolution against the dictator Anastasio Somoza and the Sandinistas' electoral defeat by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in 1990, many people here are weary of turmoil and conclude that kicking out another government will not necessarily help.
But Mr. Mayrena suspects that men with guns will come around again, perhaps soon, and that the choice of whether to join them will not be easy.
"We cannot tolerate this anymore," he said.
In Nicaragua, as elsewhere in Central America, the problems that fueled years of civil war -- implacable poverty, political intolerance, feeble state institutions -- have easily survived the cold war.
 
The People Are Armed
 But the new cycle of political instability and economic decline here has taken hold of a country far more politicized and full of guns than the one that existed before the Sandinista revolution. And that has led many people to fear renewed conflict on a much wider, less ideological scale.
"This is not a Sandinista thing," said Porfirio Gamez, 35, a former Sandinista official who has organized a group in Leon that represents former combatants on both sides of the war and tens of thousands of people who have lost their jobs. "This is the poor people coming together against the rich."
President Chamorro's term expires in 1996, and her political future may depend on her ability to negotiate with both the Sandinistas and the center-right parties. Bitter differences among the three sides have paralyzed politics for months, aggravating the polarization and uncertainty that have discouraged the investment that Nicaragua badly needs.
"I feel like we are on the edge of the cliff," said the former Sandinista Vice President, Sergio Ramirez Mercado. "If there is no understanding here, the next step is down."
 
The Prosperity Is Deceptive
 Managua in particular shows some signs of flourishing. With more wealthy Nicaraguans drawing on their bank accounts overseas and sinking their money into the local economy, and with new credits from the Government, shops selling everything from frozen yogurt to cellular telephones have begun to fill the vast empty spaces left by the devastating earthquake that struck the capital in 1972. New Toyota Land Cruisers seem to outnumber the old Soviet-built Ladas.
But a deepening poverty is also more and more visible. Beggars work the intersections, jostling for attention with candy vendors, windshield washers and people selling any item of possible value. Street crime is rising. Squatter settlements have proliferated, and in the evenings they disgorge young women in party dresses, off to join a flourishing trade in prostitution.
"War, hurricane, earthquake, tidal wave -- Nicaragua has suffered all of that," said Rosa Mercedes Lopez, 28, who lives with her husband and four children in a slum on the edge of Managua. "Now there is real hunger."
After 10 years of a government that seized power in the name of social justice and tried to achieve it by confiscating thousands of properties from the wealthy, subsidizing the poor with foreign aid and virtually eliminating imports of luxury goods, the change under President Chamorro has left many angry.
"There is an incredible resentment here," said Omar Estrada, 32, an official of the telephone workers' union in Leon. "When we see all of these cars and these bourgeois people, it bothers us like hell."
Following deep cuts in Government spending, the privatization of 300 state-owned companies and the closing of scores more, unemployment and underemployment afflict 60 percent of the work force. Per-capita income was $459 last year, less than a third what it was in the mid-1970's.
Teachers, who earn about $70 a month, say more and more children are dropping out to help support their families. Because of sweeping cuts in the health budget, even the most indigent are being asked to contribute to the cost of their care.
 
The Medical Care Is Faltering
 Maria Auxiliadora Morales, 24, told of an all-night standoff in a Government hospital this month as she pleaded for medicine for her screaming 9-month-old son, who had bronchitis.
"They told me, 'You are going to let that kid die if you don't pay for the shots,' but I didn't have any money," she recalled.
Finally, the next morning, two injections were given free. But she had to pay about $1.40 each for five others. On a good day, her husband earns $3 or $4 selling visa-request forms outside the United States Embassy.
At another Government pediatric hospital in the city, the director, Julio J. Otero, said that his modest budget had been cut by nearly two-thirds over the last few years, and that many nurses, who earned about $65 a month, had quit to sell chewing gum and other items on the street.
 
The Accusations Are Flying
 Leaders of the Sandinista Front argue that Mrs. Chamorro's Government has been intimidated into unrealistic austerity policies by the International Monetary Fund and other lenders. Other critics accuse the Government of mismanaging more than $2 billion in foreign aid and forgiven loans.
Defending their record, Government officials point to the obstacles they inherited.
"People in Nicaragua have gotten it confused," said the Finance Minister, Emilio A. Pereira. "They think it is the economic policy that is tough. It is the reality that is tough."
Having taken over a foreign debt that had swelled to $10.8 billion from $1.6 billion under the Sandinistas and an economy that had contracted steadily for six years, the Chamorro Government undertook radical restructuring. Arrears were cleared up with foreign banks, the budget deficit was eliminated and inflation was cut to 3.5 percent last year.
Most state-owned companies have been sold to private investors, trade barriers are lower and credits are available for imports, but only about $400 million in private investment has flowed into the economy.
The newly private industries have found themselves saddled with far more debts than expected. Market prices for key exports like cotton and coffee have fallen steadily. Mr. Pereira, the Finance Minister, estimated that $100 million was squandered in bad loans by state banks.
There is wide agreement that the greatest impediments to investment have been the Government's inability to resolve more than a fraction of the hundreds of ownership claims on property that the Sandinistas confiscated, and the deepening political strife that the property question, among other issues, has brought on.
"I think we were somewhat naive in thinking that with a change in Government, things would pick up more easily than they have," said the Inter-American Development Bank's representative in Managua, Joel A. Riley. "There has to be a major sign of some sort -- political or other -- to turn around Nicaragua's image abroad, because private investment is the only way to put this back together again."
 
U.S. Aid Is in Jeopardy
 Adding to the uncertainty is a threat that $98 million in United States aid might be cut off because of concern that the Sandinista leaders of the Army might have helped foreign terrorists. The Senate voted to halt the aid after the discovery of a weapons cache in Managua in May that seemed to link the Sandinistas to various terrorist groups; a House vote is expected soon.
The Government hopes to start talks in early September on a new consensus on economic policy. But there are serious questions about whether President Chamorro's leadership is strong enough to bring her opponents together for measures as drastic as many economists say she must take.
Sandinista and conservative leaders say they will push for more loans for businesses and farms, and the left has insisted on emergency social spending. But Mr. Pereira said he hoped to convince the Government's opponents of the need for further budget cuts.
But on Hacienda La Esperanza, the perception is that in so many years of violence and revolution, the political leaders had learned nothing about the need for everyone to live decently.
 
The Man Who Did Not Suffer
 But the peasants reserve most of their bitterness for the new manager of the hacienda, Oscar Galo, a 28-year-old with an M.B.A., who they said did not seem to care if they lived or died.
"The revolution's over," Mr. Galo said in English. "We can't pay people to sit around."
He admitted that he didn't pay much mind to how the laid-off workers were doing. But he added that he felt things around the farm had calmed down.
Ofelia Mungia, 35, one of Mr. Mayrena's neighbors, did not think so.
"The rich people used to make big, big money," she said. "They know that's not going to happen anymore, so they are just squeezing us out. That kid -- they have put him here to punish us. The problem is, he has never suffered like this."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 8, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A map on Aug. 31 with an article about politics and poverty in Nicaragua showed an incorrect location for La Esperanza, one site of desperation. As noted in the article, it is just outside Leon, about 20 miles northeast of that city (not 200 miles).
